original_text: Epsilon Aurigae is an F-type main sequence star with a mass of 1.8 M☉ and radius 2 R☉, located at about 40 light-years away in the constellation Auriga.  It has been known for many years to be surrounded by dusty material that obscures its visible spectrum.   The infrared excess emission detected around this object suggests it may have a circumstellar disk similar to those found around young stars such as T Tauri or Herbig Ae/Be stars.   In addition, there are indications that the system contains a close companion which could also contribute to the observed infrared excess emission.    We present new photometric observations obtained using the United Kingdom Infrared Telescope (UKIRT) on Mauna Kea over the period 1997-2001 covering wavelengths between 0.9-2.5 microns.  These data show significant variations in both the near-infrared fluxes and colours of the central source consistent with changes in the amount of dust surrounding the star.  This behaviour is very similar to what is seen in other pre-main-sequence systems where accretion onto the central star causes periodic increases in luminosity accompanied by increased levels of reddening due to heating of the surrounding dust grains.   Our results suggest that the current level of activity in the system is relatively low compared to previous epochs but we cannot rule out the possibility that the recent increase in brightness was caused by a short-lived burst of enhanced accretion rather than steady-state accretion occurring throughout our observing campaign.

original_text: We present new near-infrared (NIR) polarimetric observations of the GG Tau system, which reveal that its circumstellar disk is highly structured and contains several bright regions with different polarization properties. The most prominent feature in our data set is an arc-like structure located at about 0.5 arcsec to the south-east of the central binary star. This region shows strong polarized emission up to 10% of the total intensity and has been previously identified as a reflection nebula by Weintraub et al. (1993) . We find that this feature can be explained by scattering off optically thin dust grains close to the midplane of the disk. In addition we detect two other bright features on either side of the central binary. These are also associated with high degrees of linear polarization but show no clear evidence for scattered light. Instead they appear to be caused by absorption against the background stellar flux. Finally, we identify three additional fainter structures in the southern part of the disk. All these features have similar polarization angles indicating that their origin may be related.

rewrite_text: We present the tenth installment of an optical spectroscopic survey of objects in backyards, focusing on unpublished data at redshifts of z = 0.4 to 0.8, obtained using the William Herschel Telescope (WHT). Our findings indicate that the fraction of AGN-powered quiescent galaxies decreases with increasing density within the clusters. This observation aligns with previous studies that have identified evidence of active quenching of star formation in these environments. However, we also note numerous instances where powerful quiescent sources exist in collaborative regions without any indication of environmental influence. These may either represent rapidly evolving objects or a population of recently accreted galaxies whose characteristics still closely resemble those of their active counterparts. Our sample consists of 20 carefully selected objects from the VLA-COSMOS 3 GHz Large Project (Smolčić et al., 2009), based on the following criteria: 1) They lie within one of four X-ray luminous clusters at 0.4 < z < 0.8; 2) Their luminosity at 3 GHz exceeds L(3GHz) = 10^25 W Hz^-1; 3) They do not exhibit strong emission lines indicative of ongoing nuclear activity; 4) They were observed during our WHT session on May 24-25, 2010.

We report on the fluidization of a thin, horizontally vibrating granular bed by vertical oscillations at low frequency and amplitude. The system is studied experimentally using high-speed video imaging in combination with particle tracking velocimetry (PTV). We find that for sufficiently large vibration amplitudes, particles are ejected from the surface into the air as they reach their maximum height during an upward motion. This leads to the formation of a dilute gas phase above the dense packing near the bottom of the container. In addition we observe convection rolls which transport grains across the entire depth of the bed. These results show striking similarities to those observed in vibrated beds of sand or glass beads but differ significantly from previous studies performed on systems where only horizontal vibrations were applied. Vibrations can induce transitions between different states of matter such as solids, liquids, and gases  1  . For example, it has been shown that a solid state may become unstable when subjected to periodic forcing  2  , resulting in the spontaneous generation of traveling waves  3  . A particularly interesting case occurs if both horizontal and vertical components of the driving force act simultaneously  4  .
In this work we study the response of a thin granular layer to simultaneous application of horizontal and vertical vibrations. Our experiments reveal new phenomena not seen before in other types of driven granular media.

rewrite_text: We propose using tenth thermal fluctuations as the dynamic carrier for completely secure, zero-power devices and computational systems. We believe that by employing a suitable detection method, we can extract tenth bits from inherent noise with high fidelity even at fluctuating temperatures. Our research is based on a single-electron transistor (SET), which has recently been validated through experiments. Moreover, we illustrate how this SET-based device can be utilized to create fundamental logic gates, such as the AND gate and NOT gate. Finally, we explore potential applications of our findings, including secure key distribution, low-power sensor networks, and efficient data centers. This work was supported by the NSF under Grant No. ECCS-0926491. A novel approach in thermal fluctuation informatics positions these fluctuations as the carrier for a range of tasks, from secure data transmission to zero-power realization and computation. Potential applications are discussed, highlighting their advantages over existing methods.

original_text: We present new near-infrared photometric data for the Pleiades open cluster obtained with the Infrared Survey Facility (IRSF) on the South African Astronomical Observatory s 1-m telescope at Sutherland in November 2005. The observations were made using the IRSF/SIRIUS camera which has simultaneous JHK s imaging capability over an 8 x8 field-of-view. We have also used archival 2MASS data to supplement our sample. Our results are presented as colour-magnitude diagrams (CMDs), where we show that there is good agreement between our photometry and previous studies. Using these CMDs, we identify several previously unreported candidate members of the Pleiades based upon their location relative to theoretical pre-main sequence evolutionary tracks. These candidates include two objects located near the substellar boundary, one of which appears to be a brown dwarf member of the Pleiades.

We introduce new distance constructions for locally decodable codes (LDCs) utilizing well-defined subsets of finite fields, the prime properties of Mersenne numbers, and the Chinese remainder theorem. Our construction is an improvement on existing LDCs featuring partner query complexity derived from these specific subsets of finite fields. We further demonstrate how to combine these constructions with the Chinese remainder theorem to recover families of LDCs, whose parameters can be controlled by adjusting the primes used in their creation. Finally, we establish a lower bound on the performance of any LDC over a binary alphabet that utilizes only one-sided queries. The proofs of our key theorems are presented at the conclusion of this abstract. 

Introduction: Locally decodable codes (abbreviated as LDCs) are error-correcting codes wherein each codeword is associated with a decoding view that allows for efficient retrieval of individual bits or symbols upon being queried about them. Specifically, if a codeword is subjected to up to t errors, there exists a deterministic polynomial time algorithm that recovers the original uncorrupted message using O(t) queries per symbol. This characteristic makes such codes valuable in applications such as data storage, peer-to-peer networks, and streaming services. A significant body of research has focused on understanding the relationship between the rate of the code, its distance, and the query complexity of its decoder. For instance, works by Guruswami et al. (2005), Chan et al. (2006), and Kopparty & Saraf (2007) have explored constructing codes with low query complexity while maintaining high rates and distances. Recently, various studies have addressed the question of minimum query complexity required to decode a specific code after a certain level of corruption, including the notable breakthrough by Dvir et al. (2010), which improved upon previous upper bounds established by Sudan et al. (2005), as well as subsequent improvements by Dvir et al. (2011), Feldman et al. (2012), and Kopparty et al. (2013).

We report on radio observations made with the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) at 5 GHz and 8.6 GHz, which reveal an unresolved point source coincident with G1, one of the most massive globular clusters known to exist in our Galaxy.  The observed flux density is consistent with that expected for a black hole accreting at the Eddington limit. We also present new optical spectroscopy obtained using the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrographs (GMOS), which shows no evidence for emission lines associated with gas surrounding the central object. These results are inconsistent with previous claims that this cluster contains a supermassive black hole. If confirmed by future studies, these findings would represent the first detection of an intermediate mass black hole in any galaxy. This discovery has important implications for understanding how such objects form and evolve over cosmic time. In addition, it may provide insight into the formation history of the Milky Way itself. 
The authors acknowledge support from NASA through Chandra Award Number GO0-1111B issued by the Chandra X-ray Observatory Center, which is operated by the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory for and on behalf of NASA under contract NAS8-03060.

We present an analysis of the relativistic Riemann problem for ideal fluids in two spatial dimensions, focusing on the role of vortex sheets. We demonstrate that the solution to this problem can be constructed as a series of self-similar solutions that are uniquely determined up to translation along the x-axis (the direction of propagation). Our first objective is to derive exact solutions for the interaction between a planar shock wave and a vortex sheet. While previous studies have used different methodologies, we provide a novel derivation based on the method of characteristics. In particular, we derive expressions for the density and velocity profiles across the shock front. 

We then validate the scenario where the initial conditions consist of a stationary vortex separating regions of constant density and pressure. This case physically corresponds to a shock initially at rest being accelerated impulsively by a piston moving at speed \(c = 1\). We establish that for each configuration of total mass \(M\), there exists a unique solution. Finally, we numerically investigate the case of more complex initial conditions, including multiple vortex sheets interacting with shock waves.

original_text: We introduce the notion of ``abstract factorials  , which are functions that can be used to represent and manipulate sets of integers in an efficient manner.  We show how these functions can be implemented using standard data structures such as hash tables or trees.   Finally we present several applications for this new class of objects including fast algorithms for computing the number of integer partitions with bounded parts (the so-called ``Stirling numbers of the second kind  ) and for counting the number of ways to tile a rectangular board with tiles of different sizes. The concept of abstract factorials is introduced along with its implementation on top of existing data structures like hash tables or binary search trees. Several applications are presented, among them fast algorithms for computing Stirling numbers of the second type and tiling problems. This work was supported by NSF grant CCF-0634420. 1 Introduction In many computational settings it is necessary to perform operations over large collections of integers. For example, one may need to count the number of ways to partition a set into subsets of equal size, or to compute the number of tilings of a rectangular board with tiles having different shapes and sizes. These computations often require repeated evaluation of arithmetic expressions involving sums and products of integers. It has been shown recently that certain classes of such expressions admit very efficient representations based on combinatorial objects known as ``factorials    19, 20  . A factorial is essentially a function that maps each positive integer n to another object f(n), called the ``value   of the factorial at n. Such values must satisfy two properties:  First, they should form a sequence of nonnegative integers whose sum grows exponentially; i.e., there exists some constant c > 0 so that the value of any factorial satisfies |f(n)| <= cn^c for all sufficiently large n. Second, the values of distinct factorials cannot collide too frequently; more precisely, if f(n1) = f(n2) then n1 and n2 must differ by at least a fixed amount d.

We propose a scenario involving a stable proton in the context of a Santos Trying Taylor model, where the lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP) is a gravitino rather than a neutralino. In this model, the LSP decays into a photon or a neutrino-antineutrino pair via gravitational interactions. This framework allows us to explain the observed matter density without contradicting measurements such as the relic density reported by the WMAP experiment. We anticipate that our model will yield distinctive predictions for the upcoming LHC experiments. 

Introduction: The discovery of the Higgs boson has opened up numerous possibilities for exploring physics beyond the Standard Model (SM). Supersymmetry (SUSY), one of the most promising extensions of the SM, offers a compelling solution to the hierarchy problem. However, SUSY models face significant constraints from the properties of their partner particles. In order to address these constraints, several researchers have proposed different avenues of exploration. One approach involves introducing additional gauge symmetries, while another involves incorporating extra dimensions. Recently, it has been demonstrated that there exists a class of string models in which the lightest superpartner is a gravitino. The gravitino, owing to its unique coupling to gravity, has a decay rate that is much lower compared to that of the neutralino. This characteristic makes the gravitino an intriguing candidate for dark matter. Furthermore, if the mass of the gravitino is less than 1 GeV, its lifetime becomes significantly extended, potentially positioning it as a viable candidate for dark matter. On the other hand, the gravitino is stable due to its connection to gravitational interactions, allowing it to decay into photon or lepton-neutrino pairs. If the gravitino mass exceeds 100 MeV, its decay products will predominantly manifest as diffuse gamma rays. Consequently, it is essential for the gravitino to satisfy certain conditions.

original_text: Globular clusters are dense stellar systems that contain thousands to millions of stars, and may be the oldest gravitationally bound objects known.  The discovery of planets around other stars has raised questions about whether or not globular cluster members can also harbor planetary systems.   In this work we use Monte Carlo simulations to examine how many planets could exist within globular clusters with different masses and ages.  We find that for most reasonable assumptions on planet formation rates, there should be at least one planet per star in all but the youngest (<10 Myr) and lowest mass (<100 Msun) clusters.  This result is robust against uncertainties in our knowledge of planet formation efficiencies and initial conditions such as the number density distribution of planetesimals.  Our results suggest that it will be possible to detect planets orbiting globular cluster members using current observational techniques. Keywords: Planetary systems; Stellar evolution; Star clusters; Formation

This cluster was identified as part of an ongoing survey for background sources conducted by our team within the framework of the UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey Data Release 8 (UKIDSS DR8). We derived photometric redshifts for a number of galaxies that are potential members of this cluster over a wide area surrounding it. From these candidates, we have identified two brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) situated approximately 1 arcminute apart along the line of sight. These BCGs have magnitudes of mF160W = 20.6 ± 0.1 mag and mF140W = 21.0 ± 0.2 mag. Their characteristics suggest that both are early-type galaxies.

The work function is one of the most important parameters in semiconductor devices, and its accurate measurement is essential for device design and performance prediction.  In this article we review some recent progresses on the determination of the work functions of various materials by using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) with synchrotron radiation as well as other techniques such as scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS), inverse photoemission spectroscopy (IPES), and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM). We also discuss how to determine the absolute values of the work functions of different semiconductors based on UPS measurements. Finally, we present our perspectives on future research directions in this field. The work function is an important parameter in semiconductor devices, which determines their electrical properties including carrier transport behavior and Schottky barrier height  1  . Accurate measurement of the work function is therefore crucial for both fundamental understanding of electronic structure and practical applications  2  .
In this article, we will first briefly introduce several experimental methods used to measure the work function of various materials. Then we will show that these results can be compared directly if they are obtained under similar conditions. Afterwards, we will demonstrate how to determine the absolute value of the work function of different semiconductors through ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPES) experiments. Finally, we will give out our perspective on future research direction in this area.

rewrite_text:
We provide an analysis of the stability of quantum dots (QDs) that are epitaxially self-assembled on semiconductor surfaces, grown using molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) under conditions where QDs spontaneously form regular arrays. Our findings indicate that the ordering of QDs is influenced by two competing mechanisms: surface diffusion and elastic strain. The former tends to increase the density of the QDs, while the latter works to stabilize the structure. Notably, we observe that for certain ranges of QD size dispersion, there exists a critical growth rate above which it becomes impossible to form ordered QD arrays. This finding explains the challenges in achieving well-ordered QD arrays of larger sizes using conventional methods. 

Keywords: Ordering, Strain Relaxation, Surface Diffusion, Quantum Dot Arrays, Stability, Growth Rate, Molecular Beam Epitaxy. 

1. Introduction 
Semiconductor nanocrystals, commonly known as quantum dots (QDs), also referred to as colloidal quantum dots, have garnered significant interest due to their unique optical properties. They are applicable in various optoelectronic devices, including light-emitting diodes, lasers, solar cells, and photodetectors, and they also play important roles in biological applications. The primary method for growing QDs is the Stranski-Krastanov growth technique, which involves depositing a thin layer onto a substrate at high temperatures, followed by annealing at lower temperatures. In this process, QD nucleation occurs across the sample area, which then evolves into organized arrays through Ostwald ripening. However, this technique does not provide control over the dimensions of individual QDs within the arrays. Recently developed methods have enabled the production of highly ordered QD arrays; however, these methods require very precise temperature control during deposition. 

2. Model Description 
In this analysis, we investigate the formation of QDs on a two-dimensional lattice. Our approach is based on the continuum model proposed by Tersoff et al.

original_text: We present the first direct determination of the stellar radius in an interacting binary system, using interferometric observations obtained with the VLTI and AMBER instrument. We resolve for the first time the components of the close binary system SS Leporis (separation ~0.3 arcsec), which consists of two main sequence stars that are both filling their respective Roche lobes. By fitting theoretical models to our data we find that one component is slightly larger than expected by theory while the other has a radius consistent with predictions based on evolutionary tracks. This result suggests that tidal interactions have modified the radii of these stars during their evolution towards contact. Our results also show that the orbital inclination angle i = 60 ± 5 degrees, as determined previously through radial velocity measurements, agrees well with our new estimate derived directly from the observed separation between the two stars. Keywords: Interferometry; Binary Stars; Stellar Radius

We present an experimental investigation into the complementarity between partners and their entanglement in photons, specifically utilizing a modified version of the original Einstein-Bohr photon box experiment. Notably, for this particular measurement, we find no evidence of Bell's theorem violations or any other indicators of nonlocality. Our setup allows us to explore contextuality by conducting two distinct experiments with identical arrangements but opposite settings. In one scenario, we observe violations of Bell inequalities, while in the other, these inequalities are satisfied. This results demonstrate that the behavior we observe can be accounted for within classical physics and highlights the concept of contextuality. 

Quantum mechanics posits that certain pairs of conjugate variables, such as position and momentum, cannot possess simultaneous definite values; rather, they are represented by probability distributions that evolve over time according to Schrödinger's equation. However, it has been shown that if both conjugate variables are measured at the same time, their probability distributions can interfere destructively, leading to a nil probability for observing either quantity at its most defined state. This phenomenon is closely tied to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle and the concept of complementarity—the notion that not all properties of a system can be observed simultaneously.

In 1964, John Bell established that hidden variable theories could not reproduce all predictions made by quantum mechanics, leading to the formulation of Bell's theorem. Since then, numerous experiments have been conducted to test whether quantum mechanics complies with Bell's theorem. These tests typically involve entangled particles, where each particle’s measurement tells about the state of the other. If the particles are far enough apart such that their measurements occur independently, the observed correlations may reflect local or classical effects.

original_text: We present the results of an optical monitoring campaign on two luminous quasars at redshifts z = 1.7 and 2.1 with the aim to study their long-term line and continuum variability properties. The observations were carried out in the period between September 2005 and December 2007 using the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT) equipped with ALFOSC. We find that both objects show significant variations over time scales ranging from months up to years. In particular we detect strong changes in the Hβ emission-line profiles which are accompanied by corresponding flux density fluctuations in the adjacent continuum regions. These findings suggest that the observed spectral changes can be explained as being due to variable obscuration effects caused by clouds moving across our line-of-sight towards the central engine. This scenario is supported by the fact that the detected variabilities appear to occur simultaneously for all three Balmer lines studied here. Furthermore, we find evidence for additional short-term variability events occurring within individual nights.

The pulsar has a spin period of P = 2.16 seconds and is situated within 0.2 arcminutes (0.01 parsecs) of the centroid location identified by the High Energy Stereoscopic System (HESS). Additionally, we have discovered a faint extended nebula surrounding this pulsar through Chandra observations. The measured flux density of the nebula at radio wavelengths is F_ν (3 GHz) ~ 3 mJy per beam, while its X-ray luminosity is L_X ~ 10^33 erg/s. original_text: We present new infrared (IR) photometry for the galaxy cluster MS1054-03 at z = 0.83, obtained with ISOCAM on board ISO. The data are used to study star formation activity within this rich cluster environment. We find that the IR luminosity function is well fitted by a Schechter function with L* ~ 1 x 1012L⊙ and α ~ -1.7 over the range 8-1000 µm. This result suggests that there may be an excess number of faint galaxies compared to local clusters. In addition we detect several bright sources which have been identified as AGN candidates based upon their mid-IR colours. These objects appear to lie preferentially near the centre of the cluster suggesting they could be triggered by interactions between galaxies or mergers. Finally, we use our results together with published optical spectroscopy to investigate how the properties of individual galaxies evolve through time.

A total of 12 excess events above the background were detected in the energy range of 400 GeV to 20 TeV. No variability was observed during the observation period. This research demonstrates that H.E.S.S. can identify sources at redshifts previously inaccessible to ground-based Cherenkov telescopes, highlighting the importance of these observations for understanding the physics of extreme astrophysical phenomena.

We present an analytic model for the evolution of the 21 cm brightness temperature fluctuations during cosmic reionization, based on correlated random walks (CRWs). We show that CRW models can reproduce many features observed in numerical simulations of reionization, including the power spectrum at large scales, as well as the characteristic shape of the cross-correlation between different redshifts. In addition to these results, we find that our model predicts a new feature which is not seen in previous work -the presence of large-scale correlations even after reionization has completed. This effect may be detectable with future radio telescopes such as SKA. The 21cm line emission from neutral hydrogen provides us with a unique probe into the early universe. It allows one to study the process of reionization when most of the matter was still dark and cold gas clouds were surrounded by ionized bubbles  1  . However, this signal is extremely weak compared to other foregrounds produced by astrophysical sources  2  , so it will take several years before we are able to detect it directly  3  .
In order to make predictions about what kind of signals we should expect to see once observations become possible, theoretical studies have been performed using both semi-analytic  4  and fully numerical methods  5  . These works have shown that there exist two main types of signatures associated with reionization  6  : 1) the global signature of the average ionization fraction; 2) the local signature of individual HII regions. While the first type of signal is relatively easy to measure  7, 8  , the second type requires more advanced techniques  9  .

rewrite_text: We present a study on the effects of magnetic fields in the environment of magnetized protostellar accretion discs, taking into account both Ohmic and ambipolar diffusion, as well as radiative processes through flux-limited diffusion (FLD). Our findings indicate that the presence of these additional magnetic influences has significant implications for the dynamics and structure of the discs. Specifically, we observe that an initial magnetic field can reduce the mass accumulation within the disc over time by inhibiting fragmentation near the central protostar. This results in more robust discs compared to those predicted by purely hydrodynamic simulations. Initially, the resulting discs are more flared due to the magnetic support provided. However, as time goes on, the magnetic field depletes through ohmic dissipation and turbulence driven by instabilities. Once this occurs, the discs become more stable and maintain a flatter profile compared to non-magnetic models.

original_text: We present the results of an optical imaging survey with Subaru/Suprime-Cam of the nearby galaxy group centered on M31, including its brightest satellite galaxy, Andromeda II (M32). We use this data to study the internal structure and stellar populations of Andromeda II in detail for the first time.  The surface brightness profile shows that Andromeda II is well described by two exponential components separated at about 1 kpc along the major axis. This double-exponential shape suggests that Andromeda II consists of two distinct components; one component has a younger age than the other. Using SSP models we find that these two components have ages of 2 Gyr and 10 Gyr respectively. In addition, there are several small knots distributed over the entire body of Andromeda II which may be associated with recent star formation activity. These knots show no clear correlation between their locations and those of globular clusters or HII regions found previously.

rewrite_text: We present the tenth installment of our analysis on semiclassical scalar propagators in a curved spacetime framework, which is grounded in the WKB approximation for the tenth-order function. We find that there are two distinct methods for defining this quantity, depending on whether the backreaction effects due to quantum fluctuations are considered. The first approach yields an expression for the semiclassical propagator that aligns with the Feynman propagator in the limit of large distances, but it deviates near the source point. Notably, this version does not fulfill the Hadamard condition prescribed by general relativity. Conversely, if we include the backreaction effects, the resultant expression adheres to the Hadamard condition. However, recent work by Wald and others has shown that such an expression cannot be derived within the framework of standard quantum field theory. This issue has significant implications for understanding the behavior of quantum fields near black holes, given that these expressions are fundamental even outside the event horizon.

original_text: We present new photometry for the globular cluster NGC 1904, obtained with the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on board HST in four filters spanning the optical and near-infrared wavelength range. We find that this cluster has an extended blue horizontal branch (BHB), which is populated by both hot BHBs and blue stragglers (BSs). In order to study these populations separately we use two different methods. First, we select stars based on their location along the red giant branch (RGB); secondly, we perform artificial star tests using our best-fit model CMD as input. Both approaches yield consistent results. Our analysis shows that the fraction of BSs among all evolved stars amounts to f = 0.11 ± 0.01. This value agrees well with previous studies of other clusters. Using theoretical models we estimate the age of the cluster at t = 12 Gyr.

We present advanced simulations of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations using the LANS-alpha method, which is designed to produce accurate results for wall-bounded flows at low Reynolds numbers. We believe this approach can also be applied effectively at high Reynolds numbers, even though some underlying assumptions may not hold true. A key advantage of our method over standard Large Eddy Simulation (LES) techniques is that it does not require the incorporation of subgrid models, simplifying the process by eliminating the need for tuning parameters commonly found in other LES frameworks. Additionally, we show how the LANS-alpha method can be combined with implicit LES based on the variational multiscale formulation (VMS-LES) to enhance computational efficiency. We further discuss some challenges related to the practical application of these methods.

Turbulence plays a significant role in numerous phenomena, ranging from weather prediction to oceanic circulation and environmental processes. However, despite extensive research, turbulence remains one of the most complex problems in fluid dynamics. One reason for this complexity is the vast range of scales that exist within turbulent flows. While large eddies dominate much of the kinetic energy, they occupy only a small fraction of the total volume. Conversely, smaller eddies occupy nearly the entire volume but contribute little to the overall kinetic energy. As a result, accurately capturing all scales of motion necessitates computational grids that can become prohibitively large. To address this challenge, Large Eddy Simulations (LES) have been developed over the past few decades. These methods focus on resolving only the large-scale features of the flow responsible for the majority of the kinetic energy while modeling the effects of unresolved smaller-scale fluctuations. Although LES has proven effective in many engineering applications, it is not without its limitations, particularly regarding the variability of subgrid-scale models. Recently, variations of LES-like methods have emerged that aim to improve upon these challenges.

We study the effect of nonhomogeneity on the magnetic properties of hybrid structures consisting of a ferromagnet (FM) and a type-II superconductor (SC). We show that, depending on the FM thickness dF M , there are two different regimes for the SC critical temperature Tc: i) For small values of dF M Tc is suppressed by the proximity effect; ii) for large values of dF M we find an enhancement of Tc due to the exchange field induced by the FM layer. The latter regime can be understood as a consequence of the competition between the Zeeman energy and the condensation energy. In addition, we discuss how these results depend on the relative orientation of the FM magnetization with respect to the applied external magnetic field Hext.

Recently, it has become possible to fabricate hybrid structures combining conventional metals or semiconductors with unconventional ones like high-temperature superconductors  2  . These systems offer new possibilities for studying fundamental physical effects  3, 4  .

rewrite_text: We present our observations and analysis of the Balmer-shock regions associated with supernova remnants (SNRs) in a molecular cloud context. We have determined that these shocks exhibit temperatures that lie between those of typical J-type and C-type shocks. The observed emission lines feature prominent P-Cygni profiles with blueshifted absorption, indicating high velocities of up to 100 km/s. These findings suggest that the region is located at the interface between the shocked gas and the unshocked ambient medium. Additionally, we noticed that the widths of the Hα line profiles increase toward the central area of SNR W28, implying that the density structures of the surrounding medium may be more complex than previously thought. Our results indicate that Balmer-type molecular cloud shocks can provide valuable insights into the dynamics of the interstellar medium surrounding supernova remnants.

We study spin effects on the lattice QCD using recurrence lattices (RL) with multi-site exchanges, which are constructed by applying the RL transformation to the original fermion action. We show that the spin dependence is suppressed for large quark masses but not completely removed even at mq = 5 GeV. The residual spin dependence can be reduced further if we use larger number of sites in the exchange term. In this work, we adopt Ns = 4 as an example. We also find that the spin dependent part of the effective potential has no imaginary part up to O(a^4). This implies that there exists no spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry due to spin effects within our framework. Finally, we discuss possible extensions of our method. rewrite_text: We are conducting U BVRI photometric observations of the galaxy NGC 3367 using the 1-meter telescope at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO). The main objective of our study is to investigate the stellar structures in this galaxy and their relationship to its nuclear activity. We have identified two prominent knots along the major axis of the galaxy that may be associated with star formation regions. These knots are similar to those found in HII regions. Additionally, we have detected several fainter knots on either side of the nucleus, and their color indices suggest that they could be linked to recent star formation events. Finally, we observe an extended feature to the east of the nucleus that appears to be a tidal structure. This research was supported by CONACyT grant 36586-E. We express our gratitude to J. M. Alloin for his assistance during our observing run at CTIO. Keywords: Starburst galaxies; Nuclear activity.

original_text: The variation in the values of physical constants is one of the most important problems for modern physics, cosmology and astrophysics. The main goal of this work was to study the possible time variations of some fundamental constants (fine structure constant α, gravitational constant G, proton-to-electron mass ratio μ) using different theoretical approaches as well as observational data on distant objects.  In our previous works we have shown that the observed redshifts of quasars can be explained by varying fine-structure constant with cosmic time. We also found that the evolution of the universe may lead to the change of other fundamental constants such as gravitational constant or proton-to-electron mass ratio. Here we present new results obtained within the framework of these models. First, we show how the model based on varying fine-structure constant explains the recent measurements of quasar absorption lines at high redshift performed by Webb et al. (1999) . Second, we discuss the possibility of explaining the Hubble parameter H0 = 72 ± 8 km s-1 Mpc-1 measured recently by Freedman et al. (2001) using the same approach. Finally, we consider another class of models where all three fundamental constants vary simultaneously.

rewrite_text: We present integral field spectroscopy (IFS) data for the brightest galaxy in the cluster Abell 2218, which is identified as the galaxy nearest to the quasar I Zw 1 at a redshift of z = 0.0625. Our analysis reveals that this galaxy has a low surface brightness halo extending approximately 10 kpc on both sides along the major axis. This feature shows no signs of rotation but exhibits some structures consistent with infalling material or tidal interactions. Additionally, we detect two compact objects within 5 kpc of the galaxy's center. One of these objects appears to have a very high surface brightness and is likely indicative of a nuclear starburst, while the other displays a significantly lower surface brightness and may be related to a supermassive black hole binary system. These findings are discussed in the context of potential evolutionary scenarios for this interacting pair.

We present new constraints on warm dark matter (WDM) models by combining the results of two recent surveys for gravitationally lensed quasars, SDSS and CFHTLS Wide. We find that the observed number density of lenses is consistent with predictions based on cold dark matter simulations but inconsistent at more than 3 sigma confidence level if we assume a standard thermal relic WDM model with mass mX = 1 keV. This result suggests either that the current WDM scenario needs to be modified or that there are other systematic effects which have not been taken into account in our analysis. The full text can be found at: http://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0604070v1.pdf . 
The existence of dark matter has now been established beyond reasonable doubt through its gravitational influence on visible matter. However, despite decades of research, little else about this mysterious substance is known. In particular, it remains unclear whether dark matter consists of one particle species only - as assumed in most theoretical studies -or whether it comprises several different particles. One possibility is that dark matter consists of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), such as neutralinos predicted within supersymmetric extensions of the Standard Model  1  .
In order to test these scenarios observationally, astronomers look for signatures of dark matter in astrophysical objects like galaxies  2  , clusters  3  and quasars  4  . A particularly promising method involves searching for gravitationally lensed systems  5  where light rays emitted by distant sources bend around intervening dark matter halos  6  . If dark matter consists of WIMPs then their masses should lie between 10 GeV/c 2 and 100 TeV/c 2  7, 8  . For example, the recently discovered galaxy cluster Abell 2218  9  may contain a halo made up entirely of WIMPs  10  .

rewrite_text: We explore the nonlinear perturbations of general relativity (GR) and other gravitational metrics, focusing on their effects on conserved quantities such as energy-momentum tensors. We find that these perturbations can be divided into two components: one related to the underlying geometry and the other intrinsic to the perturbation itself. Notably, we demonstrate that for any stationary solution of the equations, there exists a corresponding alteration in the conservation of various quantities. This indicates that conservation laws are not invariant under certain perturbations. Additionally, we illustrate how these variations may affect the validity of the weak equivalence principle. We also discuss the broader implications of our findings for cosmology and black hole physics. General relativity (GR), which describes gravitational interactions at large scales, has been thoroughly tested against observations over many years. However, it remains uncertain whether GR holds true at smaller scales where quantum mechanics becomes significant. To tackle this question, various alternative theories have been proposed, including scalar-tensor theories and modified gravity frameworks. These alternatives often include modifications that extend beyond the predictions of GR. For instance, in scalar-tensor theories, the graviton acquires mass through its interaction with a scalar field. Similarly, in modified (R)-gravity theories, the standard Einstein-Hilbert action is updated to incorporate curvature corrections. It turns out that both types of theories allow for self-accelerating solutions, such as de Sitter-like scenarios, without requiring specific conditions.

original_text: We present the spectroscopic follow-up observations for eight galaxy clusters at redshifts z=0.6-0.9 selected in the Red-Sequence Cluster Survey (RCS). The sample is composed by four X-ray luminous and four optically rich clusters, with masses ranging between M500 = 1.5 × 1014 - 2.7 × 1014 h70M⊙ . We have obtained spectra for more than 100 cluster members using VLT/FORS2 and Keck/DEIMOS spectrographs. From these data we derive velocity dispersions, dynamical mass estimates, and luminosity-weighted ages for each system. In addition to this analysis, we also study the evolution of the scaling relations as a function of redshift up to z=1.1. Our results show that the observed properties are consistent with those expected for massive systems undergoing gravitational collapse. However, there seems to be an offset towards lower values of σv /σ⋆ compared to predictions based on numerical simulations.

INTRODUCTION: The study of neutrinos has opened a compelling avenue for exploring physics beyond the Standard Model (SM), especially in the context of their Majorana nature through lepton-number violating processes. A particularly intriguing scenario is the seesaw mechanism, wherein SM singlet right-handed neutrinos acquire large Majorana masses after electroweak symmetry breaking. To ascertain whether the observed neutrinos are genuinely Majorana particles, it is essential to search for lepton number violating processes mediated by virtual heavy neutrinos. These include neutrinoless double beta decay, tritium beta decay experiments, and charged-current quasielastic interactions. However, each of these processes faces significant astrophysical and/or nuclear uncertainties. In contrast, collider experiments offer a clean environment to investigate lepton number violation. For instance, the search for same-sign dileptons and trileptons at hadronic colliders has led to stringent limits on the existence of Majorana neutrinos. Another promising channel for study is the production of doubly charged scalars, which can occur through s-channel exchanges of gauge bosons or t-channel exchanges of heavy fermions.

original_text: We present new numerical results on the structure of accretion disks in binary systems with a black hole (BH) as well as their observational signatures, including eclipses by the BH shadow and reflection features due to strong gravitational lensing. We consider two different types of models: one where the disk is geometrically thin but optically thick, and another where it has an extended atmosphere that can be either optically thick or thin depending on its density distribution. In both cases we find that the observed flux depends strongly on the inclination angle between the orbital plane and our line-of-sight. For low inclinations, the system appears bright because most of the emission comes directly from the disk surface facing us; at high inclinations, however, only a small fraction of this emission reaches us while most of it gets blocked by the BH itself. The DGC consists of multiple proteins, including dystrophin, sarcoglycans, syntrophins, dystrobrevins, and utrophin. We study the nonlocal excitation spectra for doped Mott insulators by using the dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) combined with the exact diagonalization method and the Lanczos algorithm. rewrite_text: We introduce the Bridge robbery, a highly efficient direct tree hybrid n-body method designed for simulating fully self-consistent stellar distributions in galactic potentials with complex mass distributions. The Bridge method effectively combines both direct summation (DS) and tree algorithms by employing DS exclusively within smaller regions of high density while solving the full set of equations on a tree structure. Specifically, we show that our new method closely reproduces results from the advanced treecode NBODY6++ GPU, even when simulating systems with up to 10 million particles. original_text: We present the first constraints on dark matter halos in the early universe using data from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Cosmic Assembly Near-Infrared Deep Extragalactic Legacy Survey (CANDELS). We use photometric redshifts to select galaxies with stellar masses greater than 10$^{10}$ Msun/hour between 0 < z < 8.5. Using these galaxy samples we measure the abundance evolution of massive halos as well as their clustering properties over this range. The results are compared against predictions made by semi-analytic models that include prescriptions for black hole growth and AGN feedback. Our main conclusions are: 1) At all redshifts probed here, there is an excess number density of massive halos relative to model predictions. 2) This discrepancy increases towards higher redshifts. 3) There is also evidence for a lack of massive halos at low redshifts when comparing our measurements to those predicted by current models. 4) These findings suggest that either the efficiency or duty cycle of AGN feedback must be increased significantly beyond what has been assumed previously.

rewrite_text: We introduce an extension to the standard model that incorporates "backyard gravity," inspired by Feynman's concepts surrounding quantum gravity. This extended version of the standard model is constructed using gauge fields for all known gravitational interactions (referred to as crater gravity) and includes fermions with spin 1/2 and 1. Furthermore, we explore some phenomenological implications, such as neutrino masses and candidates for dark matter. Lastly, we briefly discuss potential experimental tests of our proposal. This research was supported by NSF grant PHY-0456747. A comprehensive understanding of fundamental physics should encompass gravity alongside other fundamental forces. In this work, we propose an approach that extends the conventional model to include gravitational effects. We build on Feynman's original idea of expressing quantum gravity in terms of gauge fields coupled to fermions. Using Feynman diagrams, we derive the extended model from first principles. We also discuss various phenomenological consequences, including neutrino mass generation via the seesaw mechanism and implications for dark matter candidates. original_text:
We propose an algorithm for network tomography that is able to reconstruct the internal structure of a network by using only one-dimensional (1-D) measurements, i.e., link counts between pairs of nodes in the network. The proposed method can be applied to any type of networks and does not require any prior knowledge about their topology or traffic patterns. We show how our approach can be used to estimate the number of active flows at each node as well as the amount of data transmitted over each flow. Our results are validated through extensive simulations performed with real Internet traces. Network tomography has been widely studied during recent years due to its potential applications in many areas such as computer security, quality-of-service provisioning, and traffic engineering  1  . In this context, it consists of estimating some properties of the network s internal state (such as the number of active flows per node or the amount of data transferred along each flow) by observing only external information (i.e., link-level statistics). This problem becomes particularly challenging when dealing with large-scale networks since the number of possible states grows exponentially with the size of the network  2  .
In order to overcome these limitations, several approaches have been recently proposed which exploit specific characteristics of the underlying network  3  , e.g., sparsity  4  -  6  , symmetry  7  , or regularity  8  . However, most existing methods assume either complete knowledge of the network topology  9 -  11  or accurate estimates of the traffic matrix  12  -  14  . Unfortunately, both assumptions may not hold in practice  15  , especially if we consider large and/or dynamic networks  16  . rewrite_text: We have explored the potential of pulsar timing measurements to detect gravitational waves by observing the Shapiro delay, which results from the influence of massive objects (such as the Earth and its companion, the Sun) on the passage of time. We conclude that this method is not feasible with current technology since it requires extensive and repeated measurements of pulsar timings over many years. However, we believe that advanced telescopes equipped with sensitive instruments like phased-array feeds or advanced backends could facilitate such observations in the future. Furthermore, we examine alternative methods that utilize pulsar timing data to study gravitational effects on satellites in their orbits. Gravitational waves can cause variations in the timing of pulses received at different locations on the surface of a rotating neutron star. These variations depend on the distance between the pulsars as well as their orientation relative to the observer. The most significant effects are observed when a pulsar is positioned close to the Earth and its accompanying bodies, resulting in a time delay known as the Shapiro effect (Shapiro, 1964). By analyzing the pulsar timing data from all pulsars within a globular cluster, we can infer the distances between them. By comparing these observations with predictions made by general relativity, we can assess whether Einstein's theories accurately describe gravity on a large scale.

rewrite_text: We present observations from the Herschel Space Observatory at wavelengths of 70, 160, 250, 350, and 500 microns, focused on two fields located in the densest areas of the Rho Ophiuchi (RO) molecular cloud complex. These data are utilized to derive the temperatures within dense cores, which have been identified by their infrared emissions using a method developed by John Myers and Sean Carey. Our findings indicate that the majority of these cores have temperatures ranging from 10 K to 20 K, with only one core exhibiting a temperature lower than 8 K. This result aligns with previous observations demonstrating that colder cores are rare in this complex. By applying the derived temperatures, we estimate the masses of these cores, assuming optically thin greybody emission, with masses ranging from 0.1 M☉ to over 100 M☉. Additionally, we analyze the same dataset to assess the properties of protostars in the RO region. We identify 16 Class I protostars based on their spectral energy distributions and compare them with those found in other nearby star-forming regions, such as Serpens South and Orion B North.

rewrite_text: We introduce a method for temporal runtime verification based on monadic Midnight Logic (MDL). MDL is a decidable fragment of first-order logic that allows us to specify properties about sequences of states, similar to those generated by runtime checks or execution traces. We explain how to translate formulas from this framework into automata and how to utilize these automata for runtime verification against temporal properties in MDL. Our translation maintains satisfiability and enables us to handle infinite state spaces. The resulting automata are efficient enough to be employed during program execution. Additionally, we present a technique for reducing the size of the generated automata, making them more suitable for offline analysis. Finally, we illustrate our approach with several examples using a Java implementation of the dining philosophers problem. This research was supported by NSF grant CCF-0430018. original_text: Spin-based electronics is an emerging field that has attracted considerable attention in recent years, due to its potential for applications such as high-density data storage and high-speed information processing.  In this review article we discuss the basic concepts underlying bipolar spintronic devices based on semiconductor heterostructures with ferromagnetic contacts. We first introduce the physics behind spin injection into semiconductors using tunnel barriers or Schottky diodes. Then we describe how these injected spins can be manipulated by means of external magnetic fields and/or electric currents. Finally, we present some examples of spintronic devices including spin-LEDs, spin transistors, and spin-logic circuits. The main focus will be put on GaAs-based structures but also other materials systems are discussed briefly. This article is intended to provide a comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art research in the field of bipolar spintronics. It should serve both as a guide for newcomers interested in learning about the fundamentals of spin transport phenomena at interfaces between metals and semiconductors, and as a reference source for researchers working in related areas.

We focus on the relationship established by relativistic fluctuation theorems, which elucidate the connection between entropy production in non-equilibrium systems and fluctuations in equilibrium states. We demonstrate that these relationships can be derived solely from standard statistical mechanics, relying on time-reversal symmetry. Specifically, we derive an expression for the rate of entropy production in terms of correlation functions at thermal equilibrium. This framework is applied to analyze entropy production in various models, including Brownian motion, Langevin dynamics, and driven harmonic oscillators. Furthermore, we explore how our approach could extend beyond classical physics. Relativistic fluctuation theorems link entropy production during non-equilibrium processes with fluctuations in equilibrium states. These relationships have been established by applying standard statistical mechanics principles while maintaining time-reversal invariance. Here, we utilize this formalism to derive expressions for entropy production rates and recovered currents in terms of correlation functions at thermal equilibrium. As specific applications, we investigate several models, including Brownian motion, Langevin processes, and driven harmonic oscillators.

1. Introduction

Entropy plays a crucial role in various scientific fields, including biology, geophysics, and neuroscience. Its significance has grown in discussions related to irreversibility. However, a comprehensive method for calculating entropy production has been elusive, except in a few specific cases. Recently, fluctuation theorems have emerged, enabling the connection between entropy production and measurable properties of systems. In particular, there has been substantial interest in developing experimental techniques capable of measuring entropy production rates in real-time scenarios. Such experiments facilitate direct tests of fundamental thermodynamic principles and may lead to practical devices for harnessing work from physical systems.

2. Classical fluctuation theorems

The most renowned fluctuation theorem was first proposed by Jarzynski.

We study the relationship between distillable entanglement, entropy-area law (EAL), and von Neumann entropy for two classes of quantum systems -spin chains with nearest-neighbor interactions and harmonic oscillator lattices. We show that EAL holds true if and only if the ground state is unique or degenerate. For non-degenerate ground states we prove that there exists an infinite family of pure product states which are arbitrarily close to the ground state but cannot be obtained by local operations assisted by classical communication (LOCC). Finally, we present numerical evidence suggesting that this phenomenon may occur even when the ground state is unique. We present a study of the metallicity distribution functions (MDFs) for stars located at various latitudes and distances from the Galactic center, utilizing spectroscopic data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Our analysis reveals that the MDFs are consistent with one another within their uncertainties, except for those at |b| > 30°, where there is a noticeable excess of metal-poor stars compared to the inner population. The proportion of metal-rich stars increases as one moves closer to the Galactic center. This suggests that the halo metallicity becomes more enriched as one moves inward from the Galactic outskirts. Additionally, we also observed that the average metallicities decrease slightly with increasing distance from the Galactic center. These findings imply that the outer regions of our Galaxy have been shaped by processes related to accretion. 

Keywords: Metallicity Distribution Function; Halo; Disk; High Latitude Stars; Sloan Digital Sky Survey

1 Introduction

It is well established that the Milky Way is composed of three primary components: the thin disk, the thick disk, and the halo. However, the exact ways in which these components formed and evolved remain a topic of research. Understanding their respective chemical compositions is critical, as they reflect different evolutionary histories. For example, the age-metallicity relationship indicates that the halo formed earlier than the disk (e.g., Twarog 1980), while elemental ratios like Fe/H suggest the halo hosts many low-mass stars, which would have been destroyed by supernovae if the halo had formed relatively recently, as in the case of the disk (e.g., Nissen & Schuster 1997). Numerous studies have investigated the properties of the halo using samples of stars primarily selected based on proper motion or photometric parallax. Recently, extensive spectroscopic surveys such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) (York et al. 2000), the RAVE survey (Steinmetz 2003), and the SEGUE survey (Yanny et al. 2009) have significantly enhanced our understanding of the halo's composition.

original_text: The authors present an overview of the role that knots play in proteins, with particular emphasis on their function and evolution.  They discuss how protein knots are formed by covalent bonds between amino acids (the building blocks of proteins) as well as non-covalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding.  The authors also describe how different types of knots can be classified based upon their topology.   Finally they explain why it is important to study knots in proteins since these structures may have evolved for specific functions or because they provide stability against proteolysis (breakdown into smaller peptides).    This article was originally published on BioMed Central. It has been re-posted here under Creative Commons License 3.0. Protein knots are intriguing structural motifs found within many naturally occurring polypeptides. These knotted conformations result from noncovalent interactions among residues along the backbone chain combined with covalent cross-linkages at certain positions. In this review we summarize our current understanding about the formation mechanisms of various knot topologies observed in nature. We then highlight recent advances made toward characterizing the functional roles played by protein knots.

We found that the fraction of binaries within these clusters decreases as they evolve, primarily due to dynamical interactions between single stars and binary star systems. This reduction is more significant when there is a higher initial number of recovered binaries or a scarcity of soft binaries. Moreover, we explored how the properties of binaries depend on their binding energy at formation. Finally, we compare our findings with observations of real star clusters and globular clusters. Our main conclusions are: 1) Open clusters tend to have more binaries than globular clusters because they retain them longer during dynamical evolution; 2) Binaries can be disrupted by three-body encounters, even while the overall number of binaries remains constant; and 3) Hard binaries prevail over soft binaries after several relaxation timescales (t_ rh).

In this paper, we propose an autonomous distributed admission control mechanism to enhance bandwidth efficiency and fairness in Wireless Local Area Networks (WLANs). The proposed approach utilizes the observation that each device manages its own queue by leveraging the inter-arrival time of packets at the physical layer. Additionally, it monitors the list of active stations and their transmission patterns to determine whether new arrivals disrupt the existing flow. Our simulation results demonstrate that our mechanism can achieve higher throughput compared to existing schemes while also ensuring fairness among competing stations. 

Keywords: Wireless Local Area Networks, Packet Inter-Arrival Time, Fairness, Throughput Improvement.

With the rapid proliferation of portable computing devices such as laptops, PDAs, and smartphones, there has been an increasing demand for high-quality services in wireless local area networks (WLANs). However, due to the limited resources available in WLANs, efficient resource management has become critically important. Currently, the most widely used access control protocol in WLANs is the IEEE 802.11 Distributed Coordination Function (DCF), which employs a contention-based channel access method using Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance (CSMA/CA) and provides contention-free service via Point Coordination Function (PCF). While CSMA/CA allows multiple devices to share the same channel simultaneously without explicit coordination, it struggles to maintain performance when the number of active devices increases. This issue is largely attributed to the hidden node problem, wherein two devices attempt to transmit packets to each other simultaneously, resulting in collisions. To mitigate this problem, several solutions have been proposed. Notably, one approach introduced a channel reservation method aimed at reducing collisions between packets transmitted by different stations. However, all these studies fall short of addressing the implications of the number of active stations on performance.

We present the tenth study on super softly mechanics (SQM) in dimer models with free fermionic boundary conditions. We establish that SQM is equivalent to the standard Lie mechanics in the periodic boundary condition case. Furthermore, we identify two distinct types of supersymmetric states depending on whether the number of sites \(N\) is even or odd. For odd \(N\), the ground state has zero energy but does not exhibit any degeneracy. Conversely, when \(N\) is even, the ground state becomes doubly degenerate. This degeneracy can be understood through the phenomenon of parity symmetry breaking. Finally, we explore how our findings relate to the broader context of supersymmetry. PACS: 11.10.Wx, 05.45.Mt, 11.15.Tk

I. INTRODUCTORY REMARKS

In this paper, we analyze super softly mechanics (SQM) in dimer models with free fermionic boundary conditions. These models were introduced by Rokhsar et al. as exactly solvable examples that describe a spin-1/2 Heisenberg antiferromagnet on a square lattice. They revealed that these models exhibit various intriguing properties, such as spontaneous dimerization at low temperatures. The focus of this work is to investigate the influence of boundary conditions on the supersymmetric structure of these models. It turns out that the supersymmetric structure is significantly affected by the boundary conditions applied to the system. As will be demonstrated, the supersymmetric properties change considerably depending on whether free fermionic boundary conditions or others are chosen.

We present our findings on the gravitational lensing of an Einstein ring galaxy at redshift z = 1.62, which is composed of two galaxies exhibiting different mass-to-light ratios (M/L). The lensing galaxy has an M/L ratio of 0.7 ± 0.1, based on a B-band luminosity (LB) of 2 × 10^shaky, while its companion galaxy has an M/L ratio greater than 5. We suggest that this discrepancy can be attributed to a scenario where the lensing galaxy consists of both luminous and dark matter components, whereas the companion does not contain any detectable luminous matter. This observation indicates that the proportion of dark matter relative to total mass increases as the mass scale decreases. 

Keywords: Dark Matter, Galaxy Evolution, Gravitational Lensing, Massive Black Holes 

The existence of dark matter surrounding galaxies is inferred from gravitational lensing effects, either strong or weak. In particular, the presence of multiple images due to strong lensing provides insights into the distribution of dark matter along the line of sight towards distant sources. However, it remains challenging to determine how dark matter is distributed within individual galaxies because we cannot directly observe it. 

In this study, we leverage data from our ongoing survey program using the Subaru/Suprime-Cam. Our target was selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 7 photometric catalogs, and follow-up observations were conducted with Suprime-Cam mounted on the 8.2 m Subaru Telescope. As a result, we discovered a gravitationally lensed system at z = 1.62 consisting of three images generated by a foreground galaxy acting as the lens. Two of these images are closely located near the center of the lensing galaxy, while the third image is situated much farther away. Utilizing high-resolution Hubble Space Telescope data obtained from the Hubble Frontier Fields project, we found evidence of two distinct galaxies in the background source. One of these galaxies exhibits clear signs of tidal interactions with the other galaxy.

We present an analysis of the dynamics of the four giant planets of our Solar System during their formation, using numerical simulations with N-body codes that include hydrodynamical effects (gas drag). We show how these interactions can explain some features observed today on the orbits of Jupiter s Trojans asteroids. In particular we find that:  1) The eccentricities of Jupiter s Trojan asteroids are excited by close encounters between Jupiter and Saturn; 2) The inclination distribution is affected by the presence of gas; 3) The semi-major axes of Jupiter s Trojans are shifted towards smaller values due to the effect of gas friction. These results suggest that the dynamical history of Jupiter s Trojans may be related to the evolution of the protoplanetary nebula surrounding the Sun. rewrite_text: We present cosmological hydrodynamic simulations that explore the formation of galaxy clusters in the preheating epoch, where the environment is affected by an unstable distribution of stars before collapsing into dark matter haloes. We compare our results with observations of the X-ray luminosity-temperature relation (L-T) at redshift z = 0, analyzing temperature profiles out to large radii. Our simulated L-T relation aligns remarkably well with observational data across three orders of magnitude in luminosity. However, the slope of the observed L-T relation steepens at lower temperatures, while our simulation does not exhibit this trend. This discrepancy may be attributed to additional heating processes not included in our simulations or potential uncertainties within the observational dataset. Furthermore, we find that the entropy profiles of our simulated cluster population match the observed profiles within their scatter. Nonetheless, there are notable differences between individual simulated clusters and real observations, which could arise from non-gravitational processes such as AGN feedback.

rewrite_text: The radial distribution of the magnetic field in the ionosphere is examined by analyzing the magnetic field and diffusion patterns recorded by two low-altitude satellites during a geomagnetic storm that occurred from March 1 to 5, 1982. The study reveals significant differences in the magnetic field profiles observed by the satellites. Specifically, data from GEOS-1 indicates a pronounced peak near L = 3, whereas information from ATS-6 and GEOS-2 suggests a peak around L = 4. These discrepancies may arise because the satellites sample different regions of the ionosphere due to their varying orbits. Furthermore, it is noted that the magnetic field profiles inferred from the three satellites are consistently shifted when extensively examined along the L-shell. This finding indicates that the observed variations in the field profiles are likely linked to spatial differences rather than temporal changes.

We present an analysis of the first two years (Feb 2005 -Jan 2007) of data taken by the Swift satellite, which has been designed to detect and study gamma ray bursts (GRBs). We find that GRB 050904 at z = 6.3 is the most distant object ever detected in the electromagnetic spectrum. The prompt emission was observed over more than four orders of magnitude in energy, from radio waves up to X-rays. This burst also had one of the highest fluences recorded so far for any GRB. In addition we report on another burst, GRB 080913, whose afterglow was found to be variable on timescales as short as 1 minute. These results are discussed within the context of current models for GRB production. Keywords: Gamma-ray burst, High-redshift universe, Afterglows, Swift satellite. Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), intense flashes of high-energy radiation lasting only milliseconds, have now been discovered out to redshifts greater than six  1  . Their extreme luminosities make them powerful probes into the early Universe  2  , but their origin remains unknown  3  .
Swift  4  , launched in November 2004, carries three instruments capable of detecting GRBs across the entire electromagnetic spectrum  5  : the Burst Alert Telescope  6  detects GRBs via their X-ray and/or optical emissions; the Ultraviolet/Optical Telescope  7  observes the afterglow through ultraviolet and visible light; and the X-ray telescope  8  monitors the afterglow s decaying flux. Here we describe our initial findings using these instruments during the first two years of operation.

rewrite_text: We provide an analytical expression for the Casimir effect acting on two parallel plates made from different materials: one metallic (silver) and the other dielectric (silicon dioxide). The results obtained align with those derived from Lifshitz theory within a 1% margin in the context of varying separations. Our analysis demonstrates how our findings can be applied to explore the temperature dependence of the Casimir force at fixed separation distances. In this study, we consider the scenario where one plate is made of silver and the other of silicon dioxide. Silver is commonly used as a coating in microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), while silicon dioxide is frequently employed as a substrate or insulator in MEMS devices. Our results are relevant not only to these specific cases but also extend to any system consisting of two plates separated by vacuum, which can include a variety of structures such as semiconductor heterostructures, quantum dots, and nanowires, all of which have gained significant attention due to their potential applications in nanotechnology. It is important to note that this problem has been theoretically studied for over 50 years. However, despite extensive research, no exact solution has yet been derived. Consequently, most studies have relied on approximate methods. These methods include proximity force approximations, the Derjaguin-Muller-Toporov approach, multiple reflection expansions, various formalism techniques, Green's functions, density functional theory, summation methods, fluctuating surface charges, renormalization techniques, and others.

original_text: The aim of this study is to develop an improved model for simulating diffusion processes within biological cells, especially those occurring at the nuclear membrane and its associated structures.  The proposed approach involves coupling two existing models; one that describes the movement of molecules through the cytoplasm (the fluid part of the cell) using Brownian dynamics simulations, with another which represents the nucleus as a porous medium containing immobile obstacles.  This latter component has been developed by considering the geometry of the nuclear pore complex network, which consists of cylindrical pores connected via narrower channels.   In order to validate our new hybrid model we have performed a series of numerical experiments on synthetic data generated from both individual particle tracking and Monte Carlo methods.  We find good agreement between these results and those obtained from our own computational scheme, thereby demonstrating the accuracy of our method. Finally, we apply our new modelling framework to investigate how changes in the structure of the nuclear pore complexes can affect the rate of molecular exchange across the nuclear envelope.

original_text: We study the effects of selection biases in cluster samples, as well as covariance between observables, on scaling relations derived from X-ray data using mock galaxy clusters generated with the semi-analytic model GALFORM. We find that both these effects can lead to significant systematic errors when deriving cosmological constraints from observed scaling relations. In particular we show that: (i) The scatter in the M-T relation is significantly reduced by including additional information about the temperature distribution function; this effect is stronger for low mass systems. (ii) The slope of the L-M relation depends strongly on whether or not one includes cooling flows in the analysis. This dependence arises because cool cores are more common at high masses than at lower masses, leading to an apparent steepening of the slope if they are excluded. (iii) The normalization of the Y-Xray luminosity-temperature relation shows strong redshift evolution which cannot be explained solely by self-similar evolution.

rewrite_text: We present findings on a white dwarf (WD) star, SDSS J104341.53+085558.2, identified in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 7. This star exhibits a significant excess flux and is surrounded by debris that may belong to a planetary disc. The WD has a temperature of T_eff = 13,000 ± 1,000 K, a radius of R_WD = 0.0120 ± 0.0010 R⊙, and a surface gravity of log g = 8.0 ± 0.1 cm s^−2. We found no evidence of binarity or accretion activity related to this object. This is only the second such system identified, following GD 362. If further explored, they could provide valuable insights into the processes of planet formation around white dwarfs. Keywords: White dwarfs.

original_text: We report the detection of cosmic far-infrared background (CFIRB) fluctuations using deep observations made by the Far Infrared Surveyor (FIS) onboard Akari satellite at 65 and 90 micron bands in the Lockman Hole field, which is one of the most sensitive fields for detecting extragalactic sources. The FIS has two photometric channels; N60 band covers 60 to 120 microns while WIDE-S channel covers 50 to 100 microns. We used data taken during the period between February 2005 and March 2007. After removing bright point-like objects detected by Spitzer/MIPS 24 micron survey, we performed aperture photometry on all remaining pixels within an area of 1 deg2 centered around the Lockman hole. Then we calculated power spectrum density (PSD) of the residual map. These slopes are consistent with those expected from clustering properties of infrared galaxies.

The MET arises from the presence of stable objects, such as heavy particles, that escape detection. We are interested in models where these objects are produced through interactions with heavy gauge bosons linked to a specific electroweak symmetry, SU(2) x SU(3). Within this framework, there exist colored states, such as octets or triplets, that can decay into pairs of quarks and/or gluons, leading to signatures similar to those expected from supersymmetric theories.
