rewrite_text: The BFKL framework is a significant tool in high-energy physics, particularly for analyzing interactions between colliding hadrons. It focuses on the behavior of the scattering amplitude in terms of the fraction of longitudinal momentum carried by one of the colliding particles. The BFKL formalism has been refined into practical computational techniques that utilize numerical methods and specialized functions. In this presentation, I will discuss the implications of the gluon Green's function within the framework of the dipole formalism, which allows us to perform analytical calculations. This method was initially developed by Mueller and Tang to analyze diffractive deep inelastic scattering (DDIS) off protons. It can also be applied to other processes, such as heavy quark production in proton-proton collisions and photon-photon interactions. We will cover our numerical implementations and share some preliminary results obtained with our code. Finally, we will highlight the potential applications of this work in more realistic phenomenological scenarios.

original_text: The deformation principle is the main tool in this article for constructing new geometric structures on physical spaces, which are not necessarily Riemannian manifolds but can be more general objects such as Finsler or pseudo-Finsler ones.  The basic idea behind it consists in deforming an initial space into another one by means of some suitable transformation group acting transitively on both spaces. This method allows to obtain many interesting results concerning various aspects of geometry and physics (e.g., geodesic flows,...). In particular, we show that any homogeneous Finsler manifold admits a canonical connection with totally skew-symmetric torsion whose curvature tensor satisfies certain properties similar to those satisfied by the Weyl conformal curvature tensor. We also prove that every locally Minkowski spacetime has a natural generalization of the Poincaré metric, called the generalized Poincaré metric, which turns out to be invariant under all local Lorentz transformations. Finally, we present several examples illustrating our approach.

rewrite_text: The Blazhko effect is one of the most enigmatic phenomena observed in pulsating stars, particularly in RR Lyrae type variables (RR Lyr), and has been studied for over 100 years. This phenomenon was first identified by George Blazhko, who noted that nearly half of all RR Lyr stars exhibit this behavior. While numerous studies have aimed to explore the Blazhko effect, satisfactory explanations have remained elusive. In this work, we focus on the observations made through the WET collaboration during two campaigns in 2002 and 2004. Our data comprises extensive observations that enable us to investigate the Blazhko effect over an unprecedentedly long time frame. This extensive study allows us to determine the average modulation rate and the characteristics of the modulation properties of RR Gem II, which we compare with findings from other Blazhko-modulated RR Lyr stars. Our results align closely with theoretical expectations, contributing valuable insights to this intriguing phenomenon.

We present an extraordinary optical transient (OT) discovered by the Palomar Transient Factory (PTF). The OT exhibited a magnitude of R = 16.7 and reached R = 14.6 within approximately one day. It is situated near the core of M85, one of the closest galaxies to our Milky Way. We found that this event shares several characteristics with Type Ia supernovae but lacks the typical spectral features associated with these phenomena. This suggests that we may be observing a different type of explosion that could be related to various other transient events, such as tidal disruption flares or superluminous supernovae. 

**Keywords:** Supernova, Optical transient, PTF, Tidal disruption flare, Brightest cluster

**Introduction:** Recently, there has been an increase in reported cases of luminous optical transients associated with nearby galaxies. Notable examples include the well-known eruptions of Eta Carinae (Davidson & Humphreys 1997; Smith et al. 1998), SN 2005ap (Gal-Yam et al. 2005; Foley et al. 2007), ASASSN-14li (Holoien et al. 2014a), ATLAS14aaq (Dong et al. 2015), PS1-10jh (Gezari et al. 2012), iPTF16axa (Kasliwal et al. 2016), and ASASSN-15oi (Shappee et al. 2016). Many of these events have been linked to supermassive black holes within active galactic nuclei. However, their precise nature remains debated. Some researchers have proposed that they may be the result of tidal disruptions of stars by black holes (TDE) (Komossa 2002; Gezari et al. 2009; Bloom et al. 2011; Holoien et al. 2013b; Arcavi et al. 2014; Brown et al. 2017), while others contend that they could represent the explosion dynamics of thermonuclear outbursts (similar to SNe Ia) (Valenti et al. 2009).

We show that the maximum weighted edge biclique problem is NP-hard to approximate within any constant factor, even for graphs with bounded degree 3 or 4. We also present several applications of this result in computational biology. In particular we prove hardness results on finding conserved regions between two genomes under different evolutionary models as well as on reconstructing ancestral gene orders using parsimony principle. Finally, we give an efficient algorithm for computing all maximal cliques in chordal bipartite graphs. rewrite_text: The Chandra X-ray Observatory has been observing the supernova remnant (SNR) created by SN1987A in the Large Magellanic Cloud for over three decades, offering a remarkable glimpse into this intriguing and youthful astrophysical object. The observations have shown that the explosion is interacting with dense circumstellar material surrounding the progenitor star at speeds reaching up to 1,000 km/s. This interaction generates bright knots of emission, which appear to be primarily composed of oxygen-rich ejecta mixed with shocked interstellar gas. Additionally, it seems there is a significant amount of this material trapped behind the forward shock wave. In this report, we present our analysis of these features based on the data acquired during the Chandra observations.

original_text: We consider the statistical properties of nonstationary random acoustic and electromagnetical waves in terms of their correlation functions, power spectra, and probability density functions (PDFs). We show that these quantities can be expressed by means of solutions to certain partial differential equations with time-dependent coefficients. The PDFs are obtained for both stationary and nonstationary cases using the method of characteristics. In particular, we derive an exact expression for the PDF of the amplitude fluctuations of a monochromatic plane wave propagating through a turbulent medium. This result is used to obtain expressions for the mean-square fluctuation levels of the electric field strength and intensity at any point along the propagation path. Finally, we discuss some applications of our results to radiowave scintillation theory and radar detection problems. PACS: 42.65.Tg, 43.20 .Fx, 47.55.+q, 47.60.+j

We propose an experimental scheme for generating graph states using the quantum Ising model in transverse magnetic field and its generalization to higher dimensions, which is realized by coupling spins via two-mode squeezed vacuum fields. We show that this method can be used to generate arbitrary graph states on one-dimensional (1D) chain as well as two-dimensional square lattice. In particular, we demonstrate how to prepare 1D cluster states and 2D cluster-dot states. The proposed scheme has several advantages over previous proposals such as high fidelity, scalability, and flexibility. It also provides a new way to study many-body physics beyond the standard paradigm based on fermions or bosons. Graph states are useful resources for various applications including measurement-based quantum computation  1  , quantum communication  2  , and quantum metrology  3  . They have been generated experimentally  4  -  8  .
In recent years there has been considerable interest in developing schemes for preparing graph states  9  -  17  . Most existing methods require either sophisticated optical elements  10  -  12  or complicated interactions between atoms  13  -  15  . Recently, it was shown that graph states could be prepared efficiently using only linear optics  16  -  18  . However, these approaches suffer from low efficiency due to photon loss during transmission through optical fibers  19  . Alternatively, graph states may be produced deterministically using trapped ions  20  -  22  . This approach requires precise control of ion-ion interaction strength and suffers from limited scalability  23  .

We investigate the impact of radiative transfer (RT) on the ultraviolet radiation of the 21 cm line at high redshifts, utilizing cosmological hydrodynamic simulations both with and without RT. Our findings indicate that RT can increase the intensity of the 21 cm signal by up to an order of magnitude compared to calculations that neglect RT effects. This enhancement is primarily driven by Lyman-alpha photons that penetrate the intergalactic medium, which subsequently interact with neutral hydrogen atoms. This interaction leads to significant heating of the intergalactic medium through photoionization and Compton scattering. Furthermore, we determine that the effects of RT alter the shape of the power spectrum of the 21 cm temperature fluctuations. Our results suggest that future radio telescopes, such as the Square Kilometre Array (SKA), will be capable of detecting this signal if they are equipped with the proper technology. 

Keywords: Hydrogen, Radiative Transfer, Power Spectrum, Cosmic Dawn

We present an analysis of the gravitational waveforms emitted by two neutron stars orbiting each other, and show that they can be used to detect violations of Lorentz invariance (LI). We consider both scalar-tensor theories with spontaneous breaking of LI as well as vector-tensor theories where LI is violated through the presence of a preferred reference frame. In these models we find that there are characteristic deviations from general relativity which lead to measurable differences between the observed gravitational waveform and those predicted within Einstein s theory. 
 
 The detection of such deviations would provide strong evidence for new physics beyond standard model expectations. This could have important consequences on our understanding of fundamental interactions at high energies. For example, it may shed light on the origin of dark energy or even reveal the existence of extra dimensions of space-time. It also has implications for cosmology since many extensions of the Standard Model predict time variations of physical constants like Newton s constant G.

rewrite_text: We present observations of flaring activity in the very-high-energy (VHE) gamma-ray band for the blazar PKS 2155-304, which was documented between September and November 2007, exhibiting a doubling time of approximately 1 day. During this period, the source achieved its highest recorded state at TeV energies. Our results are based on data obtained simultaneously with Swift-XRT and UVOT instruments, which did not show significant changes in X-ray or optical emissions throughout the outburst. This observation indicates that the high-energy emission is likely due to inverse Compton scattering by relativistic electrons located near the central black hole, rather than synchrotron radiation produced by electrons accelerated to high Lorentz factors within the jet. These findings support existing models that suggest shocks develop when the jet interacts with the surrounding medium. Keywords: Blazars, High-Energy Emission.

We present here a detailed discussion on the concept of allovalency, which is defined as the simultaneous binding to multiple sites in one molecule by different ligands (or receptors). We show that this definition does not apply to many cases where it has been used previously. In particular we discuss how multisite phosphorylation can be described within our formalism without introducing any new concepts or parameters beyond those already introduced for single-site phosphorylation. Finally, we argue why rebinding effects are negligible under most conditions relevant for signaling cascades. The concept of  allovalency  was first introduced more than 20 years ago  1  . It refers to the simultaneous binding of two or more ligands to several sites in one receptor protein  2  , see Fig 1(A) . This phenomenon occurs frequently during signal transduction processes such as kinase cascades  3  .
The term  allovalent  was coined because it describes a situation intermediate between monovalent and multivalent interactions  4  : while each ligand binds only once per receptor, there may exist several copies of the same ligand bound simultaneously to the same receptor. Allovalent interactions have been studied extensively both experimentally  5  and theoretically  6  . However, despite its widespread use, the precise meaning of  allovalency  remains ambiguous  7, 8  . For example, some authors define allovalency as  the simultaneous interaction with multiple sites in one molecule via different molecules   9  . Others consider allovalency to occur when  ligand molecules bind independently but cooperatively to multiple sites in one receptor molecule   10  . Yet others require that  allovalent complexes must contain at least three components   11  .

rewrite_text: In this study, we investigate the interactions between carriers in semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) by numerically solving the time-dependent Schrödinger equation for two interacting electrons or holes within an anisotropic QD potential. We discover that the behavior of the system varies significantly depending on the initial state, resulting in three distinct regimes: the weak coupling regime, characterized by the absence of dark states; the strong coupling regime, where one electron is excited into higher energy states while the other remains in its ground state; and the mixed regime, where both electrons oscillate simultaneously at slightly different frequencies. Furthermore, we examine how these regimes are influenced by the parameters of the QD, such as its size and shape. Our findings also have practical implications, including the generation of entangled photon pairs through biexciton processes. Quantum dots have been the focus of extensive research over the past decade due to their remarkable optical properties. A key advantage of QDs is the ability to tune their emission characteristics by varying their size, allowing them to function across a broad range of wavelengths. In this work, we concentrate on the impact of carrier-carrier interactions within semiconductor QDs, utilizing a numerical approach to solve the time-dependent Schrödinger equations. When carriers are in close proximity, they engage in strong interactions that can lead to the formation of bound excitonic complexes. However, if the interactions are weak, they may experience Coulomb attraction leading to the formation of virtual excitons. These virtual excitons can either recombine radiatively or non-radiatively, potentially leading to Auger processes. Conversely, during situations such as the pumping of photoexcited carriers or in the presence of external electric fields, the interactions can become sufficiently strong to be treated perturbatively.

original_text: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is an ideal laboratory for studying Galactic structure, stellar populations, chemical evolution, and cosmology because it has many advantages over other nearby galaxies such as M31 or M33.  The distance to the LMC can be determined by using Cepheids which are bright periodic variable stars that pulsate in radial fundamental mode. In this study we used two different methods to determine distances to Cepheids in the LMC. First method was based on non-linear least squares fitting technique called testimator while second one was based on statistical analysis known as Schwarz information criterion (SIC). We found that both methods gave consistent results within their uncertainties. Our final sample consists of 1228 Cepheids located between 30 < R < 50 kpc from the center of the galaxy. Using these data sets we derived new period-luminosity relations for classical Cepheids in the infrared bands JHKs.

We introduce a method for analyzing metabolic networks that utilizes a backyard-theoretic framework, specifically Shannon's entropy. We propose that this framework can be enhanced by considering not just individual metabolites, but also pairs or higher-order tuples of them as fundamental elements for calculating entropy. This approach allows us to define what we call pathway entropies, which help quantify the uncertainty associated with different components of the metabolic network. The proposed method enables researchers to pinpoint areas within the network where uncertainty is most pronounced. Additionally, we present a novel visualization technique for metabolic networks that leverages these new entropy-based measures. We validate our approach by applying it to two examples sourced from the biochemistry literature.

Metabolic networks are crucial in various biological processes, including cell growth and metabolism. They consist of a complex web of transforming biochemical reactions, such as the conversion of substrates into energy-rich adenosine triphosphate (ATP) through glycolysis. The study of metabolic networks has gained significant attention due to their potential as drug targets and their ability to offer valuable insights into cellular dynamics. For instance, identifying key enzymes involved in specific pathways can aid in the development of therapeutics against certain conditions. Moreover, metabolic networks have been shown to exhibit properties similar to those found in social networks, hinting at underlying common principles among different types of networks.

In addition to analyzing the functionality of metabolic networks, several computational models have been developed. Stoichiometric approaches, for example, seek to mathematically describe all possible states of a given metabolic network. However, the high dimensionality of these models makes it challenging to analyze large metabolic networks effectively. As a result, alternative methods have been proposed to address these limitations.

original_text: We propose to realize strong atom-field coupling between a single-mode microwave field and ultracold atoms trapped inside a microchip-based Fabry-Perot resonator with high finesse mirrors. The system is described by the Jaynes-Cummings model, which predicts Rabi oscillations at the single-atom level. We show that this scheme can be implemented using current technology. In particular we discuss how to trap cold atoms close to one mirror surface and how to couple them efficiently to the microwave mode via evanescent fields. Finally, we present numerical results showing that it should be possible to reach the regime where quantum effects become important even if only a small number of atoms are loaded into the cavity. This work was supported by the European Commission under contract IST-2001-34011 Quantum Photonics (QAP). It has been performed within the framework of the EUROTOP network of excellence. A new approach towards realizing strongly interacting light-matter systems is proposed based on trapping ultracold atoms near high-finesse mirrors. By exploiting the large electric dipole moment associated with atomic transitions in the microwave domain, we demonstrate that such a setup allows us to achieve strong atom-field coupling at the single-atom limit.

rewrite_text: We conducted optical and near-infrared photometry of SN 2006bp, which was discovered on September 24th in NGC 6946 by astronomer Brian Puckett (Puckett et al., 2007). This supernova is situated at an unusually large distance from its host galaxy, with a recession velocity of approximately 1000 km/s. We propose an algorithm that learns how to segment time series data into meaningful segments by using a combination of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) Experts and Adaptive Variance Estimation (AVE). The proposed method is based on the idea that each expert in our ensemble has its own internal representation of the input sequence which can be used as prior knowledge when estimating the uncertainty associated with the prediction made by this particular expert. We show that such approach leads to better results than state-of-the-art methods both in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. 
The main contributions of this work are summarized below: 
1. A novel framework for modeling uncertain predictions produced by multiple RNN Experts.
2. An efficient online training procedure for updating parameters of all Experts simultaneously.
3. Extensive experiments conducted on several real-world datasets demonstrate superior performance of the proposed method over existing approaches. Learning to predict future values of a given time series requires understanding patterns hidden within it. However, due to high complexity of many real world problems, finding these patterns may require processing large amounts of data. In order to make accurate predictions we need to find a way to extract useful information from raw data while at the same time being able to deal with noise present in the signal. This problem becomes even more challenging if one wants to process data streams arriving continuously or having very short duration between consecutive samples.

We present the results of our numerical simulations of magnetized, rotating white dwarfs undergoing accretion-induced collapse (AIC). We found that for sufficiently rapid rotation and strong magnetic fields, AIC can result in explosions that have characteristics similar to those observed in Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia). The explosion is driven by the release of gravitational energy as the collapsed core rebounds after reaching nuclear densities. Additionally, we discovered that the presence of a strong toroidal magnetic field can create asymmetries in the ejecta. These asymmetries may be responsible for the polarization signals observed in some SNe Ia. 

**Keywords**: Type Ia Supernovae, Rotation, Magnetic Fields, White Dwarf Stars, Accretion-Induced Collapse

**1. Introduction**  
Recent observations have revealed that many Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) exhibit significant linear polarization. This has been interpreted as evidence of asymmetric explosions, which may be triggered by strong magnetic fields or rapid rotation. However, it remains unclear whether either factor alone can account for such highly polarized light curves. In this study, we investigate how the combination of rapid rotation and strong magnetic fields influences the outcome of accretion-induced collapse (AIC), wherein a white dwarf collapses into a neutron star. To conduct this investigation, we employ two-dimensional axisymmetric hydrodynamic simulations utilizing the FLASH code. Our initial models consist of rigidly rotating white dwarfs with masses ranging from 0.6 to 1.2 solar masses. To incorporate the effects of general relativity on the dynamics of the white dwarf, we apply the polytropic equation of state \( P = K\rho^\Gamma \), where \( \rho \) is the mass density and \( P \) is the pressure. The main objective of this research is to determine whether AIC events triggered by rapid rotation and/or strong magnetic fields can produce the high levels of polarization observed in SNe Ia.

The author considers the problem of gravitational interaction between bodies in terms of their informational content. The main idea is that the gravitational field can be considered as an ensemble of gravitons which carry information about the source body. Gravitational waves are treated as carriers of information on the state of motion of gravitating objects. It is shown how this approach allows one to explain some phenomena observed in astrophysics (the Pioneer anomaly) and cosmology (dark energy). In addition, it is proposed to use the concept of  information potential  for describing the evolution of the universe. The main idea here is that the gravitational field may be viewed as an ensemble of gravitons/quanta carrying information about the source body; gravitational waves are then seen as carriers of information regarding the state of motion of the gravitating objects. This viewpoint enables us to provide explanations for certain phenomena observed in astrophysical settings (e.g., the Pioneer anomaly), as well as in cosmological contexts (e.g., dark energy). Moreover, we propose using the notion of “information potential” to describe the evolution of the Universe.

We present an analysis of the properties of giant planet candidates detected by the Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE) survey, which has been monitoring stars towards the Galactic bulge for more than ten years. We find that most of these systems are likely to be composed of two low-mass objects with masses below 0.5 MJup orbiting each other on periods longer than 100 days. The majority of them have orbital inclinations close to 90 degrees. These results suggest that many of the planetary mass companions found around nearby solar-type stars may also exist around distant red giants. This is important because it allows us to study their atmospheric composition using high-resolution spectroscopy.

rewrite_text: We propose that, in addition to the contributions from parent stars and neutrinos, there is another significant source of uncertainty during the early stages of the cosmos that has largely been overlooked by previous researchers. This is particularly relevant because the universe became transparent to photons at redshifts of approximately z ~ 1100 (around the time when matter and radiation decoupled), allowing these photons to travel freely outward. The subsequent reduction in density leads to the universe expanding more rapidly than it otherwise would, resulting in an accelerated expansion rate. We estimate that this effect can account for up to 10% of the total luminosity output from certain types of stars that may be lost due to this phenomenon. We investigated the mechanics of Jarvis microtubules in vitro, utilizing optical tweezers to apply forces along their lengths. Our findings reveal that microtubules exhibit remarkable stiffness against bending, yet they are relatively flexible when it comes to stretching. The elastic behavior can be effectively described by an entropic spring model with a persistence length of approximately 1.5 micrometers. Microtubules can be reshaped into configurations such as rings or helices without experiencing permanent deformation. Furthermore, when we examine their bending behavior, we observed that the degree of bending depends on the imposed force. This suggests that microtubules possess internal structures that develop during polymerization. These insights enhance our understanding of microtubule behavior within cells, where they are subjected to both external forces and internal tensions from interacting proteins. Microtubules (MTs) are crucial in various cellular functions, including cell division, intracellular transport, and mechanosensing. They are composed of tubulin dimers arranged head-to-tail into protofilaments. MTs originate from centrosomes and exhibit dynamic instability, transitioning stochastically between periods of growth and shrinkage. Additionally, microtubules interact strongly with motor proteins. For example, kinesin-1 moves processively along microtubules, whereas dyneins exert pulling forces. These motors generate forces that can cause microtubules to buckle and deform. Previous studies have suggested that such deformations could lead to mechanical instabilities and even catastrophic failures. However, there has been limited research on the mechanics of individual microtubules under strain. In this letter, we employ optical tweezers to analyze the elastic properties of Jarvis microtubules. Our results indicate that microtubules are quite stiff against bending but exhibit softness when stretched. We demonstrate that microtubules can be formed into ring-like structures without permanent deformation. Lastly, we observe that after being bent, microtubules have an internal structure that influences their elastic response. Our experiments reveal novel aspects of microtubule mechanics, advancing our understanding of how they respond to forces generated by cellular activities.

We present an analysis of peculiar velocities in the local universe, based on data obtained by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). We use a sample of galaxies with measured redshifts and distances to construct a map of the velocity field around us. The resulting flow is dominated by coherent motions that are consistent with our location within a void centered at about 50 Mpc distance. This result confirms earlier findings using different methods. 
 
 In addition we find evidence for a dipole component in this flow which points away from the center of the void towards Virgo. Our results suggest that the bulk motion of matter in the nearby universe may be influenced by large-scale structure. These results have implications for cosmological models as well as for studies of galaxy formation and evolution. They also provide new constraints on theories of dark energy. We investigate the behavior of trajectories and non-repetitive pauses near the event horizons of rotating black holes using the Hamilton-Jacobi method. This approach extends the traditional geodesic framework to account for corrections stemming from perturbative effects. Our findings reveal that both spherical and non-circular orbits possess two distinct families, each characterized by different orbital frequencies at the same radius. The inner family exhibits lower orbital frequencies compared to the outer one; the inner solution describes bound orbits while the outer solution describes unbound ones. For circular orbits, we show how these behaviors can be derived from the established laws of black hole mechanics. Furthermore, we provide numerical evidence that the innermost stable circular orbit (ISCO) shifts inward as the spin parameter increases. Finally, we explore the implications of our results for astrophysical phenomena, such as accretion disks surrounding rotating black holes.

In the introduction, we note that the discovery of the binary pulsar PSR1913 + 16, along with accurate measurements of the mass ratio between its neutron star components and their companion white dwarf, led to the conclusion that most binary systems ultimately evolve into black holes characterized by surrounding accretion disks. Since then, numerous observations have supported this model. Understanding the dynamics of matter falling into black holes necessitates knowledge of where it becomes trapped or ejected. This understanding is crucial for identifying the location of the innermost stable circular orbit (ISCO), which marks the closest possible radius where matter can stably orbit a black hole. The position of the ISCO is highly sensitive to the black hole's spin parameter \( J = Ma^2 / (2r_g) \). Specifically, if \( J < M^2 \), then the ISCO radius is greater than \( 3M \). However, as \( J \) approaches \( M^2 \), the ISCO radius decreases sharply, ultimately reaching the Schwarzschild radius \( R_s \equiv 2GM / c^2 \). Thus, understanding the properties of the ISCO provides critical insights into the physics governing matter in the vicinity of black holes.

We present the discovery and characterization of two  hot Jupiter  planets orbiting stars that are members of wide binaries, HD 196885AB (a = 1.8 AU) and HD 208598AB (a = 3.6 AU). The planet around HD 196885A is an inflated gas giant with M sin i = 0.88 MJup and P = 4.3 days; it orbits its primary at a distance of only 0.04 AU. We find no evidence for additional companions to either host star down to masses as low as 5 MJup within separations of 10 AU. Both systems have orbital eccentricities consistent with zero. These results suggest that hot Jupiters can survive close encounters with other stars during their formation or early evolution.  - Introduction 
 
 Hot Jupiters are massive gaseous planets on short-period orbits about solar-type stars. They represent one of the most extreme environments in our Solar System, but they may be common among nearby Sun-like stars. In fact, recent surveys indicate that roughly 20% of sun-like stars harbor such planets . However, these planets are thought to form beyond several AU before migrating inward through interactions with the protoplanetary disk and/or gravitational scattering by other bodies. This raises questions regarding how these planets manage to avoid being ejected into interstellar space after undergoing strong dynamical interactions with other objects while still retaining sufficient angular momentum to reach their current locations near their parent stars .

In this Letter we report the detection of two new  hot Jupiter  planets using high-precision radial velocity measurements obtained over more than eight years with the High Accuracy Radial Velocity Planet Searcher instrument (HARPS), which is installed on the European Southern Observatory s 3.6-m telescope located at La Silla Observatory in Chile. One of these planets has an extremely small semi-major axis of just 0.04 AU, making it one of the closest known exoplanets to its parent star.

We report on an observation made with Chandra s High Energy Transmission Grating Spectrometer (HETGS) that shows dramatic variability of absorption lines in the spectrum of the black hole candidate Cygnus X1, which is known to have strong winds and outflows. The observed line profiles are consistent with those expected for highly ionized iron atoms moving at speeds up to 0.2c along our line-of-sight toward the central source. We find no evidence for significant changes in the ionization state or column density of these absorbers over time scales as short as one hour. These results provide new insights into the physical conditions near the accretion disk around this supermassive black hole. This work was supported by NASA under contract NAS8-03060.

 Introduction

Such flows may play important roles in regulating the growth of supermassive black holes through their effects on both the surrounding gas and radiation fields. They also represent potential sources of feedback between AGNs and their host galaxies. However, despite many theoretical predictions about how such winds should behave, direct observational constraints remain limited due to the difficulty of observing them directly. One promising approach involves using high-resolution spectroscopy to study the absorption features produced when wind material passes across the line-of-sight towards the central continuum source. We find that the Type I migration rate is significantly influenced by the disk's viscosity; it decreases for lower viscosities at small radii but increases again beyond a critical radius (typically around 1 AU). This behavior can be understood by examining the balance between corotation torques and Lindblad torques. Furthermore, we have discovered that mass accretion onto planets depends on their orbital distance due to the gradient created across the gap opened by the planet. Our results suggest two potential scenarios for the observed distribution of exoplanets: either they form very close to their host stars or they undergo significant migration after their formation.

We propose an efficient numerical scheme to solve the nonlinear dynamics of semiconductor microcavity lasers with arbitrary pumping profiles and cavity losses, which is based on the combination of two different truncation schemes. The first one is used to reduce the number of equations by eliminating all but those that are relevant at any given time instant; this allows us to obtain accurate results even when only few modes contribute significantly to the total emission spectrum. The second one is applied to eliminate the fast oscillating terms appearing due to the presence of multiple longitudinal modes within each transverse mode family. We show how these two techniques can be combined into a single algorithm, which we call  dynamics-controlled truncation  (DCT). Finally, we demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of our method by comparing it against other existing methods. In particular, we consider three different types of pumping profiles: constant, periodic, and random pulsed pumping. 
I. INTRODU CTION
Semiconductor microcavity lasers  attract considerable attention because they provide a promising route towards low-threshold laser sources  1  . However, their complex multimode nature makes them difficult to model numerically  2  , especially if the pumping profile or the cavity loss varies over time  3  .
In order to overcome such difficulties, several authors have proposed various approaches  4  -  8  . For example, in Ref.  6  , the authors use a reduced set of rate equations to describe the evolution of the slowly varying amplitudes of the dominant modes. This approach has been extended recently to include higher-order effects  7  as well as nonuniform gain saturation  9  . Another possibility consists in using truncated Fourier series expansions  10  , where the coefficients of the expansion are determined self-consistently  11  . Alternatively, one may also employ direct integration of Maxwell s equations  12  , although this requires very large computational resources  13  .

We introduce the first examination of the infrared extinction law (IRAL) in a cloud core, L183. The IRAL is determined by comparing near-infrared observations to mid-infrared data collected from the same line of sight through the cloud. Our analysis reveals that the IRAL exhibits no significant variation with depth into the cloud, even at an extinction value of AV = 1000 mag. This suggests that dust grains are not entirely destroyed, even under the extreme conditions found deep within dense clouds. We propose that growth processes may be limited in these environments due to efficient fragmentation resulting from collisions among large grains. These findings have significant implications for understanding the formation processes of planetesimals. 

**Keywords**: Infrared extinction law, dust properties, interstellar medium, shock waves. 

1. **Introduction**  
It has been suggested that interstellar dust grains can grow to millimeter sizes or larger within dense molecular clouds because they can survive against destructive collisions with other grains (e.g., coagulation processes; Ossenkopf & Henning, 1994). However, other studies have indicated that there are many regions in dense environments where the dust density exceeds 10^6 cm^{-3} (unpublished data, Stepnik et al., 2003; Pagani et al., 2003), which contradicts this scenario. To address this discrepancy, it has been proposed that larger grains could be destroyed through collisional fragmentation as they reach sizes comparable to the mean free path of hydrogen (Ormel et al., 2007). Another possibility is that dust grains do not simply disappear, but instead break into smaller fragments during collisions (e.g., Blum & Wurm, 2008). If this is the case, we would expect to observe evidence of ongoing fragmentation, such as sub-micron-sized particles in dense regions. In fact, several observational studies have reported the presence of sub-millimeter emission features attributed to silicate and/or carbonaceous dust in such dense environments (e.g., Jones et al., 1993; Chiar et al., 1998; Kessler et al., 2000).

We present the tenth result from applying the paused-analytic repetitive VESPA to investigate the role of dark matter in the Millennium Simulation, particularly focusing on how various factors influence the observed properties of galaxies. Our models successfully replicate many observational data points for different types of galaxies at a redshift of 0 (e.g., luminosity functions), but they also predict some new outcomes that can be validated with confidence using future surveys like Euclid or LSST. Specifically, we found that:  

- The density of quiescent galaxies is too high compared to expectations; this issue could be mitigated if AGN feedback were more effective than we have assumed.

rewrite_text: In this paper, we present a rigorous formulation and proof of the equivalence between Ising spin glasses (ISGs) and Ising models (IMs). We show that, in the thermodynamic limit as \( N \to \infty \) with a fixed ratio \( J/T \), the partition functions of ISGs can be mapped onto those of IMs by employing a method that preserves essential features, such as free energy density, given by \( f = -k_B T \ln Z / N \). The key idea is to introduce a set of variables {s} ≡ {s₁, . . . , sN} representing the magnetizations of each site \( i \) in {1, . . . , N}, and then to reformulate the original problem in a way that these variables are coupled only through their interactions. This enables us to rigorously demonstrate that the two systems share exactly the same critical properties as the number of sites approaches infinity. The structure of the paper is as follows: In Section II, we define the model under investigation and introduce the basic definitions and notation used throughout the work. In Section III, we provide a detailed description of the framework introduced above and derive its implications for finite system sizes \( N \). In Section IV, we discuss how this framework can be extended to infinite-size lattices. Finally, in Section V, we present the detailed proof of the theorem establishing the equivalence between ISGs and IMs.

We propose that the dark matter is composed of bosonic ultracompact (UC) objects, which can transition into a superfluid state at low temperatures. We investigate how this theory could shed light on several perplexing issues in astrophysics and cosmology. In particular, we argue that: (i) the flat rotation curves of spiral galaxies can be explained by the presence of a halo of bosonic dark matter surrounding each galaxy; (ii) the formation of large-scale structures such as galaxies occurs through the amplification of primordial density fluctuations caused by inflation; (iii) dark matter may manifest as gravitationally bound states of scalar fields with masses around \(10^{22}\) GeV. This article is part of a series on Quantum Matter. For further details, please see http://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0604070. 

**Introduction**: Many theories that extend beyond the Standard Model predict the existence of new types of elementary particles, which have yet to be confirmed experimentally. One particularly intriguing class of models involves so-called WIMPZILLAs, which are stable relics with masses around \(10^9\) GeV. These particles could have formed thermally in the early universe, and their presence could still be detected through their annihilation. In this letter, we propose an alternative explanation for the nature of dark matter, suggesting that it consists of self-gravitating bosons. Boson stars are gravitationally bound states of scalar fields, with several candidates arising from various extensions of the Standard Model. Initially studied in the context of supersymmetric grand unified theories, where they serve as solitonic objects, boson stars have more recently been examined in the context of quantum field theory. If these objects do exist, they would contribute to a population of compact structures that could account for all or part of the observed dark matter.

The LBNE will use a novel design for its proton driver that combines two existing technologies - Cyclotrons and Recirculating Linacs - into one compact system.  This report describes the status of this project as of September 2009.   It also presents some preliminary results on the physics potential of the LBNE program. The Long Baseline Neutrinos Experiment (LBNE), currently under development by an international collaboration, plans to construct a new accelerator based neutrino beam facility in northern New Mexico. The facility would be located about 1000 km away from the FermiLab site in Chicago, IL where it could take advantage of the intense NuMI neutrino beam produced there. In addition to providing high intensity neutrino beams over a wide range of energies, the facility would include a large liquid argon time projection chamber detector capable of measuring both charged current interactions and neutral current elastic scattering events. The facility would provide unique opportunities to explore fundamental questions related to neutrino masses and mixings, CP violation, and other phenomena associated with neutrino oscillations.

However, we also identify three systems where the disk is likely to have an inner hole or gap; TW Hya, DM Tau, and GM Aur. In addition, we detect two transitional disks around V4046 Sgr and Sz 91. rewrite_text: We present a framework for understanding why quantum mechanics displays nonlocal characteristics, highlighting the challenge of reliably predicting whether a measurement will be obtained in any given experiment. We explore how this can result in superluminal connections between two parties that are significantly entangled, utilizing only classical communication and local operations (LOCC). We then expand the Born rule to accommodate this framework, moving beyond the traditional von Neumann formalism. The proposed formulation of quantum mechanics presumes that all experiments occur under ideal conditions, where no errors arise during state preparation or execution. However, in reality, there are always some imperfections, such as decoherence from environmental interaction, imprecise state setups, and measurement inaccuracies. To address these influences, various methods have been proposed, including stochastic Schrödinger equations, quantum fox approaches, and probabilistic frameworks. Here, we introduce another perspective known as Quantum Bayesianism. In this approach, the wave function is interpreted as encapsulating our knowledge about the system, rather than merely reflecting its intrinsic properties. This means that when a measurement is taken, the outcome is informed by an update of our knowledge in accordance with Bayes' theorem. For instance, if Alice measures the spin of her particle along the x-axis, she updates her beliefs based on the outcome. If Bob subsequently measures his particle’s spin along the same axis but arrives at a different result, his understanding of the system must also be adjusted accordingly.

We investigate the acceleration efficiency of cosmic rays (CR) in relativistic shocks using Monte Carlo simulations and detailed calculations. Our results indicate that for strong shocks with Mach numbers ranging from M = 10 to 100, only about 1% of cosmic rays can be accelerated to ultra-high energies (UHE). This low efficiency arises because most particles are scattered back upstream before they acquire enough energy to cross the shock front again. Consequently, the limited efficiency of UHE acceleration imposes an upper limit on the energy of protons, which can reach only a fraction of the total cosmic ray luminosity produced by such shocks. Our findings suggest that the observed fluxes of UHE protons cannot be solely accounted for by diffusive shock acceleration theories related to cosmological shocks. However, we do not rule out other mechanisms that have recently been proposed to explain the origin of UHE cosmic rays. 

Keywords: Cosmic Ray Acceleration, Diffusive Shock Acceleration, Relativistic Shocks.

The author presents an alternative approach to teaching special relativity by utilizing concepts from electromagnetism and their applications in physics, which can help illustrate the symmetry properties involved. The idea behind this method is that students can grasp the essential principles of special relativity without needing to confront complex mathematical constructs like tensors or spinor fields. This article outlines how this approach works through examples related to the Lorentz transformations. It also discusses potential applications of this methodology in other areas of physics. Specifically, it demonstrates how one can use these concepts to understand the origin of gauge symmetries in theoretical physics. 

Special relativity (SR) has been taught in numerous universities since its inception in 1905. Despite many advancements, there is still no widely accepted method for introducing SR to undergraduate students. In exploring this topic, several authors have suggested new teaching strategies for SR. These approaches often emphasize the fundamental principles of SR through simple experiments conducted in various classroom settings. They typically require minimal mathematical background. Some of these innovative ideas were inspired by Feynman's teachings, while others build on modern computer simulations.

We study the electrical excitation of nonlinear waves in a 2D channel with an applied voltage bias between two parallel metal plates separated by a dielectric layer. We show that, depending on the parameters of the system (the thickness of the dielectric layer, the density of electrons), different types of nonlinear waves can be excited. In particular, we find that for certain values of these parameters solitary wave solutions exist which are similar to those found earlier in 1D systems. 
 
 The existence of such solitary waves is confirmed experimentally using time-resolved optical reflectivity measurements performed at room temperature on samples consisting of GaAs/AlGaAs quantum wells grown by molecular beam epitaxy. These experiments reveal the presence of bright solitary waves propagating along the direction perpendicular to the applied electric field. Their propagation velocities agree well with theoretical predictions based on numerical simulations of the underlying equations. 
The results presented here may have important applications in semiconductor devices where it has been shown recently that the generation of solitary waves leads to improved performance characteristics.

rewrite_text: We report on observations using the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) and Spitzer Space Telescope to study the galaxy population in the cluster Abell 2744 at a redshift of z = 0.308. Our findings indicate that most of the red sequence galaxies are situated on the outskirts of the X-ray emission regions, while the blue cloud galaxies are predominantly found within these areas. The spatial distribution of star formation rate density aligns with this observation. These results suggest that ram pressure stripping may be responsible for suppressing star formation activity in many galaxies. Additionally, we have identified several star-forming galaxies that exhibit strong O III λ5007 line emissions in their spectra, as detected by the HST/ACS grism. Their star formation rates range from 100 to 400 solar masses per year, yet they do not appear to be active galactic nuclei (AGNs) based on their optical colors and mid-infrared properties. The significant velocity dispersions of these galaxies imply that they may be undergoing mergers.

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of the distribution of measured orbital parameters and masses for all confirmed extrasolar planets with known mass (N = 73). We find that this sample can be categorized into three distinct groups, which we refer to as super-Earths, mini-Neptunes, and hot Jupiters. The first two categories are characterized by low eccentricities and high mutual inclinations among their orbits, whereas hot Jupiters exhibit large eccentricities and diverse inclinations. Super-Earths and mini-Neptunes cluster together in the radius-mass space. These observations suggest that these three populations represent different formation environments or evolutionary histories. In particular, our findings imply that super-Earths likely formed through core accretion followed by in-situ migration, while mini-Neptunes were likely formed through dynamical instabilities. Finally, we demonstrate how these findings can serve as informative priors in the search for new exoplanets using methods such as those employed by the Kepler mission.

original_text: We present an analysis of star-formation activity associated with low radio luminosity active galactic nuclei (AGNs) using data from the Sloan DigitalSky Survey (SDSS). We find that these objects are typically hosted by massive galaxies, and have high specific star formation rates compared to inactive galaxies at similar redshifts. The majority of our sample is found to be obscured by dusty torii, as indicated by their optical colors and infrared emission. These results suggest that there may exist two populations of AGN: one which hosts significant amounts of star formation, and another where no such activity is observed. This work was supported by NASA grant NNG05GJ40G. Active Galactic Nuclei (AGNs), powered by supermassive black holes accreting matter from surrounding gas clouds, are known to produce copious quantities of radiation across all wavelengths. However, it has been unclear whether this energy output also leads to enhanced levels of star formation within host galaxies. In order to investigate this question we use data from the SloanDigital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et al., 2000) , specifically targeting sources classified as narrow-line Seyfert 1 s (NLS1s) based on their optical spectra. NLS1s represent a subclass of AGNs whose properties differ significantly from those of more typical broad line quasars (BLQs; Osterbrock & Pogge 1985) . They tend to reside in lower mass galaxies than BLQSOs, and exhibit higher Eddington ratios (Boller et al., 1996; Grupe, Thomas, & Leighly 1999; Mathur 2000; Komossa et al., 2006a ,b Gallo 2007 .

rewrite_text: We present the tenth part of our study on the potential existence and stability of ultra-cool (UC) planets around the star Gliese 581, which is located roughly 20 light years from Earth. We conducted multiple simulations for different orbital configurations of three hypothetical planets with masses ranging from 1 to 10 times that of Earth (1 - 10 M⊕). Our calculations indicate that all of these planets are dynamically stable over time scales exceeding 100 million years. The most massive planet has an eccentricity of 0.2, and its periastron distance varies between 0.05 AU and 0.15 AU, depending on the initial conditions used. This planet could behave similarly to a hot Jupiter, as it orbits very close to its host star. Additionally, we discovered another region where two or more hypothetical planets can coexist stably. In this region, one of the planets may be a super-Earth type, with a mass greater than 5 M⊕ but less than 8 M⊕.

original_text: The Galactic center (GC) is one of the most interesting regions in our Galaxy, but it has been difficult to study because of its proximity to the Sun. The GC contains many compact radio sources that are thought to be associated with young pulsars or magnetars. In this thesis we present results on two surveys at 1.4 GHz using the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA). We have observed the central region of the Galaxy for about 100 hours over three epochs between 2005-2007. Our first survey covers an area of 2 degrees centered around Sgr A*. This survey was designed to search for new compact radio sources near the GC as well as to investigate the nature of the diffuse emission surrounding Sgr A*. Our second survey covered a larger area of 4 degrees centered around the GC. This survey was aimed at studying the distribution of molecular gas towards the GC by observing the 12 CO(J=1-0), 13 CO(J=1-0) and C 18 O(J=1-0) lines simultaneously.

rewrite_text: We are conducting simulations of two-dimensional N = (2, 2) super-Yang-Mills theory with gauge group SU(N) on a lattice. We adopted an improved action and performed calculations at various values of the coupling constant g, specifically within the range of 0.1 < g < 1.0. The lattice size for most of our runs was 16 x 32, except for one case where we used a 24 x 48 lattice. To further explore finite-size effects, we also carried out some simulations on 12 x 24 and 20 x 40 lattices. The primary aim of this study is to investigate whether the observed correlation between confinement and deconfinement, noted by other researchers, continues to hold in the continuum limit. Our results suggest that there are no significant discrepancies between the different lattice sizes within the statistical uncertainties. This finding indicates that the system does not exhibit any critical behavior as it approaches the continuum limit.

original_text: The future evolution of the local large scale structure is investigated by using N-body simulations with different cosmological models, including dark energy (DE) and cold dark matter (CDM). The results show that in the Λ-CDM model without DE, the growth rate of large-scale structures decreases rapidly at late times due to the effect of CDM. In contrast, for the same initial conditions but with DE included, the growth rates are almost constant over time. This indicates that the inclusion of DE can significantly affect the formation of large-scale structures on very large scales. We also find that the density profiles of clusters formed in these two cases have significant differences. These results suggest that it may be possible to distinguish between these two scenarios through observations of cluster properties such as their mass functions or X-ray luminosities. Keywords: Cold dark matter; Dark energy; Growth factor; Clustering statistics; Density profile; Cosmology

We present spatially resolved spectroscopic observations of the central regions (r < 1 kpc) of six nearby, massive early-type galaxies located in clusters or groups with Mvir > [UNK]. The data were obtained using the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph on the Gemini North telescope as part of our ongoing program to understand the formation histories of these galaxies. We employed pPXF techniques to analyze the observed spectra by fitting them to models that include a passively evolving stellar population alongside a starburst component at various ages and metallicities. Our findings are summarized as follows: 
- All galaxies show evidence for multiple stellar populations in their line-of-sight stellar distributions.
- In every case, we found that the stellar content consists of two distinct populations: one composed of older stars (ages > 8 Gyr) and the other containing younger stars (ages between 1 and 8 Gyr).
- For four out of the six targets, the younger stellar population exhibits higher metallicity than the older population.

We consider the Standard Model (SM) in 5 dimensions, where one extra dimension is compactified to an orbifold S 1 /Z 2 . The SM fields are assumed to be localized at different fixed points along this extra dimension. We show that such models can naturally explain why there should exist three generations of fermions and gauge bosons with their observed masses and mixings. In addition we find that these models provide new ways for understanding some other issues related to the SM like neutrino mass generation or flavor changing neutral currents. Finally we discuss how our results could be tested experimentally. It has been known since the work by Pati & Salam  1  , that if quarks and leptons were unified into larger multiplets then it would be possible to understand the pattern of quark-lepton masses and mixings within Grand Unified Theories (GUTs). However, despite many attempts over more than 30 years no realistic GUT has yet been constructed which incorporates all the features of the Standard Model (SM).
In recent years another possibility was suggested  2  -  4  : If the SM fields live in higher dimensional space-time, they may have Kaluza-Klein excitations corresponding to additional states with masses of order 1/R, where R denotes the size of the extra dimensions. rewrite_text:
We examine the relic density of dark matter (DM) as it relates to freeze-out and freeze-in mechanisms within the framework of Universal Extra Dimensions (UED). This study takes into account the influence of Majorana mass terms on the neutrino fields. We find that the DM can be classified as either fermionic or bosonic, depending on the parameters in question. Notably, if the UED scale is near 1 TeV, the DM candidate could be a scalar field, which has recently been proposed as an explanation for the PAMELA positron excess observed at high energies. Our findings are presented in the context of LHC physics, particularly in relation to phenomena beyond the Standard Model.

Introduction: The discovery of a Higgs-like particle at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), alongside other compelling evidence, has confirmed the existence of a fundamental scalar particle responsible for electroweak symmetry breaking. However, many questions remain about the nature of this scalar sector, including its spin, whether it is CP-even or CP-odd, its couplings to gauge bosons and fermions, and the potential existence of additional scalar particles in nature. These questions are expected to be addressed as new data becomes available from ongoing experiments such as ATLAS and CMS. 

One of the most intriguing avenues of exploration involves considering the potential limitations of the Standard Model (SM). This includes extending the SM into extra dimensions, which introduces Kaluza-Klein excitations for all matter fields. Previous studies have investigated the phenomenology of these Kaluza-Klein modes in depth. Notably, it has been demonstrated that the lightest Kaluza-Klein excitation of the graviton could serve as a candidate for cold dark matter (CDM). This connection is significant, considering that CDM comprises approximately 23% of the energy content in our universe. Furthermore, the presence of these extra dimensions may influence the production of Kaluza-Klein states through various decay and annihilation processes. Recent work has pointed out additional implications of these findings.

The problem is to estimate the number of independent measurements in an experiment, given that some statistical properties are known for each measurement. The method proposed here uses only information about the mean value and variance of the distribution of results obtained by repeated measurements on one sample (or several samples). It can be used as a tool for planning experiments with minimal error or for estimating the accuracy of existing experimental data. This article presents a new approach to this problem based on the concept of entropy. In particular, it shows how to calculate the mutual information between two random variables using their probability density functions. A numerical example illustrates the application of these methods. 
 
 Keywords: Redundancy estimation, Entropy, Mutual Information, Experiment Planning 
 
 1 Introduction 
 
 When designing an experiment, we need to know what kind of precision our measuring instrument will give us. If we want to measure something precisely enough, then we should make sure that there is no correlation between successive measurements made on the same object  1  . For example, if we have a device which measures the temperature of water at room temperature T = 20 °C , then we would like to obtain values close to 20 ± 0.1°C when repeating the measurement many times  2  .
 
In practice, however, such repeatability cannot always be achieved because of various factors affecting the measurement process  3  . Therefore, before starting any research work, you must determine whether your measuring equipment meets all requirements  4  . 
 
 2 Problem statement 
 
 Let X be a continuous random variable describing the result of a single measurement performed under certain conditions  5  . We assume that the distribution function F(x) of X has been determined experimentally  6  . Then the question arises - how many independent measurements do we need to perform so that the average deviation of the measured values does not exceed a specified threshold ?

rewrite_text: We present the measurement of loop widths in active regions observed by TRACE at 171 Å during the solar minimum period (May - June 2001). Our analysis shows that loops with varying characteristics have different width distributions, which are described by power-law functions. The average widths of these distributions increase with temperature, suggesting an equilibrium between stationary structures within the magnetic fields and their environment. However, we found that there is no correlation between the widths observed in individual loops and those derived from the overall profiles of entire active regions. This indicates that the consistent size of loop widths may be a result of averaging effects rather than inherent properties of coronal structures. Additionally, we found that the widths derived from observations taken at different angles do not significantly depend on the angle of the line of sight with respect to the magnetic field vector.

original_text: The rapid growth in the use and production of digital media has created an urgent need to develop new models that support long-term access, preservation, and reuse of personal archives.  In this article we present a service model for managing personal archives based on three key concepts:  The archive is viewed as a collection of interrelated objects (e.g., documents, photos); each object is associated with one or more services that provide functionality such as storage, editing, sharing, etc.; and these services are organized into a hierarchy reflecting their relationships.   We describe how our approach can be used by individuals to manage their own personal archives, and also discuss its potential application within organizations where large volumes of data must be managed over extended periods of time. The rapid growth in the use of digital media has led to increased interest in developing systems that allow users to preserve and share their personal information across multiple devices and platforms. However, current approaches have focused primarily on providing solutions for storing and accessing content rather than addressing issues related to preserving it over time. This problem becomes particularly acute when dealing with collections containing thousands of items spanning several years. To address this issue, we propose a service-oriented architecture for organizing and maintaining personal archives.

rewrite_text: The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) is an ongoing project designed to study quasars and other astronomical objects. The fourth data release occurred on September 30, 2003. This release features over 100,000 quasar candidates selected based on their color from the SDSS survey. Additionally, it includes about 20,000 quasars that were not included in earlier releases because they did not meet the selection criteria at that time. Besides these newly discovered quasars, the release also encompasses all quasars identified during the first four years of the survey as well as those found since then, which are still pending public release. Over 250,000 quasars are now accessible through this dataset, all of which have been spectroscopically confirmed using data collected with the 2.5-meter telescope located at Apache Point Observatory in New Mexico.

We study the second-order correlation function for an atom interacting with two modes of light, one resonant and another off-resonant to atomic transition frequency. We show that higher order antibunching can be observed when the atom is initially prepared in an excited state or ground state superposition. The effect is more pronounced if the initial state has some population on the excited state. This phenomenon may have applications in quantum information processing. 
 
 Introduction:-In recent years there has been considerable interest in studying nonclassical properties of radiation fields generated by atoms  1  . In particular, it was shown that the photon statistics of such systems are governed by the first-order coherence function g (1) (τ)  2  , which describes bunching behavior at short times and anti-bunching at longer times  3  . It is well known that this property arises due to destructive interference between different pathways leading to emission of photons  4  .
Recently, several authors studied the effects of spontaneous emission on the second-order correlation functions  5  -  8  . They showed that the presence of spontaneous emission leads to sub-Poissonian statistics  6 - 8  . However, these studies were restricted only to the case where the atom interacts with a single mode of field. In addition, they found that the intensity noise of the emitted light depends strongly on the relative phase difference between the driving lasers. Motivated by these experimental results we consider here the problem of calculating the second-order correlation function of an atom interacting simultaneously with two modes of light  12  .

rewrite_text: The Fermi Large Area Telescope (LAT) has transformed our understanding of blazars by offering unparalleled sensitivity to gamma rays above 100 MeV. The LAT is now capable of detecting flaring activity at GeV energies, which were not observable with previous missions like EGRET on CGRO or AGILE/GRID. This new data allows us to delve deeper into the physics of these objects than ever before. In this presentation, I will discuss how we can utilize the capabilities of ground-based observatories, specifically the collaborations between GLAST and EXIST, to monitor blazars across a wider range of phenomena. These investigations aim to provide detailed insights into the processes occurring within relativistic jets across various wavelengths. We will also explore some of the compelling scientific questions that these facilities could help answer. Finally, I will present preliminary results from my research on the impact of intergalactic interactions on blazar spectra.

rewrite_text: The effects of adding small amounts of unsaturated hydrocarbons, specifically allene or propyne, to rich methane/air mixtures were experimentally investigated using counterflow diffusion flames. The flame structure was analyzed through OH* chemiluminescence and laser fluorescence techniques for CH2O and CH3O radicals. Results indicated that both additives had noticeable impacts on the flame characteristics; they caused a slight increase in flame temperature but reduced the mole fraction of OH radicals. This reduction contributed to a lower rate of soot formation, as indicated by the observed soot volume fractions downstream of the flame front. Additionally, it was noted that the presence of these additives enhanced the formation of certain radicals. These findings are discussed in relation to the interactions occurring between hydrocarbon species and oxygen atoms. Finally, the overall effects of the additives on the flame properties were analyzed comprehensively.

The development and application of superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs) in magnetic resonance imaging has been reviewed, with emphasis on the recent advances made by our group at UCLA. The SQUID is an extremely sensitive magnetometer that can be used to detect very small changes in the local magnetic field produced by nuclear spins during NMR experiments. In this review we describe how these devices have been incorporated into several different types of low-field MRI systems including micro-SQUID arrays fabricated using standard semiconductor processing techniques as well as macroscopic SQUID gradiometers developed specifically for use in human brain studies. We also discuss some of the challenges associated with operating such instruments under conditions where the ambient magnetic fields are not completely shielded or controlled. Finally, we present results obtained recently using one of these new technologies to study the effects of anesthesia on functional connectivity within the human brain. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), which was first demonstrated more than 30 years ago, provides detailed information about the structure and function of living tissues through noninvasive measurements of their water content  1  . This technique relies upon the detection of tiny radio-frequency signals emitted by hydrogen nuclei when they precess around the main magnetic field B 0 , which is generated by a large electromagnet  2  .
In conventional clinical scanners, the strength of B 0 ranges between 1 T and 3 T  3  . However, there are many applications where it would be desirable to perform MRI scans at much lower fields  4  . For example, the use of high-field magnets may cause significant heating problems due to dielectric losses in biological tissue  5  . Many researchers have measured the SEDs of these stars using ground-based telescopes, as well as space observatories like ISO, Spitzer Space Telescope, and AKARI. These studies reveal that the flux increases as the effective temperature decreases. In addition to their red hues, they exhibit strong molecular absorption bands at wavelengths longer than 2 microns. We study the phonon-assisted relaxation dynamics of an excited atom trapped by a surface-induced optical lattice (SIL). We show that, for sufficiently deep SILs and low temperatures, the atom can be localized within one well of the SIL with high probability. In this regime we find that the lifetime of the atom is determined by its coupling to bulk acoustic phonons via the deformation potential interaction. The resulting lifetimes are found to agree very well with experimental results obtained on cesium atoms trapped at the interface between two dielectric materials.

These systems provide a unique opportunity to explore quantum many-body phenomena such as superfluidity  4  , supersolids  5  , and topological insulators  6  using cold-atom experiments  7–9  .
 
In these experiments, laser light is focused onto the surface of a transparent material which creates periodic potentials along the direction normal to the surface  10  . rewrite_text: The magnetic properties of carbon nanotubes and fullerenes have been extensively studied, yet their fundamental characteristics remain less understood. In this work, we utilize density functional theory to explore how the presence of an external magnetic field influences the electronic properties of zigzag (n = 3) and armchair (n = 4) nanographenes of varying sizes. Our results indicate that for both n = 3 and n = 4 nanographenes, there are no localized states in the band gap when exposed to magnetic fields up to 10 T along the tube axis. However, as the size increases, the effects diminish significantly under strong fields due to the formation of Landau levels. The magnetic response is found to depend strongly on the chirality of the nanographene. Specifically, while zigzag tubes exhibit diamagnetic behavior at low fields, they transition to paramagnetic behavior above 1 T. In contrast, armchair tubes consistently show paramagnetic behavior, even under very weak fields.

In this talk we will discuss how to define QGI s using noncommutative geometry techniques such as operator algebras and von Neumann algebras.   We will also explain how these objects can be used to study the classification problem of Riemannian manifolds with positive scalar curvature. The Quantum Group of Isometries (QGI), first defined by Alain Connes, plays an important role in both classical and noncommutative geometry. It is the universal object for deforming classical Lie groups into their corresponding quantum groups. This talk will give an introduction to QGI’s and show that they can be studied through operator algebra theory and von Neumann algebras. rewrite_text: The electronic and transport properties of ripples in layer-stacked graphene are studied using tight-binding models informed by first-principles hopping parameters based on density functional theory (DFT). The analysis reveals that the presence of ripples can induce a bandgap at the Dirac point in both armchair and zigzag orientations. Furthermore, it is observed that electron mobility decreases as the amplitude of the ripples increases, due to the rise in scattering centers created by the ripple structures. These findings are significant for understanding the underlying mechanisms behind experimental observations related to the effects of rippling on the electronic performance of graphene devices. Graphene possesses impressive electronic properties due to its unique two-dimensional honeycomb lattice, which contributes to various novel phenomena such as high carrier mobility, Klein tunneling, and valley polarization. Nevertheless, experimental studies have demonstrated that pristine monolayer graphene tends to develop ripples spontaneously. It was first suggested that these ripples could impact the efficiency of graphene-based devices. In this study, we analyze how these ripples affect the electronic and transport properties through a tight-binding approach. We find that the ripple-induced strains can lead to a bandgap formation near the Fermi level in both armchair and zigzag configurations. Additionally, electron mobility is found to decrease as the amplitude of the ripples increases due to the introduction of additional scattering centers.

original_text: We present the results of our CCD photometric study of 42 open clusters in the southern hemisphere, carried out at the 1-meter telescope of the South African Astronomical Observatory (SAAO). The observations were made with an SBIG STL-1001E camera equipped with a Kodak KAF-0400 chip and Johnson V filter during three observing runs between September 1998 and February 1999. We have used DAOPHOT II to perform aperture photometry on all stars detected within each cluster field-of-view. A total number of about 15000 stars was measured for each cluster. In addition we obtained UBVRI photometry for some of these clusters using the same instrumentation as described above.  From this data set we derived the following parameters: reddening E(B-V), distance modulus DM, age t, metallicity  Fe/H  , mass function slope x, core radius rc, central surface brightness µ0, concentration index c, and integrated absolute magnitude M.
