rewrite_text: Graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) are promising candidates for futuristic nanoelectronic devices due to their unique properties and high carrier mobility at room temperature. However, the scalability of GNR field-effect transistors (GNRFETs) has not been fully explored due to the challenges in simulating realistic device structures at the atomic level using techniques such as density functional theory or the tight-binding method. In this study, we conducted large-scale transport simulations on GNRFETs by solving the nonequilibrium Green's function equations within a rigorous mass transport framework. We found that the subthreshold swing decreases rapidly when the channel length is shorter than 10 nm, while it increases slowly for lengths greater than 20 nm. The ON/OFF current ratio shows significant improvements, but it tends to saturate around 100. These results suggest that optimal channel lengths should be between 10 to 20 nm, depending on the required performance characteristics. Our findings provide useful guidelines for designing practical graphene-based transistors.

The effect of the lubricant viscosity on friction in elastohydrodynamic (EHD) regime is investigated by using numerical simulations based on Reynolds equation coupled with elasticity equations for an axisymmetric slider bearing system. The results show that, at low sliding speeds, the traction decreases as the lubricant viscosity increases due to the increase of pressure gradient along the film thickness direction. At high sliding speeds, however, the opposite trend occurs because the viscous shear stress becomes dominant over the pressure gradient term. In mixed lubrication regimes where both hydrodynamic and boundary layers exist simultaneously, it was found that the minimum traction can be reduced significantly when the lubricant viscosity is increased. This reduction is attributed mainly to the decrease of the maximum pressure in the contact region. 
 
 Keywords: Elastohydrodynamics; Slider Bearing; Minimum Film Thickness; Viscosity; Pressure Gradient Term

rewrite_text: The Eisenhower neutrino factory experiments are poised to explore physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) with unprecedented precision and are expected to provide crucial insights into the matter-antimatter asymmetry as well as potential candidates for dark matter. In this presentation, I will give an overview of our ongoing studies on how to investigate various new physics scenarios using these facilities. The results presented here have been obtained by combining data from the T2K experiment and its off-axis near detector, ND280. These analyses include searches for sterile neutrinos, lepton flavor-violating processes such as neutrinoless double beta decay, CP violation effects in the lepton sector, and the production of exotic Higgs bosons that couple to both quarks and leptons. We will also discuss potential improvements in measurements that could be achieved by combining the data from the T2K and NOvA experiments. Finally, we will explore the prospects for probing new physics at future accelerator-based neutrino factories.

original_text: We present new mid-IR photometry and spectroscopy of the HUDF-JD2 galaxy at redshift 2.081, which is one of the most luminous infrared galaxies known to date. The SED shows that it has an extremely red continuum with strong PAH emission features in its rest frame optical spectrum. We find evidence for both star formation activity (from the UV-optical) as well as obscured AGN activity (from X-ray observations). This object may be representative of a population of dusty star-forming galaxies undergoing rapid evolution during this critical epoch when massive black holes are growing rapidly along with their host galaxies. Keywords: Infrared, Redshift, Spectroscopy, Photometry, Black Hole Growth, Star Formation Rate Density, Ultraviolet Background Radiation, Cosmic Evolution, Cosmology, Extragalactic Astronomy, High Energy Astrophysics, Space Science, Nearby Galaxies

rewrite_text: The mechanics of time-independent, non-dissipative nonequilibrium states are examined through the lens of entropy production and the fluctuation theorem. The foundational equations are established for systems undergoing specific transformations, though they can be extended to a continuous spectrum as needed. It is demonstrated that the probability distribution function (PDF) of total entropy production exhibits exponential decay at high levels of entropy production. This finding aligns with recent experimental data regarding PDFs of heat flux between two systems coupled via a molecular junction. Furthermore, this approach allows us to analyze the statistical characteristics of total entropy production and its fluctuations. Finally, we explore the implications of these results for transport phenomena in molecular junctions, noting that our model accurately predicts the current-voltage characteristics observed at varying temperatures.

original_text: We present an analysis of the ages, metallicities and distances to nearby main-sequence F-type dwarf stars (d < 25 pc) using high-resolution spectroscopy obtained with the HARPS spectrograph on board of the European Space Agency s space observatory COROT. We find that there is no correlation between stellar metallicity and distance from the Sun within this sample. This result suggests that the local thin disk has not been significantly affected by radial migration processes over its lifetime. rewrite_text: We present the results of our numerical simulations of magnetorotational collapse (MRC) in primordial stars with initial masses ranging from 100 to 1000 solar masses, formed at redshifts of z = 20 − 30. Our findings indicate that in all models examined, magnetic fields play a crucial role in the formation of black holes. The final mass of the black hole is influenced by the strength of the magnetic fields. For weaker magnetic fields (B < 10^10 G), we found that the formation of typical mass black holes occurs, whereas stronger fields (B > 10^10 G) lead to the creation of supermassive black holes. Additionally, the strength of the magnetic fields impacts the spin parameters of the resulting black holes, varying with the initial mass of their progenitor stars. Keywords: Black Hole, Primordial Star Formation, Magnetohydrodynamics.

We propose an efficient reduced complexity sphere decoding (RSD) algorithm for square quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM). The proposed RSD is based on the new lattice representation, which can be viewed as a generalization of the well-known real-valued lattice representation to complex-valued lattices. We show that our RSD has lower computational complexity than existing algorithms in terms of both number of arithmetic operations and memory requirement. In addition, we demonstrate by simulation results that our RSD achieves better bit error rate performance over conventional RSDs at high signal-to-noise ratio region. Finally, we provide some insights into how to further reduce the computational complexity of our RSD without sacrificing its BER performance. Index Terms - Reduced complexity sphere decoding, Quadrature amplitude modulation, Computational complexity reduction, Bit error rate performance improvement. I. INTRODUCTIO N Quadrature amplitude modulation (Q AM )  1  , also known as phase-shift keying (PSK), is one of the most popular digital modulations used in wireless communications due to its simple implementation  2  . However, it suffers from poor power efficiency when compared with other high-order constellations such as 16-QAM or 64-QAM  3  .
In order to improve the power efficiency while maintaining good bit error rate (BER) performance, many research efforts have been made recently  4  -  8  . Among them, reduced complexity sphere decoding (RCSD)  9  -  11  plays an important role because RCSD provides near optimal BER performance with much less computational complexity than maximum-likelihood detection  12  . For example, the authors in  10  developed a novel RCSD scheme for square QAM using the so-called real-valued lattice representation  13  . It was shown in  14  that this approach requires only about half of the number of arithmetic operations required by the original RCSD  15  . Moreover, the authors in  16  showed that their RCSD outperforms the previous works  17  ,  19  in terms of BER performance under various channel conditions. Although these approaches are very promising, they still suffer from relatively large computational complexity especially at low-to-medium SNR

We analyze the amplitudes of charmless hadronic B decays into a scalar meson and either an axial-vector or tensor meson using the framework of QCD factorization, particularly at large recoil. We find that, despite the branching fractions being affected due to helicity suppression, these processes serve as valuable probes for physics beyond the Standard Model through their CP asymmetries. 

In this paper, we focus on two specific types of charmless hadronic decays: \( B \to SV \) (where \( S = P, A_0 \) and \( V = T_1 \)) and \( B \to SV \) (where \( S = P \) and \( V = A_1 \)). The first type is characterized by one spectator quark in the final state, while the second has no spectator quarks. In both cases, there is only one spectator quark contributing to the helicity state of the decay. Despite this, these decays can still provide significant insights into physics beyond the Standard Model, particularly through comparisons of their CP-violating asymmetries with those of other decay modes. Theoretically, these decays have been investigated using various approaches, including naive factorization, perturbative QCD, soft-collinear effective theory, and QCD factorization. Different theoretical predictions have varied significantly. For example, using naive factorization, one study found \( \text{Br}(B^- \to K^* 0 \pi^-) / \text{Br}(B^- \to K \pi) = 0.27 \pm 0.04 \), while other references suggested a range around \( 0.1 - 0.2 \). This disparity highlights the need for further theoretical work before drawing any firm conclusions about these decays.

original_text: We present Chandra observations of supernova (SN) 2004et, which is one of only two type IIp SNe ever observed in X-rays. The data were obtained on 2005 February 24-26 with the Advanced CCD Imaging Spectrometer (ACIS-S). We detect no significant emission above background at energies below 1 keV or above 8 keV; we therefore restrict our analysis to the range 1-8 keV. In this energy band, we find that the spectrum can be fit by an absorbed blackbody model with kT = 0.7 ± 0.1 keV and N H = 2.5 +1.0 −0.8 × 10 22 cm −2 . These values are consistent with those found for other type IIp SNe. Using these parameters as well as the distance inferred from optical photometry, we calculate the luminosity of SN 2004et during its first 100 days after explosion. This value agrees very well with theoretical predictions based upon models of stellar evolution.

rewrite_text: We explore the phenomenology of crash compactifications with large extra dimensions, focusing on supersymmetric scenarios relevant to the mass ranges accessible by current experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). We examine two classes of models that are motivated by theories involving extra dimensions: heterotic orbifolds and strongly coupled Type IIB orientifold constructions. In both cases, we find that there is an intriguing relationship between the Kaluza-Klein excitations tied to the extra dimensions and the lightest superpartners of the Standard Model. For certain parameter ranges, it may be possible to produce gluinos or squarks through Drell-Yan processes. Alternatively, these states could decay into lighter Standard Model superpartners, which would then cascade down to the lightest stable particle, the neutralino. The resulting collider signals are highly sensitive to the specifics of the underlying model parameters as well as the configuration of the extra dimensions.

We present an algorithm for the decomposition of the local stellar kinematics into vector spherical harmonic functions (VSH). The method is applied to simulated data and real observations, where we recover the underlying VSH coefficients with high accuracy. We show that our approach can be used as a powerful tool in galactic dynamics studies by recovering the gravitational potential of the Milky Way s dark matter halo. In addition, it allows us to study the anisotropy of the stellar orbits on different scales. 
 
 Keywords: Vector spherical harmonics, Galactic dynamics, Stellar kinematics, Gravitational potentials 
 
 1 Introduction 
 
 Spherical Harmonic Analysis has been widely used over many decades to analyse astronomical datasets such as galaxy surveys or star counts. However, this technique cannot easily be extended to deal with non-scalar quantities like velocities or accelerations. This problem was overcome by expanding these quantities onto vector spherical harmonics (VSH) which are defined as tensor products of scalar spherical harmonics  1  . These new basis functions have already found applications in fields ranging from cosmology  2  , solar physics  3  , heliophysics  4  and geophysics  5  .
 
In recent years there has been growing interest in using VSHs to model the observed properties of galaxies  6  -  8  . For example, they were recently employed to decompose the line-of-sight component of the stellar kinematics  9  . Here, we extend their use to also include the tangential components of the stellar motions. As a result, we obtain a complete description of the three-dimensional distribution of the stellar kinematics within each spatial bin. Moreover, since the expansion coefficients depend only on angular coordinates, they can be determined independently at every point along the line-of-sight. Therefore, our method does not require any assumptions about the symmetry of the system under investigation.

rewrite_text: We present an unpublished framework for consistently modeling a given dataset, where we explore all hypotheses that align with a certain set of observations and select those that optimize their posterior probabilities according to Bayes' theorem. We demonstrate how this can be achieved efficiently using dynamic programming techniques. The resulting algorithm operates within a constant factor under specific conditions. Our framework allows us to reason consistently across multiple experiments conducted either sequentially or simultaneously. While this problem has been explored in statistics, it has only recently gained attention within the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI). In AI, it has been addressed as part of PAC (Probably Approximately Correct) learning, where models learn from examples with minimal mistakes. However, these approaches often lack guarantees when multiple hypotheses fit the data equally well. In contrast, our method provides provable guarantees even in the presence of multiple compatible hypotheses. Finally, we illustrate the practicality of our approach through two applications: 1) a method for detecting anomalies in probabilistic databases; and 2) a technique for clustering protein families based on sequence data.

We report on the observation of electron doping in cuprate superconductors by interfacing them to manganite insulators through epitaxial growth and chemical bonding at interfaces.  The interface between La0.7Sr0.3MnO3 (LSMO) and YBa2Cu3O6+x (YBCO), which are both parent compounds for high temperature superconductivity, is found to be highly conducting despite the large lattice mismatch between LSMO and YBCO. This suggests that charge transfer across the interface occurs due to strong electronic hybridization rather than strain relaxation alone. We also find that the hole concentration in the YBCO layer can be controlled by varying the thickness of the LSMO layer grown on top of it. These results demonstrate an alternative approach towards engineering the carrier density in cuprate superconductors using oxide heterostructures. High-temperature superconductivity has been observed only in materials containing copper-oxygen planes known as CuO2 layers  1  . In these systems, holes doped into the CuO2 plane give rise to Cooper pairs leading to superfluidity  2  . However, the maximum critical temperature Tc = 92 K achieved so far in this class of materials is still well below the theoretical limit predicted by Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer theory  3  , raising questions about how to further enhance Tc  4  .
In recent years there have been significant efforts made to explore new routes toward enhancing Tc beyond its current record value  5  . One promising route involves introducing electrons into the CuO2 plane  6  . For example, replacing oxygen atoms in the CuO2 plane with fluorine leads to a reduction in the number of holes in the system  7, 8  . Alternatively, one may introduce electrons directly into the CuO2 plane by growing thin films of transition metal oxides such as SrTiO3  9  or LaAlO3  10  onto the surface of cuprate superconductors. While these approaches show promise, they require precise control over film composition and structure during deposition  11  . An alternative strategy would involve controlling the carrier density in cuprates without changing their crystal structures  12  .

We present the catalog of host galaxies associated with gravitational wave events observed by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO), focusing on compact binary coalescences, black hole-neutron star mergers, and black hole-black hole binaries. This catalog includes data gathered during the early scientific operations of Advanced LIGO, which took place from September 2005 to January 2010. We provide information on galaxy redshifts and references for each host galaxy. This serves as an update to our previous publication. The data can be accessed at http://arxiv.org/abs/1306.5481 and are available both as a text file and via the Zenodo repository.

We propose to use the concept of Maxwell s demon in order to explain how nanodevices can be used for information processing, storage or transmission. We show that this approach is useful because it allows us to understand why some devices are more efficient than others at performing these tasks. In particular we consider two types of nanodevices which have been proposed recently as candidates for quantum computers - spin chains and arrays of coupled cavities. The first type consists of an array of spins arranged on a line with nearest neighbour interactions between them while the second one has a similar structure but instead of spins it contains atoms trapped inside optical cavities. For both cases we calculate their efficiency using the Landauer principle. Finally we discuss possible experimental implementations of our ideas. It describes a hypothetical intelligent being who could control microscopic particles individually so that they would always move into separate containers depending on whether each particle had a higher energy level or lower energy level  2  .
Maxwell s demon is usually described as a thought experiment whose purpose is to demonstrate that entropy cannot decrease spontaneously  3  , i.e., that heat does not flow spontaneously from hot bodies to cold ones  4  . However, there exists another interpretation of Maxwell s demon according to which he imagined a device capable of sorting individual molecules based on their velocities  5  . This interpretation leads naturally to the question about what sort of physical system might behave like such a device  6  .

We investigate the noise properties of parent fox detectors equipped with a signal recycling mirror (SRM). Our findings show that, for an interferometer utilizing an SRM, there is no inherent limit on its sensitivity at high frequencies due to quantum noise fluctuations. The shot-noise limited sensitivity can be enhanced by increasing the circulating power within the cavity formed by the two mirrors. However, this improvement comes at the cost of increasing radiation pressure noise associated with the mirror's movement. Furthermore, we realize that the sensitivity of these detectors significantly depends on whether the input mirror is suspended. Finally, we discuss how these insights can be applied to improve the design of advanced LIGO-like detectors. PACS numbers: 04.80.Nn, 95.35.+d, 98.80.Cq. 

Quantum noise imposes limits on the performance of current gravitational wave detectors, such as Advanced LIGO. These detectors employ Michelson interferometry and utilize Fabry-Perot cavities to enhance their sensitivity. Recent semi-classical analyses have demonstrated that the shot noise limited performance of these detectors cannot be improved beyond a certain point without introducing additional technical noise sources. It has also been proposed that one solution to mitigate this issue is to incorporate an additional mirror, a signal recycling mirror (SRM), into the optical setup of the interferometer. With this approach, it is possible to increase the circulating power within the interferometer while maintaining the same level of shot-noise limited sensitivity achieved prior to incorporating the SRM.

We show that this result agrees with previous results obtained by other methods at one-loop order. The new formula has several advantages over existing expressions:  It does not require any additional approximations beyond those inherent in the use of perturbation theory; it allows us to calculate the effective potential directly without having to solve complicated integral equations first; finally, we are able to obtain the full dependence on temperature and chemical potentials simultaneously. original_text: We present an analysis of the kinematics, metallicity distribution function (MDF), and chemical abundances in the outer halo of our Galaxy using data obtained with the Subaru Telescope for two fields along the leading arm of the Magellanic stream. We find that the MDFs are well represented by three Gaussian components centered at  Fe/H  = -1.7, -0.9, and +0.2 dex, respectively. original_text: The collision between the Milky Way and its nearest neighbor, M31 (Andromeda), is predicted to occur in about 4 billion years.  This will be one of the most spectacular events ever witnessed by humans.   In this talk I will describe how we can use observations made with telescopes on Earth as well as space-based observatories such as Hubble Space Telescope to study these collisions and learn more about dark matter, galaxies, stars, black holes, and other cosmic phenomena that are part of our universe. I will also discuss some of my research projects related to studying galaxy mergers using data obtained at the W.M. Keck Observatory located on Mauna Kea, Hawaii. Finally, I ll share what it was like for me to work there during my summer internship last year. Keywords: Dark Matter, Galaxy merger, Black Hole, Cosmic Evolution, Cosmology, Astrophysics

rewrite_text: The lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) is an alternative approach for solving the Navier-Stokes equations in fluid dynamics, and it has gained popularity due to its advantages over traditional methods such as finite volume and finite element approaches. In this study, we present a lattice Boltzmann model that is capable of handling high Reynolds number flows with high compressibility by employing multiple relaxation times (MRT). The MRT-LBM solves the discrete velocity model (DVM), where each distribution function represents the behavior of macroscopic fluid properties at different velocities. We utilize the D2Q9 DVM to address two-dimensional incompressible flow. To validate our proposed method, we conduct several benchmark tests including lid-driven cavity flow, Couette flow, Poiseuille flow, Taylor vortex flow, and flow through a channel. Our results show a strong agreement between the outcomes produced by the MRT-LBM and those reported in the existing literature.

We present an algorithm to solve numerically the time-dependent equations describing the growth of ionized regions in the early universe, based on the Weighted Essentially Non-Oscillatory (WENO) scheme. The numerical solution is obtained by solving simultaneously two coupled partial differential equations that describe the evolution of the ionization fraction and temperature fields inside each cell of a grid covering the computational domain. We show how this method can be used to study the reionization process driven by UV photons emitted by galaxies. In particular we compare our results with those obtained using the Smooth Particle Hydrodynamics technique. Our tests indicate that both methods are able to reproduce qualitatively similar results but there are some quantitative differences between them which may have important consequences when studying the statistical properties of the IGM during the reionization epoch.

In addition, it allows us to calculate corrections to the classical theory due to higher-order terms in the expansion of the effective action about flat space-time. rewrite_text: In this exploration, we focus on power control for cellular systems using Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA). We analyze the uplink scenario where each user transmits to its base station using an orthogonal spreading sequence, and all users share the same frequency band. Our goal is to minimize the total transmit power while satisfying individual quality-of-service constraints for each user. To tackle this problem, we employ concepts from stochastic geometry, which allows us to model the locations of both mobile users and interferers as point sources. Our findings are summarized as follows: First, we derive closed-form expressions for the outage probability as the number of active users increases indefinitely. These expressions help us assess how many users can reliably transmit simultaneously over the channel. Second, we propose distributed power control schemes that can asymptotically achieve these limits under certain conditions. Third, we develop a power control algorithm that approaches optimality, even when only partial information about the channel conditions or interference is available. Lastly, we present simulation results that illustrate our theoretical insights.

It states that all non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function have real part equal to 1/2. This theorem will be proved using the theory of modular forms. We find that these characteristics are strongly correlated for pairs of halos that are located within less than one virial radius (the region where the density is approximately constant). This correlation remains significant even when we consider only pairs aligned along the line-of-sight between them. These correlations can be attributed to tidal forces exerted by neighboring halos. Specifically, we note that the shapes of the halos are highly sensitive to their proximity to regions of symmetry in the underlying gravitational potential landscape. Finally, we compare our findings with observations of galaxy clusters obtained through weak lensing. Our analysis suggests that the observed cluster morphologies could provide valuable constraints on the nature of primordial fluctuations that influenced structure formation in the early universe.

We report the discovery of a new isolated neutron star (INS) candidate, PSR J1852+0040, in the southern hemisphere using data collected by the Parkes radio telescope and the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA). The pulsar was discovered during a search for millisecond pulsars with high proper motions. It has a spin period P = 1.4 ms and is located at a distance D = 3 kpc. Its dispersion measure DM = 0.6 pc cm-3 implies that it lies behind most of the galactic disk but not far enough to be associated with any known supernova remnant or open cluster. We have also detected its X-ray counterpart in archival Chandra observations. This source appears point-like and shows no evidence of extended emission. Based on these properties we conclude that this object is likely to be a young INS. If confirmed as such, our results will provide important constraints on models of pulsar formation and evolution.

We present an analysis of Lyman alpha emitters (LAEs) selected by narrowband imaging with Subaru/Suprime-Cam and spectroscopic follow-up observations using VLT/VIMOS at z ~ 3.1, which is one of the most active epochs for galaxy formation. We find that LAEs are distributed over a wide range of environments; they exist both in isolated regions as well as in dense clusters. The clustering properties of LAEs depend on their luminosities. In particular, we found that bright LAEs show stronger clustering than faint ones do. This result suggests that bright LAEs may be more evolved systems compared to fainter ones. Furthermore, we investigated the dependence of clustering strength on the equivalent widths of Lyman-alpha emission lines. Our results suggest that strong clustering objects tend to have higher equivalent widths. These findings imply that there exists some evolutionary link between LAEs and LBGs.

We examine a system of two different bosonic species trapped in an optical lattice, where one species is initially represented as a coherent state at each site, while the other exists as a thermal cloud. We find that this configuration supports both stable soliton solutions and asymmetric soliton solutions that remain robust against coherent perturbations for various chemical potentials. The stability characteristics of these solitons can be analyzed by investigating their linearization spectrum around the stationary states. Notably, we observe that the presence of a finite temperature introduces modes related to phonon-like excitations. Ultimately, we illustrate how our findings can be applied to describe experimental setups involving spinor condensates in optical lattices.

Introduction: Recent advancements have enabled the creation of ultracold gases composed of multiple atomic species. These systems open up exciting opportunities to investigate novel phenomena, such as supersolids, quantum turbulence, or spin-dependent interactions. In this study, we focus on a fascinating scenario where two distinct types of atoms interact via s-wave scattering but differ in mass and/or internal characteristics. This situation is particularly relevant in mixtures of hyperfine states or isotopes within the same atomic species. For example, experimental work has shown that mixtures of 87Rb and 41K can be formed after evaporative cooling. Another significant study involves the use of 40K and 6Li, where the lighter species can behave as impurities immersed in a degenerate gas of fermions. Conversely, if the masses are reversed, the heavier species may act as impurities.

original_text: We study the mechanical properties of disordered networks of fibers with different bending rigidities by means of numerical simulations based on molecular dynamics (MD) and Monte Carlo (MC). We find that the elastic moduli are strongly dependent on the bending rigidity, which is related to the persistence length of the fibers. The results show that the shear modulus increases as the bending rigidity decreases while the bulk modulus remains almost unchanged for all values of the bending rigidity studied here. In addition we observe that the distribution functions of forces acting between particles depend significantly on the bending rigidity. For small bending rigidities there exist strong correlations among neighboring particles leading to large fluctuations in the local stress field. These findings suggest that the microscopic structure plays an important role in determining macroscopic material properties such as elasticity. Disordered networks of fibers have been widely used to model various materials ranging from biological tissues to granular media  1-3 . However, it has not yet been fully understood how the microstructure affects their macroscopic behavior. Here we investigate this problem using computer simulation techniques.

rewrite_text: We investigate an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel with multiple inputs, each characterized by different delays and gains. We assume that these channels are independent; specifically, there is only one input whose gain coefficient exceeds a certain threshold. The achievable rate region for this type of channel has been explored by several researchers under various conditions regarding the inputs and their parameters. Notably, it has been recently demonstrated that when all inputs have equal power, the achievable rate region can be obtained using superposition coding at the transmitter and successive decoding at the receiver. However, when the powers of the inputs differ significantly, the optimality of such coding strategies remains unclear. In this work, we show that even if the inputs do not allow for superposition coding or successive decoding, their collective contributions cannot be ignored. Furthermore, we derive upper bounds on the gap between the achievable rates using any coding scheme and the optimal capacity of the channel.

We study the effect of competing short-range attractive and repulsive interactions in a model for collapsed polymers, which are described by an effective one-dimensional potential with two minima separated by a barrier. We show that this system exhibits a rich phase diagram as function of temperature T , interaction strength U0 and asymmetry parameter . The main results are: (i) For small values of we find three different phases: a low-temperature disordered phase, a high-temperature ordered phase and a critical point separating them. (ii) In the limit of large barriers between the wells, i.e., when becomes very large or T decreases to zero, the transition line approaches the value Uc = 2U0/3 predicted by mean-field theory.

A common feature of these systems is their ability to form compact structures due to strong shortrange attractions combined with longer-ranged repulsions. rewrite_text: We examine substantial one-way permutation families in terms of their capacity to withstand specific attacks from computationally limited adversaries, who can only make a restricted number of queries to the permutation. We demonstrate how this perspective relates to the complexity of various attack scenarios. In particular, we assert that if a one-way permutation is resilient against non-adaptive chosen-ciphertext adversaries, it will also resist adaptive ones. This finding suggests that for every one-way permutation, there exists another that can withstand both types of attacks simultaneously. Furthermore, we introduce a novel concept known as distortion between two families of one-way permutations, which we utilize to derive lower bounds on the parameters necessary for maintaining resilience against different classes of attacks. original_text: The question whether time is an illusion or not has been debated for centuries, and the answer remains elusive.  In this article we will examine some of the arguments that have been put forward in favour of the existence of time as well as those against it.   We will then consider how these arguments relate to our understanding of space-time and its relationship with matter.   Finally, we will look at how quantum mechanics may provide us with new insights into the nature of time. The question  Does time exist?  has been asked many times throughout history by philosophers, scientists and ordinary people alike. It seems like such a simple question but there are actually several different ways one can interpret what  time  means when asking about its existence. For example, if you ask yourself  Is time real?  your answer might be yes because you think that time is something that exists independently of any observer (i.e., outside of ourselves). On the other hand, if you were to ask yourself  Do I experience time passing?  your answer would probably be no since you believe that only humans experience time.

rewrite_text: We present the tenth on-site population study of the most prominent supercluster, SCl 126 (Abell 1689), utilizing spectroscopic data obtained from the VLT/VIMOS and Keck/DEIMOS telescopes. Our findings reveal that galaxies are aligned along filaments that vary at different redshifts. The fraction of galaxies exhibiting properties characteristic of mergers increases significantly at lower redshifts, whereas the proportion of late-type galaxies decreases. This trend is particularly pronounced for brighter galaxies compared to fainter ones. In addition to this general observation, we also detect interesting anomalies, such as a surplus of late-type galaxies around the Abell 1689A cluster and a deficiency of bright galaxies between the Abell 1689B and C clusters. Our analysis indicates that the observed patterns cannot be solely attributed to passive evolution of galaxy populations but may also be influenced by processes such as mergers and interactions.

rewrite_text: We are investigating two exoplanets similar to Jupiter that are orbiting stars in wide binary systems: HD 196885AB (with a semi-major axis of 1.8 AU) and HD 208598AB (with a semi-major axis of 3.6 AU). The planet orbiting HD 196885A is an inflated gas giant with a mass of approximately 0.88 Jupiter masses and an orbital period of 4.3 days, positioned at a remarkably close distance of only 0.04 AU from its star. We found no evidence of additional companions to either host star down to masses as low as 5 Jupiter masses within separations of 10 AU. Both planets exhibit orbital eccentricities consistent with being close to zero. These findings suggest that "hot Jupiters" can survive close encounters with other stars during their formation or evolution. Hot Jupiters are gas giants situated very close to their parent stars, and while they are among the most extreme types of planets found in our solar system, they appear to be common around nearby Sun-like stars. Studies, such as those by Santos, indicate that about 20% of Sun-like stars may host such planets. However, these planets are thought to migrate inward from several AU, likely influenced by interactions with the protoplanetary disk and/or perturbations from other bodies. This raises questions about how these planets avoid being ejected into interstellar space after experiencing strong dynamical interactions with others while still remaining in their current close orbits. In this letter, we report on the investigation of the two Jupiter-like planets using precise radial velocity measurements taken over more than eight years with the High Accuracy Radial Velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS), located at the 3.6-meter telescope of the European Southern Observatory at La Silla Observatory in Chile. One of the planets has a remarkably close orbit, with a semi-major axis of just 0.04 AU, making it one of the closest known exoplanets to its host star.

original_text: We study the glass transition of an ensemble of adhesive hard spheres with repulsive interactions decaying as 1/r6, where r is distance between particles. We find that this system exhibits two distinct relaxation processes at low temperatures: one fast process associated with local rearrangements within clusters of strongly bonded particles; another slower process related to collective motion of these clusters. The latter process can be described by mode-coupling theory (MCT) for colloidal suspensions. However, we show that MCT fails quantitatively when applied directly to our data because it does not take into account the presence of strong bonds which lead to additional slow modes. By introducing a simple modification to MCT, we are able to obtain excellent agreement with experimental results over several decades in time and frequency. This modified version of MCT also predicts correctly the temperature dependence of the structural relaxation time near Tg. We study the ground state properties of an interacting electron gas confined to a onedimensional (1D) quantum dot with parabolic confinement potential and repulsive Coulomb interaction between electrons. We show that, for sufficiently strong confining potential, the system undergoes a phase transition into a deformed Wigner crystal at low temperatures. The article addresses the issue of dark matter's existence in our galaxy, specifically regarding its impact on phenomena beyond its gravitational effects, such as its influence on astrophysical tourism (stars). The author posits that these hypothetical dark matter particles can be conceptualized as celestial mechanics entities with unique properties. Notably, the discussion highlights how such entities could potentially account for some of the observations recently reported by the DAMA experiment at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory. It is important to note that this explanation does not conflict with any established experimental data. However, there are significant challenges associated with the proposed theory that will be further explored. This research was funded by the Russian Science Foundation under grant No. 14-50-00040. I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK: Dark matter (DM) remains one of the most significant mysteries in modern physics. Its presence has only been inferred indirectly through its effects on gravitational phenomena such as galactic formations, galaxy clusters, and others, while direct detection experiments have thus far been unsuccessful. Numerous models of cold dark matter (CDM) exist, yet only a few have undergone experimental verification. One theory suggests that dark matter consists of elementary particles. These particles could potentially interact weakly or electromagnetically with ordinary matter, allowing them to escape detection even if they are present in large quantities. Conversely, if they interact strongly with normal matter, they could be detectable. Various experiments searching for dark matter interactions have been conducted. Recently, observations by the DAMA collaboration have garnered considerable attention due to reported annual modulation effects thought to be caused by Earth’s orbit around the Sun, leading to an increased rate of nuclear recoils detected from June through October compared to December through February. Such behavior cannot be explained within the standard model of particle physics, prompting various authors to propose alternative explanations.

original_text: We study evolutionary games played by agents that are randomly distributed over the nodes of an unstructured network, and interact only with their immediate neighbors in this network. We show how to compute Nash equilibria for such games using local computations at each node. Our approach is based on computing best responses locally at every agent s neighborhood, which we then use as input to a global algorithm that computes all Nash equilibria. The main technical challenge lies in showing that our local algorithms terminate after polynomially many rounds (in terms of the number of players), even though they may be executed concurrently across different parts of the network. This result holds under mild assumptions about the underlying interaction graph. In particular, it applies to any undirected connected graph where there exists some constant upper bound on the degree of its vertices. As a consequence, we obtain polynomial-time algorithms for finding Nash equilibria in several classes of games including congestion games, matching pennies games, and coordination games.

The problem of evaluating propositional Jarvis formulas in conjunctive normal form (CNF) has been studied extensively, leading to the development of many efficient algorithms. However, most current methods struggle with large CNFs containing millions or even billions of clauses due to their high computational complexity. In this study, we introduce two innovative approaches that enhance the efficiency of CNF formula evaluation: one leverages parallelization through GPUs, and the other utilizes data compression by representing each clause as a dynamic vector instead of a set of literals. We have integrated these techniques into our new package, CLEVER-CNF, which demonstrates improved performance over existing state-of-the-art solvers, such as SATzilla and Lingeling, when tested against several benchmark sets commonly used in the SAT community.

We present an explicit formula for solutions to some classes of nonlinear fractional diffusion equations with variable coefficients and nonlocal initial conditions, which are expressed by means of the generalized Mittag-Leffler function Eα(−z) and the H-function. The results obtained can be used as a basis for numerical methods for solving such problems. We also discuss applications of our approach to the description of anomalous transport processes in complex systems. Introduction.
The theory of fractional calculus has been developed rapidly during recent years due to its numerous applications in various fields of science and engineering (see e.g.,  1  -  4  ). In particular, it is widely applied to describe anomalous transport phenomena observed in many physical models  5  . For example, this approach was successfully employed to model subdiffusion  6  , superdiffusion  7  , and Lévy flights  8  .
In general, fractional differential equations have no exact analytical solution  9  . Therefore, there exists great interest in developing efficient numerical algorithms for their approximate treatment  10  . However, even if we use powerful computers, these approaches may not always provide sufficiently accurate results  11  . This problem becomes especially important when one deals with strongly nonlinear problems  12  or considers very large time intervals  13  . To overcome difficulties associated with the lack of exact solutions, several authors proposed different techniques based on special functions  14  -  16  . Among them, the most popular ones include the Mittag-Leffler  17  and Wright  18  functions, Fox s H-functions  19  , and others  20  -  22  .

rewrite_text: The composition of the cosmic rays impacting Earth is analyzed by examining their spectrum and mass. The most accurate measurements come from detectors based on air shower observations, which focus on cosmic ray interactions between the atmosphere and ground. In this study, we focus on measuring shower depth profiles as well as various composition-related observables derived from them. These observables include the number of muons per meter squared (N_m), the ratio of muons to electrons at 1000 meters above sea level (f_1000), and the logarithmic mass (ln(A)). We compare these measurements for different zenith angles and energy levels. For protons, as the zenith angle increases, f_1000 rises while N_m decreases. This trend can be explained by the fact that heavier primary particles interact higher in the atmosphere, leading to the production of more muons relative to electrons when compared to lighter primaries. At lower energies, there is a notable excess of events characterized by low values of N_m and high values of f_1000, suggesting a contribution from heavier primary particles such as helium or nitrogen.

rewrite_text: The spin transistor is a crucial device for the future of spintronics and has garnered significant interest; however, practical implementation has faced challenges due to a lack of materials that exhibit strong spin-orbit coupling (SOC). In this context, we propose utilizing graphene as a suitable candidate by leveraging its unique electronic properties. We outline how this can lead to a novel type of spin transistor that operates at room temperature without the need for external magnetic fields or complex gate voltages. The proposed device consists of two ferromagnetic contacts connected through a graphene channel. By applying a voltage between these contacts, we can manipulate the SOC in the graphene, influencing the transmission of spin current through it. This results in spin behavior reminiscent of traditional transistors. Furthermore, our analysis indicates that this device achieves high on/off ratios even under realistic operating conditions. We also discuss potential experimental implementations of this device. Graphene stands out as a promising material for spintronic applications due to its remarkable properties. It enables the development of devices that rely on pure spin currents, which can avoid limitations posed by Joule heating. In particular, the spin Hall effect allows for effective generation and manipulation of spin currents using solely electric fields. Despite numerous theoretical proposals, there have been limited experimental demonstrations of graphene-based spintronic devices. One challenge may involve finding suitable materials with sufficiently strong spin-orbit coupling. Additionally, many experiments have been conducted at low temperatures, where fluctuations can adversely affect the performance of spintronic devices.

original_text: We present an analysis of galaxy clusters selected by their red-sequence galaxies (Gladders & Yee 2005) from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 4 (DR4). We use two different methods to select cluster candidates, and then apply photometric redshift cuts on these samples to obtain final catalogues with high purity. The first method is based on the matched filter technique developed for X-ray surveys (Postman et al 1996) , while the second one uses a friends-of-friends algorithm applied directly to the galaxy distribution. In order to test our selection algorithms we compare them against mock galaxy clusters extracted from N-body simulations. Our main results are as follows:  1. Using the matched filter technique we find that the number density of galaxy clusters at z < 0.5 is n(z<0.5) = 3.6 +/- 0.2 x 10-3 h3 Mpc-3 . This value agrees well with previous determinations using other techniques.  2. By applying the same matched filter technique to simulated galaxy clusters we show how this method can be used to estimate the mass function of galaxy clusters up to z ~1.0.

rewrite_text: The Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) is an accelerator complex situated at Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York. The primary goal of this facility is to create and investigate nuclear matter under extreme conditions by colliding heavy ions at high energies and studying the resulting properties. Additionally, RHIC offers opportunities for a variety of experiments involving different particles such as protons or photons. This research will enhance our understanding of spin-dependent functions such as g_1 (x), g1p (x), longitudinal double-spin asymmetries A_L, transverse single-spin asymmetry A_T, and transversity distributions h_1 / T (x). These experiments are conducted by the Solenoidal Tracker at RHIC (STAR), which features two large Time Projection Chambers (TPCs) filled with a gas mixture of 90% helium-4 and 10% isobutane-1.

original_text: We present new observations of the solar atmosphere obtained with the Solar Ultraviolet Imager (SUVI) onboard the Coriolis satellite, which show dynamic fibrils in both H-alpha and CIV lines. The SUVI data are compared to simultaneous ground-based observations made at Big Bear Observatory using the 1-meter telescope equipped with an H-Alpha filter and a Fabry-Perot interferometer tuned to the CIV line. We find that the observed structures have similar properties as those seen previously by other authors but we also see some differences between them. In particular, our results suggest that the fibril structure is more complex than it was thought before. This complexity may be related to the fact that these structures are formed under different physical conditions. Our analysis shows that the observed features can be explained by assuming that they represent plasma flows along magnetic field lines. These flows could play important role in heating up the upper layers of the solar atmosphere.

rewrite_text: We present data on the thermal inertia of Near-Earth Asteroids (NEAs) as measured by the Spitzer Space Telescope (SST). Based on this data, we derive an estimate of the effective thermal inertia, I = 100 ± 50 J m^-2 s^-1/2 K^-1, which aligns well with measurements obtained by other researchers using various techniques. Our findings are consistent with laboratory experiments conducted at high temperatures, which show that thermal conductivity decreases as temperature increases. By analyzing the thermal inertias, we investigate the Yarkovsky effect acting on NEAs. Our calculations suggest that this effect may play a significant role in driving certain NEAs into orbits that cross the Earth's path, with important implications for the capability of space missions to deflect potential asteroid threats. Near-Earth Asteroids pose a risk to civilization due to their potential to impact Earth within a million years. To mitigate this risk, it is essential to develop strategies capable of deflecting or redirecting NEAs before they’re on a collision course with Earth. One potential method involves applying a torque to change an NEA's trajectory through the Yarkovsky–O'Keefe–Radzievskii–Paddack (YORP) effect. However, the success of this approach hinges on our ability to accurately predict the dynamics of the YORP effect.

We present sub-arcsecond resolution interferometric observations in the millimeter continuum, 12CO(J=1-0), 13CO(J=1-0) and C18O(J=1-0). We find that the molecular gas is distributed into two components with different kinematics. The main component has an extent of 1 kpc (0.5 arcsec at z = 2.3) and shows blueshifted emission on its eastern side and redshifted emission on its western side. This suggests that this component may be associated to outflowing material. A second component is detected only in 12CO(J=1-1) and it is located 0.2 arcsec eastward of the first one. It also shows blueshifted velocities but they are smaller than those observed for the main component. Both components show similar line widths suggesting that both have comparable dynamical masses. These results suggest that the bulk of the molecular gas is concentrated in these two components which could represent the progenitors of massive elliptical galaxies seen today. 
 
 Keywords: Ultraluminous Infrared Galaxies

This approach is based on an extension of the Partners Hauser-Feshbach framework that considers the effects of nuclear interactions within the context of statistical densities and transmission coefficients calculated using the Hartree-Fock-Bogoliubov (HFB) theory. rewrite_text: We present simultaneous observations from XMM-Newton and the Spitzer Space Telescope (SST) of the Galactic black hole candidate GRS 1915+105 during an active phase characterized by strong variability across all wavelengths. Our analysis reveals the presence of two distinct tracks in the source's luminosity, observed across near-infrared (NIR), optical/UV, and soft/hard X-ray bands. The NIR-optical track lags behind the soft X-ray track by approximately 20 days, while the UV and X-ray tracks show no lag in relation to the X-ray data. This suggests that different physical factors may be responsible for these two tracks. Additionally, we observed evidence of hysteresis in both tracks, providing valuable insights into the physics of accretion flows around supermassive black holes.

The present work is devoted to the study of some new effects in the process of combustion of liquid fuels, which are observed under the action of laser radiation with different wavelengths and power densities on the fuel surface. The results obtained show that the use of pulsed lasers can significantly increase the efficiency of burning liquid fuels by increasing their evaporation rate due to the formation of plasma at the fuel surface. In addition, it was found that the presence of an additional source of energy (laser) leads to changes in the structure of the flame front, as evidenced by the appearance of bright spots near its edge. It has been shown experimentally that these spots correspond to local increases in temperature up to several thousand degrees Celsius. This phenomenon may be used for creating highly efficient heat sources based on the combustion of liquid fuels.

The Variable Star One-Shot project is a community-driven package designed for the analysis of astronomical data. It was created by members of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in collaboration with researchers from various institutions. The project's objective is to offer a flexible toolset for analyzing diverse types of astronomical datasets, including photometric time series and spectroscopic data, utilizing advanced techniques such as image subtraction, cross-correlation, variable star detection, and spectral line analysis. The project is licensed under the GNU General Public License v3.0 and is accessible on GitHub at: https://github.com/VariableStar/one-shot-astro.

One-Shot Astro includes several tools that aid in the swift analysis of large datasets. These tools comprise One-Shot DataCleaner, which conducts quality control on raw data; One-Shot Mosaic, which creates mosaics from multiple dithered exposures; One-Shot Astrometry, which calculates astrometric positions for individual objects or entire fields; One-Shot Photometry, which measures flux and/or magnitudes across a field of view; One-Shot Pipeline, which automates the processing of these tasks into a single workflow; and One-Shot MapMaker, which allows users to generate custom maps based on their own catalogs. Additionally, the One-Shot Astro repository contains many supplementary modules that enable users to perform specialized analyses, such as One-Shot Query, which provides access to various astrophysical databases through SQL queries, and One-Shot FastPhot, which employs machine learning techniques to analyze stellar light curves.

original_text: We present the results of an analysis aimed at improving the stellar parameters for the host star of planet TrES-2, as well as its planetary system properties. We use high-precision photometry obtained with the MOST satellite to derive new values for the orbital period (P = 3.819 days), transit epoch (T0 = 2454000 MJD) and radius ratio (Rp/Rs = 0.11). These are combined with existing radial velocity data in order to refine the mass estimates for both components of this double-lined spectroscopic binary. Our best-fit model yields masses of 1.06 ± 0.04M⊙ and 0.84 ± 0.03M⊙ for the primary and secondary stars respectively, along with radii of 1.16 ± 0.02R⊙ and 0.91 ± 0.01R⊙ . This leads us to revise upward our previous estimate of the age of the system by about 50%, placing it firmly within the range expected for planets formed via core accretion theory.

We propose a novel approach to deriving the spacetime metric from observational data, such as that gathered from the Planck satellite and other experiments. This method hinges on the principle that, in general relativity (GR), the Einstein field equations are equivalent to the geodesic equations for massive particles. We utilize this equivalence to extract the metric tensor directly from the observed trajectories of photons at various redshifts. This enables us to reconstruct the four-dimensional geometry of spacetime without assuming any specific model or parametrization. To demonstrate our technique, we apply it to simulated data generated using the publicly available CAMB software. Our results show that the recovered metric closely matches the original one used to create the mock data. Lastly, we discuss potential applications of our method to real astrophysical datasets. 

Cosmology has entered a transformative era due to significant advances in data recovery, allowing astronomers to uncover many crucial aspects of the universe's evolution. Key datasets include the temperature anisotropy power spectrum obtained from the WMAP, Planck, and SPT satellites; baryon acoustic oscillations identified through various observations; and the luminosity distance-redshift relation derived from type Ia supernovae. These rich datasets provide unprecedented opportunities for exploring fundamental physics beyond the Standard Model. Furthermore, modern cosmological experiments offer insights into the universe's expansion history over time. For instance, measuring the cosmic microwave background fluctuations sheds light on the universe's early stages when its density was dominated by radiation and baryonic matter. Conversely, studying the dynamics of cosmological expansion reveals behaviors at later stages when dark energy begins to play a significant role.

original_text: We study the efficiency of scrip systems in which users can buy goods with their own currency or by exchanging it for other people s currency (scrip). We show that when there are many buyers and sellers who use such a system to trade items, then the system is efficient if most people have an incentive to be fair traders. However, we also find that this may not always happen because some users may try to hoard money while others may act altruistically. In particular, we consider two types of user behavior: selfishness and altruism. Selfish users maximize their utility at each transaction; they will accept only offers that give them more than what they pay out. Altruistic users do not care about maximizing their individual utilities but rather want to make sure that everyone gets paid as much as possible. We analyze these behaviors using game-theoretic models and derive conditions under which both selfish and altruistic users behave fairly.

rewrite_text: We present findings on the distribution and luminosity function (LF) of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in cluster environments, based on Chandra observations of 16 identified clusters at redshifts ranging from 0.1 to 1.0. Our results indicate that the fraction of X-ray luminous AGNs increases with redshift, but decreases with cluster mass. The LF of AGNs is well described by a power law with an exponential cutoff above Lx = 10^43 erg s^-1 Hz^-1. The derived parameters are consistent with those of previously studied AGNs, within the given uncertainties. These findings suggest that AGNs play significant roles in heating intracluster gas and may also influence star formation processes within galaxies. rewrite_text: In this study, we introduce an efficient direct-voting mechanism for providing Data Fusion Assurance (DFA) in wireless sensor networks (WSNs). The proposed DFA approach is built on the principle that each node can cast its vote in coordination with other nodes and then reach a global decision through collective voting. To minimize the communication overheads associated with direct voting, our scheme incorporates two innovative strategies: 1) only one node is permitted to cast its vote at any given time; 2) all nodes are allowed to transmit their votes simultaneously during distinct time slots. We provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis to demonstrate how energy consumption will be significantly reduced compared to existing methods. Finally, our simulation results illustrate that our approach outperforms current state-of-the-art techniques in terms of both efficiency and power usage. Keywords: Data Fusion Assurance, Wireless Sensor Networks, Energy-Efficient Direct Voting. This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant No. 61371040.

original_text: The Large Area Telescope (LAT) on board Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope is scheduled to be launched in June 2008 and will perform high energy gamma ray astronomy for at least 3 years. The LAT consists of 4 identical towers, each with tracker and calorimeter subsystems. Each tower has an anti-coincidence detector that covers its entire surface area. In addition there are two instruments dedicated to detecting bursts of gamma rays -the GBM and the LAT itself. The GBM is composed of 12 sodium iodide scintillation crystals read out by photomultiplier tubes. It is designed to detect GRBs over a wide range of energies between 8 keV and 1 MeV. This work presents results obtained during ground calibration tests performed on all four GBM detectors prior to launch. We present data taken using radioactive sources as well as cosmic muons. These data were used to determine the response functions of the detectors which can then be used to reconstruct the incident photon fluxes.

rewrite_text: The missing satellites problem (MSP) is a significant challenge in the field of computational science, with applications that range from satellite navigation to the removal of obstructive elements. The MSP addresses scenarios where certain satellites remain unobserved or undetected due to gravitational influences from celestial bodies like planets or asteroids. In this study, we present an algorithm that accurately resolves the MSP in any dimension \( d \geq 2 \), utilizing a time complexity of \( O(n^2 + m) \), where \( n = |S| \) represents the total number of satellites and \( m = |E| \) denotes the number of edges in the graph. Our approach combines innovative techniques from fast polynomial multiplication, advanced data structures, and efficient graph traversal methodologies. We also demonstrate how our algorithm can be applied to important problems, such as calculating the minimum distance between two sets of points in \( \mathbb{R}^d \). Finally, we validate the effectiveness of our method through experiments conducted on real-world datasets.

original_text: We present the results of our investigation into how stellar evolution models are affected by individual element abundances in stars, focusing on the sensitivity to changes in helium abundance (Y). We use two different sets of evolutionary tracks with varying Y values for masses between 0.8 M⊙ and 8 M⊙ at solar metallicity. The first set is based on the Padova code while the second one uses the Geneva code. For each track we calculate synthetic spectra using the SPECTRUM code. These synthetic spectra are then used as input to determine the best-fit parameters of observed high-resolution optical spectra of Galactic open clusters. Our analysis shows that both codes produce similar results when fitting these cluster data. However, there are significant differences in the derived ages depending on which code was used. This discrepancy can be explained by the fact that the Padova tracks have been calculated without convective overshooting whereas the Geneva tracks include this effect.

Moreover, we observe an anisotropic broadening of the Stokes linewidths when circularly polarized light is used, suggesting a splitting of the emission into two components. original_text: We study the dynamics of an analog recurrent neural network (RNN) driven by temporally fluctuating white noise in its synapses, and show that it can be described by the Thouless-AndersonPalmer (TAP) equations. The observed fluxes align with those expected for a Wolf-Rayet star, with an effective temperature of approximately 50 kK and a surface gravity of log g ~ 5.5 - 6.0. From our VISIR data, we estimate the total number of Wolf-Rayet stars in NGC 300 to be N_WR = 1.1 × 10^7 ± 0.3 × 10^7 per solar mass. The main motivation for studying QFTs on such spaces comes from string theories which are formulated as open strings attached to D-branes whose positions can be described by noncommuting matrices. We will show that it is possible to define a covariant derivative operator acting on fields living on the GroenewoldMoyal plane. rewrite_text: We propose models for non-abelian gauge networks, which are founded on the concept that the dynamics are influenced by multiple entangled particles moving at varying velocities and orientations. We demonstrate how to construct such gauge-dependent models using Feynman diagrams. Specifically, we examine two types of diagrams: (i) loop-like diagrams associated with the exchange of gluons between pairs of particles, and (ii) interconnected diagrams that involve interactions among three or more particles. These diagrams can be understood as representing junctions where several particles converge at a single point. We explore some characteristics of these models and compare them with particle interactions derived from the Abelian-Higgs framework. Finally, we numerically investigate the evolution of an initial configuration consisting of a loop structure transitioning into a complex entanglement of particles using Monte Carlo simulations. This research was supported by the DFG under the SFB-TR9 program in Gravitational Physics.

original_text: We report on the discovery and spectroscopic confirmation of an extremely bright, strongly lensed galaxy at z = 3.1 (AB mag=18.6) found by searching for high-z galaxies behind Abell 1689 using the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS). The lensing cluster is known to have a large number of arcs produced by multiple images of background sources. We find that this object has six distinct components with similar colors and magnitudes which are aligned along a line-of-sight distance of ~2 arcmin. This system appears to be a multiply-imaged version of a single source whose intrinsic luminosity is comparable to those of the most luminous quasars currently known. The total flux density of all 6 components combined corresponds to a rest frame UV continuum luminosity of 1.5 x 10^26 W Hz^-1 or about 100 times brighter than any other known gravitationally-lensed galaxy.

We find that LPT-based initial conditions can produce spurious large-scale power at late times, a problem that is not mitigated by the volume of data used to generate these initial conditions. This issue can be reduced by applying a low-pass filter to the evolved density field before creating initial conditions with second-order LPT. However, this approach does not entirely eliminate all undesirable effects related to the use of LPT-generated initial conditions. Additionally, we discuss how the choice of time step used to evolve the initial conditions impacts their accuracy. Finally, we demonstrate that it is feasible to construct viable initial conditions for large-volume cosmological simulations without resorting to costly high-resolution hydrodynamic simulations. The generation of realistic initial conditions is crucial for cosmological N-body simulations.

We present an improved version of our previous calculation for the nuclear matter properties and the single-particle energies in spherical nuclei based on the covariant density functional theory with the tensor terms included. The new results are obtained by using the recently developed method to calculate the exchange-correlation contributions to the energy density functionals, which is free from any adjustable parameters. We find that the calculated binding energies per particle agree well with those observed experimentally except for some light nuclei such as 4He and 8Be. In particular, we obtain a reasonable value for the spin-orbit splitting between the p1/2 and p3/2 states in 16O nucleus. This indicates that the tensor force plays an important role in determining the shell structure around the Fermi surface. It should be noted here that this result has been achieved without introducing any additional parameter into the original formalisms proposed previously. 
 
 Keywords: Tensor force, Energy density functional

The work function is a crucial parameter in semiconductor devices, influencing their electrical properties, carrier transport behavior, and Schottky barrier height. Accurate measurement of the work function is essential for both fundamental understanding and practical applications. In this article, we review several advances in measuring the work functions of various materials using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) with synchrotron radiation, as well as other techniques such as scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy (STM/STS), inverse photoemission spectroscopy (IPES), and Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM). We also discuss how to determine the absolute values of work functions for different semiconductors based on UPS findings. Finally, we share our perspective on future research directions in this field.

### Experimental Methods: Ultraviolet Photoelectron Spectroscopy (UPS)

Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy has been instrumental in exploring the surface properties of various materials, including those with low electron affinities. The technique involves measuring the kinetic energy of electrons ejected from a sample when it is illuminated by monochromatic light at photon energy hν. By analyzing the kinetic energy of photoelectrons emitted from the Fermi level (EF), the work function (Φ) can be determined using a specific equation, where e is the elementary charge and m* is the effective mass of the photoelectrons. For instance, Figure 1 illustrates this process.

We present new observations of the outflows driven by massive protostars using the Submillimeter Array (SMA) at 1.3 mm, which are compared with previous results obtained with single-dish telescopes. We find that the SMA data reveal more compact structures than those seen previously; this is likely due to missing flux and/or resolution effects. The total mass loss rates inferred for these sources range between 10^-4 and 10^-3 Msun/yr, while their momentum flux ranges between 10^-2 and 10^1 Lsun/c/s. These values are similar to those found for low-mass Class 0 objects but higher than expected if scaled up according to the luminosity-to-mass ratio. This suggests that there may be additional mechanisms driving the outflows besides radiation pressure on dust grains. 
 
 In addition we report the detection of infalling gas toward two of our targets. For G35.20-1.74NW, we detect an inward motion of ~0.5 km/s over a distance of ~1000 AU. For IRAS 18162-2048, we see evidence for both inward motions as well as outward motions along different lines-of-sight.

rewrite_text: We investigate the (0, 2) gauged sigma model in four dimensions with gauge group SU(N). We consider two different supermanifolds as target spaces for this model: one is the supersphere and the other is the supercoset \( SL(3, \mathbb{R}) / SO(3) \). This realization has been previously studied by Witten. In both scenarios, we find that there are no tachyons or divergences at tree level. However, when we lower the sigma model parameters to a one-loop level, we discover that they do not vanish, even when we take into account all possible counterterms allowed by symmetries. This suggests that these models suffer from perturbative non-renormalizability. On the positive side, it turns out that the models exhibit a global symmetry that can be utilized to construct a relevant set of conserved currents. These findings motivate us to propose Ward identities that relate correlation functions involving operators of different spins.

original_text: The dynamics-based approach is an emerging method for studying terrestrial exoplanets, which are planets with masses similar to that of Earth orbiting other stars in the solar system.  The main goal of this research is to study how these planets form and evolve over time.   This approach uses numerical simulations to model the formation and evolution of planetary systems by solving equations describing the orbital motion of bodies interacting gravitationally.   In addition, it also takes into account physical processes such as tidal dissipation, collisions between planetesimals (small rocky objects), and atmospheric escape.    By using this approach we can better understand how our own planet formed billions of years ago and what conditions were necessary for life on Earth to develop. Keywords: Planetary Science; Astrobiology; Tidal Dissipation; Collisions Between Planetesimals; Atmospheric Escape. rewrite_text: We introduce a novel implementation of complementarity and provider nonlocality through a photonic version of the Einstein-Bohr photon box thought experiment. Our work establishes that this framework exhibits both classical correlations, which align with hidden variable theories, and quantum correlations that cannot be explained by such models. Our findings demonstrate the capability of this setup to simultaneously manifest all three types of Bell inequalities. The original Einstein-Bohr photon box, initially referred to as the EPRB (Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen-Bohm) experiment, has been instrumental in examining various aspects of quantum mechanics, including entanglement, Bell's theorem, and teleportation principles. In its classic form, it consists of a source emitting pairs of photons at random intervals; one photon passes through a beam splitter while the other moves towards a detector. If we analyze whether each photon reaches one of the output ports of the beam splitter, we can confirm that exactly one photon arrives at each detector. This measurement can be performed locally on each photon without disturbing the state of the other. However, if we examine both photons jointly, they may arrive simultaneously at the same detector. For these experiments to demonstrate genuine quantum effects, the detectors must exhibit high efficiency to ensure that the likelihood of detecting more than one photon per pair is minimal. Previous implementations of Einstein-Bohr boxes have relied on inefficient single-photon detectors or avalanche photodiodes, which prevent us from distinguishing between different numbers of photons and hinder the observation of authentic quantum correlations.

We have demonstrated the first polymer optical fiber (POF) demultiplexer using a single-mode POF and multimode interference couplers (MMI). The device consists of three MMI s with different lengths, which are connected in series to form a Mach-Zehnder interferometer structure. A broadband light source is coupled into one end of the input POF through a lens system consisting of two lenses. Light emerging at each output port was detected by a photodiode array after passing through another lens system. We obtained a maximum extinction ratio of 20 dB between adjacent channels over a wavelength range of 1530-1570 nm for a channel spacing of 0.8 nm. This result shows that our proposed scheme can be used as a low-cost demultiplexing element for high-density WDM systems based on POFs. 
 
 Keywords: Polymer optical fibers, Multimode interference coupler, Channel demultiplexer
