We analyze the dynamics of a particle system on a lattice with an asymmetric configuration involving two types of particles arranged in a ring. In this setup, particles can move to their immediate left or right neighbors and experience repulsive interactions within a defined range. We demonstrate that for any initial configuration of particles, there exists a unique stationary state characterized by a density that solely depends on the distance between lattice sites. Notably, this density diminishes exponentially as one moves away from the origin. This finding indicates that the particle correlations also decay exponentially at large distances, despite the absence of translational invariance in the underlying microscopic interactions. Our proof employs techniques from probability theory, particularly martingale methods, and functional analysis. These results hold for both finite and infinite lattice systems.

I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK

Research into the dynamics of lattice gases has significantly advanced our understanding of nonequilibrium steady states. These models illustrate the behavior of particles according to stochastic rules, enabling the preservation of detailed balance in certain scenarios. One well-studied class involves exclusion processes where particles move along a linear array subject to constraints. In these systems, each site can host either zero or one particle, and allowed transitions occur to neighboring sites only if they are unoccupied. When these movements are independent, the associated Markov process fulfills detailed balance with respect to a specific product measure. However, if the dynamics depend on the occupancy of nearby sites, this balance is disrupted. Despite lacking equilibrium behavior, many of these models exhibit intriguing features that parallel phenomena observed in equilibrium systems.

We present optical and near-infrared photometry of SN 2006bp, which was discovered on September 24th in NGC 6946 by amateur astronomer Brian Puckett (Puckett et al., 2007) . The supernova is located at an unusually large distance for its host galaxy, with a recession velocity of ~1000 km/sec. 
 
 We find that the light curve can be well fit using a model consisting of three components: shock breakout emission, radioactive decay powered luminosity, and dust extinction. Using this model we derive physical parameters such as the progenitor radius, mass loss rate, and explosion energy. Our results are consistent with those found for other type-II SNe but suggest that the progenitor star had a lower initial mass than previously thought. This may indicate that there exists more diversity among progenitors of type-II SNe than has been realized so far. In addition to these findings, our observations provide new insights into the physics of shock breakout and early-time evolution of type-II SNe.

rewrite_text: We investigate the wiretap channel with feedback, where an eavesdropper can receive information regarding the legitimate user's actions and use it to enhance their decoding capabilities. We demonstrate that for any positive feedback capacity, there exists a sequence of (2, n) codes such that each code achieves a rate of at least R. This result is established by integrating polar coding techniques with concepts from successive cancellation list decoding. Our proof relies on a new converse bound for the secrecy capacity region of the wiretap channel with feedback. Additionally, we present numerical simulations that illustrate the effectiveness of our achievability results. In this work, we build on the foundational framework set forth by Wyner in his analysis of the wiretap channel. Specifically, we concentrate on the scenario where the legitimate user receives feedback about previous transmissions to enhance their decoding strategies. Our results demonstrate that polar codes combined with successive cancellation list decoding come close to achieving secrecy rates when applied to channels with feedback. Furthermore, we show that if the number of messages increases exponentially with respect to the block length, then every message can be reliably transmitted using codes with a rate that scales linearly in relation to the number of messages. The structure of this paper is as follows: Section II outlines the notation and definitions; Section III presents our main theorem; Section IV sketches the proof of Theorem 3.1; and Section V concludes the discussion.

original_text: We report water vapor (H2O) and silicon monoxide (SiO) maser emission toward the central star of the protoplanetary  nebula OH231.8+4.2, which is associated with an infrared source IRAS 18286-1231. The H2O masers are distributed over a region of ~0.1 arcsec diameter around the star at a velocity range of -40 to +20 km s-1 relative to the systemic velocity of the nebula. We detected SiO masers only on one side of the star within 0.05 arcsec radius at velocities ranging between -50 and -30 km s-1. These results suggest that the H2O masers trace shocked gas near the stellar surface while the SiO masers arise from outflowing material along the polar axis.  This work was supported by Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research (No. 15740160)  from MEXT Japan.

rewrite_text: We present observations of an intervening absorber at redshift z ~ 1.5 - 2.0 towards the gamma-ray burst (GRB) 050525A, which is one of only two GRBs with spectroscopic redshifts confirmed via absorption lines. We observe absorption features corresponding to Mg II λλ2796, 2803, Fe II λ2382, 2344, and 2600, C III λ977, Si IV λ1394, 1403, O VI λ1032, 1038, N V λ1239, 1243, as well as Lyα and Lyβ, associated with an absorber at z = 2.01 ± 0.02. The column density is estimated at N_HI/cm² = 19.6 +0.2 -0.1, indicating a total hydrogen density of approximately 5 × 10²⁰ cm⁻². Additionally, we observe strong low-ionization species such as Al III λ1854, 1862, and S IV λ1063, 1073, which are typically not present in high-redshift absorbers. These characteristics imply that this absorber may be similar to those found along quasar sightlines.

original_text: We present results on the first phase of an unbiased survey for high-mass protostars (HMPSs) using the Red MSX Source (RMS) database and the NRAO 12m telescope at Kitt Peak Observatory, Arizona. The sample consists of all sources with infrared excesses that are associated with radio emission within the Galactic latitude range |b| < 5 degrees. We observed these candidates in the J=1-0 transition line of carbon monoxide (13CO), which is optically thin even towards dense cores. Our goal was to identify HMPSs by searching for compact molecular outflows traced by high-velocity wings in their 13CO spectra. In total we detected 16 HMPS candidates among our sample of 61 targets. These objects have luminosities between 10^6-10^7 Lsun and masses ranging from 8 Msun up to >100 Msun. They show evidence for bipolar outflow activity as well as infall motions.

rewrite_text: Glutamatergic synapses are the most prevalent excitatory synapses in the brain, yet the mechanisms underlying their localization are not fully understood. In this study, we found that glutamate receptors (GluRs) can be transported to synaptic sites through lateral diffusion along the membrane or indirectly via endocytosis and recycling through endosomes. We utilized single-molecule total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy to track GluR2-containing AMPA receptors tagged with a fluorescent marker in the dendrites of hippocampal neurons. Our findings revealed two distinct trafficking pathways for receptors to be delivered to synapses. First, receptors diffuse laterally along the membrane until they encounter an existing synapse, where they become trapped. Second, receptors that undergo endocytosis are encapsulated in endosomal vesicles and recycle back to the cell surface through Rab11-positive recycling endosomes before being targeted to new synapses. These discoveries provide valuable insights into the mechanisms involved in the formation of functional neuronal circuits and contribute to our understanding of synaptic plasticity.

We present the results of long-term monitoring observations with the Rossi X-Ray Timing Explorer (RXTE) Proportional Counter Array and All-Sky Monitor for anomalous X-ray pulsar 4U0142+61, which is one of the most active accreting neutron stars in our Galaxy. The source was observed during more than 10 years between 1996 February and 2007 December. We found that the pulse period shows significant changes on time scales ranging from days to months. In addition, we detected several large-amplitude outbursts lasting up to 100 days each. These outbursts are characterized by an increase in both intensity and hardness ratio. During these outbursts, the spin-up rate increased significantly compared to those before or after them. This indicates that the magnetic field strength at the surface of the star increases when it undergoes such outbursts. 
 
 Keywords: Accretion disk - Neutron star - Outburst

We present an analysis of the unique Type Ib supernova (SN) 2005bf in NGC 6946, which is one of only two supernovae with a clear connection to a gamma-ray burst (GRB). The light curve and spectral features of SN 2005bf are compared with those of other GRB-associated supernovae, as well as with Type Ia and IIb supernovae. We find that SN 2005bf exhibits several unusual characteristics among this group. Notably, it has a very rapid decline rate during its nebular phase, suggesting that its ejecta mass could be significantly larger than that typically seen in ordinary core-collapse supernovae. This implies that the progenitor star was likely massive enough to form a black hole directly, without experiencing a supernova phase. If this is accurate, we anticipate that the central engine of the associated GRB was likely powered by accretion onto the black hole rather than by radioactive decay processes. Our analysis also suggests that the explosion site is located close to the center of the host galaxy, which indicates that the progenitor may have received a natal kick prior to the explosion. 

Keywords: Gamma-ray bursts

We report on the fabrication and characterization of electro-optically tunable microresonator devices based on proton exchange (PE) grown lithium niobate-on-insulator substrates. The PE process is used to create an optical waveguide with low loss, high index contrast, and large nonlinearity within the substrate material. A ring-resonator geometry is then defined by electron-beam lithography followed by reactive ion etching. Finally, Ti/Au electrodes are deposited onto both sides of the device for electrical tuning. We demonstrate continuous wavelength tuning over more than 30 nm at 1555 nm using only 1 V reverse bias applied across the device. This work represents one step towards realizing electrically-tuned integrated photonic circuits that can be monolithically fabricated on insulators. Lithium niobate has been widely studied as a promising candidate for optoelectronics applications due to its excellent properties such as wide transparency range, large second-order susceptibility, and relatively low propagation losses  1  . In addition, it also exhibits strong piezoelectric and pyroelectric effects which make it possible to achieve efficient electro-optic modulation  2  .

rewrite_text: We investigate how classical uncertainty and market crashes affect asset prices in a repetitive trading environment, where traders have access to various sources of information about an underlying state variable. Our analysis shows that when there is a lack of common knowledge among traders regarding the true state of the variable, they tend to disagree on its perceived value, even if all have access to the same information. This disagreement leads to price fluctuations that can be exacerbated by the presence of noise traders who base their decisions on misleading indicators. Consequently, we find that this behavior results in volatility clustering and fat tails, which align with observed empirical characteristics. Additionally, we demonstrate that these effects remain significant in both stable and turbulent market conditions, exhibiting non-Gaussian statistical properties. The findings presented here provide valuable insights into how uncertainty influences the dynamic properties of asset prices and suggest potential avenues for further research aimed at enhancing our understanding of these phenomena within more realistic trading behavior models.

We study the possibility that leptons acquire their masses through an effective dimension-5 operator, which is suppressed by some heavy scale M . We show how this scenario can be realized in supersymmetric theories with extra dimensions and discuss its phenomenological consequences for neutrino physics. 
 
 In particular we consider the case where the lepton number violating interactions are localized on a brane at y = 0 while the Standard Model fields live in the bulk. The resulting mass matrix has two zero eigenvalues corresponding to the light active neutrinos and one massive eigenvalue m ~ 10 GeV associated with the sterile neutrino. This leads to interesting predictions for neutrinoless double beta decay as well as for cosmology. For example, if the Majorana phase vanishes then there will be no contribution to neutrinoless double-beta decay but the sterile neutrino may still contribute significantly to dark matter production during inflation or reheating.

We present a method to numerically address the equations governing the growth of ionized regions in the universe, utilizing the Weighted Essentially Non-Oscillatory (WENO) scheme. Our approach involves solving two coupled partial differential equations simultaneously, which describe the evolution of the ionization fraction and temperature fields within each cell of a grid covering the volume of interest. We demonstrate how this method can be applied to investigate the reionization process driven by UV photons emitted from galaxies. Specifically, we compare our results with those obtained using the Smooth Particle Hydrodynamics technique. Our tests indicate that both methods can reproduce the qualitative features of the ionization process; however, some distinctions arise between them that have significant implications for understanding the properties of the intergalactic medium (IGM) during the reionization epoch. 

Keywords: Numerical Methods, Computational Science, Cosmology, Reionization.

We report the discovery of an eclipsing binary system HS1857+5144, which is composed of two white dwarfs with masses 0.6 M⊙and 0.8M⊙respectively. The orbital period of this system is 1.5 hours. We find that the mass ratio q = M2/M1=0.84 ±0.04 for this system by using the method of spectral disentangling. This value indicates that it may be in the stage before the final merger into one single degenerate star. In addition to its short orbital period, we also found that the temperature difference between these two components is very large (∼10000K). These results suggest that this system has just evolved out of common envelope phase.

rewrite_text: In this study, we introduce a new approach for identifying individuals based on the analysis of facial attributes and their interrelationships. We extract a range of visual features from images using advanced computer vision techniques to convert them into numerical representations. These features can be utilized to train machine learning algorithms such as Support Vector Machines (SVMs) or Random Forests (RF). Furthermore, we explore the relationships among these features through Graphical Models (GM), enabling us to understand how they interact with one another. We evaluate our methodology on two distinct datasets, examining its effectiveness in recognizing individuals in controlled conditions. Our results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods when identifying individuals across multiple sessions. This research was supported by the National Science Foundation under grants IIS-1253153 and CNS-1527225. In summary, we present a novel method for facial recognition, extracting visual features and analyzing their interactions via graphical models, and validating our approach with two publicly available datasets.

original_text: We present new results on the properties of X-ray selected, optically bright (MAB <-21) galaxies in the CDF-S field with spectroscopic redshifts between 1<z<3.5. We use deep Chandra data to identify sources that are obscured by column densities NH>1022 cm-2 as well as those which have intrinsic luminosities above 1043 erg s-1 Hz-1. The majority of these objects show evidence for being heavily absorbed active galactic nuclei (AGNs). Using Spitzer mid-infrared spectroscopy we find that most of our sample is dominated by star formation activity rather than an old stellar population. In addition, we detect strong Fe Kα emission lines in many of the obscured AGNs indicating high accretion rates onto supermassive black holes. By combining optical and infrared photometry with SED modeling techniques we derive accurate estimates of the total stellar mass content within each galaxy. Our analysis shows that there exists a tight correlation between the masses of central supermassive black holes and their host spheroids over more than four orders of magnitude in BH mass.

The aim of this study is to determine whether this relatively simple model can replicate certain experimental features observed in silicate melts, such as the stretched exponential behavior of the intermediate scattering function and the presence of two distinct time scales in the dynamics. To achieve this, we conduct molecular dynamics (MD) and Monte Carlo (MC) simulations on systems with up to N = 1000 particles. Notably, through MC simulations, we are able to explore larger configurations than those achievable with MD simulations. Our findings indicate that both simulation methods exhibit similar structural patterns, yet there are subtle differences that may be relevant when comparing with experimental data. Lastly, we discuss how our results align with theoretical approaches based on mode-coupling theory.

original_text: We consider sparse multipath channels with random delays, where each path is modeled as an independent Rayleigh fading channel. We derive exact expressions for ergodic capacity and outage probability over such channels under wideband regime (i.e., when bandwidth grows without bound). Our results show that both ergodic capacity and outages are determined by the number of paths N , their average power Pn = E{|hn(t)|2}, and delay spread T . In particular, we find that ergodic capacity scales linearly with bandwidth W at high SNR if N > 2W/πT or N < πT /4W; otherwise it saturates to a constant value. Moreover, our analysis shows that outage probability decays exponentially fast with increasing bandwidth W if N > 4W/πT ; otherwise it decreases only polynomially. rewrite_text: We present an analysis of data from the Eisenhower project using the Chandra X-ray Observatory to search for evidence of dark matter being annihilated by collisions at the Galactic Center (GC). We found no excess emissions above the background levels, and we established upper limits on the fluxes of dark matter annihilation products. These limits can be used to constrain models of physics beyond the Standard Model that predict the existence of stable dark matter particles, which would produce gamma-ray signals similar to those expected from dark matter annihilation. The GC is considered one of the most promising locations for indirect searches for dark matter due to the large concentrations of dark matter present in a small volume. Furthermore, there are astrophysical sources near the GC that can accelerate protons to energies sufficient to create gamma rays through processes such as pion production or inverse Compton scattering off ambient photons. However, these sources could complicate the interpretation of any observed gamma-ray signals associated with dark matter annihilation.

We present a study on the magnetic properties of self-assembled arrays of cobalt (Co) crater spheres, fabricated using an electrochemical deposition method onto carbon-coated confiscated grids. The results reveal anisotropic behavior in the hysteresis loops at low temperatures, as well as superparamagnetic characteristics at temperatures above 300 K. We found that the coercivity decreases rapidly when the magnetic field is applied parallel to the easy axis, while it remains relatively unchanged for fields applied perpendicularly. This suggests that the easy axis aligns along the chain direction. Additionally, we observed that the remanent magnetization gradually increases up to approximately 100 Oe after annealing the sample at 400 °C under specific conditions. These findings imply that the observed anisotropy arises from dipole-dipole interactions rather than inter-site interactions. 
**Keywords:** Anisotropy, Cobalt, Hollow Sphere, Self-Assembly, Superparamagnetism.

We present new calculations for the radiative transfer in stellar winds, including the effects of line-blanketing and clumping on the wind structure. We find that neglecting the porosity of the wind leads to an overestimate of the mass loss rate by up to two orders of magnitude compared with our results. This is because the density contrast between the dense clumps and the interclump medium increases as one moves out into the wind, leading to more absorption at large distances than would be expected if the wind were smooth. The effect becomes stronger when the wind velocity decreases or the metallicity increases. 
 
 Keywords: Stellar winds, Radiation hydrodynamics, Line-driven winds, Porosity, Clumping 
 
 Hot stars lose mass through their stellar winds driven by radiation pressure on spectral lines (Castor et al., 1975; Abbott & Lucy, 1985) . In order to understand how these winds are structured it is necessary to solve the coupled equations of radiative transfer and fluid dynamics simultaneously. However, this problem has proved extremely difficult to solve numerically due to its multi-scale nature - both spatially and temporally - which requires very high resolution grids to resolve all relevant scales correctly. As such, most previous studies have used simplified treatments of either the radiative transfer or the fluid dynamics, but not both together. For example, some authors assume that the wind consists entirely of optically thin gas (e.g. Friend & Castor, 1983) while others use simple prescriptions for the radial dependence of the optical depth (e.g. Pauldrach et al., 1986) , or even ignore the effects of opacity altogether (e.g. Lamers & Cassinelli, 1999 ) . Other authors make simplifying assumptions about the flow itself, e.g. assuming spherical symmetry (e.g. Puls et al., 1996 ) , steady state (e.g. Owocki et al. , 1988 ) and/or stationarity (e.g. Runacres & Owocki , 2002 ) . 
 
 Here we present new calculations for the structure of line-driven winds

rewrite_text: The Stochastic Loewner Evolution (SLE) is a significant development in the study of random curves and fractals, particularly as a scaling limit of certain models such as self-interacting random walks. The SLE path can be regarded as a continuous version of Brownian motion with drift. It has established connections to numerous fields including quantum gravity, statistical mechanics, mathematical physics, and computer science. In this article, we will offer a brief introduction to the fundamental concepts behind the SLE framework, along with examples that highlight its applications. We will also provide references for further reading on the topic. For more information about SLE, please see the following resources: http://arxiv.org/abs/9906028, http://arxiv.org/abs/0909.0366, and http://arxiv.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.71.026110.

original_text: We present an absolute calibration of MIPS photometry at 24, 70, and 160 microns using stellar calibrators observed by the Infrared Array Camera (IRAC) onboard the Spitzer Space Telescope. We use these observations to derive corrections that account for differences in aperture size between IRAC and MIPS as well as color-dependent effects due to differing filter profiles. These corrections are applied to all sources detected with signal-to-noise ratios greater than 5 in each band. For fainter sources we apply additional corrections based upon the measured fluxes of bright stars within the same field-of-view. This method is used to calibrate over 1 million objects across the sky. We find excellent agreement between our results and those obtained independently by other groups. Our final uncertainties include contributions from both statistical errors and systematics associated with the choice of stellar calibrators. We also provide estimates of the uncertainty introduced into the derived colors when applying this technique.

rewrite_text: Muon-catalyzed fusion (MCF) is a nuclear process that can be utilized to produce energy in deuterium-sodium (DS) reactors, but it requires ultra-pure hydrogen as fuel. The MuCap experiment at TRIUMF has developed a novel method for producing ultra-pure hydrogen using liquid helium cryogenic distillation combined with two stages of molecular sieves. This system is capable of generating up to 1 liter of ultra-pure hydrogen per minute with less than 10 parts per trillion in impurities. It will supply sufficient clean hydrogen to support the MuCap experiment until 2020, when further experiments are scheduled to begin to gather data. A high-purification hydrogen circulation system was designed and constructed for the MuCap experiment at TRIUMF. The liquid helium cryogenic distillation process involves two stages of molecular sieve beds to achieve the high purity necessary for MCF research. The system can provide up to one liter of purified hydrogen per minute with an impurity content lower than 10 parts per trillion.

The fabrication, structure and properties of uranium oxide (UO 2 )/uranium nitride (UN) superlattices are reported in this work. The UO 2 /UN superlattice was grown on Si(100) substrates by pulsed laser deposition using an excimer KrF laser operating at 248 nm with a repetition rate of 10 Hz. A series of samples were prepared under different conditions to investigate the effects of substrate temperature T s , oxygen partial pressure P O 2 and nitrogen partial pressure P N 2 . X-ray diffraction measurements show that all the films have a single phase corresponding to the tetragonal structure of UN. The lattice parameters c and a increase slightly as the growth temperature increases from 300 °C to 600 °C. The results also indicate that the film thickness decreases when increasing either P O 2 or P N 2 .
Transmission electron microscopy shows that the interface between the two layers is sharp without any interfacial layer.

We present a novel method to assess the memory characteristics (size, mass, and density) of exomoons solely based on their transit light curves. We demonstrate that this approach is resilient to uncertainties in the orbital parameters of the planets by applying it to simulated datasets with varying attributes, including the semi-major axis, eccentricity, argument of periastron, longitude of the ascending node, epoch anomaly, and time through periastron. The results are compared to those derived when varying these six orbital elements alongside the radius ratio of the moon to its host planet and the host's orbital parameters simultaneously. Our analysis indicates that our method can robustly retrieve the physical characteristics of the moons even when the input data displays varying eccentricities or inclinations. 

Keywords: Exoplanet, Moon, Transit Timing Variations, Photometry. 

Transiting planets have been discovered around more than 1,000 stars to date. Many of these exhibit dimming events caused by the presence of orbiting moons. These moons play critical roles in planetary evolution but cannot be observed directly due to their relatively small sizes. As a result, we seek alternative methods to infer their physical attributes. Notably, the presence of moons around extrasolar giant planets provides significant insights into the formation processes of such bodies. Here, we propose an innovative strategy to estimate the characteristics of exomoons based exclusively on the analysis of their transit light curves. This method does not require any prior knowledge of the planet's orbital parameters and enables the detection of moons with high inclinations or eccentricities relative to the inclination of the system. Furthermore, it remains applicable regardless of whether the planet is tidally locked or free-rotating. Ultimately, it yields consistent estimates of the moon’s size, mass, and density. To validate our method, we apply it to simulated datasets created under various conditions, demonstrating its effectiveness and reliability.

original_text: The Megapie (Megavoltage Ionization Projection Imaging Experiment) is an experiment designed to study the feasibility and performance of proton radiography for medical applications. The main goal of this project was to develop a compact, high intensity ion source based on laser-plasma interaction in order to produce protons with energies up to several hundred MeV. In addition, it has been shown that such sources can be used as targets for neutron production by spallation reactions induced by energetic ions. This work presents results obtained during experiments performed at GSI Darmstadt using a pulsed deuteron beam accelerated by the SIS-18 synchrotron accelerator. Neutrons produced by the D+D reaction were detected by means of two fission chambers placed around the target chamber. A detailed analysis of these data allowed us to determine the number of neutrons emitted per incident deuteron particle and their energy distribution.

We present a tenth report to the Bulletin of the Labs regarding feedback from mass particles on recovered concentration and enstrophy in fully developed turbulence. The cascade mechanism is described by utilizing a set of coupled ordinary differential equations grounded in dimensional analysis and Kolmogorov's similarity theory. We found that the presence of particles can significantly influence both the transfer rate between different scales and the dissipation occurring at smaller scales. Specifically, we observe that the total transfer of energy to smaller scales decreases when there is significant mass particle feedback. This finding suggests that the presence of heavy particles can enhance the efficiency of turbulent mixing. Furthermore, our report indicates that the effects of mass feedback become more pronounced with an increase in Stokes number or a higher initial volume fraction of particles. Our results provide valuable insights into how heavy particles impact the dynamics of recovered flows.

We report on observations made in March and April 2002 at 345 GHz using the Atacama Submillimiter Telescope Experiment (ASTE). We detected no significant emission associated with the host galaxy of the gamma-ray burst GRB 980425, which was discovered by BeppoSAX on Apr. 25, 1998 . The 3 sigma upper limit to the flux density is < 0.5 Jy beam-1 , corresponding to an integrated line intensity ICO< 1 x 10^9 K km s^-1 pc^2 or Mgas < 2 x 10^8 Msun .
The non-detection suggests that either the molecular gas mass is much lower than previously estimated or that it has been destroyed by the intense UV radiation field produced during the burst.  These results are consistent with those obtained recently by other groups who have searched for CO emission from this source. If our result can be confirmed then it will provide important constraints on models of the formation of massive stars.

rewrite_text: We introduce a novel approach to optimizing search processes in databases that leverages Grover's algorithm, utilizing only two qubits to represent an entry in the database, which can be expressed as a binary number. The algorithm has been implemented using the IBM Q Experience simulator with four different databases, each containing up to 16 entries. We rigorously compared our method against Grover's original algorithm on the same datasets. Our results indicate that the proposed algorithm performs better than classical methods when searching through smaller databases (up to 8 entries). However, its efficiency decreases as the database size exceeds this limit. This research was supported by the Australian Research Council Discovery Project DP160103745. There is a growing interest in developing tools for efficiently searching through large datasets. These techniques are particularly applicable to various fields, including machine learning, pattern recognition, computer science, bioinformatics, and more, where they facilitate deeper exploration of complex data. In general, N qubits can encode M elements in a database. For Grover's algorithm, the required number of iterations is O(√(N/M)) to locate any specific entry from M elements stored in N qubits. It's important to note that the number of required iterations increases exponentially with respect to both N and M, rendering these methods inefficient when handling very large databases.

original_text: We present the results for the dynamics of baryons in terms of string theory, vector dominance model (VDM) and chiral perturbation theory (ChPT). The VDM is used to calculate the mass spectrum of hadrons with one heavy quark Q = c or b. In this approach we have calculated masses of charmonium states J/ψ , ψ′ , Υ and their radial excitations as well as bottomonium states Υ(1S), Υ(2S), Υ(3S), Υ(4S) and their radial excitations using potential parameters determined by fitting experimental data on meson masses. We also predict the masses of some exotic states like X(3872), Y(4260), Zc(3900) etc., which are not yet observed experimentally. Using these masses we then determine the decay constants of various excited states of quarks into leptons. These decay constants are compared with those obtained within ChPT at leading order.

rewrite_text: Circinus X-1 is an X-ray binary system consisting of a neutron star and its companion, which has been observed across multiple wavelengths, from optical to gamma-ray emissions. The source exhibits fluctuating X-ray activity due to the obscuration of the central X-ray emission region, caused by matter falling onto the accretion disk surrounding the compact object. In this study, we utilize data collected during two distinct observational campaigns with the Suzaku satellite (from 2005 to 2007) and INTEGRAL/IBIS (from 2003 to 2009). We have analyzed the spectral properties of the source for each observation separately and also conducted a joint analysis. Our results indicate that the spectrum can be characterized by a combination of several components, including: blackbody emission from the neutron star's surface; Comptonized radiation from the surrounding accretion disk; reflected emission resulting from the reprocessing of X-rays by the surrounding matter into softer photons; and an iron line feature produced by the fluorescence of cold matter located close to the neutron star.

We present the results of our Spitzer Space Telescope survey for protostars and young stellar objects (YSOs) in three nearby, intermediate mass star-forming regions: NGC 1333, Serpens South, and Perseus North. We identify over 100 candidate YSOs with infrared excesses indicative of circumstellar disks and/or envelopes. The majority are Class I sources that have recently formed outflows or jets; however we also find several dozen more evolved Class II/III sources. In addition to these disk-bearing systems, we detect numerous isolated point-like sources whose SEDs suggest they are deeply embedded protostars. These observations provide new insights into how stars form in IM environments. Our sample includes many previously unidentified low-luminosity protostars which will be useful targets for future studies at higher angular resolution. This work is based on observations made with the Spitzer Space Telescope, which is operated by NASA under contract 1407. Support for this work was provided by NASA through an award issued by JPL/Caltech.

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of the literature regarding post-Hartree-Fock (HF) corrections to atomization energies for various molecular systems. This analysis employs correlated Gaussian functions and explores extrapolation methods. Our results indicate that the correlation effects are more significant than what is captured by the HF calculations, depending on the choice of basis sets used in the computations. We compare our findings with those reported by other researchers who have investigated this issue. Finally, we discuss how these insights can enhance the accuracy of thermochemical data calculated using the CCSD(T) approach. There has been substantial interest in understanding the impact of correlated effects on various thermochemical properties, such as enthalpies of formation and reaction energies. While these properties are often measured experimentally, it would be beneficial if they could also be accurately predicted theoretically. One promising method for calculating the total electronic energy (E_total) of a molecule employs a series of increasingly sophisticated quantum mechanical approximations, where n = 1 corresponds to Hartree-Fock and n = 2 refers to second-order Møller-Plesset perturbation theory (MP2). Corrections beyond MP2 can be estimated through high-level ab initio calculations on smaller subsets of atoms or by utilizing fitted parameters to refine existing data.

We present the results on searches for new physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) in ttbar events at sqrt(s) = 7 TeV, using data collected by ATLAS during 2011 corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 4.7 fb-1 . The analysis is performed with three different final states: lepton+jets , dilepton and all-hadronic channels. We consider two types of models that can be tested with these analyses: vector-like quarks decaying into tWb or tbHq final states. In both cases we use simplified models where only one coupling parameter is varied while keeping others fixed to their SM values. No significant deviations are observed compared to the predictions based on the SM. Limits are set on the parameters describing the interactions between heavy particles and fermions. These limits improve upon previous measurements made at LEP2 and LHC Run I.

rewrite_text: We present detailed observations of three protostellar cores in Orion B, which are among the nearby prestellar regions. The data were obtained using the Submillimeter Array (SMA) at wavelengths of 1.3 mm and 0.87 mm as part of an ongoing survey aimed at understanding the earliest stages of star formation. We find that all three sources exhibit evidence of infall on scales ranging from 1000 AU to 10000 AU. Additionally, we detect outflows associated with two of these sources. These observations suggest that the formation process of these protostars is characterized by rapid mass accretion onto the central object through a circumstellar disk. This accretion may be influenced by gravitational collapse or magneto-rotational instabilities within the core. Lastly, our SMA maps reveal extended emission around each source, which could represent molecular envelopes or disks surrounding the protostar. Our findings provide crucial constraints on theoretical models regarding the dynamics of young stellar objects.

original_text: The present work is devoted to the study of the relationship between the orbital motion and the energy levels in atoms, ions or molecules. The main idea consists on establishing an analogy between the circular orbits of planets around their central star (Kepler s laws) and the electron shells in atoms (Pauli principle). In this way we can obtain new relationships among physical quantities such as the radius of the planet, its mass, the distance between two consecutive orbits, etc., which are useful when studying atomic systems. We also show that these results allow us to establish a connection between the Pauli principle and the concept of spin angular momentum. Finally, we propose some applications of our formalism to solve problems related to molecular physics. rewrite_text: The formation and characterization of lipid membranes are crucial for various biological processes, such as cellular functions and protein transport across membranes. In this study, we employed atomic force microscopy to examine the properties of stacked layers of phospholipids in water. We observed that these structures form spontaneously on mica surfaces at room temperature after the lipids are added to the solution. The height profiles indicate that the thicknesses of the individual layers range from 1 to 2 nanometers, depending on their composition. By analyzing the lateral diffusion of the layers over time, we can assess their mobility. Our findings show that the mobility of the layers is significantly influenced by the number of layers present. Specifically, while most of the single-layer structures can diffuse freely over large areas, the two-layer structures exhibit only limited displacement perpendicular to the surface. This behavior suggests that mobility decreases when more than one layer is present.

We study the formation and dynamics of bright-dark solitons in spin-1 condensates with spin-orbit coupling, which are described by the Gross-Pitaevskii equation for two coupled fields. We show that dark-bright solitons can be formed when one field is initially localized at the center of the trap while the other has an extended profile. The resulting solitonic states have been observed experimentally. 
 
 In addition to their fundamental interest as nonlinear excitations, these structures may also play important roles in quantum information processing applications such as atom interferometry or quantum logic gates based on matter waves. Finally we discuss how our results could be generalized beyond the mean-field approximation.

Their existence was confirmed experimentally in optical fibers  14  and more recently in ultracold atoms  15  .

rewrite_text: We investigate the properties of the spin-1/2 square lattice with nearest-neighbor antiferromagnetic interactions and vacancies, employing exact diagonalization (ED) on finite systems of up to 12x12 sites. We find that for low concentrations of vacancies, there is no significant change in the magnetic order parameter or the energy gap between singlet and triplet excitations compared to the pure system. However, we observe an increase in the density of states at zero energy as the concentration of vacancies rises. This phenomenon can be explained by the formation of bound pairs of vacancies that cluster together due to their mutual attraction. The energy levels of these pairs are highly dependent on the distance between them but show only weak dependence on the size of the cluster considered. Furthermore, we discuss how this behavior changes when we account for next-nearest-neighbor interactions instead of just nearest-neighbor interactions. Finally, we explore potential experimental realizations of our findings.

We present the results of our analysis on the statistical properties of dust FIR emission in nearby galaxies, based on data obtained by ISO and Spitzer space telescopes. We find that the distribution function of dust FIR luminosity is well described by a log-normal form with an exponential tail at high luminosities. The mean value of the logarithmic luminosity dispersion for all samples considered here is 0.3 dex (factor of 2). This result suggests that there are two populations of dusty star-forming regions within each galaxy -one population associated with normal star formation activity and another one associated with intense bursts of star formation. Our study also shows that the fraction of galaxies containing such extreme objects increases towards higher redshifts. These findings have important implications for understanding the physical processes responsible for the evolution of distant galaxies as well as their contribution to the cosmic infrared background radiation.

We focus on the modeling of the accretion disk continuum emission in black hole candidates (BHCs). We have developed an analytical model to calculate the spectrum produced by a thin, optically thick accretion disk surrounding a Schwarzschild black hole and compared it with several BHCs characterized by different mass functions. The observed spectra can be accurately reproduced when we assume that the upper limit of the disk extends to 6 gravitational radii. This finding suggests that the standard thin disk model is applicable for understanding the X-ray continuum emission of these objects. 

**Keywords**: Black holes, Spectroscopy, X-ray, Modeling, Accretion disks, Emission lines, Broad-band spectral energy distribution, Luminosity function, Mass measurement, Stellar-mass black holes, Supermassive black holes, Active galactic nuclei, Quasars, Cosmic evolution. 

**1 Introduction** 

Significant advances have been made in understanding the phenomena occurring near supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in active galactic nuclei (AGN), quasars, and other high-energy sources. Much of this research relies on observations of the broad-band spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of SMBHs across various astronomical scales. However, due to their inherent complexities, directly measuring the luminosities of most AGNs can be challenging. Instead, researchers often use indirect methods such as reverberation mapping or statistical correlations between different properties of AGNs to estimate their luminosities. For example, if one were to analyze how light behaves as it interacts with regions of interest within an AGN, one could derive its luminosity using geometrical considerations. Alternatively, knowing the distance to an AGN allows for its apparent magnitude to be determined. Unfortunately, both methods require detailed knowledge of the emitting regions, which is not always accessible through observational means. Consequently, to derive more reliable estimates of the luminosities of AGNs, it is essential to utilize models that can reproduce the observed SEDs of nearby AGNs effectively.

We present constraints on models of neutrino mass, mixing angles, and interactions using data from the Planck satellite experiment. We use measurements of the cosmic microwave background temperature anisotropy power spectrum to constrain cosmological parameters including the sum of the masses of all three active neutrinos ( m ), the effective number of relativistic species at recombination (), and the primordial helium abundance (). The results are consistent with previous analyses but have improved precision due to the inclusion of polarization information in addition to temperature fluctuations. 
 
 In particular we find that the total neutrino mass is constrained by Planck to be less than 0.23 eV at 95% confidence level for normal hierarchy or less than 0.28 eV for inverted hierarchy. These limits improve upon those obtained previously from WMAP7+SDSS3+HST by factors of 2.5-3.0. For comparison, these values correspond roughly to one third of an electron volt per neutrino flavor.

rewrite_text:
We propose a new metric on the space of worldsheet sigma model couplings that facilitates gradient renormalization, extending beyond traditional perturbative methods. This metric has several advantages over existing proposals, demonstrating positive features in the effective action and eliminating issues related to counterterms at higher orders. We explore how this metric can be utilized to compute effective functions up to stationary points in perturbative expansions, relying solely on Feynman diagrams with single-loop contributions as fundamental components. This approach allows us to calculate the effective function for the dilaton coupling to the Ricci scalar, yielding results consistent with those found in other studies, though they have not been easily accessible due to technical challenges. Furthermore, we present evidence for non-trivial fixed points in the effective action of the coupling constant. These findings reinforce the notion that the worldsheet sigma model can serve as a valuable framework for examining quantum gravity.

Introduction: It was recently demonstrated that the worldsheet sigma model (WSSM) is a powerful tool for investigating quantum gravity through its connection to the tensionless string integral. One particularly intriguing aspect of this framework is the computational efficiency it provides in obtaining perturbative corrections to the WSSM effective action from the path integral, without the need for intricate calculations of graviton exchanges or loops. It has been suggested that the WSSM could also be applied to study the flow of couplings under the renormalization group (RG). However, given that the WSSM encompasses infinitely many degrees of freedom, there is no finite parameter space where RG flow can occur in a conventional sense. Instead, the RG flow must take place along specific trajectories through the vast landscape of all potential models. To facilitate exploration and understanding of such trajectories, it would be advantageous to define a suitable metric on the space of WSSM couplings that allows for comparisons between different models. This metric should enable us to determine whether two points in the space of WSSMs are close together or far apart.

We present an analytical model to study the effect of mass loading feedback on particle concentration and enstrophy in fully developed turbulence. The cascade process is modeled by using a set of coupled ordinary differential equations, which are derived based on dimensional analysis and Kolmogorov s similarity hypothesis. We show that the presence of particles can significantly affect both the energy transfer rate between different scales as well as the dissipation rates at small scales. In particular, we find that the total amount of energy transferred into smaller scales decreases when there exists significant mass loading feedback. This result suggests that the presence of heavy particles may lead to reduced turbulent mixing efficiency. Finally, our results also indicate that the effects of mass loading feedback become more pronounced if the Stokes number increases or the initial volume fraction of particles becomes larger. Our findings provide useful insights into understanding how heavy particles influence the dynamics of fluid flows. C

rewrite_text: We introduce the concept of the northeast dynamics associated with cohomologically expanding maps and demonstrate that, in many cases, they are equivalent to a certain type of dynamical system referred to as the fox dynamics. Our goal is to illustrate how these full dynamics can be employed to investigate the behavior of such maps on various specified spaces. Let \( X \) be an infinite-dimensional Banach space equipped with a norm. For each integer \( n \geq 1 \), we define the open ball \( B(n) = \{ x \in X : \|x\| < n \} \). A continuous map \( T: X \to X \) is termed cohomologically expanding if there exists a constant \( C > 0 \) such that for all integers \( m, n \geq 1 \), the diameter satisfies \( \text{diam}(T^{-m}(B(n))) \leq Cn \). In this context, \( T \) exhibits several essential properties: (1) \( T \) is continuous; (2) \( T \) is surjective. The dynamics we explore reveal that under certain conditions, the existence of one type of dynamical system implies the presence of another that behaves regularly when restricted to finite-dimensional subspaces. Now, let’s clarify what a dynamical system is. Given any point \( x \in X \), the orbit \( O(x) \) is defined as \( O(x) := \{ T^k(x) : k \in \mathbb{Z} \} \). The set \( O(x) \), equipped with the metric defined by \( d_O(x_1, x_2) = \sup \{ d(x_1, y) : y \in O(x_2) \} \) for \( x_1 \in O(x_1) \) and \( x_2 \in O(x_2) \), becomes a compact metric space known as the orbital space at \( x \). If \( T \) is cohomologically expanding, then every orbit is homeomorphic to a Cantor set.

original_text: We present new results on the long-term evolution of solar magnetic fields, obtained by applying an advanced data analysis technique to observations made with the Wilcox Solar Observatory (WSO) magnetograph between 1976 and 2009. The method is based on wavelet transforms in combination with principal component analysis (PCA). It allows us to separate different types of variability into their individual components at each point in time. We find that there are two distinct modes of solar magnetic field evolution over this period. One mode shows strong fluctuations around a mean value which varies slowly but significantly during the cycle 23/24 minimum. This behaviour can be explained as being due to the presence of large-scale dynamo waves driven by differential rotation. In addition we identify another type of variation which appears to have no preferred frequency or spatial scale. These variations show significant correlations with sunspot number and other proxies for solar activity. They may therefore represent some form of global response of the Sun s magnetic field to changes in its internal dynamics.

rewrite_text: We present evidence for dark matter annihilation in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) haze, which is an excess emission at large scales compared to the Galactic background, first identified by the Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP). We utilize data from Planck and the Fermi Large Area Telescope (LAT), as well as a detailed analysis of the CMB temperature anisotropies from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT). The observed spectrum of this signal can be explained if it originates from dark matter particles with masses between 1 GeV and 10 TeV, annihilating into pairs of photons or leptons. This scenario requires a coupling of about 100 times stronger than that of standard thermal relics. If confirmed, our findings provide compelling evidence for models in which dark matter self-annihilates into Standard Model particles. This could have significant implications for the nature of dark matter itself, suggesting it may involve non-standard interactions or extend beyond the minimal supersymmetric framework of the Standard Model.

We present findings on the characterization of microwave continuum emission from air shower plasmas, using data collected by the LOPES experiment in Germany between 2004 and 2006. The observed signals align with what is expected from Cherenkov radiation emitted by relativistic electrons accelerated to energies of up to 100 MeV within the showers, as previously explored. We found no evidence suggesting contributions from incoherent synchrotron or bremsstrahlung processes. These results offer valuable insights into the physics of cosmic rays at high energies and demonstrate the potential of this research for investigating phenomena such as thunderstorms. 

Keywords: Cosmic rays, Radio emission, Air showers, Coherence, Synchrotron radiation

Recently, there has been increased interest in developing novel methods for detecting ultra-high-energy (UHE) cosmic rays based on their interactions with the Earth's atmosphere. One promising approach involves measuring the radio frequency (RF) emission produced when UHE cosmic rays collide with the atmosphere, which can be detected remotely over large distances. A key characteristic of this RF emission is a broad broadband pulse lasting several microseconds. This pulse is generated by the charged particle cascade created by each cosmic ray as it interacts strongly with the geomagnetic field, resulting in coherent emissions across a wide range of frequencies. However, other sources can also contribute to the overall RF emission. Here, we present observations made with the Low-Frequency Array (LOFAR), part of the International LOFAR Telescope. Our analysis primarily focuses on data collected between 2004 and 2006 with the Long Wavelength Array (LWA), a phased array consisting of 144 dual-polarized dipole antennas operating at wavelengths ranging from 10 m to 80 m. During this time, the LWA was located near Karthaus Township, Germany, where it recorded signals from over 20 million air shower events.

original_text: We present the latest advances in optical frequency combs and their applications to precision metrology, including calibration techniques for high-resolution spectroscopy instruments such as Fourier transform spectrometers (FTS). We discuss how these techniques can be used to improve measurement accuracy by orders of magnitude over traditional methods.  In particular we describe two novel approaches that are being developed at NIST:  1) The use of an optical frequency comb locked to a high-accuracy atomic clock to calibrate FTS measurements with sub-Hz uncertainty. 2) A technique called  self-calibration  which allows one to measure absolute frequencies without requiring any external reference standards or other auxiliary equipment. These techniques have been demonstrated using both laboratory experiments and field tests. They represent important steps towards realizing the vision of a future where all spectroscopic measurements will be traceable back to fundamental physical constants. This is especially relevant today given the growing interest in developing portable, low-cost devices capable of performing accurate chemical analysis anywhere around the world.

We report on measurements of spin-transfer-torque vector (STTV) in magnetic tunnel junctions with perpendicular anisotropy and in-plane magnetization. The STTV is determined by measuring the current-induced switching field distribution for different directions of an external magnetic field applied along the film plane. rewrite_text: We address the challenge of efficient modulation for downlink communications in Code-Division Multiple Access (CDMA) networks. In this scenario, each user faces individual delay constraints and has a rechargeable battery that can be powered by harvesting ambient radio signals. We model this challenge as a noncooperative game where users compete for limited power resources while adhering to their own transmission constraints. Specifically, we demonstrate how to calculate Nash equilibria for these games using convex optimization techniques. Our results show significant improvements in both throughput and energy efficiency compared to traditional schemes that use fixed-rate signals. The framework allows us to analyze trade-offs among various performance metrics, including delay, outage probability, and energy consumption. This research was supported by NSF grants CNS-0932040 and CCF-0939370. The code is available at http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.5481.

original_text: We have analyzed the shapes of interstellar extinction curves in the infrared through ultraviolet wavelength range using data for more than 100 sight lines with known distances and reddenings, including those obtained by us at Kitt Peak National Observatory (KPNO) and Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO). We find that all observed extinction curves can be fitted well by a single power law function A(lambda) = lambda -alpha , where alpha is an index ranging between 1.5 to 2.0. This result suggests that there are no significant differences among various types of interstellar dust grains as far as their optical properties are concerned. In addition, we show that the value of alpha correlates strongly with the total-to-selective extinction ratio Rv . These results suggest that the shape of interstellar extinction curve may provide important information on the physical conditions of interstellar matter along individual sight lines. We analyze the ultraviolet (UV) behavior of gauged chiral supergravities in six dimensions, with a particular focus on their supersymmetric AdS7 vacua. Our findings indicate that these systems are not free at high energies; rather, they possess a nontrivial fixed point characterized by a finite number of degrees of freedom. This analysis is facilitated by employing the recently developed method of holographic renormalization to compute the flow of the gauge coupling constants, as well as the contributions from higher-derivative terms in the effective action. The resulting insights can help stabilize the scalar potential against quantum corrections. Notably, we demonstrate the existence of a broad class of models that exhibit metastable de Sitter vacua. These findings provide further evidence for the existence of stable non-supersymmetric AdS7 vacua in this context. 

Introduction: It has previously been established that certain classes of N = 1 superconformal field theories (SCFTs) in four dimensions can be derived from compactifications of type IIA strings on Calabi-Yau threefolds, denoted as X3. Additionally, it was found that such constructions typically yield massive gravitons in five dimensions, with their masses scaling as M²_grav ∼ V⁻³, where V represents the volume of X3. Consequently, one anticipates that the five-dimensional gravitational constant G5 will exhibit logarithmic running behavior. It was proposed that this behavior could be mitigated by considering non-perturbative effects stemming from Euclidean D3-branes, which contribute to the Lagrangian through the term L ∈ H⁴(X3; Z). Indeed, these instanton effects generate a term proportional to R ∧ R in the low-energy effective theory. If this term dominates over other contributions, the resulting vacuum solution should correspond to an anti-de Sitter space. Furthermore, since the instanton contributions scale as g_s⁻¹, where g_s is the string coupling constant, one can conclude that the radius of curvature of the anti-de Sitter space decreases rapidly in the weak coupling limit. Thus, achieving a phenomenologically viable scenario requires careful consideration of these dynamics.

We study the properties of Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) with an arbitrary number N of particles trapped by a harmonic oscillator and exposed to a disordered external potential. We show that, for any strength of disorder, there is always a finite fraction of atoms localized at each site of the lattice. The localization length decreases as the disorder increases but remains macroscopic even when the disorder becomes very large compared to the interatomic interaction energy. This result holds true both in one dimension and higher dimensions.  In particular we find that the critical disorder above which all states are localized scales like 1/N in 1D and 1/d in 2D and 3D where d is the spatial dimension. Our results provide a microscopic understanding of recent experiments on ultracold atomic gases in optical lattices. Introduction:-Recent experimental advances have made it possible to create quantum degenerate gases of bosons or fermions confined in periodic potentials  1  . These systems can be described theoretically using the framework of the Bose-Hubbard model  2  , which has been extensively studied over the past decade  3  .
In this work we consider the case of a gas of interacting bosons in a disordered potential. Disorder leads to Anderson localization  4  : eigenstates become exponentially localized around their initial position if the disorder exceeds some threshold value  5  . It was recently shown experimentally  6  that such a system exhibits a transition between extended Bloch-like states and localized Wannier-Stark ladders  7, 8  . However, these experiments were performed only in the weak-disorder regime, i.e., when the disorder amplitude V0 is much smaller than the characteristic hopping matrix element J. Here we investigate how the presence of interactions affects the physics of strongly disordered systems.

rewrite_text: We report the discovery of an unusual object in the outer solar system, likely composed primarily of icy materials. The trans-Neptunian body, designated (65489) Ceto/Phorcys, was discovered by NASA's Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer on September 24, 2010, at a heliocentric distance of approximately 5 AU. It has been observed for over two years using ground-based telescopes as well as spaceborne observatories such as the Spitzer Space Telescope and the Herschel Space Observatory. Our analysis of these datasets indicates that this object is a binary Centaur, with its components locked in a mutual tidal interaction. This unique combination of characteristics makes it one of only three known binary systems in the solar system where both components have diameters greater than 100 km. Our study suggests that Phorcys is a nearly spherical body with dimensions of approximately 400 x 300 x 250 kilometers, and its surface temperature is estimated to be around -100 degrees Celsius.

We present new constraints on planet formation timescales by combining infrared photometry and spectroscopy with optical data to study the circumstellar environments of young stars in nearby open clusters. We find that most weak-lined T Tauri stars (WTTS) have disks, but only half as many show evidence for accretion onto their central star. The fraction of WTTSs showing signs of accretion decreases rapidly between ages of 1 Myr and 3 Myr. This suggests that disk dispersal is an important process during this period. In addition, we find that the distribution of dust temperatures in these systems evolves significantly over time. These results are consistent with models where planets form quickly after the dissipation of the protoplanetary disk. However, our sample size is small and additional observations will be needed before firm conclusions can be drawn about how planet formation proceeds.

The source exhibits a 2-10 keV flux of approximately 4 x 10^-13 erg cm^-2 s^-1, corresponding to a luminosity of approximately 3 x 10^44 erg s^-1 at this redshift. We find that the spectrum can be modeled using a power law along with Galactic absorption and reflection, employing the pexrav model in XSPEC. This results in a photon index of Γ = 1.9+0.2-0.1 and a reflection fraction of R = 0.7+1.0-1.3. The observed luminosity in the 0.5-7 keV band is approximately 5 x 10^43 erg/sec, which translates to an Eddington ratio of L/LEdd = 0.01-0.03, assuming a black hole mass of M_BH ~ 10^9 M⊙.

original_text: We study the spatial and kinematic alignment between central and satellite halos in cosmological N-body simulations, focusing on their dependence on halo mass ratio (q = Msat/Mcen) and redshift z. We find that satellites are preferentially located along filaments connecting to their host galaxy at all redshifts studied here (0 < z < 3). The degree of this alignment increases with decreasing q for fixed z, but decreases with increasing z for fixed q. This trend is consistent with theoretical predictions based on tidal torque theory. In addition, we show that the velocity difference between central and satellite galaxies depends strongly on both q and z. For example, when q > 0.1, the mean radial velocity difference |vr| decreases rapidly as z increases; however, |vr| remains nearly constant over cosmic time if q < 0.01. These results suggest that the observed evolution of the luminosity function may be affected by the dynamical friction acting on satellite galaxies.

In this study, we introduce an adaptive service provisioning system designed to ensure quality of service (QoS) guarantees while optimizing resource allocation for both base stations (BSs) and mobile users (MUs) to enhance user experience. Our proposed model builds on a multi-tier framework that factors in user mobility within the QoS criteria. We approach the issue as a joint optimization problem involving BS power control, MU transmission rates, and their coordination with BSs. To address this, we decompose the original problem into two distinct subproblems: one focused on each BS and the other on all MUs. Subsequently, we apply a distributed method to iteratively solve these subproblems using dual decomposition. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed solution outperforms existing methods in various scenarios. 

In recent years, wireless networks have gained popularity due to their low cost and ease of deployment. However, they are vulnerable to various attacks, such as eavesdropping, jamming, and data tampering. To enhance the security of wireless communications, recent research has focused on leveraging physical layer attributes for secure transmission without relying on conventional cryptographic methods. Research indicates that if a legitimate transmitter-receiver pair lacks shared information about the channel's properties that could be exploited by potential eavesdroppers, achieving perfect secrecy is impossible, even with multiple antennas at the transmitter. Consequently, practical solutions must address issues such as estimation inaccuracies, limited transmit power, and finite antenna availability.

original_text: We present the Hamiltonian formulation for general relativity with matter fields on an arbitrary spacetime manifold, including both classical and quantum aspects. The basic idea is to use the ADM decomposition of the metric into space and time components as well as lapse and shift functions. We then introduce canonical momenta conjugate to these variables which are used to construct the primary constraints of the theory. These constraints generate gauge transformations under which all physical quantities must be invariant. In order to obtain the correct number of degrees of freedom we have to impose secondary constraints that eliminate unphysical modes. Finally, we perform the canonical quantization by promoting the phase-space variables to operators acting on wave-functions defined over superspace (the space of all possible metrics). This leads us to the Wheeler-DeWitt equation whose solutions can be interpreted as probability amplitudes between different states of the universe. We also discuss how this approach could be applied to inflationary models.

SDSS J121811+465501 is a dwarf galaxy identified in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). Despite its classification as a dwarf elliptical galaxy, its surface brightness profile suggests that it is actually quite diffuse and low in density. We conducted deep optical spectroscopy of this galaxy using the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph on Gemini North to determine its fundamental characteristics. The spectrum reveals strong Balmer absorption lines, indicating the presence of young stellar populations. The galaxy’s metallicity is found to be approximately solar or lower, making SDSS J121811+465501 one of the lowest-metallicity galaxies known at redshift z = 0.1. This study represents an exploration of a population of stars likely formed during an era when star formation was more prevalent than it is today. 

Keywords: Dwarf Elliptical Galaxy, Oxygen Abundance, Gemini Observatory, Sloan Digital Sky Survey, Low Surface Brightness.

We present an atomistic multiscale approach to the study of charge transport through stretched single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). The method combines molecular dynamics simulations with quantum mechanical calculations on small fragments, which are used as input for a tight-binding description of larger systems. We show that this scheme allows us to reproduce experimental results obtained by scanning tunneling microscopy experiments performed at room temperature. In particular we find that our calculated conductance agrees well with experiment when using realistic values for the hopping parameters between neighboring base pairs. Our analysis shows that the main contribution to the current is due to electrons localized along the backbone chain. These findings suggest that ssDNA can be considered as a promising material for future applications such as nanoelectronic devices or sensors. 
 
 Introduction 
 
 Single stranded DNA has been studied extensively over many years both experimentally  1 - 3  and theoretically  4 - 6  . It was found that its structure depends strongly on environmental conditions like pH value  7  , ionic strength  8  -  10  , solvent  11  , temperature  12  , stretching  13  , etc.. This makes it possible to use ssDNA as a sensor  14  -  16  or even as a nanomaterial  17  -  19  . For example, recent studies have shown that ssDNA can form stable helical structures  20  -  22  . Furthermore, it was demonstrated that ssDNA can act as a template for protein synthesis  23  .
 
In addition to these structural properties there is growing interest in understanding how charge carriers move through ssDNA  24  -  26  . Recent theoretical investigations showed that electron transfer rates depend sensitively on the conformation of the molecule  27  -  29  . Experimentally, it was observed that the conductivity decreases exponentially with increasing length  30  -  32  . However, the exact mechanism behind this effect remains unclear  33  .

Using this approach we calculate the transmission function T(E), i.e., the probability amplitude for an electron injected into one end of the system to reach the other end

rewrite_text: We address the issue of Eisenhower regression in the context of measurement error, where the errors are assumed to be normally distributed and uncorrelated between different observations, but correlated within each set of measurements (i.e., for a single target star). We derive a formula for the covariance of the estimated parameters, which remains valid even when the number of data points per measurement set varies across different sets. This allows us to understand how the accuracy of our estimates depends on the distribution of observations across all stars. Our method can also serve as a framework for optimizing observational strategies by minimizing the uncertainty in the resultant estimates. Specifically, we find that it can be beneficial to utilize only a small fraction of available data points when estimating the primary parameters while employing most or all data points to recover their derivatives. Finally, we demonstrate our approach using simulated data derived from the Hipparcos astrometric satellite.

original_text: We present an open-source framework, called Bubblesched, that allows to build portable thread schedulers for hierarchical multiprocessors (HMPs). rewrite_text: We investigate the influence of viscous accretion, disruption, and external photonic evaporation on the growth, radial drift, and fragmentation of dust in protoplanetary disks. Our study examines how these processes impact the structure of grain size distributions and their spatial distribution within the disk. Specifically, we find that: (i) The grain sizes are constrained to a range between 1 mm and 10 cm, depending on the intensity of the UV radiation; (ii) Larger grains are expelled from the inner regions of the disk due to lower density and heat; (iii) Fragmentation occurs more readily near the star, where increased energy leads to higher collisional velocities. These findings have significant implications for planet formation theories, suggesting that planetesimals can only form close to the star, while larger bodies like asteroids and comets can originate from more distant regions of the disk.

Weak gravitational lensing is an important tool to study dark matter halos in galaxy clusters, but it requires large telescopes or space-based observatories with high angular resolution cameras. In this work we use Chandra data to measure the gas mass fraction (fgas) profiles of two massive galaxy clusters selected by their strong shear signal using HST/ACS images. We compare these fgas measurements with those derived from weak-lensing analysis performed on Subaru/Suprime-Cam imaging data. The comparison shows that both methods agree well within the statistical uncertainties at radii larger than 0.5 r500. At smaller radii there are significant differences between the results obtained with different techniques. These discrepancies may be caused by systematic effects associated with each method and/or by intrinsic scatter among individual clusters. This project was supported by NASA grant NNX10AD65G. We thank J. Richard McInnes for providing us with his software package for fitting the surface brightness profile of galaxy clusters. 
 
 Keywords: galaxy cluster, Chandra, weak lensing

We present the tenth analysis of blazars in our study, utilizing data from the Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP) satellite and the Swift observatory during their initial operational period from 2004 to 2005. When comparing their distributions across various parameters—including redshift, luminosity distance, discovered source density at 1 GHz, optical magnitude, and X-ray photon counts—we find no significant overlap between the two datasets. We study the dynamics of three agent games with two strategies each, where agents are connected by an underlying network and play pairwise interactions according to their strategy choices. We show that for any initial state there is always at least one absorbing state in which all agents have the same strategy choice. In addition we find that if the number of nodes with either strategy exceeds 1 then this state can be reached within finite time. Finally, we provide bounds on how fast such convergence occurs as well as conditions under which it will occur exponentially quickly. The results presented here generalize previous work done on two-agent evolutionary games to multi-agent systems. Evolutionary game theory has been used extensively over the past decade to model competition between different species or individuals competing for limited resources  1  . A common approach taken when modeling these types of problems is to consider a population consisting of many interacting agents who choose among several possible strategies  2  , and then use mathematical tools developed in statistical physics  3  to analyze the resulting system behavior  4  .
In recent years researchers have begun studying more complex models involving multiple populations  5  , spatial structure  6  , and heterogeneous environments  7, 8  . However, most existing research focuses only on two-player games  9  , while less attention has been paid to multi-agent systems  10  . Here we present new results showing that even simple multi-agent systems exhibit richer dynamical behaviors than previously thought  11  .

rewrite_text: We examined the mid-infrared (MIR) spectrum of the judge's region in the Virgo cluster using Spitzer/IRS at high spatial resolution. The MIR emission is influenced by polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon features and silicate absorption, showing spatial variations over several kiloparsecs along the galaxy's structure. We found evidence for a compact source contributing to this emission, located within 0.5 arcseconds (approximately 0.1 parsecs) of the nucleus. This nuclear source has been identified as a compact, paused core and is a near-infrared continuum source, previously unobserved in noble spectral bands. It displays strong PAH emission lines and weak ionized line emission. Additionally, we detected a number of other sources in the observed field, including two bright starburst regions located about 10 arcminutes away from M87. These findings suggest that the MIR characteristics of active galactic nuclei can be studied even in densely populated regions like those found near the centers of rich clusters such as Virgo.
