rewrite_text: We explore the phenomenon of surface modes that emerge in a layered medium with distinct nonlinear properties. These modes, under the influence of edge effects, exhibit characteristics similar to gap solitons found in periodic structures. The existence of these modes is investigated by numerically solving an eigenvalue problem. We focus on the stability properties of such modes in the presence of small perturbations. Experimental observation of surface mode localization can be achieved using optical waveguide arrays or photonic crystals. In this study, we specifically consider the scenario where two layers have opposite nonlinearities (for example, one layer is positive and the other negative). This situation arises when the material parameters change sign across a boundary, particularly near the transition between regions of normal and anomalous dispersion. We demonstrate the existence of a class of solutions, reminiscent of gap solitons, resulting from the interaction between linear and nonlinear effects. These solutions exist only within a specific frequency range and decay exponentially from their origin. Their characteristics depend significantly on the ratio of the amplitudes of the incoming and reflected waves.

original_text: The development of large space telescopes requires the use of lightweight materials to reduce launch costs and increase telescope performance in orbit. Silicon Carbide (SiC) is an excellent candidate material due to its high strength, low density, and radiation hardness at cryogenic temperatures. However, it has been shown that SiC exhibits significant changes in thermal expansion with temperature which can lead to dimensional instability during cool-downs or warm-ups. This work presents results on the measurement of the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) of SiC-100 over a wide range of temperatures using a novel technique based on laser interferometry. The measured values are compared against literature data as well as theoretical predictions obtained by ab initio calculations. It was found that the experimental measurements agree very well with theory within the uncertainty limits. These results will be used to improve the design of future space missions such as JWST and WFIRST-AFTA.

This sample includes six binary stars that were not previously reported in DR2 due to their faintness for Gaia to measure effective parallaxes. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the mass distribution of these newly discovered dwarf stars based on their photometric distances. This study marks the first time such an analysis has been conducted using Gaia data. Our findings show a significant agreement between our observed mass function and theoretical predictions. These results highlight the capability of Gaia as a powerful tool for investigating the nearby stellar population. We study pair production of doubly-charged scalars in association with two jets, which can be induced by both weak gauge bosons (W or Z) and photons via loops involving heavy fermions such as top quarks. We derive constraints on the masses of these particles using current experimental data for W+jets and Z+jets processes collected by ATLAS and CMS experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). In addition to the standard model backgrounds, we also consider contributions from other new physics models that may have similar signatures. The results are presented in terms of exclusion limits on the mass parameters of various new physics scenarios. Finally, we discuss possible signals of this process at future runs of the LHC. PACS numbers: 12.60.Jv, 13 .85.Rm, 14.80.Ly 
I. INTRODUCTIO N
The discovery of neutrinos has opened up an exciting possibility of probing beyond Standard Model (SM), especially its Majorana nature  1  , through their lepton number violating interactions  2  . One interesting scenario is the seesaw mechanism  3  where SM singlet right-handed neutrinos acquire large Majorana masses after electroweak symmetry breaking  4  .
In order to test whether the observed light neutrinos are indeed Majorana particles, one needs to look for lepton-number-violating processes mediated by virtual heavy neutrinos  5  . These include neutrinoless double beta decay  6  , tritium beta decay  7  , and charged-current quasielastic scattering  8  . However, it turns out that all these processes suffer from severe astrophysical and/or nuclear matrix element uncertainties  9  . On the other hand, colliders provide clean environments to probe lepton number violation directly  10  . For example, searches for same-sign dileptons  11  and trileptons  12  at hadronic colliders could lead to important information about Majorana neutrinos  13  . Another promising channel is the production of doubly-charge scalar particles  14  , which can occur either through s-channel exchange of neutral gauge bosons  15  or t-channel exchange of heavy ferm

We analyze the Wightman functions and energy densities on a Z_2-symmetric, thick brane embedded in anti-de Sitter (AdS) spacetime with a single site. We find that there are two types of solutions to the equations depending on whether the brane mass is zero or not. In both scenarios, we show that these quantities can be expressed as sums over modified Bessel functions. The results presented herein have potential applications in scenarios involving thick branes at finite temperature and/or density. 
PACS: 11.10.Kk, 12.20.Ds, 98.80.Cq 
Keywords: Vacuum fluctuations, Anti-de Sitter spacetime, Thick brane, Modified Bessel function.

1. Introduction 
An intriguing aspect of higher-dimensional theories is their capacity to incorporate gravity into the fundamental framework of nature. This has sparked increased interest in the study of brane-world scenarios that exhibit supersymmetry. One such class of spacetimes is characterized by warped geometries, defined by the metric 
\[ ds^2 = e^{2A(y)} (\eta_{\mu\nu} dx^\mu dx^\nu + dy^2), \]
where \( y \) denotes the coordinate along the brane, \( A(y) \) represents the warp factor, and \( \eta_{\mu\nu} \) is the Minkowski metric. In the five-dimensional case, this corresponds to the Randall-Sundrum model. Recent studies have demonstrated that the presence of a nontrivial warp factor leads to significant changes in the physics of fields propagating in the bulk. These effects include modifications to the standard dispersion relations, spontaneous symmetry breaking, and fermion localization, among others. The nature of the effects due to the warp factor is critically dependent on its behavior near the boundary of the brane. If the warp factor decays sufficiently rapidly at infinity, all AdS observables will align with those derived from a standard flat-space defect. Conversely, if the warp factor does not diminish quickly enough, some novel phenomena arise.

original_text:
We present an approach to the description of macroscopic configurations in terms of quantum states, which is based on the concept of entanglement entropy and its generalization for mixed states. We show that this representation allows one to obtain exact results for some statistical properties of systems with many degrees of freedom. In particular, we consider the problem of calculating the partition function of classical spin models at high temperatures. The proposed method can be used as a basis for constructing approximate algorithms for solving problems related to the calculation of thermodynamic characteristics of complex systems. Introduction.
The main goal of statistical mechanics is to describe the behavior of macroscopic objects (for example, gases) by using microscopic information about their constituents (atoms). This task becomes especially difficult when dealing with large systems consisting of many particles or spins. For such cases, it is necessary to use approximations, since direct calculations are impossible due to the exponential growth of the number of possible microstates with increasing system size N . One of these approaches is the so-called mean-field approximation  1  , according to which each particle interacts only with all other particles simultaneously; i.e., the interaction between different pairs of particles is neglected. However, even within this simplified model, the calculation of the partition function Z = Tr exp(−βH) (1) remains extremely complicated  2  .
In recent years, there has been growing interest in developing new methods for describing macroscopic configurations in terms similar to those used in quantum physics  3  -  8  . These studies were inspired by the fact that both classical and quantum descriptions have certain common features  9  : they are formulated in terms of wave functions ψ(x), where x denotes either positions of particles or spins, respectively. Moreover, the evolution of these wave functions obeys the same Schrödinger equation ih∂ t |ψ(t) = H|ψ(t) , where H is the corresponding Hamiltonian operator. It should also be noted that the density matrix ρ = |ψ(t) ψ(t)| plays the role of a probability distribution in both theories  10  .

rewrite_text: We are developing dynamic models for the Milky Way halo that incorporate various spherical components, each defined by its own density and velocity dispersion profiles. Our approach relies on Jeans' theorem applied to the phase-space distribution function (DF) to infer the DF from the projected surface mass density along any line of sight. We demonstrate how this method can be utilized with observational data, such as that obtained from kinematic tracers or gravitational lensing. Specifically, we apply our approach to two distinct datasets: 1) a sample of RR Lyrae stars observed in the Galactic bulge, and 2) gravitational lensing data from the Bullet Cluster. Our results are compared to previous studies that used simpler models assuming constant anisotropies across all radii or power-law radial dependencies. We find that these simplistic models can introduce significant biases when interpreting the data.

In this work, we study the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff (DMT) for large multiple-input and multiple-output systems with independent Rayleigh fading channels. We first derive an exact expression for DMT by using the asymptotic analysis technique proposed in  1  . Then, based on our derived results, we propose two low-complexity suboptimal schemes to achieve near-optimum performance at low SNR region. Finally, simulation results are provided to verify the effectiveness of these proposed schemes. The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:  1) An exact expression is obtained for the DMT of large MIMO systems; 2) Two low-complexity suboptimum schemes are proposed; 3) Simulation results show that both proposed schemes have good performances compared with existing ones. In recent years, there has been growing interest in studying large-scale antenna arrays due to their potential advantages over conventional small-scale antenna arrays  2  -  4  , such as higher data rates, lower transmit power consumption, reduced inter-cell interference, etc.. However, it should also be noted that increasing the number of antennas will lead to increased hardware cost and energy consumption  5  .
To fully exploit the benefits brought about by massive MIMO technology while keeping its disadvantages under control, many researchers have studied how to optimize the design parameters  6 -  8  or develop new transmission techniques  9  -  11  . Among them, one important issue is to investigate the fundamental limits of largescale antenna array systems  12  -  14  . For example, Zheng et al.  15  investigated the ergodic capacity scaling law of multi-cell multiuser massive MIMO networks. Liu et al.  16  analyzed the outage probability of downlink massive MIMO systems. Wang et al.  17  studied the achievable rate of uplink massive MIMO systems with imperfect channel state information (CSI). Moreover, some other works  18  -  20  focused on analyzing the error performance of large-scale antenna array systems.

rewrite_text: We present near-infrared (NIR) observations and analysis of the binary system UZ Tau E, which consists of two T Tauri stars with masses of approximately 0.8 solar masses separated by 0.4 arcseconds. We found no evidence for a secondary source of variability; instead, our data suggest that one or both stars in the binary may experience heightened mass transfer near periastron. original_text: We introduce the concept of neutral networks, which are graphs that represent relationships between sequences and shapes in an unsupervised manner. We show how these can be used for shape recognition by training them on synthetic data generated using computer graphics techniques. The resulting network is able to recognize shapes with high accuracy even when they have been transformed or distorted. Finally we demonstrate our method on real world images showing its ability to generalize well beyond the training set. In this work we present a novel approach to learning about shapes through their relationship to sequences. Our main contribution is introducing the concept of neutral networks as a way to learn such relationships without supervision. Neutral networks are graphs whose nodes correspond to sequences (e.g., strings) and edges connect similar sequences. They provide a natural representation for capturing relationships between different types of information. For example, one could use a neutral network to capture relationships between sentences and documents, or between music notes and melodies. Here we focus on applying neutral networks to the problem of recognizing shapes based solely on their sequence of points sampled along their boundary. This task has many applications including medical image analysis where it may not always be possible to obtain ground truth labels due to privacy concerns.

rewrite_text: We present four new quasars with redshifts greater than 6, discovered in the Canada France Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS). These quasars were identified as part of an ongoing survey for high-luminosity quasars utilizing photometric data from both CFHT and the Spitzer Space Telescope. We analyze their optical to near-infrared spectral energy distributions (SEDs), which are well-fitted by composite quasar templates. Their luminosities range from approximately \(1.5 \times 10^{14} \, \text{erg} \, \text{s}^{-1} \, \text{cm}^{-2}\) to \(2.1 \times 10^{15} \, \text{erg} \, \text{s}^{-1} \, \text{cm}^{-2}\). These findings indicate that there is still potential for discovering very luminous quasars beyond redshift six. Moreover, they provide additional evidence that supermassive black holes underwent rapid growth during this early phase of cosmic evolution. The four newly discovered quasars highlight the capabilities of the CFHTLS, leveraging deep optical data from CFHT alongside infrared observations from the Spitzer Space Telescope.

We study the generalized Dicke model with an arbitrary number N of two-level atoms interacting with one-mode radiation field, and show that it can be mapped to a spin-1/2 system by using the Holstein-Primakoff transformation. We then use the exact diagonalization method to calculate its ground state energy spectrum for different values of the coupling constant g and the number N . The results are compared with those obtained by other methods such as perturbation theory and numerical integration. It is found that our results agree well with previous ones when the coupling strength is small but deviate significantly from them if the coupling becomes strong. Finally we discuss some possible applications of this work. PACS: 03.65.Ud, 05.45.Mt, 11.10.Gh, 12.20.Dc, 13.25.Gv

However, it fails completely at large-coupling limit since the mapping procedure breaks down due to the appearance of unphysical states  13  . Recently, several authors  14 -19  have tried to overcome this difficulty by introducing new transformations or approximations. Nevertheless, their solutions still suffer from certain drawbacks  20, 21  .

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of the effects that mergers have on the scaling relationships between black holes (BHs), galaxies, and other gravitationally bound systems. We utilized cosmological simulations to examine how BH mass correlates with galaxy properties across various merger histories. Our findings indicate that mergers can significantly impact these relationships by introducing scatter at fixed luminosities or affecting the dispersion of galaxy properties. This is particularly pronounced in low-mass galaxies undergoing vigorous star formation. Additionally, we discovered that mergers lead to an increase in the BH-to-galaxy mass ratio, as well as an increase in the fraction of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) among the sampled galaxies. These results align with observations of AGN host galaxies. Ultimately, our research suggests that the observed correlation between supermassive BH masses and bulge properties may be driven primarily by the fact that both grow during major mergers. Keywords: Galaxy evolution; Supermassive black hole.

original_text: We present the results of long-term numerical simulations of binary black hole (BBH) evolution, including gravitational radiation reaction and general relativistic effects such as frame dragging and tidal disruption. We focus on binaries with total mass M = 100-1000M⊙ that evolve through collisional nuclear environments at high redshifts z > 10. Our main goal is to study how BBHs can grow by accretion during their early stages of evolution when they are surrounded by dense gas clouds. In particular we investigate whether these systems can reach masses above 1000M⊙ before merging within a Hubble time. The initial conditions for our models were obtained using Monte Carlo sampling of the distribution function of isolated BBHs constructed by Belczynski et al. (2010) . For each model we performed several runs starting from different orbital configurations. All calculations were carried out assuming circular orbits. We find that most of the massive binaries merge within a few hundred million years after formation due to emission of gravitational waves. However, some of them survive until today if they form in regions where the density of surrounding gas exceeds $10^{9}$ cm$^{-3}$. These binaries may be detectable by future space-based gravitational wave observatories like LISA or DECIGO/BBO.

rewrite_text: We present findings from our study on bimodality in galaxies and active galactic nuclei (AGN). Our results indicate that there is no significant difference in the fraction of AGNs hosted by red or blue galaxies. However, we do observe an excess of AGNs in comparison to normal galaxies at intermediate colors. This suggests that AGNs are not preferentially associated with either red or blue galaxies, contrary to previous assumptions; instead, they appear to be more prevalent among galaxies with intermediate colors. The absence of a correlation between galaxy color and AGN activity indicates that AGNs may have a limited role in suppressing star formation in blue galaxies. Alternatively, it could imply that AGNs exert varying effects depending on their luminosity and/or accretion rate. Furthermore, we find that all AGNs are located in galaxies with bulges, regardless of whether these galaxies are classified as early-type or late-type.

original_text: We present the first detection of relativistically modulated X-ray fluxes from the Galactic Center black hole candidate SgrA*, using data obtained with Chandra and XMM-Newton observatories over an eight-year period (2000-2007). The observed light curves show clear periodic dips on time scales ranging between 20 minutes to several hours that are consistent with being caused by general relativistic effects near the event horizon of this supermassive black hole. We find no evidence for long-term variability or flaring activity during these observations. These results provide strong support for theoretical models where the emission is produced close to the last stable orbit around the central black hole via accretion disk instabilities. rewrite_text: Magnetic manipulation has emerged as a crucial component in biomedical research and point-of-care diagnostics. However, its applications have typically been restricted to large, cumbersome devices that are not practical for field use. In this study, we present a method for continuous magnetophoresis-based blood cell sorting utilizing microfluidics. We demonstrate the effective isolation of red blood cells (RBCs) from whole blood by employing a magnetic gradient across a microchannel containing RBCs suspended in a buffer solution. Our findings indicate that this approach can serve as a reliable method for separating various types of blood cells with high purity and efficiency. This research has significant implications for developing portable diagnostic tools based on microscale blood analysis. Magnetic manipulation is essential in multiple fields, including medicine, biotechnology, environmental science, and industry. However, existing systems often consist of bulky equipment, making them unsuitable for use outside laboratory settings. Recently, there has been an increased focus on miniaturizing these systems into lab-on-a-chip formats, integrating functionalities such as sample preparation, analysis, delivery, and bioassays onto a single chip. Notably, magnetic separators have garnered interest due to their low cost, portability, and compatibility with other microfabricated components. Several studies have demonstrated the use of magnetic force for cell manipulation within microchannels or on planar surfaces. Despite these advancements, current methods still face challenges. They often rely on specific operating conditions that limit throughput and necessitate large sample volumes. Additionally, existing techniques typically allow for the separation of only two cell populations at a time, making it difficult to process more complex mixtures. The fabrication of these devices can also be complicated and may require intricate multi-step processes, while most studies have been conducted under static conditions, which restricts design flexibility.

original_text: We present new infrared photometry for the sample of giant low surface brightness galaxies (LSBGs) studied by van Dokkum et al. (2015) . We use these data to explore their stellar populations and dust content, as well as investigate whether they are consistent with being massive analogues of local dwarf spheroidal galaxies. The LSBGs have been observed in J-(1.25 um), H-(1.65um), Ks-(2.17um), 3.6um, 4.5um, 5.8um & 8.0um bands using Spitzer/IRAC and MIPS cameras on board the Spitzer Space Telescope. Our results show that all but one galaxy has an old age population dominated by red giants at least 1 Gyr older than those found in typical early-type galaxies. This is supported by our analysis which shows that most of them have very little cold dust emission compared to other types of galaxies. These findings suggest that the majority of the LSBGs may be undergoing passive evolution without significant star formation activity over the past few billion years.

rewrite_text: We utilized the Spitzer Infrared Spectrograph (IRS) to study the nearby galaxy pair Mrk 297. The two galaxies are located approximately 3 kpc apart; one is an elliptical galaxy featuring a bright central point source, while the other is a Seyfert 2 galaxy characterized by strong emission lines. We detected several molecular hydrogen emission lines, specifically H$_2$ transitions S(0) through S(20). These emissions span a wide range of spatial scales, from less than 100 pc to more than 500 pc.

original_text: We present new observations of the molecular gas in the central region of the nearby galaxy NGC 891, obtained with the IRAM 30m telescope at 1mm and 3mm wavelengths. The data reveal an extended distribution of dense (n(H2) ~ 104 cm-3), warm (T~50K) molecular gas that is associated with the optical disk of this edge-on spiral galaxy. We find evidence for two distinct components to the molecular gas distribution; one component follows closely the dust lane seen in visible light images while another component extends out into the surrounding intergalactic medium. This latter component has been detected previously by other authors but our higher resolution data allow us to resolve it into individual clouds. In addition we detect several compact sources within the galactic plane which are likely to be young star forming regions. These results suggest that there may exist a significant reservoir of molecular material outside the main body of galaxies such as NGC 891.

rewrite_text: The Large Area Telescope (LAT) on the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope was scheduled to launch in June 2008, with a target launch date of August 7, 2007. The LAT is designed to detect gamma rays ranging from 20 MeV to 300 GeV over a broad field of view (2 steradians), allowing it to observe the entire sky at these energies every three hours. This presentation will explore how supernova remnants can appear as sources of high-energy emissions when viewed by this advanced instrument. Specifically, I will focus on the following questions: - How many remnants should we expect to observe? - What types of remnants have been detected? - What can we learn about particle acceleration mechanisms? - How can we optimize our observations? - What topics will be addressed during our discussion?

original_text: We present the results of our study on the possible existence and stability of terrestrial planets around the star Gliese 581, which is located at about 20 light-years away from Earth. We have performed numerical simulations for different orbital configurations of three hypothetical terrestrial planets with masses ranging between 1 to 10 times that of Earth s mass (1-10 M⊕). Our calculations show that all these systems are dynamically stable over time scales longer than 100 Myr. The most massive planet has an eccentric orbit with e=0.2 and its periastron distance ranges between 0.05 AU and 0.15 AU depending on the initial conditions used. This planet can be considered as a hot Jupiter-like planet because it orbits very close to its host star. However, we find that there exists another region where two or more terrestrial planets may exist stably. In this region, one of them could be a super-Earth-type planet with a mass larger than 5M⊕ but smaller than 8M⊕.

rewrite_text: We present spectropolarimetric observations of the M8 + M9 binary system LHS 1070A and B (GJ 436) using ESPaDOnS at CFHT. The two stars are separated by only 0.1 arcseconds and have been identified as magnetically active for several observations. We find that both stars exhibit circularly polarized emission lines, indicative of Zeeman splitting resulting from their magnetic fields. Furthermore, we detect Stokes V signatures, which suggest the presence of significant linear polarization across all observed spectral lines, likely due to scattering processes within the stars' atmospheres. By combining our dataset with previously published photometric measurements, we determine rotation periods of P_A = 3.6 ± 0.1 days for component A and P_B = 4.2 ± 0.3 days for component B. These periods are notably shorter than those reported in earlier studies that relied solely on photometry. Our findings indicate that the rotation rates of the individual stars are strongly influenced by their effective temperatures and surface gravities.

original_text: We study the magnetic field amplification in supernova remnants (SNRs) due to cosmic ray streaming instability, which is driven by anisotropic diffusion of energetic particles across the mean magnetic field lines. We show that this process can be responsible for the observed level of magnetic fields in young SNRs and may explain their origin. The growth rate of the instability depends on the ratio between the gyrofrequency of relativistic protons and the frequency of plasma waves excited by them. This ratio decreases with time as the number density of accelerated particles increases downstream of the shock front. As a result, the instability saturates at some distance behind the shock front where the magnetic energy density becomes comparable to the kinetic energy density of the flow. In order to estimate the saturation scale we use an analytical model developed recently by Bell et al. (2013) . It allows us to calculate the spectrum of amplified magnetic fluctuations produced by cosmic ray streaming instability.

We are conducting an analysis of ellipsoidal oscillations induced by substellar companions in binary star systems and discussing the prospects for detecting these signals using the Kepler mission. We find that these effects can be observed across a wide range of orbital periods (from 1 to 1000 days) and companion masses (0.1 to 10 MJ). The strength of the signal is proportional to the square of the mass ratio between the star and its companion, potentially reaching up to 0.1% of the total flux at optical wavelengths. For typical parameters in star-planet systems, we estimate that this effect could produce peak-to-peak variations in brightness on the order of 10 mmag or greater. Detecting these variations will require several months of continuous monitoring with the Kepler spacecraft's photometer. However, if such a signal is observed, it would provide strong evidence for the presence of a low-mass planet or companion orbiting the host star. 

Keywords: Ellipsoidal variations, Planetary systems.

We present an analysis of the observed distribution of the magnetic field geometries for stars across the upper main sequence (UMS). We use data on the projected surface magnetic fields and rotation periods, as well as stellar parameters derived by spectroscopic observations, to determine the fraction of oblique rotators among UMS stars with different masses and ages. The results are compared with predictions based on dynamo models that include effects of differential rotation. 
 
 In our sample we find that the fraction of obliquely rotating stars increases towards lower masses: it is about 50% for F-type dwarfs but only 20% for G-type giants. This trend can be explained if the large-scale magnetic fields generated by dynamos operating at the base of convective envelopes become more complex during evolution along the red giant branch. Our findings also suggest that the fraction of obliquely-rotating stars decreases with age. For example, this fraction is higher than 80% for young open clusters such as NGC 2516 or Pleiades, while it drops below 40% for old open clusters like M67.

rewrite_text: We investigate a probabilistic cellular automaton (PCA) that features two species: "mob" and "backyard," which interact in an oscillatory manner. The PCA is structured on a square lattice where each site can be occupied by at most one particle of either type. We find that for certain parameter values, there are stable periodic configurations within this system. These configurations are identified using a mean-field approach. Notably, we discover that the periodicity depends solely on the density of the particles per unit area. This finding is consistent with simulations conducted on finite lattices. Furthermore, we discuss how our results could serve as a model for population dynamics observed in nature. Probabilistic cellular automata have been widely studied due to their potential applications across various fields, including physics, biology, and computer science. They consist of a set of cells arranged in a grid whose states evolve according to specific rules based on their own state and the states of their neighbors. In this study, we focus on a two-species probabilistic cellular automaton comprising N sites on a square lattice \( L = \mathbb{Z}^2 \). Each cell \( i \in L \) can be in one of four states: 0, 1, 2, or 3, corresponding to backyard, patrolling, mob, and prey, respectively. At time \( t = 0 \), all sites are initialized with the following probabilities: \( P(0) = \frac{1}{4} \) for being vacant, \( P(1) = \frac{1}{2} \) for having a prey, and \( P(2) = \frac{1}{4} \) for having a mobster. The evolution of the system is governed by applying transition probabilities simultaneously at time \( t \) and the subsequent time \( t + 1 \).

A maximum likelihood fit is performed on this sample to extract the branching fraction B(D+ ->K-pi+pipi+), which is found to be  _ = (1.55 +/- 0.10 ) x 10-3 , where the uncertainty includes both statistical and systematic contributions. rewrite_text:
The solar cycle is a significant phenomenon in space weather, which can have substantial impacts on Earth and its technological systems. The influence of solar activity has been studied extensively with varying degrees of success. In this study, we employ mean-field models to predict solar cycle 24 based on data from satellite observations. We find that our model accurately predicts the timing of the current solar cycle but underestimates its intensity by approximately one cycle. Our analysis suggests that the Sun will enter a solar minimum phase around 2013-2014, with a subsequent peak expected around 2017-2018. This prediction aligns reasonably well with forecasts made by other researchers. However, it is important to note that there are significant uncertainties associated with these predictions due to the chaotic nature of the solar dynamo. Future research will help address some of these uncertainties. 

Keywords: Space Weather, Solar Dynamo, Mean Field Modeling, Prediction.

original_text: We consider the problem of scheduling multiple bag-of-work applications on parallel machines with non-cooperative tasks, where each task has its own deadline and budget constraints. We propose an algorithm that is based on the idea of partitioning time into intervals such that all tasks in one interval can be scheduled simultaneously without violating their deadlines or budgets. The proposed algorithm uses dynamic programming to find the optimal schedule for these intervals. Finally, we show how this approach can be extended to handle more general cases by using bin-packing techniques. Our experimental results demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing algorithms. In particular, our algorithm outperforms state-of-the-art approaches when there are many small tasks and/or tight deadlines/budgets. rewrite_text: We present the results of our analysis of GRB 080916C, one of the most notable gamma-ray bursts observed by Swift/BAT and Fermi/GBM. We determined that this burst is consistent with originating from off-axis, with an angle θ ~ 60° relative to its line of sight. Notably, we illustrate how the density of such an environment leads to a double-peaked structure in the time-integrated spectrum of the burst.

This work utilized the Near Infrared Camera and Multi-Object Spectrometer (NICMOS) aboard the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) as part of program GO-10775. The data were collected in two filters, F160W and F222M, during three epochs each. We employed these NIR data to measure distances to all four clusters by comparing their observed magnitudes with those predicted using theoretical isochrones. Our findings are consistent, within uncertainties, with previously established distances from optical photometric studies. For Terzan 5, we determined a distance of d = 8.2 ± 0.3 kpc; for Liller 1, d = 7.7 ± 0.4 kpc; for UKS 1, d = 6.8 ± 0.5 kpc; and for Terzan 4, d = 9.0 ± 0.6 kpc.

We present the results of an analysis of all available data on cometary dust tails, including those observed by spacecraft and ground-based telescopes in recent years. We find that most of these objects are associated with Jupiter family comets (JFCs), which have orbital periods less than 20 yr. The JFCs produce dust tails that can be traced for up to several thousand AU along their orbits. These tails appear as narrow streams of material extending outward at high speed from the parent bodies. In some cases they show evidence of being disrupted into multiple fragments or branches. Most of the tail structures we observe are consistent with models where particles are released continuously over time scales ranging from months to thousands of years. However, there is growing observational evidence suggesting that many of these tails may also contain significant amounts of freshly produced dust grains ejected during more recent outburst events. This suggests that the production rate of dust particles in these systems varies significantly both spatially and temporally.

We present an analysis of the distribution of star formation, stellar material, and dust in two nearby edge-on spiral galaxies with prominent bars, namely NGC 1365 and NGC 1530. We utilize high-resolution observations from the Herschel Space Observatory to investigate the structure of the interstellar medium in these galaxies. Our main findings are as follows: 

- In both galaxies, we find that molecular hydrogen is concentrated along the edges of the bar, whereas atomic hydrogen is distributed more uniformly among the stellar regions.
- The star formation rate peaks at the ends of the bar where the density of molecular hydrogen is highest. This suggests that the gravitational torques exerted by the bar can trigger the conversion of molecular gas into new generations of stars.
- The emission associated with polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons shows a clear correlation with areas of active star formation.
- Our data, combined with hydrodynamical simulations, indicate that the observed distribution of the interstellar medium can be explained if the bar potential has effectively driven gas towards its Lindblad resonances.

We study the generic properties of discrete choice models with social influence, where agents make decisions based on their own private information and the choices made by others in their neighborhood.  We show that if there is no correlation between individuals  private signals then any equilibrium must be symmetric across individuals (i.e., all equilibria are identical up to relabeling). If instead there exists some positive correlation among individuals  private signals, we prove that there always exist asymmetric equilibria. Finally, for intermediate levels of correlation, we provide examples showing both types of equilibria can co-exist. These results hold regardless of whether or not agents have common knowledge about each other s payoffs. 
Our analysis relies heavily on recent advances in the theory of global games. The main idea behind our approach is to view an agent s decision problem as a two-stage game played against nature. At stage one, Nature chooses her signal realization; at stage two, she makes her choice conditional on this realized signal.

The analysis includes several examples, including the Ising model in a one-dimensional setup with nearest neighbor interactions or a ring geometry. It is demonstrated that there exists a critical temperature \( T_c \) at which the entropy per spin reaches zero. For temperatures above \( T_c \), the entropy per spin increases linearly with the number of spins \( N \) in the system, while for temperatures below \( T_c \), it decreases exponentially with \( N \). original_text: We report on the electronic structure and magnetic properties of zigzag graphene nanoribbons (ZGNRs) with different edge structures, including hydrogenated ZGNR (H-ZGNR), fluorinated ZGNR (F-ZGNR), oxygenated ZGNR (O-ZGNR), and nitrogen-doped O-ZGNR (N-ZGNR). We find that all these ZGNRs are half-metals except for H-ZGNR which is metallic. The band gaps of F-ZGNR and N-ZGNR increase as compared to those of pristine ZGNR due to the electronegativity difference between carbon atoms at edges and their neighbors. In contrast, the band gap decreases slightly when oxygen replaces one or two carbon atoms at each edge because of charge transfer from oxygen to neighboring carbon atom(s). rewrite_text: We present a distant ultraviolet (UV) image of star formation rates (SFRs) for galaxies within 10 Mpc, using GALEX data, and compare these SFRs with those obtained from optical emission lines. We explore luminosities, continuum fluxes, and UV-optical correlations. Our analysis shows that all estimates are correlated when examining higher luminosity galaxies, but discrepancies arise in low-luminosity dwarf galaxies where some estimates diverge. The scatter between different estimators increases at lower luminosities, primarily due to variations in how they account for dust extinction. Additionally, we find systematic offsets among some of the estimators, which may be attributed to stylistic differences or calibration uncertainties. Finally, we narrowed our sample to investigate the relationship between stellar mass and the star formation rate as obtained through different methods. Our findings suggest that combining multiple indicators leads to a more reliable estimate of SFR rather than depending solely on a single method.

We present results on the role played by the rho meson in describing pion electroproduction data obtained with the CLAS detector at Jefferson Lab (JLab). The analysis is performed within an effective field theory approach, where we use chiral perturbation theory to describe the interaction between pions and nucleons up to next-to-leading order. We then introduce vector-meson degrees of freedom through the hidden gauge formalism. In particular, we consider contributions coming from one-loop diagrams involving rho mesons as well as tree-level processes mediated by rho mesons. Our theoretical framework allows us to study both neutral current reactions such as elastic ep scattering or charged current reactions like single-pion production off protons. Using this model, we are able to reproduce experimental data for all these observables simultaneously. Finally, we discuss how our findings can be used to extract information about the properties of the rho meson. This work was supported by the U.S.

rewrite_text: We have examined how different velocity distribution functions (VDFs) influence the observed line profiles in the solar corona. Our analysis considered both isotropic and anisotropic nonthermal distributions. We found that the presence of nonthermal distributions can significantly alter the shapes of the simulated line profiles compared to those derived from assuming purely Maxwellian distributions. These effects become more pronounced as the temperature decreases and/or the degree of anisotropy increases. Notably, we observed that nonthermal distributions lead to asymmetries between the redshifted and blueshifted wings of the line profiles. These findings imply that using coronal line emissions could help constrain the characteristics of the underlying VDFs. However, this requires careful analysis of the Doppler shifts associated with each emission feature along the line of sight.

We report on the room-temperature ferromagnetism in Mn-doped ZnO thin films grown by pulsed laser deposition (PLD). The Curie temperatures are found to be around 300 K for all samples with different doping levels, which is much higher than that reported previously. We also find that the magnetization increases linearly as the applied field decreases and shows hysteresis loops at low fields. These results indicate that the observed ferromagnetic behavior may originate from exchange coupling between localized spins rather than intrinsic ferromagnetism.

rewrite_text: We explore the orbital dynamics and stability characteristics of oligarchic co-orbitals in the Solar System, specifically bodies with masses comparable to that of Jupiter that have been trapped in orbits close to those of Neptune or Uranus for billions of years. We discuss how these bodies can be identified through their long-term dynamical behaviors as well as their current positions relative to Neptune's orbit. The existence of such bodies is supported by dynamical integrations over timescales of up to 10 billion years using the symplectic N-body code SyMBA. Additionally, we have identified at least two other stable regions where oligarchs may reside. Our findings suggest that the Solar System hosts several dozen oligarchic co-orbitals: at least four trans-Neptunian objects (Pluto, Charon, Haumea, and Makemake) have been identified as belonging to this category; another group of three bodies (Sedna, 2000 CR 105, and 2003 SQ 317) exists around 30 AU; and finally, our simulations indicate that there may be further oligarchs located between 50 and 60 AU.

We propose that the prompt emission of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) is due to high-energy protons, muons and electron-positron pairs produced by ultra-relativistic shocks in GRB jets. The observed MeV-GeV spectrum can be explained as synchrotron radiation emitted by these particles accelerated at the shock front. We show that this model naturally explains why the peak energy of the observed spectrum decreases with time during the prompt phase. In addition, we find that our model predicts an anti-correlation between the duration of the prompt phase and the luminosity of the afterglow for short-hard GRBs. This prediction could be tested using future observations made by Fermi/LAT and Swift/BAT. Introduction -Gamma-ray bursts are brief flashes of high energy photons lasting only milliseconds or less  1  . They have been detected out to redshifts z = 8.2  2  , which implies their total energy output may exceed 10^53 erg  3  . Despite decades of research into the origin of GRBs there remains no consensus on how they work  4  .
The most popular models involve either black holes or neutron stars collapsing into a black hole  5  . However, it has recently become clear that many GRBs do not fit neatly into one category  6  . For example, some GRBs appear to contain two separate pulses  7, 8  while others exhibit extended periods of activity  9  . Furthermore, some GRBs seem to occur when two galaxies merge  10  . These complexities suggest that more than one mechanism might operate simultaneously  11  .

This behavior is modeled using a harmonic term related to the local fluctuating curvature. We find that this model exhibits three distinct phases depending on temperature (T). rewrite_text: We examine a scenario involving multiple users, each equipped with several antennas that transmit data to a single base station (BS) using time-division multiplexing. The BS employs maximum ratio combining (MRC), zero forcing (ZF), or minimum mean square error (MMSE) receivers, depending on whether it possesses perfect channel state information (CSI). We derive expressions for the ergodic rates achieved by this system under Rayleigh fading conditions. Our findings indicate that ZF performs worse than MMSE when the number of users exceeds the number of transmit antennas at the BS; conversely, MMSE shows superior performance in this scenario. Moreover, we observe that the performance gap between these two methods decreases as the number of receive antennas increases. Keywords: Antenna combining, downlink channel, MIMO systems, Rayleigh fading channels, time-division codes.

original_text: We present new characterizations for multivariable functions in the Schur class, which are defined as those analytic on the open unit disk that satisfy certain growth conditions at infinity.  We show how to construct such functions by using an operator-theoretic approach based on the concept of a positive kernel. In particular, we prove that every function in the Schur class can be realized as the transfer function of some stable system with state space dimension equal to its McMillan degree (the number of poles inside the closed unit disk). This result is obtained via a generalization of the classical theorem due to Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov. Finally, we also provide necessary and sufficient conditions under which two given functions belong to the same Schur class. These results have applications in control theory and signal processing. rewrite_text: We present the tenth installment of our research on composition, molecular line emission, dust properties, and energy balance in dense cores with metallicities ranging from 1/100 solar to 1/10,000 solar. Our findings indicate that the temperature decreases by approximately 10 K as core density increases across all studied metallicities (1/100 - 1/10,000 solar). This decrease is faster than predicted by current models, which suggest constant temperatures throughout the cloud. This behavior may be attributed to the increasing significance of surface processes at higher densities. Furthermore, we provide evidence for a substantial depletion of carbon onto grains, even at high metallicities like Z = 1/10,000 solar. Our results suggest that the density above which CO becomes optically thick is strongly dependent on metallicity, with lower metallicities allowing for higher densities compared to their higher metallicity counterparts. Lastly, we find that the observed abundance ratios align with expectations if the clouds were initially chemically enriched by Type II supernovae.

We present new high-resolution (0.5 arcsec) radio continuum observations at 1.4 GHz and 4.8 GHz made with the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA). These data are combined to produce images in Stokes parameters I, Q, U and V which allow us to investigate both total intensity emission as well as linear polarization properties across the face of this nearby spiral galaxy. We find that the polarized emission is concentrated along the brightest regions of the disk where it reaches values up to ~8%. In addition we detect significant circularly polarized emission associated with two supernova remnants located near the center of the galaxy. This work represents an important step towards understanding magnetic field structure on kiloparsec scales within galaxies. It also provides valuable information for future studies aimed at investigating cosmic ray transport processes through galactic disks. 
 
 Keywords: Radio astronomy, Galaxy evolution, Magnetic fields, Polarization

We propose using Forward Stagewise Regression (FSR) for linear models with non-negative outcomes. FSR is an iterative method that sequentially adds one variable at a time until a predefined stopping criterion is satisfied. We demonstrate how FSR can be effectively combined with the monotone Lasso penalty to enhance variable selection, allowing it to retain all relevant predictors while ensuring their significance remains intact. The resulting approach has a similar computational complexity to standard Lasso regression but yields better recovery of coefficients on both simulated datasets and real-world examples compared to traditional analyses of microarray data.

Forward Stagewise Regression (FSR), introduced by Frank & Friedman, operates through an iterative process where in each iteration a variable is added to the existing set of selected features based on its contribution to the objective function. This process continues until it meets a stopping criterion, like reaching a specified number of iterations or achieving a certain level of accuracy. In this study, we concentrate on applying FSR within the framework of linear models with non-negative outcomes. 

For example, if our objective is to identify variables linked to risk factors, it would be logical to focus solely on those predictors that have been shown to increase risk, rather than those that might reduce it. A key advantage of FSR over other variable selection methods, such as stepwise regression, is that it does not rely on any prior parameters for selection. However, FSR does have two significant drawbacks when applied in scenarios with many potential covariates: 1) It may require numerous iterations before the solution converges; 2) There is no guarantee that the final model will include all relevant predictors.

We use a sample of 380,000 LRGs selected to have 0.4 < zphot < 1.0 and Mr < --21.5 + 5logh. The angular correlation function is measured for this sample using the Landy & Szalay estimator on scales between 10  and 100 . To account for redshift space distortions we measure the projected cross-correlation functions wp(rp), where rp = Dproj/ H(z)/H0 , H(z) is the Hubble parameter at redshift z, and H0 is its value today. These measurements are made over a range of transverse separations corresponding to physical scales ranging from 2 h-1 Mpc to 20 h-1 Mpc. In addition, we also measure the real-space two-point correlation function by applying the method developed by Eisenstein et al. (2007) . This measurement is performed only out to a maximum separation of 60 h-1 Mpc due to the limited number density of our galaxy sample.

We report on the measurement of transverse spin asymmetries (SSA) for hadronic dijets at midrapidity in p + p collisions at √sNN = 5.02 TeV, utilizing data collected by the CMS experiment in 2012, corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 2.3 fb⁻¹. The SSAs are analyzed as functions of various kinematic variables, including transverse momentum, rapidity, azimuthal angle between the jets, and event centrality. Our findings indicate no dependence of the asymmetry on any kinematic variable, except for a decrease in the magnitude of the asymmetry with increasing rapidity. We compare our results with theoretical predictions based on perturbative QCD calculations that incorporate higher-order corrections and uncertainties in parton distribution functions. The results are consistent within the reported experimental and theoretical uncertainties, making this the most precise measurement of this observable to date.

Single transverse spin asymmetries have been identified in various experiments involving polarized protons and neutrons, including studies of inclusive pion production, semi-inclusive deep-inelastic scattering, Drell-Yan lepton pair production, prompt photon production, and direct photons. These measurements provide crucial insights into the spin structure of nucleons. Specifically, they can test the validity of factorization theorems that connect hard scattering cross sections to partonic distributions within protons. Furthermore, these observables offer avenues to explore physics beyond the Standard Model. Recent suggestions have indicated that large transverse spin asymmetries might arise from the interference of two amplitudes involving different helicities of quarks, mediated by longitudinally polarized gluons in high-energy collisions. Such effects challenge parity conservation and provide potential evidence for new physics. However, there has only been one prior measurement of transverse spin asymmetries in hadronic dijet production at high energies, conducted at RHIC, where the center-of-mass energy per nucleon-nucleon collision is notably lower at √sNN = 200 GeV.

We present new Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Advanced Camera for Survey (ACS)
coronagraphic observations in visible light and near-infrared wavelengths that reveal an extended dusty disk surrounding the Herbig Ae star HD 100546, which is known to harbor a protoplanetary disk with spiral arms. The ACS coronagraph was used to block out direct stellar radiation at small angular separations from the central star while allowing us to detect scattered light from circumstellar material located farther away. We find evidence for two bright rings of emission separated by ~0.5′′ along the major axis of the disk. These features are most likely due to scattering off large grains or planetesimals orbiting close to their parent stars. 
 
 In addition, we have detected several dark gaps within these bright rings as well as fainter structures extending outward into the outer regions of the disk. Our results suggest that this system may be undergoing planet formation through gravitational interactions between larger bodies such as planets and/or planetesimals.

rewrite_text: We investigate the challenge of finding a stable first-order reduced basis for the solution of a partial differential equation (PDE) using Proper Orthogonal Decomposition (POD). We demonstrate that this can be accomplished by solving a sequence of unstable eigenvalue problems associated with Chebyshev polynomials, which are derived from the original POD Galerkin formulation and its adjoint formulation. Our proposed method is illustrated through two numerical examples, where we show that it provides a more stable solution compared to standard greedy algorithms. This research was supported by the EPSRC grant EP/K034494/1. Modeling techniques have long been recognized as efficient strategies for reducing computational complexity when simulating complex systems described by PDEs. One specific approach for constructing the reduced basis employs Proper Orthogonal Decomposition (POD), where the solution \( u (x, t) \in \mathbb{R}^N \) of a PDE is approximated in a low-dimensional subspace spanned by a set of orthonormal functions \( \{ \phi_i(x) \}_{i=1}^N \).

original_text: We present deep imaging data for the nearby dwarf spheroidal galaxy, Hercules (dSph), obtained with the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT). The new observations are used to study the structure and stellar populations in this system. We find that the surface brightness profile is well described by an exponential function over most of its extent but shows evidence for a break at about 30 arcsec radius. This feature may be associated with tidal disruption or stripping due to interactions between Hercules and other galaxies. Using colour-magnitude diagrams we show that there exists two distinct components within Hercules; one which has been stripped off and another which appears to have remained intact. These results suggest that Hercules was once more extended than it currently is today. Finally, using our photometric catalogue we measure the line-of-sight velocity dispersion as a function of projected distance from the centre of Hercules. Our measurements indicate that the central region of Hercules exhibits higher values compared to those measured further out.

rewrite_text: We present our analysis of archival Chandra data for the cluster Sersic 159-03, which exhibits excess X-ray emission below 1 keV, known as the soft excess. We determined that this feature is inconsistent with thermal bremsstrahlung or line emissions from any known atomic species, leading us to conclude that it may be attributed to other mechanisms, such as inverse Compton scattering involving relativistic electrons. The observed spectrum can be modeled as a combination of a power-law component and a blackbody at a temperature of kT = 0.2 keV; however, we found that this model is statistically inadequate when compared to more physically grounded models that incorporate both bremsstrahlung and inverse Compton processes. Notably, we show that the inclusion of a second blackbody component significantly improves the fit, surpassing the results from simpler models. Utilizing these findings, we estimate the total luminosity of the soft excess to be Lx ~ 10^45 erg s^-1 within a radius of R500 = 2 Mpc. This luminosity is comparable to the bolometric luminosities inferred from several nearby galaxy clusters as measured through their synchrotron emissions.

original_text: The first stars in the universe were born out of primordial gas clouds, which collapsed under their own gravity to form dense cores that ignited nuclear fusion and became hot white dwarfs.  The most massive of these early stars are now known as Population III (PopIII) stars.   In this work we present results for PopIII star formation using cosmological hydrodynamic simulations with radiative transfer calculations performed on an adaptive mesh refinement grid.  We find that PopIII stars can be formed by direct collapse of metal-free gas clouds at redshifts z > 20.  These stars have masses M * = 100 - 1000M⊙ and lifetimes t < 10Myr.  They evolve into black holes or pair-instability supernovae after consuming all available fuel within their convective envelopes.  Our results show that PopIII stars may contribute significantly to reionization of the intergalactic medium around redshift z ~ 15.

The objective of this study is to investigate whether there is a relationship between the distributions of firm size and profitability, using data from Japanese firms spanning the years 1971 to 2000. The analysis reveals that both firm size and profitability adhere to a log-normal distribution, albeit with different parameters. Additionally, it was observed that firm size growth follows Gibrat's Law, while profitability growth does not. This indicates that the connection between firm size and profitability can be attributed to the fact that they have distinct underlying distributions. Finally, there is evidence suggesting that the processes influencing firm size have evolved over time, and we also found indications that the factors affecting profitability have changed. These results imply that the relationship between firm size and profitability may vary over time due to their different underlying distributions. 

Keywords: Firm Size Distribution, Profitability Distribution.

original_text: The Spitzer Bright Field (SBF) is an all-sky survey at 3.6, 4.5, 5.8 & 8 microns carried out by the Infrared Array Camera on board the Spitzer Space Telescope.  The SBF was designed to provide deep infrared photometry for extragalactic studies in order to complement existing optical surveys such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.   This dataset contains images taken with IRAC channel 1 (3.6 micron), channel 2 (4.5 micron), channel 3 (5.8 micron) and channel 4 (8 micron). Each image has been processed using the MOPEX software package developed by the Spitzer Science Center. These images are available through the NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database (NED).  For more information about this project please see http://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/docs/sbf/sbf-intro.html

We propose that if an operator is adjointable, then it has a dense range in its domain. We illustrate how this result can be applied to provide an alternative proof of the Magajna-Schweitzer theorem, which addresses the existence of self-adjoint operators for densely defined operators with equal deficiency indices. Let \( H \) be a Hilbert space over \( \mathbb{C} \). An operator \( T: D(T) \subseteq H \to H \) is said to have a dense range (or simply to be dense), where \( D(T) \) is the domain of \( T \), if for every vector \( x \in H \), there exists a sequence \( \{ x_n \}_{n \in \mathbb{N}} \) such that \( \lim_{n \to \infty} \| x_n - Tx \| = 0 \). In other words, the range of \( T \) intersects every non-empty open set in \( H \). The dense range theorem states that any adjointable operator necessarily has a dense range. 

THEOREM 1.1: If \( T: D(T) \subseteq H \to H \) is adjointable, then \( R(T^*) = D(T) \).

original_text: We present new observations at 1.4 GHz with the VLA of polarized emission from the nearby (7 Mpc) grand-design spiral galaxy NGC 6946. The data reveal several interesting features that are not seen in previous radio continuum studies of this galaxy. We find that:  -The total intensity distribution is dominated by two bright nuclear components separated by about 2 kpc along an axis perpendicular to the main galactic disk.  -There is no evidence for large-scale ordered fields on kiloparsec scales as previously reported.   -The polarization vectors show a clear pattern of alternating directions across the central region of the galaxy which we interpret as a signature of a global magnetic field reversal between the two nuclei.  -The rotation measure map shows a ring-like structure around each nucleus where the RM changes sign indicating a change in direction of the line-of-sight component of the magnetic field. This feature may be related to the so-called depolarization rings observed in other galaxies but it could also result from beam smearing effects or from intrinsic Faraday dispersion within the source itself.  -The polarized intensity distribution reveals a number of extended structures including a prominent southern arm extending over more than 10 kpc towards the south-east.

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of the X-ray spectrum and variability properties of Mrk 509, one of the brightest Seyfert galaxies observed by XMM-Newton. We find that its 0.5 - 10 keV continuum can be well described by a power law with Γ = 2.1 ± 0.2 (χ² / dof = 111 / 101), along with reflection modeled as a PEXRAV component with R = 0.7 - 1.0 and NH = 10 - 23×10²² cm⁻². The parameters we obtained are consistent within the errors with those from earlier Chandra observations. No significant spectral changes were detected between different epochs analyzed from multiple observations. However, we did observe strong variability across all energy bands during our observation. In particular, there was a significant increase of a factor of 3 in the photon count rate in the soft band over approximately 20 ks, accompanied by a slower decline towards the initial observation. This behavior may indicate that the source is in a state where the accretion luminosity is fluctuating rapidly due to some instability or perturbation.

We present an improved quantum hard-sphere ground-state equation-of-state (EOS) for the description of dense matter in astrophysics and nuclear physics, which is based on the exact solution to the Schrödinger equation with a repulsive delta-function potential. The EOS has been derived by solving numerically the corresponding integral equations using the method of successive iterations. We have also obtained analytical expressions for the pressure and energy density as functions of the number density at zero temperature. Our results are compared with those calculated previously within various approximations such as the virial expansion up to second order, the Carnahan-Starling approximation, and the Percus-Yevick approximation. It turns out that our new EOS agrees well with these previous calculations over wide ranges of densities and temperatures. In particular, it reproduces very accurately the low-density limit where the ideal gas law holds exactly. 
 
 Keywords: Equation of state

rewrite_text: We discuss the patterns of supersymmetry breaking for vector multiplets that transform under non-adjoint representations of SO(N). We observe that there are two distinct classes of theories, based on whether the representation is real or not. In particular, we demonstrate how to construct explicit examples with N = 1 and N = 2 supersymmetries that spontaneously break all of their supersymmetries. Theories involving adjoint matter fields can be retrieved as limiting cases by taking appropriate limits. This research was partially supported by NSF grant PHY-0456735. Since its introduction over thirty years ago, supersymmetry (SUSY) has played a significant role in many aspects of the Standard Model. It offers an elegant solution to the hierarchy problem between the weak scale and the Planck scale, while also providing insights into gauge coupling unification. In recent years, it has become clear that SUSY must be broken to align with experimental results. However, despite extensive efforts over several decades, a fully satisfactory framework for spontaneous SUSY breaking has yet to be established. One promising approach involves using supergravity to generate soft terms that can lead to SUSY breaking. Another avenue is to explore higher-dimensional theories where SUSY is either softly broken or spontaneously broken via boundary conditions. Additionally, there is ongoing research into models based on local symmetries, such as gauged or global SUSY.

original_text: The aim of this book is to provide an overview on the state-of-the-art in on-line condition monitoring and fault diagnosis for industrial processes, with special emphasis on computational intelligence techniques such as neural networks (NNs), fuzzy logic systems (FLS) or evolutionary algorithms (EAs). The book covers both theoretical aspects and practical applications of these methods. It also discusses some recent advances in intelligent sensor technologies that are essential for successful implementation of on-line condition monitoring schemes. This book will be useful not only for researchers but also for engineers who want to apply computational intelligence techniques into their own research work. Contents include:  Chapter 1: Introduction to On-line Condition Monitoring.  Chapter 2: Intelligent Sensors for On-line Condition Monitoring.  Chapters 3-7: Neural Networks for Fault Diagnosis.  Chapters 8-10: Fuzzy Logic Systems for Fault Diagnosis.   Chapters 11-13: Evolutionary Algorithms for Fault Diagnosis.   ...

rewrite_text: The Standard Model (SM) predicts the existence of several heavy particles, such as the W and Z bosons, which mediate weak interactions between quarks and leptons. Experiments conducted at the Large Hadron Collider have sought to identify these particles in their datasets, but no conclusive evidence has been found to date. In this study, we focus on analyzing heavy vector-like fermions that decay into pairs of charged or neutral gauge bosons, using proton-proton collision data collected by the ATLAS experiment during Run 1, at a center-of-mass energy of √s = 7 TeV, with an integrated luminosity of 4.6 fb⁻¹. We consider two benchmark models: one based on the SU(2)_L x U(1)_Y gauge group and another based on SO(10). For both models, we perform detailed simulations to assess signal acceptance and background interference. Based on our analysis, we establish limits on the product of the cross section and branching ratio for different masses ranging from 0.5 TeV to 3 TeV.

original_text: We present an analysis of all known short-period cataclysmic variables (CVs) in which we find that most systems have orbital periods longer than 3 hrs and are dominated by SW Sex stars, while those with shorter periods tend to be AM Her binaries. We show that this dichotomy is consistent with theoretical predictions for the evolution of CVs driven by angular momentum loss via gravitational radiation. The observed distribution of orbital periods can also be explained if there exists a minimum period below which no CVs exist due to magnetic braking. This result has important implications on our understanding of how CVs evolve towards shorter orbital periods. Cataclysmic Variables (CVs), interacting binary star systems consisting of a white dwarf primary accreting matter from its low-mass companion through Roche lobe overflow, are among the best studied classes of close binary stars. They provide unique opportunities to study many aspects of astrophysics such as stellar structure and evolution, mass transfer processes, nuclear burning at high temperatures, and relativistic effects near compact objects. In particular, they offer insights into the formation mechanisms of both single and double degenerate white dwarfs, the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae.

rewrite_text: We analyze the stability of viscous stagnation points for a medium characterized by viscosity and heat conduction by employing the method of characteristics. We find that if the initial data are sufficiently regular, there exists a unique global solution to this problem that converges exponentially fast to the inviscid solution (the Rankine-Hugoniot condition) as time approaches infinity. If the initial data is compactly supported, we demonstrate that the solution remains uniformly bounded on any finite time interval [0, T]. Finally, under certain conditions on the initial data, we establish exponential decay of solutions as time progresses. The results we present here generalize previous findings that were limited to the case where the density function (ρ) behaves as ρ ∝ γ with 0 < γ ≤ 1. Viscous flows play a crucial role in various dynamic system phenomena, such as fluid dynamics or wave propagation. original_text: We have studied the origin of the 60 K plateau in YBa2Cu3Ox by measuring the specific heat and magnetic susceptibility as functions of temperature, field strength, oxygen content x, and doping level p. The results show that the 60 K anomaly is due to an antiferromagnetic transition at TAF = 56 K for x= 0.6 but disappears with increasing x or decreasing p. We also find that the low-temperature upturns observed in both C/T and χ(T) are caused by impurity phases which appear when x > 0.65.  These results suggest that the 60 K anomality may be related to the appearance of these impurities. In addition we found that the high-field magnetization shows a sharp increase below 50 K indicating that there exists another phase transition near this temperature. This new phase has been identified as a charge density wave state (CDW). Finally, our data indicate that the CDW state appears only if the sample contains some amount of impurities.

We introduce a hierarchical approach to describe the state and environment of coupled systems in Mongolia's flu beds using a set of coupled equations, which we term the Hierarchy of Density Tensors (HDT). The HDT is developed by employing the Nakajima-Zwanzig projection operator technique on the von Neumann equation associated with the total system. This framework allows us to investigate how decoherence impacts the system over extended timescales. Notably, it offers insights into the spectrum of system operators related to the off-diagonal elements of the density tensor, as well as the stationary states attained in the long-time limit. As an example, we apply our formalism to explore the dissipative spin-boson model with Ohmic dissipation, comparing the results against simulations derived from the Quantum Monte Carlo Wavefunction method.

**I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK**

Understanding the behavior of macroscopic systems under the influence of their environments has been a fundamental question in physics since its inception. This issue becomes increasingly complex when considering many-body systems such as those found in condensed matter and quantum field theories, where the number of degrees of freedom can be quite large. A powerful strategy for addressing these challenges involves studying the state of the system conditioned on specific measurements made on its environmental degrees of freedom. In recent years, there have been multiple efforts aimed at establishing efficient frameworks to describe the dynamics of these systems. Among these, the Hierarchy of Density Matrices (HDM) has emerged as a promising alternative due to its capacity to account for non-Markovian effects. Nevertheless, while the HDM can provide accurate descriptions of finite-time evolutions, it struggles to correctly capture the asymptotic behavior of systems. To address this issue, we present a modified formulation of the HDM, leading to the recovered Hierarchy of Density Tensors.

We test whether the observed value of lambda is consistent with the prediction that it should be equal to one third of the square root of the number density of galaxies in the universe today, as suggested by Tegmark et al. (2006) . We find no evidence against this hypothesis using data on galaxy luminosity functions at redshifts z = 0.1, 1.0 and 3.5 taken from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS). The predicted values are obtained assuming that the dark energy equation-of-state parameter w is constant over time. This assumption may not hold if there exists an interaction between dark matter and dark energy. However, we show that even allowing w to vary significantly does not affect our results. 
 
 In addition, we use the WMAP 5-year cosmological parameters to calculate the expected temperature anisotropy power spectrum of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) given the current best-fit model. We compare these theoretical predictions with measurements made by the Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe (WMAP), finding good agreement across all multipole moments up to lmax = 1000.

We are undertaking a study to obtain spectroscopic data from nine cataclysmic variables (CVs) using the HIRES spectrograph on the Keck I telescope in Hawaii, and we will compare these findings with data from another ten CVs. Our observations reveal that all CVs exhibit double-peaked emission lines, which are distinct features indicative of accretion disks surrounding the white dwarfs. The line profiles show significant changes during outbursts, where the mass accretion rate increases by several magnitudes compared to quiescent states. Additionally, we observed absorption features at redshifted velocities in some cases, suggesting the presence of a third body or mass inflow into the disk. These observations provide critical constraints for theoretical models of CV evolution.

Keywords: Accretion Disk, Double-Peaked Emission Lines, White Dwarf, Cataclysmic Variables

1. Introduction  
Cataclysmic Variables (CVs), often referred to as dwarf novae, are binary systems consisting of a white dwarf and a late-type star filling its Roche lobe. Mass is transferred through the Lagrangian point L1 onto the surface of the white dwarf, forming an accretion disk around the compact star. This process leads to outbursts that occur due to thermal instabilities in the accretion disk, resulting in fluctuations in luminosity over time scales ranging from hours to several days. During these outbursts, the accretion rate surges by several orders of magnitude, causing strong emissions and high temperatures in the outer regions of the disk, while the light from the system may diminish due to obscuration effects. The variety of CVs offers valuable insights into accretion dynamics, magnetic fields, and angular momentum transport. Moreover, CVs can serve as distance indicators and probes of galactic structure. 

2. Observations & Data Reduction  
Our sample comprises nine CVs, which were observed between 2004 and 2007 using the High Resolution Echelle Spectrometer (HIRES) mounted on the 10-meter Keck I telescope located on Mauna Kea.

original_text: We propose that the dark matter in our universe is composed of milli-charged particles, which are neutral under electromagnetism but carry an electric charge on the order of 10^(-6)e (electrons). We show how this scenario can be realized within the context of the Standard Model by introducing a new gauge boson with mass mX ~ 1TeV/c2 into the theory through the Stueckelberg extension to the Standard Model. The introduction of such a massive vector particle leads to modifications to the usual Feynman rules for charged fermions interacting via photons or gluons. In particular, we find that the cross section for scattering between two milli-charged particles mediated by a photon is suppressed compared to the case where there were no additional massive vector boson present. This suppression results in a reduction of the number density of milli-charged dark matter particles at late times as they annihilate more slowly than their un-massive counterparts.
