We present a study of the magneto-rotational instability (MRI) in protoplanetary disks, based on the idea that the disks can be divided into two regions with distinct physical properties. The inner region is characterized by high density and temperature, while the outer region is less dense but hotter than the surrounding material. Our findings demonstrate how this division helps us explain many observed characteristics of MRI-driven turbulence in accretion disks around young stars. Specifically, we found that: 
- The growth rate of the fastest-growing modes decreases significantly at smaller radii due to the properties of the inner region.
- The radial profile of turbulent viscosity follows the distribution of magnetic field strength.
- The efficiency of angular momentum transport increases substantially at larger radii due to a rapid rise in surface density.
- The calculated mass accretion rates are consistent with those inferred from observations of T Tauri stars.

The PVLAS collaboration has recently reported results on light-by-light scattering in vacuum, which are inconsistent with Standard Model predictions.  In this note we discuss possible interpretations of these data within the framework of quantum field theory and string theory. We argue that the most natural interpretation is to assume that the observed effect arises due to new particles coupling to photons via an effective dimension-8 operator. The required mass scale for such particles can be as low as 10 GeV or even lower if one assumes that they couple only weakly to ordinary matter. If confirmed by further experiments, these observations would have profound implications both for particle physics phenomenology and cosmological models. The PVLAS collaboration has recently announced their measurement of light-by-light scattering in vacuo  1  . This process violates parity conservation at tree level and thus cannot occur in the Standard Model (SM)  2  , but it could arise through loop effects  3  .
In particular, the authors report observing a signal consistent with the SM prediction  4

The NIR polarization patterns correlate with those observed in the optical range, suggesting that they originate from light scattered by an illuminating source situated behind the dense core of the molecular cloud. We have identified evidence of two distinct regions along our line of sight to this nebula; one is associated with the brightest section, while the other displays lower polarization levels but shows polarized flux at longer wavelengths. These findings indicate that there may be multiple sources contributing to the observed emission. Additionally, we have detected several absorption features that may be attributed to ices in the vicinity of the nebula. Our observations also indicate a potential outflow cavity, as evidenced by blueshifted CO emission lines. This research was funded by NASA under grant HST-GO-11775.0-A from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which operates under NASA contract NAS5-26555.

We present an explicit expression for the irreducible form of the metric variation of the action term in sixth order gravity, which is valid to all orders in perturbation theory. We also show that this result can be used to derive an approximate expression for the stress energy tensor of the gravitational field. The results are applied to study the evolution of cosmological perturbations during inflation driven by a scalar field with non-canonical kinetic term. In particular we find that the non-Gaussianity generated at second order in perturbation theory does not vanish even if the background geometry is exactly de Sitter space-time. This implies that the bispectrum produced by such models cannot be described solely in terms of local shape functions as it was previously thought.

However, despite these efforts, our understanding of the physical consequences of these theories remains incomplete due to technical difficulties associated with the analysis of their solutions. One of the main obstacles comes from the fact that the equations of motion derived from these actions contain derivatives of arbitrarily high order, making them difficult or impossible to solve analytically. A way out of this problem consists in expanding the fields around some fixed background solution and truncating the resulting series expansion after a finite number of terms. Although this approach allows one to obtain useful information about the dynamics of the system under consideration, it fails to capture important features like back-reaction effects between different modes of the same field or interactions among different fields. For example, in the case of inflationary cosmologies based on higher derivative gravity, the truncated perturbative expansions do not reproduce correctly the observed level of primordial non-Gaussianities .

We present an analysis of data collected by the Swift satellite during its second observation phase, which ran from February 2005 to January 2007, focusing on gamma-ray bursts (GRBs). Our findings indicate that GRB 050904 at redshift z = 6.3 is the most distant GRB observed so far in the electromagnetic spectrum. The prompt emissions from this burst were detected across more than four orders of magnitude, ranging from radio waves to X-rays. GRB 050904 also exhibited one of the highest fluences recorded for any GRB to date. Additionally, we report on another notable event, GRB 080913, whose afterglow showed variability on time scales as short as one minute. These findings are discussed in the context of current models for GRB production. 

Keywords: Gamma-ray bursts, high-redshift universe, afterglows, Swift satellite. 

Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), characterized by brief flashes of intense gamma radiation lasting only milliseconds, have now been detected at redshifts exceeding six. Their extreme luminosities make them excellent tools for probing the distant universe, although much about their origins remains unknown. Launched in November 2004, the Swift satellite is equipped with three instruments capable of detecting GRBs across the entire electromagnetic spectrum: the Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) detects GRBs via X-rays and/or optical emissions; the Ultraviolet/Optical Telescope (UVOT) observes the afterglow in the ultraviolet and optical ranges; and the X-ray Telescope (XRT) monitors the afterglow's decay. Here, we describe our initial findings derived from the observations made during this second operational phase.

**Burst Alert Telescope Observations of GRB 050904**

On September 5, 2006, the Burst Alert Telescope triggered on a bright source at coordinates RA = 05h54m36.6s, Dec = -69d21m59.6s. Follow-up observations determined this event to be a significant case among GRBs, as its peak photon rate reached approximately 2 × 10^4 photons s^-1 cm^-2 in the 15-150 keV range, lasting about...

We present 8.4 GHz Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) images and light curves for the supernova remnant (SNR) associated with the Type IIb supernova SN2004et, which exploded in the nearby spiral galaxy NGC 6946 on 2004 September 24 UT1. The radio emission is dominated by two bright components separated by ~0.5 arcsec at all epochs observed between 2005 January and 2007 December. We find that both components are expanding with velocities of ~5000 km/s, consistent with previous estimates based on single-dish data. However, we also detect significant proper motions of ~1000 km/s for each component over this period. These results suggest an age of about 3 years for the SNR, implying a distance to NGC 6946 of 4 Mpc. This value is significantly smaller than previously estimated distances to this object using other methods. Our measurements provide new constraints on models of core-collapse supernovae.

We study the gravitational field generated by a massive scalar point source moving on an equatorial circular geodesic around a Schwarzschild black hole, and we evolve it numerically in two spatial dimensions (2+1) with the puncture method. We find that the perturbation is dominated by a single mode which grows exponentially as time goes on. The growth rate agrees well with the prediction based on quasinormal modes for this system. This result suggests that the exponential growth may be related to the instability of the scalar field near the horizon. In addition, we also show that the amplitude of the growing mode decreases rapidly when the mass of the scalar field increases. Finally, we discuss possible applications of our results to astrophysical phenomena such as gamma-ray bursts.

rewrite_text: We present a study on the controlled interaction between a trapped atom and a singly charged ion in a Paul trap, where both particles are spatially separated by several micrometers. The particles can be manipulated along a path that connects them through electrostatic fields generated by external electrodes in the trapping chamber. We demonstrate that this setup allows us to control the collision rate and their interaction parameters. This arrangement paves the way for investigating fundamental processes such as elastic scattering or charge exchange. Furthermore, we explore how to leverage this configuration to realize entanglement between two trapped atoms through a shared interaction mediated by a common gate. Quantum protocols require scalable architectures based on multiple qubits. One promising avenue for developing such devices involves using neutral atoms stored in optical lattices; however, this approach faces challenges due to limited coherence times attributed to spontaneous emission. An alternative strategy is storing atomic qubits in ensembles of trapped ions, though these also experience significant decoherence issues due to heating. To address these challenges, hybrid approaches have been proposed that combine elements from both strategies. In this context, the storage of quantum states takes place in a well-defined manner, while a large number of neutral atoms act as flying qubits. A crucial aspect of implementing these schemes is the ability to achieve high-fidelity entanglement between both types of qubits. Recent experimental results have shown the feasibility of entangling two neutral atoms via a shared interaction. However, to achieve this goal, the atoms must be precisely aligned with one another before being released into free space.

We find that all these quantities are well described by single-parameter scaling relations as functions of radius r normalized by the virial radius Rvir.  The best-fit values of the normalization parameters depend on redshift but not significantly so; we therefore adopt fixed values based on our results for the two most distant clusters (z = 0.2 and 0.3) which yield good fits to the other six clusters. The electron number density ne(r) increases inwardly toward the center of each cluster until reaching a peak value near r ~ 0.1r200 where r200 denotes the radius enclosing an average overdensity of 200 times the critical density of the universe. Beyond this point, ne(r) declines slowly or remains roughly constant depending on the cluster. 4. The central temperatures T0 inferred from spectral fitting range from 6 keV to 12 keV, while those obtained directly from the deprojected temperature profile lie in the range 7-15 keV. These differences may be caused by non-thermal components such as AGN jets and/or magnetic fields.

rewrite_text: The compositions of type II Cepheid stars are examined using high-resolution spectra obtained from the Subaru/HDS, Keck/HIRES, VLT/UVES, and McDonald/DEIMOS spectrographs. Our findings indicate that all stars in our sample have solar or super-solar metallicities (Fe/H > +0.2). In addition to Fe I lines, we also analyzed Mg I triplet lines to ascertain their atmospheric parameters more precisely. For some of these stars, we observed significant enhancements of CNO elements as well as s-process elements; however, no clear correlation was found between the abundance patterns and pulsation periods. These results suggest that the observed abundance anomalies may be due to mass transfer during binary interactions rather than internal processes associated with pulsations. This research was supported by JSPS Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research on Priority Areas No. 16071203.

We study the conformational properties of one- and two-component bottlebrush polymers in good solvent conditions by means of Monte Carlo (MC) simulations, using an off-lattice model with freely jointed chains. We compare our results for the radius of gyration Rg(N), end-to-end distance Ree(N), persistence length P(N), and contour length Lc(N) as functions of chain length N to those obtained within the framework of the worm-like-chain (WLC) theory. The WLC approach is found to be very accurate at predicting the scaling behavior of these quantities over several orders of magnitude in chain lengths. In particular, we find that the persistence length scales linearly with the number of monomers per backbone segment, which agrees well with recent experimental findings on bottle-brush polyelectrolytes.

We focus on the phenomenon of slow wave resonance (SWR) in multilayered structures composed of anisotropic layers, each defined by its own permittivity tensor and thickness. Our analysis indicates that SWR can only occur if the principal axes of the permittivity tensors are aligned within each layer. In this context, we derive expressions for the dispersion relation between the recovered slow waves and the Bloch wavenumber \( k_x \). These findings offer guidance for the design of multilayered systems that exhibit pronounced SWR effects at lower frequencies.

**Keywords:** Slow wave resonance; Anisotropy; Multilayer structure; Dispersion relation.

1. **Introduction**
Periodic multilayers, consisting of alternating thin films made from different materials, have garnered significant interest in recent years due to their remarkable properties. These properties include high reflectance, coupled refraction, and nonlinear optical responses, making them promising candidates for various applications, such as optoelectronic devices and photovoltaics. Recent studies have illustrated that multilayers comprising anisotropic layers can give rise to intriguing electromagnetic phenomena, particularly slow wave resonance (SWR). This phenomenon is observed when the group velocity of the Bloch waves approaches zero within certain layers, leading to the emergence of a large effective refractive index, \( n_{\text{eff}} = c / v_{\text{ph}} \), where \( c \) is the speed of light in a vacuum and \( v_{\text{ph}} \) is the phase velocity of the propagating Bloch wave. This results in transmission spectra characterized by narrow stop bands, which are highly desirable for various practical applications. Despite extensive studies on SWR in multilayers, several crucial questions remain about the conditions necessary for this phenomenon to occur. For instance, experimental findings have shown that the presence of poorly aligned anisotropic layers can completely eliminate SWR, even when other layers are well-aligned. The Variable Star One-Shot project is an open-source software package for the analysis of astronomical data.  It was developed by members of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in collaboration with researchers at other institutions around the world.   The goal of this project is to provide a single tool that can be used to analyze all types of astronomical data sets, including photometric time series, spectroscopic observations, images, etc., using state-of-the-art techniques such as image subtraction, cross correlation, period finding algorithms, spectral line fitting, etc.    This software has been released under the GNU General Public License v3.0 and is available on GitHub at: https://github.com/VariableStar/one-shot-astro .
One Shot Astro includes several tools which are useful for analyzing large amounts of astronomical data quickly and efficiently.   These include one-shot-datacleaner , which performs automated quality control checks on raw data files;   one-shot-mosaic , which creates mosaicked images from multiple dithered exposures;  one-shot-astrometry , which determines astrometric solutions for individual frames or entire mosaic images;    one-shot-photometry , which measures fluxes and/or magnitudes for stars across a field-of-view;    one-shot-pipeline , which automates the process of running these various tasks together into a pipeline;    one-shot-wikimapia , which allows users to create custom sky maps based on their own catalogs of objects.     In addition to these core packages, there are also many additional modules available through the one-shot-astro repository which allow users to perform more specialized analyses, such as:    one-shot-catalog , which provides access to a variety of different astrophysical databases via SQL queries;    one-shot-fastphot , which uses machine learning methods to measure stellar

rewrite_text: We present the results of our analysis on the mass-to-light ratio (M/L) of Lyman alpha emitters (LAEs), utilizing data obtained from Subaru/Suprime-Cam in the vicinity of four quasars with redshifts ranging from 5.7 to 6.6. We derived photometric redshifts for LAE candidates within a narrow range around each quasar's emission line redshift. The M/L ratios were determined using spectral energy distributions (SEDs) for individual galaxies as well as stacked populations. Our key findings are: (1) For individual LAEs, we determined that the average log of the mass-to-light ratio (M/L_B) is approximately -1.8 dex across the luminosities sampled in our study. This indicates that most LAEs have low stellar masses compared to typical Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs). (2) Stacking the data shows that the average M/L_B increases with higher luminosity bins. Specifically, the highest luminosity bin has an average log (M/L_B) of -1.3 ± 0.4 dex, suggesting a mass that is about three times lower than what would be expected if these objects were processed by standard galaxy evolution models.

We present an algorithm to compute the Jones polynomial using three quantum wires and one ancilla qubit, which is based on the idea that the Jones polynomial can be computed by evaluating the Tutte polynomial at 1. We show how this approach leads naturally to a circuit with O(n) gates in depth O(log n), where n denotes the number of crossings in the knot diagram. The main ingredient of our construction are two new families of unitary operators acting on tensor products of Hilbert spaces associated with graphs. These operators generalize the swap operator and have applications beyond computing the Jones polynomial. In particular we use them to construct efficient quantum circuits for other problems such as counting perfect matchings or finding maximum flows.

rewrite_text: We present observations from INTEGRAL regarding the black hole candidate GRO J1655-40 during its 2005 outburst, which is associated with Nova Muscae 1991. The source was monitored in the 20-100 keV energy range for approximately 100 days, starting around MJD 53000 and concluding at MJD 53300. Our analysis utilized data from both ISGRI and SPI instruments aboard the INTEGRAL satellite. In addition to the typical spectral shape described by a power law followed by an exponential cutoff, we identified two distinct features in the spectrum. One of these has been previously noted by other researchers, although its significance remains debated. The second feature emerges only when analyzing the complete dataset with all three models considered: power law plus exponential cutoff, a simple power law, or a Comptonization model. This feature could either represent a reflection hump produced by cold material surrounding the central X-ray source or a broad iron line at approximately 6.4 keV.

rewrite_text: We investigate the merger of two white dwarfs (WDs) with varying masses and spin configurations using fully general relativistic hydrodynamic simulations. Our findings indicate that, in most scenarios examined (except when one WD is substantially more massive), the merger results in an ellipsoidal remnant surrounded by a thick accretion disk. The final mass of this merged system varies between 0.6 and 1.1 solar masses, depending on the initial conditions. In some cases, we also observe the formation of a thin accretion flow around the remnant core. Additionally, we note that the amount of mass ejected during the merger process can vary significantly based on the total mass of the binary system, with outcomes ranging from minimal to substantial ejecta. Finally, we compare our results with existing studies to assess the implications for future research. Keywords: White dwarfs.

In addition to this, we also find that the band gap decreases rapidly as increasing pressure up to 30 GPa but then becomes almost constant above 40 GPa. In this talk I will discuss some recent results about lattice models that provide an alternative approach to studying these theories. We present the tenth spectral analysis of all Swift gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) with measured redshifts and durations shorter than 2 seconds, utilizing data collected by the Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) on board the Swift satellite. Our findings indicate that most of these bursts are characterized by blackbody emission accompanied by a power-law spectrum at higher energies. We discovered that the temperature of the blackbody emission is correlated with the peak energy of the spectrum. This correlation can be interpreted as the result of photospheric radius expansion during the early phases of the burst. Additionally, we found another correlation between the blackbody temperature \( T_{bb} \), the isotropic luminosity \( L_{iso} \), and the duration \( t_{90} \). The presence of these correlations suggests that the processes responsible for the blackbody emission may also influence other properties of the bursts. 

Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), which were discovered over 40 years ago, have been extensively studied, yet many questions remain unresolved. A significant inquiry pertains to the origin of the prompt emission in GRBs. It has been proposed that this emission could arise from internal shocks or magnetic reconnection within colliding relativistic outflows, or alternatively, from external shocks interacting with the surrounding medium. Another important issue is whether GRBs can be considered standard candles; if they are, one would expect that different bursts should exhibit variations in temporal and spectral characteristics. However, observations indicate a significant diversity among GRBs. Lastly, the nature of the progenitors of GRBs remains largely unknown.

Social networks are ubiquitous in our daily life, and have been studied extensively by researchers across many disciplines. However, the analysis of social network data is often challenging due to its complexity. In this work we propose NodeTrix, an efficient hybrid representation that can be used to analyze large-scale social networks efficiently. We show how NodeTrix can be applied to solve several important problems including community detection, link prediction, node classification, and influence maximization. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that NodeTrix outperforms state-of-the-art approaches significantly both in terms of efficiency and effectiveness. 1 Introduction Social networks play an increasingly important role in people s lives. They provide us with new ways to communicate with each other, share information, collaborate, or even make friends. As such, they have attracted much attention from researchers across various fields ranging from sociology  1  , psychology  2  , biology  3  , computer science  4  , engineering  5  , etc.. The rapid development of online social media has led to unprecedented growth in the amount of available social network data  6  . For example, Facebook alone now contains more than one billion active users  7  .
However, analyzing large volumes of social network data remains a challenge because it usually involves complex relationships among nodes  8  . To tackle these challenges, recent research efforts focus on developing effective representations for social networks  9  -  11  . These representations aim at capturing different aspects of social networks while being able to scale up well when dealing with massive amounts of data  12  . Among them, matrix factorization techniques  13  -  15  have shown great promise as they allow us to represent social networks using low-rank matrices  16  . Matrix factorization methods decompose a given adjacency matrix into two smaller matrices (i.e., latent factors) which capture structural properties of the original graph  17  .

rewrite_text: We conducted extensive numerical and experimental analyses of the behavior of a liquid droplet bouncing on an inclined superhydrophobic surface, which allows for stable levitation in the air. Our findings indicate that the lifetimes of these bouncing droplets are influenced by their initial energy. We discovered that the relationship between lifetime and initial energy can be expressed using a power law, t ~ E0−α, where α = 0.5 ± 0.1, applicable to both numerical simulations and experiments. This scaling behavior suggests that the characteristics of a bouncing droplet depend only weakly on its initial energy. Additionally, we observed that the height reached during each bounce diminishes as the number of bounces increases. We also demonstrate how these results can be utilized to estimate the surface properties of materials based on experimental data. Bouncing droplets have garnered significant interest in the field of microfluidics due to their potential applications. Typically, these experiments involve millimeter-sized droplets impacting hydrophobic surfaces, though smaller droplets can also bounce off superhydrophobic coatings. In many instances, it has been noted that the droplets exhibit consistent bouncing behavior. However, there are examples of non-standard bouncing and even chaotic motion. Recent research has shown that the lifetimes—i.e., the intervals between successive impacts—of bouncing droplets are significantly dependent on their initial velocities. For instance, if the initial velocity exceeds a certain threshold, the droplet will not bounce and will instead slide down the surface. Conversely, if the initial velocity is below a specific limit, the droplet can bounce indefinitely.

We find that there is no logarithmic correction to the entanglement entropy, which agrees with previous results obtained via other methods. In addition, we show that the first-order corrections are proportional to the square root of the volume enclosed by the entangling surface. Finally, we calculate the second-order corrections and obtain an expression containing two terms. One of them has been previously found in Ref.  Phys. Rev. D 98 (2018) 084011  while another one is new. The latter can be written as a sum over all possible contractions between the Riemann tensor and its derivatives at the boundary points. This result shows that the gravitational Chern-Simons coupling constant plays a role similar to the Newton s constant in four dimensions.

rewrite_text: We propose an optical approach for implementing the Gaussian valence bond (GVB) state, which is a crucial type of quantum state in condensed matter physics. The GVB state effectively describes many-body systems exhibiting strong correlations, such as spin liquids and Mott insulators. Our proposed method facilitates the generation of entanglement between two distant parties using only basic optical elements and single-photon sources. This exploration has potential applications in quantum communication. Quantum entanglement plays a significant role in various fields, including quantum computing, quantum metrology, and secure communication. Furthermore, entangled states have been demonstrated to be valuable resources for protocols like quantum teleportation, superdense coding, remote state preparation, and secure key distribution. Recent studies have shown an increasing interest in exploring entanglement within many-body systems. In particular, the wave function of strongly correlated fermions on lattices can be viewed as a composition of local singlet pairs, often referred to as valence bonds. This category encompasses valence bond solid (VBS) states. It has been discovered that VBS states can be represented by a certain valence bond basis, which includes notable examples such as the Néel state for antiferromagnetic systems, the Haldane state for integer spin chains, and the Affleck-Kennedy-Lieb-Tasaki (AKLT) state representing gapped spin-1/2 systems. Recently, various proposals have emerged to experimentally generate these types of entangled states. However, all existing approaches rely on nonlinear interactions between photons and/or complex setups, making practical implementation challenging. Conversely, some recent demonstrations have successfully produced photonic qubits, suggesting it could be beneficial to explore methods to generate these entangled states without the need for nonlinear optical processes.

original_text: We present the first results for atmospheric dynamics in short period extra-solar gas giant planets (EGPs) using 3D general circulation models with radiative transfer and realistic opacities. We find that the night-side temperature is strongly dependent on opacity, which determines how much energy can be transported to space by radiation. The day-night contrast increases as we decrease the opacity because less heat escapes through the nightside atmosphere. This effect is more pronounced at lower pressures where convection becomes inefficient. For low enough opacities, the planet cools down completely during its orbit resulting in an extremely cold night side. Our simulations show that EGPs are likely to have very different climates depending on their composition.  Keywords: General Circulation Modeling, Extrasolar Planetary Systems, Radiation Transfer, Climate, Atmosphere, Energy Transport, Convection, Cooling Rates, Day-Night Contrast

original_text: We present the first analysis of water vapor in irradiated planets using infrared (IR) spectroscopy with the Infrared Spectrograph on board the Spitzer Space Telescope. The physical properties of solids are determined by their ground state and excited state energies, which can be computed using ab initio methods, particularly density functional theory (DFT). However, these calculations can encounter issues stemming from electron-electron interactions due to the limitations of conventional correlation potentials. In this study, we propose a method that enables us to correct DFT calculations for excited states by utilizing many-body perturbation theory (MBPT). We apply our approach to analyze the optical absorption spectrum of MgO and compare the results with experimental data. Our findings show strong agreement between the theoretical predictions and experimental results across a broad range of photon energies. The methodology we present is applicable to any system where MBPT corrections are feasible or can be implemented with reasonable computational effort. This includes most semiconductors as well as insulators, such as ionic compounds. 

Ab initio wave-function-based methods are established tools for calculating various properties of materials. These properties include ground state total energy calculations, phonon dispersion relations, elastic constants, magnetic moments, and transport properties. They are widely used to predict growth rates, defect formation energies, surface energies, and electronic band structures. Additionally, these methods offer insights into fundamental physical phenomena such as superconductivity, magnetism, charge density wave phenomena, ferroelectricity, and quantum phase transitions. Finally, they allow for the examination of the effects of external perturbations on material properties, including pressure, strain, electric fields, temperature changes, and doping levels.

We study the fractal dimension of domain walls (DWs) in two dimensional Ising spin glasses with nearest neighbor interactions and random bonds using Monte Carlo simulations at finite temperatures. We find that DWs are fractals for all values of temperature studied here, i.e., T = 0.5J/kB to 1.2J/kB where J is the strength of interaction between spins on neighboring sites.  The fractal dimensions obtained by box counting method agree well with those determined by the correlation function analysis. In addition we show that the fractal dimension decreases as the temperature increases. This result suggests that the structure of DWs becomes more complicated when the system approaches its critical point. Finally it should be noted that our results can also be applied to other systems such as vortex lines in type-II superconductors or dislocation networks in crystals. Two-dimensional Ising spin glasses have been extensively investigated both experimentally  1  and theoretically  2  . We present an analytical expression for the massless triangle Feynman integral in terms of generalized hypergeometric functions. The derivation utilizes the Mellin-Barnes representation and contour integration techniques. We include specific cases that can be used to verify our results. This work is motivated by our interest in the lack of loop corrections to specific processes, such as Higgs boson decays into two photons or gluons at next-to-leading order (NLO). 

**I. INTRODUCTORY REMARKS**  
The evaluation of loop diagrams plays a crucial role in theoretical physics. In particular, it has been demonstrated that the inclusion of radiative corrections can lead to significant changes in various observables. For instance, the NLO QCD corrections to the decay widths of heavy quarks, quark pair production, and Higgs boson decays have recently been calculated with considerable success. Despite this progress, several challenges remain regarding the evaluation of multi-loop integrals. In this letter, we focus on the following massless triangle Feynman integral, where \( m_1 = m_2 \equiv m_3 \equiv m_4 \equiv 0 \) and \( s_{12} = s \). It is important to note that this integral vanishes when any three masses are equal to zero.

The shock temperatures for molybdenum were determined by measuring the electrical resistance of samples shocked to pressures up to 1,000 kilobars (1 Mbar). The release temperature was measured using an optical pyrometer on samples that had been heated with laser light after being shocked at various levels of pressure. 
 
 Shocks produced by a pulsed power machine were used to compress the sample material between two electrodes. A voltage pulse applied across these electrodes caused current flow through the compressed material which generated Joule heating. This heat increased the resistivity of the material causing it to expand rapidly as its temperature rose above the Curie point. As this expansion occurred, the resistance dropped dramatically resulting in a sharp increase in current flowing into the sample. When the current reached a critical value, the sample exploded releasing most of its stored energy. The explosion also destroyed one or both of the electrodes so that no further measurement could be made until new ones were installed.

original_text: We present new near-infrared integral field spectroscopy observations of two nearby active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with compact nuclear star formation, NGC 1068 and Mrk 3. The data were obtained using SINFONI at VLT/UT4. We find that both AGNs have very high infrared luminosities (LIR ~10^11 Lsun), which are dominated by emission lines originating from warm molecular gas excited by young stars. In addition to these bright line features we detect spatially extended continuum emission on scales of several hundred parsecs around each nucleus. This is likely due to dust heated by the intense radiation fields produced by the AGN and/or hot young stars. Our results show that the presence of an AGN does not necessarily prevent massive star formation within its host galaxy. These findings suggest that there may be a close link between black hole growth and nuclear star formation activity.  Keywords: Active Galactic Nuclei

The results indicate that Rm, S, and β significantly affect both the saturation level of the Maxwell stress tensor and the growth rate of the density perturbations. Specifically, it was observed that, with other parameters held constant, an increase in Rm leads to a rise in both the saturation level of the Maxwell stress tensor and the growth rate of the total density fluctuations. Increasing S raises the saturation value of the stress tensor but does not impact its growth rate. original_text: We study the gauge structure of quantum spin systems with local interactions, which are described by the so-called Kitaev model. We show that this model is equivalent to an exactly solvable lattice gauge theory (LGT) whose action functional is given by the Chern-Simons term. The equivalence between these two theories allows us to use powerful techniques developed for LGTs such as the index theorem or the localization technique. In particular we prove that the ground state degeneracy of the Kitaev model on any closed 3-manifold M equals the number of independent solutions of certain differential equations called Witten s equation. This result can be viewed as a generalization of the Atiyah-Patodi-Singer index theorem to manifolds with boundary. Finally, using the results obtained above, we derive some exact formulas for the partition function of the Kitaev model defined on surfaces with boundaries. These formulas generalize the celebrated formula due to Witten for the partition function of Yang-Mills fields on Riemann surfaces.

We introduce the first view template, Roses, based on the SEOBNRv4HM model, designed to detect gravitational wave (GW) signals from black hole mergers involving binary systems with total masses ranging from 10 to 100 solar masses. original_text: We report on radio observations made with the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) and Parkes Observatory toward the magnetar candidate X-ray transient source XTE J1810−197, which was discovered in outburst by RXTE/ASM during March 2009. We detect absorption features at 21 cm that are consistent with neutral hydrogen along our line-of-sight to this source. Using these data we derive an upper limit for its distance of <5 kpc. This is inconsistent with previous estimates based upon optical photometry or near-infrared spectroscopy. The discrepancy may be due to interstellar extinction effects and/or variability between epochs of observation. If confirmed as a neutron star then it would have one of the lowest inferred surface magnetic fields known. It also has a spin period derivative that is among the highest observed for any pulsar. These properties make it unique amongst currently-known neutron stars. Keywords: Neutron Star -Magnetic Field Strength, Pulsar -Distance Measurement

The generalized twistor transform extends the traditional twistor transform to encompass interactions involving spin in various dimensions. Recently, it has been applied to compute amplitudes for massless particles as well as other scenarios. In this discussion, I will summarize some key insights on how this framework can be utilized to describe phenomena beyond free or massless states. We will also explore recent developments in dualities between different physical theories that have emerged from applying the generalized twistor transform, including relationships between N = 4 super Yang-Mills and self-dual gravity alongside its supersymmetric extensions. Furthermore, we will examine how these results are connected to string theory.

Generalized twistors, first introduced by Witten over two decades ago, offer a robust method for studying gauge theories within the context of general relativity, and they are significant in revealing intricate aspects of superstring theory. One notable aspect is the Penrose limit, which establishes a connection between amplitudes in gauge and gravity theories at weak coupling and correlation functions in conformal field theories at strong coupling. Recently, there has been a resurgence of interest in twistors due to their effectiveness in calculating scattering amplitudes. Specifically, the tree-level scattering amplitudes of gluons and gravitons in four-dimensional N = 4 super Yang-Mills theory—which is conjectured to be dual to type IIB superstrings—were computed using the original twistor transform.

We study the collective modes in two-band superconductors with different gaps and masses, using the random phase approximation (RPA). We find that there are three types of collective modes: one is gapless and has linear dispersion relation at small wave vector; another is gapped but still has quadratic dispersion relation near the Fermi surface; while the third type is fully gapped without any low-energy excitations. The latter two types can be regarded as phonon-like collective modes. In addition to these three types of collective modes, we also find an exotic mode which does not exist in single-gap systems. This new mode originates from the interband pairing interaction between electrons on different bands. It shows up only when both intraband and interband interactions are present simultaneously. Our results show that this new mode may have important effects on the transport properties of multi-band superconductors.

Moreover, the Coulomb repulsion effect becomes stronger for multi-orbital systems  6  . All these factors make the physics of multiband superconductors very rich  7, 8  .

We study the phase behavior of a system of N identical hard rods confined to a square box with periodic boundary conditions, using Monte Carlo simulations at constant pressure P . We find that for sufficiently large values of P , there is an ordered state where all particles are aligned along one direction (the x-axis), forming layers perpendicular to this axis.  The transition between disordered and ordered states occurs via a first-order phase transition which we characterize by studying the density profiles across the simulation cell as well as the order parameter distribution function. For small values of P , however, no such ordered state exists. Instead, the system exhibits a glassy dynamics characterized by slow relaxation timescales. Finally, we show how our results can be used to explain recent experiments on colloidal suspensions under shear flow. In many physical systems, it has been observed that particles tend to align themselves into regular patterns when they interact strongly enough. This phenomenon is known as capillarity  1  or self-assembly  2  .
In particular, in two dimensions, particles may form stripes  3  -  5  , squares  6  , hexagons  7  , or even more complex structures  8  depending on their shape  9  , size  10  , interactions  11  , and external fields  12  . These phenomena have attracted considerable attention over the past few years due to both fundamental interest  13  and potential applications  14  -  16  . A particularly interesting example is provided by colloidal suspensions  17  -  20  : When these are subjected to strong shear flows  21  , they often exhibit striped phases  22  -  24  whose formation mechanism remains poorly understood  25  .

We utilize two distinct sets of evolutionary tracks with Y values for stellar masses ranging from 0.8 to 8 solar masses at solar metallicity. One set is based on the Padova models, while the other is derived from the Geneva ones. For each model, we generate synthetic spectra using the SPECTRUM code. We present an analytical model to study decoherence and relaxation processes in a few coupled superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUID) immersed into a phonon bath at low temperatures. The system is described by a chain-boson Hamiltonian with nearest-neighbor interactions, which can be diagonalized exactly using the Bethe ansatz method. We show that this approach allows us to obtain exact results for the dynamics of the reduced density matrix describing the SQUID subsystem as well as its entanglement entropy. In particular we find that the decay rate of the off-diagonal elements of the reduced density matrix scales linearly with temperature T , while the von Neumann entropy grows logarithmically with time t. These findings are consistent with previous numerical studies on similar systems. 
 
 Introduction 
 
 Superconducting circuits have been proposed recently as promising candidates for realizations of quantum information processing  1  . One important issue in these proposals concerns how to protect qubits against environmental noise  2  . It has been shown theoretically  3  -  6  and experimentally  7  -  9  that coupling between different parts of a circuit may lead to unwanted effects such as dephasing or relaxation. This problem becomes particularly severe when considering large networks of interacting qubits  10  . 
 
 Here we consider a simple model consisting of two weakly-coupled SQUIDs  11  immersed into a phonon environment  12  . Our aim is to investigate the effect of the interaction term on the evolution of the reduced density matrix of each SQUID separately. To do so, we use the Bethe ansatz  13  to solve analytically the Schrödinger equation corresponding to our model. As expected, we observe that the presence of the interaction leads to decoherence and dissipation phenomena. Moreover, we find that the decay rates of the off-diagonals of the reduced density matrices scale linearly with temperature T , whereas their von Neumann entropies grow logarithmically with time t. 
Model

The total Hamiltonian H = H0 + V describes the system composed of N = 2 SQUIDs coupled via a weak tunneling amplitude J immersed into a phonon reservoir at zero temperature.

rewrite_text: We present findings on the investigation rate, mass distribution, and orbital characteristics of hypervelocity stars (HVSs) in the Galactic halo, based on spectroscopic observations using Keck II/DEIMOS over three years. Our study reveals that HVSs are occurring at a rate of 0.5 ± 0.2 per year within 100 parsecs of the Galactic center. The observed spatial density of these stars is consistent with an exponential decline relative to distance from the Galactic center. Our sample includes two HVSs with velocities exceeding 1000 km/s; one has a heliocentric radial velocity of 1240 km/s and the other 1420 km/s. These high velocities indicate that these stars were likely ejected through gravitational slingshot interactions during close encounters with black holes or massive stars. In addition to the known population of HVSs near the Sun, we also identify a significant population of high-velocity stars located farther from the Galactic center, which may be associated with other nearby supermassive black holes.

original_text: We present new observations of the nuclear region in the nearby radio galaxy NGC315, made using the Chandra X-ray Observatory (CXO) and the Very Large Array (VLA). The CXO data reveal an unresolved point source at the center of this elliptical galaxy that is surrounded by diffuse emission extending to about 1 arcmin (3 kpc), which we identify as thermal gas heated by the central AGN. We detect two bright knots embedded within the extended emission; these are likely associated with shocks driven into the surrounding medium by the expanding radio jets. Using high-resolution VLA images obtained simultaneously with the CXO observation, we find evidence for a one-sided parsec-scale radio jet emerging from the nucleus along position angle PA = -45 degrees. This jet has been previously detected on larger scales out to several kiloparsecs. In addition, there appears to be another fainter component of the radio jet located further south-west than the main knot.

rewrite_text: The nucleon is depicted as a composite entity with intricate internal structures, which can be studied through elastic scattering experiments conducted at high energies and small momentum transfers. This study focuses on the chiral perturbation theory applied to orbital quantum structures within effective field theory (EFT). We specifically examine the significance of pionic degrees of freedom in recovering the nucleon's electromagnetic properties. We find that the inclusion of explicit pions leads to substantial enhancements in the accuracy of previously established calculations based on quark degrees of freedom. Furthermore, we illustrate how the EFT framework allows for the systematic inclusion of higher-order corrections in the calculations of observable quantities. In addition, we discuss the applicability of our approach to other hadronic systems, such as mesons or hypernuclei. The nucleon is understood as a composite system made up of quarks held together by gluons. However, it has been recognized since the inception of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) that this simplistic picture does not entirely align with experimental results. While the proton’s electric charge radius aligns well with measurements, its magnetic moment is approximately 30% larger than expected from basic quark models. To address these discrepancies, it has been proposed that contributions from virtual meson fluctuations must be considered. These so-called meson-cloud effects are particularly significant when investigating large momentum transfers. Research has previously demonstrated that they play an essential role in influencing the nucleon’s electromagnetic characteristics.

Finally, we discuss how the model could be further improved by including other physical processes like supernova feedback or AGN activity. We investigate the charge ordering phenomena in low-dimensional solids by employing exact diagonalization and density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) techniques. Our findings reveal two distinct types of charge orderings: columnar (striped) and checkerboard, which depend on the electron density \( n \). The striped order occurs for \( 0 < n < 1 \), while the checkerboard order appears at half-filling when spin degeneracy is broken. Additionally, we observe an exotic paired state of electrons that does not carry any net charge, which may serve as a precursor to superconductivity. Finally, we discuss potential experimental realizations of our results.

Introduction: Low-dimensional systems, such as carbon nanotubes, semiconductor nanowires, and quantum wires, have garnered considerable interest due to their ability to exhibit unique properties that are not present in conventional three-dimensional bulk materials. The metallic behavior of carbon nanotubes has been theoretically predicted and experimentally confirmed, even when their diameter is smaller than the Fermi wavelength. Another intriguing aspect of low-dimensional systems is the emergence of various charge orders due to strong correlation effects. A crucial question is how to manipulate the electronic phase diagram of these low-dimensional materials. It is important to note that electronic properties depend not only on the geometry but also significantly on the compositional projections. Consequently, by tuning the composition of these low-dimensional systems, we can anticipate the emergence of new electronic phases. Recently, several studies have successfully synthesized low-dimensional materials with controlled compositions, leading to the discovery of many fascinating phenomena.

We present an optical and infrared study of the high-density region of the Sigma Orionis cluster, also known as the Orion Nebula Cluster. Our research includes deep JHK photometry obtained with ISAAC at the ESO/VLT, as well as X-ray data from XMM-Newton, focusing on a sample of stars within a 1 arcminute radius around the Trapezium OB stars. The main findings are summarized as follows: 

- We discovered a total of 16 spectroscopic binaries among our targets.
- An analysis of the radial velocities indicates that most of these binaries have orbital periods exceeding 100 days.
- We also report the discovery of two new candidate eclipsing binaries on the pre-main sequence.
- Furthermore, we identify several additional spectroscopic binaries in the region studied.
- Lastly, we discuss several intriguing cases where the presence of circumstellar disks is suggested by their infrared excess emission or by variability in their light.

We present the results for the one-loop amplitudes in N=8 supergravity, which are obtained by using the spinor helicity formalism with dimensional reduction to four dimensions. rewrite_text: We present new observations of the outflow driven by the protostar NGC 1333 IRAS 4A, located at the center of the Perseus molecular cloud (distance = 235 pc). The data were obtained using the Submillimeter Array and include continuum emission at 1.3 mm as well as CO (2-1) line emission. Our findings indicate that the outflow is highly collimated along a north-northeast to south-southwest direction, which aligns with the outflow toward the nearby Herbig-Haro objects HH 7-11. The total mass of the outflowing material is estimated to be approximately 0.1 M☉, while its kinetic energy is about 10^50 ergs. These results are consistent with those found for other low-mass protostellar outflows. However, we also observed significant differences between this outflow and those previously studied. In particular, our observations suggest that the outflow may have been recently triggered by interaction with another outflow or stellar object within the surrounding core region.

original_text: We present new photometry in the optical and near-infrared bands for the open cluster Blanco 1 (M35). The data were obtained with the 2 m telescope at the Observatorio Astronómico Nacional de San Pedro Mártir, Baja California Sur, Mexico; the 0.9 m telescope at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, Chile; and the Nordic Optical Telescope, La Palma, Canary Islands, Spain. We have used these observations together with archival data from the Hubble Space Telescope archive to derive an improved age estimate for this open cluster. Our results show that M35 is about 300 Myr old, which makes it one of the youngest open clusters known within 100 pc of the Sun. Using our derived age we have determined the initial mass function (IMF) of M35 down to masses as low as 3 MJUP . This IMF shows no evidence for any significant deviation from the Salpeter power law index over more than three orders of magnitude in mass.

We present the results for dark matter annihilations into gamma rays and neutrinos using an improved treatment of subhalos within galaxy clusters, including their internal structure as well as tidal stripping effects on their outer parts. We find that this leads to a significant increase (by up to one order of magnitude) in the predicted fluxes at energies above 1 GeV compared with previous studies. The effect is particularly strong when considering nearby galaxy clusters such as Virgo or Coma. This has important consequences for current and future experiments searching for signals from dark matter particles. In particular, we show how our predictions can be used to derive constraints on the properties of dark matter candidates by comparing them with existing data from Fermi/LAT and IceCube/DeepCore. If DM consists of new light particles, then these interactions would produce detectable signatures in cosmic ray spectra  2  , gamma-ray emission  3  , and high-energy neutrino production  4  .
In recent years there have been many attempts to detect DM indirectly via observations of astrophysical objects which are expected to contain large amounts of DM  5  . These include dwarf galaxies  6  , galaxy clusters  7, 8  , and galactic haloes  9  . However, no convincing evidence for DM annihilation has yet been found  10  . One possible explanation for this lack of detection could be that most of the DM mass resides in small-scale structures  11  , which are not resolved observationally  12  . Another possibility is that the DM density profiles inferred from gravitational lensing measurements  13  do not accurately reflect the true distribution of DM  14  . Finally, it should also be noted that some models predict very low rates of DM annihilation  15  .
The aim of this work is to investigate whether the inclusion of substructure information improves the prospects for detecting DM annihilation products. rewrite_text: We present an exploratory report based on the Cosmosoma experiment, which investigates potential evidence for an excess in cosmic microwave background (CMB) temperature fluctuations that deviate from predictions made by standard cosmological models. The data align with current theoretical understanding but feature some unexpected characteristics that may be attributed to foreground sources or effects related to our analysis process. We have utilized these findings to establish limits on possible contributions from primordial signals and other phenomena, such as topological defects. These limits are consistent with previous studies using different methodologies. Additionally, we report the detection of an exploratory signal at frequencies below 10 GHz, which is not predicted by current cosmological models. This could indicate either a foreground source or a novel physical phenomenon. Further investigations will require additional experiments to clarify this signal and ascertain its implications. If confirmed, it could provide significant insights into the observed anisotropy in the CMB spectrum.

We study mesoscopic fluctuations of the supercurrents flowing through two weakly coupled superconductors with different transparencies and temperatures, using the Usadel equations for quasiclassical Green s functions. We show that the current noise is suppressed by increasing transparency between the leads or decreasing temperature. The suppression can be explained as due to an increase of the effective junction length caused by Andreev reflection at the interface. In addition we find that the shot-noise power decreases when the phase difference across the junction increases. This effect originates from the dependence of the density of states on the phase difference. Finally, we discuss how our results are related to recent experiments performed on diffusive SNS junctions. 
I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK
The Josephson effect describes macroscopically coherent transport of Cooper pairs across weak links connecting two superconducting electrodes  1  . It has been observed experimentally over many decades  2  , but only recently have researchers begun to explore its microscopic origins  3  .
In this work we consider a system consisting of two weakly-coupled superconductors (S) connected via a normal metal region (N). Such systems are known as diffusive SNS junctures  4  . They exhibit interesting phenomena such as the proximity effect  5  , which causes the formation of a minigap inside the N region  6  . Another important feature of these devices is their ability to carry both charge and spin currents  7, 8  . These properties make them promising candidates for applications ranging from quantum information processing  9  to magnetic field sensing  10  .
Recently there has been renewed interest in studying the physics of diffusive SNS juncture  11  -  16  . Experimentally, this prediction could not yet be confirmed because of difficulties associated with fabricating clean NS interfaces  18  . However, several groups managed to observe similar effects indirectly  19, 20  .

rewrite_text: In this study, we address the challenge of determining how many users to activate for multi-access broadcast channels (MABCs). We assume that the optimal number of active users is equal to the rank of the channel matrix when all users have the same signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and there are no power constraints at the base station. Subsequently, under more general conditions, we demonstrate that the optimal number of users is limited by the lower of the rank of the channel or the total number of available transmit antennas. We then present an algorithm that can find the optimal solution with polynomial time complexity. This framework enables us to design more efficient MABCs while keeping computational costs manageable. In wireless communication, broadcasting refers to the transmission of signals simultaneously to multiple users over a shared medium, such as wireless frequencies or optical channels. This method is commonly employed in various applications, including television, video conferencing, and data transmission, where it is necessary to send messages to multiple users at once. However, due to limited resources, only a subset of these users will receive useful signals, while others may experience interference. This highlights the importance of optimizing the selection of users to activate so that each user can successfully receive their intended message without experiencing excessive interference from others. If one aims to maximize the overall throughput for all users, taking into account individual power constraints, the optimal strategy for selecting users becomes dependent not only on the channel state but also on the power allocation scheme. As a result, the joint optimization of user selection and power control presents significant complexity.

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of the Swift/BAT data recovered for GRB 060912, which is one of only two events classified as both a long-soft (LS) and a short-hard (SH) gamma-ray burst by the BAT observations. We find that this classification is not robust against changes in the temporal scales used or variations in time binning; it does not hold up when compared to other LS events observed by Swift. Additionally, we demonstrate that the spectral features observed during the prompt phase cannot be adequately explained by either the SH or LS models. Lastly, we suggest that the most plausible explanation for these observations is that GRB 060912 was a singular event lasting several hundred seconds, rather than a series of multiple bursts occurring during quiescent intervals. Our findings indicate that there may be a continuum of properties between the characteristics of long and short gamma-ray bursts observed by the BAT.

original_text: We present an analysis of the neutral hydrogen (HI) emission observed with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope and the Effelsberg 100-m telescope to study the dark matter content of our Galaxy. We use the rotation curve derived by Clemens (1985) , which is based on 21-cm line observations of nearby spiral galaxies. The total mass enclosed within a radius R can be written as: M(R) = Vrot2πGRL + MDW(R), where Vrot is the circular velocity at galactocentric distance R, G is Newton s constant, L is the luminosity density, and MDW(R) is the contribution due to the dark matter halo. In this work we assume that the dark matter follows a Navarro-Frenk-White profile.  Using the rotation curve for the solar neighbourhood given by Clemens (1985) (V⊙ = 220 km/sec), we find that the best-fit parameters are L0 = 0.0013 Msun/pc3 and r0 = 1 kpc. This implies that the local surface brightness ΣL = L/L0 = 3.6 × 10^−26 W/m2/Hz/sr. We present an analysis of the worst-case time complexity for inserting \( n \) elements into a binary clubhouse tree using the Fibonacci-Jarvis data structure, which is based on Young-Fibonacci insertions. We show that this approach achieves a worst-case time complexity of \( O(n \log n) \), improving upon the results of Chan et al., who established that it takes at least \( \Omega(n^{2/3}) \) time to perform these operations in the worst case. The core idea behind our proof is to apply amortized analysis to bound the number of times we need to update the tree's size during each operation. This allows us to demonstrate that the total cost incurred over all operations is bounded by \( O(n \log n) \). Additionally, we provide evidence that our bounds are tight up to constant factors.

Introduction: The Fibonacci heap data structure was introduced by Fredman and Tarjan (FT86) as part of their work on efficient algorithms for finding minimum spanning trees (MSTs), shortest paths, and other combinatorial optimization problems. The structure consists of a rooted binary tree with two fields associated with each node: a pointer and a rank. Each node maintains pointers to its left and right child nodes; however, unlike ordinary binary trees, multiple nodes can have the same key associated with any given parent node. Each node also contains a counter representing its rank, which indicates the number of keys equal to or smaller than the key of the current node that exist below it; if no such keys exist, the rank is zero. The focusing effect on relativistic electrons by an electrostatic lens is investigated theoretically for different values of the charge density, radius and potential difference between two spherical electrodes. The results are compared with those obtained using the so-called  effective momentum  approximation (EMA). It has been found that EMA gives good agreement only when the electron energy is much higher than its rest mass energy. For lower energies it overestimates the focal length as well as the maximum value of the electric field strength at the focus point. This discrepancy can be explained by taking into account the contribution to the total force acting upon the particle due to the magnetic component of the Lorentz force. In this case we have shown that the focal length decreases while the maximum electric field increases.

rewrite_text: We present the tenth set of observations made by the Multiband Imaging Photometer for Spitzer (MIPS) at 24 and 70 microns, focusing on the Serpens cloud core. This data was collected as part of the Spitzer Space Telescope's Cores to Disks Legacy program (c2d). We have identified over 100 infrared sources within an area of 0.5 square degrees centered on the Serpens South region. Most of these sources are associated with young stellar objects that are indicative of ongoing star formation activities, such as outflows or protoplanetary disks. Additionally, we have identified a few dozen sources that are likely at redshifts ranging from 1.2 to 3.6. Moreover, we report the detection of two unknown protostars located within the cores near the Serpens South filamentary structures. These findings enhance our understanding of star formation dynamics within this active molecular cloud complex.

We present the first results on infrared high-resolution spectroscopy (HRS) of post-AGB disks, obtained with CRIRES/VLT and NIRSPEC/Keck II. We find that the disk around HR 4049 is dominated by emission lines originating in an extended region at temperatures between 1000-2000 K. This temperature range corresponds to the expected location of dust grains which are being evaporated due to stellar radiation pressure. In addition we detect several absorption features which can be attributed to gas-phase molecules such as CO, H2O, OH, NH3, CH4, C2H2, SiO, HCN, CCH, CN, H2S, SO2, CS, and FeH. These observations provide new insights into the physical conditions within these objects. They also show how important it will be for future studies to combine spatially resolved information about the distribution of molecular species with detailed spectroscopic data.

Through an optimized growth procedure, we achieve high-quality QD layers with a low defect density, which is crucial for realizing extended coherence times. rewrite_text: We explored the atmospheric aerosol composition in the Kashiwa area of Chiba Prefecture, Japan, using data from Santos-based remote sensing and analysis collected between September 2009 and March 2010 during periods of significant air pollution driven by human activities. Our findings indicated that sulfate particles were primarily produced through gas-to-particle conversion via homogeneous nucleation on days with low relative humidity; however, under conditions where humidity exceeded 80%, these particles formed secondary organic aerosols (SOAs). We study how popularity emerges in collective choice dynamics, where individuals sequentially choose between two options and are influenced by their peers. We show that when agents have boundedly rational expectations about others  choices they may end up choosing an option which has no majority support but nevertheless becomes popular over time. rewrite_text: We argue that the non-Gaussian distributions observed in financial returns stem from the microscopic interactions among traders and their fluctuating behaviors, which result in complex correlations across different time scales. We present a framework for understanding these correlations based on Random Matrix Theory (RMT), which can effectively replicate all significant characteristics of real market data with high accuracy. The analysis of price returns has been extensively conducted over many years. It has been found that these returns can often be approximated by a Gaussian function, yet notable deviations have been identified. Specifically, recent studies indicate that the tails of the return distribution follow a power law decay, P(r) ~ r^(-α), with α = 3 ± 0.1. This observation challenges the assumptions of standard models like Black-Scholes or Heston, where the expected exponent should be equal to 2. To explore the origins of these deviations, we propose a novel approach based on Random Matrix Theory. RMT addresses the statistics of complex systems whose behavior depends on a large number of degrees of freedom. It has been successfully applied to describe the fluctuations of diverse phenomena, such as fluid dynamics, image processing, spin systems, particle transport, and chaotic systems. Recently, RMT has also been employed to analyze the statistical properties of stock market behaviors. In this work, we will concentrate on the memoryless Dyson Brownian motion model, which illustrates the dynamics of financial assets under the influence of white noise.

rewrite_text: We present the tenth installment of our Bulletin simulations of magnetized accretion disks, in which we utilize the magnetohydrodynamic equations for an axisymmetric framework that includes a specified radial flow of material and mass fluxes, employing the shearing-box approach. Our results show that the magnetic field is amplified by differential rotation, leading to the formation of large-scale poloidal fields whose strength increases outward as \( r^{-3/2} \) (where \( r \) is the radius). Additionally, the toroidal component of the magnetic field rapidly increases due to the winding of poloidal field lines by shear. Consequently, the magnetic Prandtl number decreases toward the center of the disk. We also find that the Maxwell stress associated with the magnetic field leads to an effective redistribution of angular momentum within the flow. This results in a more efficient outward transport of angular momentum compared to the transport induced by viscous stresses.

We study non-Abelian hydrodynamic equations for fluids with spin-orbit coupling, which are derived by applying Noether s theorem to an action functional describing the dynamics of such systems. We show that these equations can be written as a system of conservation laws for charge current density Jμc , energy-momentum tensor Tμν and spin current density JSμ . The latter is given by a sum over all particles of their individual spins Sα multiplied by certain coefficients depending on the particle type α = e, μ, τ .
The resulting transport coefficients are calculated explicitly using kinetic theory methods. In particular we find that the shear viscosity ηs vanishes identically if there exists at least one electrically charged fermion species (e.g., electrons) or if the fluid contains only neutral bosons like photons. This result holds both for relativistic and nonrelativistic fluids. Furthermore, we calculate the bulk viscosities for various examples including QED plasma, superfluid helium-4, and ultracold atomic gases. Finally, we discuss how our results could be used to describe the collective motion of atoms in Bose-Einstein condensates. 
I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK
In this work we consider fluids whose constituents have internal degrees of freedom described by quantum fields. Examples include plasmas consisting of charged particles interacting via electromagnetic field, superfluids made up of neutral bosonic atoms, and cold atom clouds where the atoms are treated as distinguishable particles. For simplicity, we will assume that the number densities of different types of particles do not change significantly during time evolution so that they may be considered constant.

rewrite_text: We present near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy obtained with Subaru/HDS on day +16 after the explosion of the Type Ib supernova SN2006jc, which displays prominent features created in its surrounding shell. The NIR spectrum is characterized by strong P-Cygni profiles of H I Balmer lines and Fe II multiplets at 4233-4245 Å. We find that these features are well reproduced by our non-LTE model calculations, assuming an electron density of ne = 1 x 10^9 cm^-3, a temperature of Te = 5500 K, and a mass-loss rate of approximately 2 x 10^-6 M☉/yr. We study the gravitational self-force acting on a wave packet in curved spacetime, and show that it causes its distortion.  We consider two types of wavepackets: one is constructed by superposing plane waves with different frequencies; another is made up of spherical waves emitted at various angles around an isolated source point. In both cases we find that the force acts as if there were additional sources located behind the packet s center-of-mass worldline. The effect can be understood intuitively using the concept of  gravitational memory . Our results are relevant for understanding how gravitational waves propagate through space-time. They also provide new insights into the problem of gravitational radiation reaction. Introduction - A fundamental question about gravitational waves (GWs) concerns how they evolve over time when propagating through curved space-time  1  . This issue has been studied extensively within the framework of linearized gravity theory  2  , where GWs are treated as small perturbations of flat Minkowski background geometry  3  .
In this work we focus on the effects due to gravitational self-coupling  4  . These arise because each part of a GW carries energy density which exerts pressure back onto itself via Newtonian gravity  5  . As such, the total force acting upon any given portion of a GW depends not only on the local curvature but also on the entire history of the wave  6  . It turns out that these forces cause significant distortions of the wave packets  7, 8  . For example, the shape of a plane-wave packet changes during propagation so that its peak moves away from the direction of motion  9  . Similar behavior was found for spherical wave packets  10  .

Magnetization, susceptibility, and specific heat measurements were conducted on the single crystals of TbFe3(BO3)4. The magnetic properties were analyzed in relation to the crystal field splitting for Tb3+ ions. It was discovered that the ground state doublet exhibits Ising-like anisotropy along the c-axis, with gz = 8.0 ± 0.1, corresponding to a significant spontaneous polarization (Ps ~ 1μC/cm²). The calculated data closely aligns with the experimental results, except for discrepancies observed in the low-temperature region below 2 K. This inconsistency may be attributed to the presence of impurities or defects in the sample. 

**Keywords:** Magnetism; Crystal field theory; Specific heat measurements; Susceptibility measurements; Single crystal growth; Anisotropic magnetoresistance; Polarized light.

**INTRODUCTION:** TbFe3(BO3)4 is part of the family of rare-earth iron borates RFe3(BO3) (where R = Y, Yb, Lu). These compounds have attracted significant attention due to their intriguing properties, including ferroelectricity, multiferroicity, colossal magnetoresistance, and unique magnetic behaviors. Specifically, TbFe3(BO3)4 exhibits a remarkable spontaneous polarization of Ps ~ 1 μC/cm² at ambient conditions, attributed to its unique structure. In this compound, Fe atoms are organized into a three-dimensional framework consisting of corner-sharing tetrahedra. In contrast, Tb atoms occupy two distinct sites; one site is coordinated by eight O atoms in a square antiprismatic arrangement, while the other is surrounded by six O atoms in a trigonal prismatic configuration. As depicted in Figs. 1(a) and 1(b), these two polyhedral types share common faces that are oriented perpendicular to the crystal axes.

This conjecture, originally suggested by Grothendieck, has been proven in several instances, such as when \( g = 0 \) or \( g = 1 \). We argue that if \( S \) has an automorphism of order greater than \( 2 \), then it necessarily has finite automorphisms that are relatively prime to this order; we provide examples where both orders can be made arbitrarily large. The proof revolves around the existence of specific families of curves on \( S \), which have recently been constructed using techniques from algebraic geometry. In particular, we adopt the framework of Eisenbud to show that the morphism of such a curve \( C \) onto \( \mathbb{P}^1 \) is birational. This implies that the image of \( C \) under the Albanese map \( \text{Alb}_S: S \to \text{Alb}_S(S) \) is not contained in any proper subvariety of \( \text{Alb}_S \).
