We study the stability properties of circumnuclear disks (CNDs) embedded within elliptical galaxies, using N-body simulations with live dark matter halos and stellar components. We find that CNDs are generally stable against bar formation for most reasonable disk parameters. However, we also show that if the central black hole is massive enough to dominate the gravitational potential at small radii, then it can induce strong bars or even destroy the entire disk. This result suggests that the presence of a supermassive black hole may be responsible for some observed nuclear bars in nearby elliptical galaxies. 
 
 Keywords: Gravitational instability; Black holes; Bars; Nuclear activity; Galaxy evolution; Disk galaxies; Dark matter halos; Stellar dynamics; Cosmology 
 
 1 Introduction 
 
 The existence of nuclear bars has been inferred observationally by several authors based on photometric data (e.g., Laine et al. 2002; Erwin 2004) . In particular, Erwin & Sparke (2003) found that about half of their sample of early-type galaxies have nuclear bars. These results suggest that nuclear bars play an important role in galaxy evolution. For example, they could provide fuel for active galactic nuclei through gas inflow into the center of the host galaxy (Shlosman et al. 1990 ). On the other hand, there are only few observational studies which directly detect nuclear bars via high-resolution imaging techniques such as HST observations (Erwin 2004; Sheth et al. 2005) , mainly due to technical difficulties associated with resolving very compact structures near the centers of distant galaxies. Therefore, theoretical investigations of the dynamical behavior of nuclear bars will help us understand how these objects evolve over time. 
 
 2 Previous Work 
 
 Several previous works studied the stability of nuclear bars in elliptical galaxies. Athanassoula et al. (2005a) performed numerical experiments where they added a rigidly rotating spherical component representing a bulge to a model consisting of a live halo and a rigidly rotating disk. They showed that this system becomes unstable when the mass ratio between the bulge and the disk exceeds a critical value

In this study, we introduce a novel method for blind identification (BI) of distributed antenna systems (DASs) tailored to robbery scenarios. Our proposed BI technique utilizes a combination of second-order statistics and higher-order cumulants to estimate the number of active users in each cell, as well as their Carrier Frequency Offsets (CFOs), which are unknown parameters that must be estimated before data transmission can occur. Through simulation results, we demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing techniques in terms of the successful identification rate, particularly when CFOs differ across cells. Moreover, our approach exhibits lower computational complexity compared to alternative solutions. 

Keywords: Blind identification; Distributed antenna systems; Second-order statistics; Higher-order cumulants; CFO estimation.

1. Introduction  
The rapid advancement of wireless technologies has led to growing demands for high spectral efficiency and reliable transmission over limited bandwidth resources. To address these challenges, various multi-antenna techniques, such as multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO), cooperative relaying, and cognitive radio, have garnered considerable attention. Among these, distributed antenna systems (DASs) offer significant benefits, including improved coverage, enhanced signal quality, reduced power consumption, and increased deployment flexibility. However, DASs also introduce certain challenges due to their operation in non-coherent environments. Specifically, the channel state information (CSI) at the transmitter cannot be obtained through traditional uplink training or downlink feedback mechanisms. Consequently, accurately estimating the CSI has emerged as a critical concern in DAS design.

To tackle this issue, several studies have explored the simultaneous estimation of user activity and channel coefficients by leveraging only the inherent statistical properties of received signals, without any prior knowledge about the transmitted signals. These methods exploit the sparse nature of user activity patterns and employ second-order statistics and higher-order cumulants to identify active users in each cell. Subsequently, they determine the channel coefficients associated with these users.

original_text: We study the problem of finding an optimal schedule for data transmission over multiple channels with interference constraints, where each channel is assigned to one transmitter-receiver pair and transmissions on different pairs are subject to mutual interference. We consider two models: (i) The first model assumes that all transmitters have fixed power levels. (ii) In the second model we assume that transmitters can adjust their powers dynamically. For both cases, we show how to find an optimal schedule by solving a sequence of linear programs. Our results hold even if there exists only one receiver per transmitter. This work was supported by NSF grant CCF-0430018. 1 Introduction Wireless networks consist of many nodes communicating via radio signals. Each node has limited range and thus cannot communicate directly with every other node. Instead, it communicates indirectly through intermediate nodes called relays or routers. A fundamental question in this context is: How should these relays be placed?

rewrite_text:
The study of the origin of light elements in the early universe is one of the most significant unresolved questions in astrophysics, cosmology, nuclear physics, and particle physics. According to the Standard Model (SM) of elementary particles, these light elements were formed in the first few minutes after the Big Bang. In this paper, I will provide an overview of our current understanding of the production of light nuclei with A = 1 - 3 through photonuclear reactions at high temperatures and densities in the early universe. This investigation includes abundance measurements derived from experiments using radioactive nuclei at GSI Darmstadt. Lastly, I will discuss potential future experiments that could address some of the key uncertainties within the SM. 

**Keywords:** Photonuclear reactions, Light element synthesis, Big Bang nucleosynthesis, Astrophysical supernovae Ia explosions, Nuclear reaction processes.

**1. Introduction** 

Light element synthesis during the early universe remains one of the most challenging questions in modern science. It has been established for some time that photons can induce nuclear fusion processes leading to the creation of light elements such as D, 3He, 4He, 7Li, and 9Be. However, our understanding of the dynamics involved in these processes has only recently begun to improve. Specifically, the temperatures (T) and densities (ρ) involved can reach up to 10^12 K and 10^15 g/cm³, respectively. These extreme conditions can only be replicated in laboratory experiments using relativistic heavy-ion collisions. However, due to the short time scales involved, these experiments do not allow us to study the formation of light elements directly; instead, they provide insights into the properties of dense matter that may be relevant to the conditions present during the initial stages of supernova explosions. Conversely, the patterns of abundances observed in primordial stars, such as Population II stars or metal-poor stars, provide important constraints on the theoretical models regarding the formation of light elements in the early universe.

We consider the problem of scheduling jobs on parallel machines with preemption and failure, where each job consists of several tasks that must be processed in sequence by different machines. We assume that if any task fails to complete processing before its deadline then all remaining tasks for this job are lost. In addition we allow preemptions at no cost within each machine but not across machines. Our objective is to minimize total completion time subject to deadlines associated with individual tasks.  We show how our results can be used to obtain an O(log n)-approximation algorithm for minimizing makespan when there may be failures during execution. Finally, we present some open problems related to our work. The research described here was supported by NSF grant CCF-0635035. This document contains supplemental material to  1  . 
Contents

A Proofs of Lemmas 1-7
B Proof of Theorem 8 B

We present the discovery of an eclipsing binary system, HS1857 + 5144, consisting of two white dwarfs with masses of approximately 0.6 M☉ each. The orbital period of this system is about 1.5 hours. Our analysis reveals a mass ratio of M2/M1 = 0.84 ± 0.04, determined through spectral disentangling techniques. This finding suggests that the system may be in a pre-merger phase, before evolving into a single degenerate star. Additionally, we observed a significant temperature difference between the two components. These characteristics imply that the system has recently emerged from a common envelope phase. 

Keywords: Hot subdwarf B stars; Eclipsing binaries; Pre-Cataclysmic Variables; White Dwarfs; Spectral Disentangling.

We present an improved method for solving radiative transfer (RT) problems using smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH). The new scheme is based on the Monte Carlo approach, which has been shown to be accurate and efficient when applied to RT problems with optically thick media. We have implemented this algorithm into our existing SPH code, Gadget-2, and tested it by simulating the collapse of a molecular cloud core under the influence of radiation pressure. Our results show that the inclusion of radiation feedback leads to more realistic models of protostellar accretion disks than those obtained without including any form of radiation physics. In addition, we find that the disk mass increases as the strength of the radiation field decreases. This suggests that the effect of photoevaporation may play an important role during the early stages of disk evolution. 
 
 Keywords: Radiative transfer, Smoothed particle hydrodynamics

rewrite_text: We present a method for evaluating Hankel determinants that is as efficient as traditional algorithms, but avoids the instability often associated with them. The determinant of a matrix A = (aij) of size n×n can be expressed in terms of its minors as det(A) = ∑(−1)^(i+j) * aij * det(Aij), where Aij is the submatrix obtained by removing the i-th row and j-th column. We demonstrate how to compute this expression efficiently using O((n^2)(log n)) arithmetic operations and storage by combining fast matrix multiplication algorithms with techniques from numerical linear algebra. Our approach allows us to compute all minors simultaneously for any point x in the interval [0, 1] using only O((n^2)(log n)) arithmetic operations and storage space. This enables us to leverage fast polynomial evaluation methods to transform the task of computing the determinant into evaluating polynomials at multiple points. Finally, we apply advanced techniques from numerical analysis to improve our time complexity bound.

We compare the magnetic flux distribution in coronal holes (CHs) with that in quiet regions using vector magnetograms observed by Hinode/SOT/SP. We find that CHs have more open field lines than quiet regions, but they also contain many closed loops. The total unsigned magnetic flux density is higher for CHs than for quiet regions at all heights above the photosphere. In addition to this difference in the amount of magnetic flux, we found that the spatial distributions are different as well; the magnetic flux density decreases faster with height in CHs compared to quiet regions. This result suggests that there may be some differences in the physical processes occurring in these two types of solar regions. (1998) , Cranmer & van Ballegooijen (2005) ).
The structure of CHs has been studied extensively both observationally and theoretically. It was suggested early on that CHs consist mainly of open field lines connected to remote parts of the Sun (Krieger et al. (1971) ), while closed loops were rarely seen inside them (Wiegelmann et al. (2010a) ). However, recent observations show that CHs do contain closed loops (Wiegelmann etal. (2010b) , Parnell et al. (2011 ), DeForest et al. (2013 , Brooks et al. (2014) ). These results suggest that CHs should not simply be regarded as open-field regions without any closed-loop structures.

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of planet-hosting binary systems, utilizing spectroscopic methods to identify binaries among stars observed by Kepler, for which we have secured high-resolution follow-up data. Our findings indicate that planets are more likely to be found around close visual binaries (less than 2 AU) compared to more distant systems (greater than 20 AU). The distinction between these two populations is statistically significant, exceeding a 3-sigma confidence level. These results suggest that the multiplicity of stars may play a role in shaping planetary system architectures. However, our sample size is limited compared to other studies, and further investigation is necessary before drawing definitive conclusions. Keywords: Binary Systems - Planets - Multiplicity - Kepler - Visual Doubles - Planet Formation - Circumstellar Disks - Exoplanets - Circumbinary Systems - Spectroscopic Binaries.

We consider the energy conditions in cosmology, which are necessary for the existence of matter with positive pressure. We show that these conditions can be violated by quantum effects at high energies. In particular, we find that the universe is accelerating now because of such violations. The results obtained agree well with observations.

This fact was confirmed later on by numerous observational data  3  . However, it remains unclear what causes this phenomenon. In this study, we introduce a method based on a Jarvis-inspired Eisenhower approach for input categorization and clustering in self-organizing networks. Our proposed framework operates on the premise that each neuron can be characterized as a cluster, reconstructed using its own weight vector. Alongside standard NG learning updates, we allow neurons to evolve by applying genetic operators such as mutation and crossover. Through experiments conducted on benchmark datasets, we demonstrate that our approach surpasses other state-of-the-art algorithms, including Self-Organizing Maps (SOMs), Growing Neural Gas (GNG), and Evolving Neural Gas (ENG). Furthermore, we illustrate how our proposed method can be effectively utilized in real-world applications such as text classification and image segmentation. 

Keywords: Evolutionary Computation, Self-Organizing Networks, Clustering, Genetic Algorithms, Text Classification, Image Segmentation.

1 Introduction  
Self-Organizing Maps (SOMs), originally developed by Kohonen, have been widely applied in various domains, including pattern recognition, speech processing, computer vision, and bioinformatics. However, a significant limitation of traditional SOMs is that they require users to specify the number of clusters in advance. To address this issue, several variations of SOMs have been proposed. Among these, the Growing Neural Gas (GNG) has gained attention for its ability to autonomously determine the topology of clusters during training. Nevertheless, most existing models of self-organizing networks suffer from two key drawbacks. First, all neurons in the network share the same set of parameters, hindering their ability to capture the distinct characteristics of different classes. Second, there is a lack of mechanisms to prevent overfitting when handling high-dimensional data.

We study the effect of measurement noise on the Markov property for stochastic processes with continuous state spaces and discrete time steps. We show that, under certain conditions, the noisy process is still Markovian if its transition probabilities are modified by an exponential factor depending only on the noise level. This result can be used to derive efficient algorithms for computing the stationary distribution of such processes. The results presented here generalize previous work on this topic which was restricted to finite-state-space models. In addition we provide examples illustrating how our theory applies to several important classes of stochastic processes including diffusion processes, autoregressive moving average (ARMA) processes, and hidden Markov models. 
I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK
The main goal of this article is to present some new theoretical results about the effects of measurement noise on the statistical behavior of stochastic processes. These results will then be applied to develop efficient numerical methods for estimating the stationary distributions of various types of stochastic processes. Our approach relies heavily on recent advances made in the field of nonlinear filtering  1  , where it has been shown that many interesting problems related to estimation or prediction can often be solved efficiently using techniques based on the concept of particle filters  2  .

We present our findings on the spatial distributions of galaxies around a bright quasar at redshift 5.2, located less than 5 megaparsecs away, using deep near-infrared imaging data obtained from the Subaru/Suprime-Cam. Our analysis reveals a significant spatial segregation between Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs), identified by their ultraviolet photometric signatures, and Lyman Alpha Emitters (LAEs). The LBGs show a distinct overdensity in the quasar's vicinity, while the LAEs do not exhibit a similar concentration. This observation suggests that the conditions for star formation might differ between these two populations. 

**Keywords:** quasar environments, clustering, high-redshift astronomy, Lyman Break Galaxies, Lyman Alpha Emitters 

**1 Introduction**   
Quasars serve as crucial probes for understanding the universe because they provide insights into the intergalactic medium through the absorption lines visible in their spectra. Additionally, quasars emit intense radiation across a wide range of wavelengths, making them valuable sources for investigating the properties of their surrounding environments. It has been proposed that quasars may initiate starburst activity in nearby regions through their ultraviolet (UV) radiation and/or feedback mechanisms (e.g., Hopkins et al. 2006). Recently, multiple studies have examined the environments of high-redshift quasars through multi-wavelength observations, including optical and near-infrared spectroscopy (e.g., Adelberger & Steidel 2005; Venemans et al. 2007), radio continuum emissions (e.g., Carilli et al. 2007; Overzier et al. 2008), and X-ray emissions (e.g., Brandt et al. 2002; Gilli et al. 2003). However, much of the existing research has focused on relatively small scales (less than 1 Mpc) due to limitations in angular resolution and telescope capabilities. Some studies have suggested the presence of larger-scale structures associated with quasars (e.g., Kurk et al. 2000; Pentericci et al.).

We find that these abundances are consistent with those predicted by standard stellar evolution theory when we take into account the effects of nuclear burning during the thermally pulsing asymptotic giant branch phase.  The observed chemical composition is also compatible with predictions made using theoretical yields calculated with state-of-the-art nucleosynthesis models including both convective overshoot mixing and rotation-induced mixing processes.

rewrite_text: We present observations of outflows from recovered protostars in the vicinity of foxes, conducted using the Submillimeter Array (SMA) at 1.3 mm. These findings are compared with observations from Norwegian dish telescopes. Our analysis indicates that SMA data reveals more compact structures than those observed from other sources, likely due to missing data and/or resolution issues. The total mass loss rate inferred for these sources ranges between 10^-4 and 10^-3 M☉ per year, while their luminosity levels are between 10^-2 and 10^1 L☉ per second. These observations are consistent with those found for low-mass Class 0 protostars but differ when considering the luminosity-to-mass ratio. This suggests that there may be additional factors driving the outflows beyond the previously observed mechanisms. Additionally, we report on the significant infall of material toward two of our targets. For G35.20-1.74NW, we detect an infall velocity of approximately 0.5 km/s over a distance of about 1000 AU. For IRAS 18162-2048, we observe evidence of both inward and outward motions along different lines of sight.

original_text: The measurement calculus is an extension to the standard quantum mechanics formalism that allows for measurements on composite systems, and it has been used in several recent works as well as in this thesis.  The main idea behind the measurement calculus is to consider all possible outcomes of a measurement process as separate states of the system being measured instead of just one outcome (as done by von Neumann). This approach leads naturally to considering the set of all possible measurement results as a new state space called the effect algebra. In addition, the measurement calculus provides a way to describe how different measurement processes can be combined into more complex ones using so-called instruments. Finally, the measurement calculus also includes a description of what happens when we perform a measurement on a system whose state is not known exactly but only up to some uncertainty. The measurement calculus was first introduced by Aharonov et al., and since then there have been many papers written about its properties and applications.

rewrite_text: We analyze a sample of satellite galaxies in a simulated environment at z = 0 using high-resolution cosmological hydrodynamic simulations from the Millennium Run. We find that there is no significant deviation between the density profiles of satellites orbiting around prominent central objects with varying luminosities or halo masses. The radial distribution of satellites exhibits an excess compared to predictions made using the subhalo abundance matching technique for distances less than 30 kpc/h. This excess can be attributed to tidal stripping of satellites prior to their accretion onto the central objects. Moreover, we observe that the fraction of surviving satellites decreases rapidly with increasing distance from the centers of their host halos. Finally, we examine how the characteristics of satellites correlate with those of their hosts. Our analysis suggests that the majority of heavily stripped satellites have been significantly affected by mergers and tidal disruptions during their infall into larger structures. These results provide crucial constraints on models of galaxy formation.

We study the slow wave resonance (SWR) effect for periodically layered media with an arbitrary number N of anisotropic layers, each characterized by its own permittivity tensor and thickness. We show that SWR is possible only if all principal axes of the permittivity tensors are parallel to one another within each layer. In this case we derive explicit expressions for the dispersion relation between the frequency f and the Bloch wavenumber kx. The results obtained can be used as guidelines for designing multilayered structures exhibiting strong SWR effects at low frequencies. 
 
 Keywords: Slow wave resonance; Anisotropy; Multilayer structure; Dispersion relations. 1 Introduction 
 
 Periodic multilayers consisting of alternating thin films made of different materials have attracted considerable attention during recent years due to their unique properties  1  . These include high reflectance  2  , negative refraction  3  , enhanced nonlinear optical response  4  , etc., which make them promising candidates for various applications such as optoelectronic devices  5  or photovoltaics  6  .
 
In particular, it has been shown recently  7–9  that periodic multilayers composed of anisotropic layers may exhibit very interesting electromagnetic phenomena including slow wave resonance (S WR). This phenomenon occurs when the phase velocity of the Bloch waves becomes equal to zero inside the medium  10  . It leads to extremely large values of the effective refractive index n eff = c / v ph  11  where c is the speed of light in vacuum and v ph is the phase velocity of the propagating Bloch mode  12  . As a result, the corresponding transmission spectrum exhibits sharp peaks associated with narrow stop bands  13  . Such features are highly desirable for many practical applications  14  . 
 
 However, despite numerous theoretical studies devoted to S WR in periodic multilayers  15–18  , there still exist several open questions related to the conditions under which this phenomenon takes place  19, 20  . For example, it was found experimentally  21  that the presence of a single misaligned anisotropic layer destroys the S WR effect completely even though other layers remain perfectly aligned. rewrite_text: We present an analysis of archival Chandra data for the central region of the nearby starburst galaxy M82 (NGC 3034). Our investigation reveals two bright, point-like sources in this area, which have been identified as Ultra-Luminous X-Ray Sources (ULXs) by Swartz et al. (2004). The first source is located at RA = 12h 54m 55s.6 and Dec = 69° 59' 45", with a count rate of 1.1 × 10^-3 counts/sec. This source has a luminosity of approximately 2 × 10^39 erg/sec, assuming it is at a distance of 8 kpc. The second source is found at RA = 12h 54m 55s.7 and Dec = 69° 59' 46", exhibiting a count rate of 0.9 × 10^-3 counts/sec, and it also has a luminosity of about 2 × 10^39 erg/sec at the same distance. Both sources appear to exhibit variability on timescales ranging from hours to days, which suggests that they may consist of black holes accreting near their Eddington limit.

original_text: We present the results of cosmological simulations aimed at studying the formation and evolution of tidally stripped satellite galaxies in clusters, which we refer to as  tidal dwarfs  (TDs). We find that TDs are formed by the stripping of gas-rich satellites during their first pericentric passage through the cluster potential well. The resulting TDs have masses ranging between 10^8 M_sun and 10^10 M_sun, sizes smaller than 100 pc, and circular velocities larger than 50 km/s. They evolve into more massive systems with higher surface brightnesses after several orbits within the host galaxy s virial radius. Our results suggest that TDs may be responsible for some fraction of the diffuse intracluster light observed around nearby rich clusters. Tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) are small star forming objects found near interacting or merging galaxies. Their origin is still debated but it has been suggested that they form when gas-rich satellites pass close enough to the center of the parent galaxy to become tidally disrupted. In this work we study the formation and evolution of TDGs using high resolution hydrodynamical cosmological zoom-in simulations performed with the code RAMSES-RT. We show that TDGs can be produced by the disruption of gas-rich satellites during the first pericenter passage inside the host galaxy halo. These TDGs typically have masses between 108M⊙ and 1011M⊙, sizes below 100pc, and circular velocities above 50km/s. After several orbital periods these TDGs grow in mass and size becoming brighter and bluer. Finally, our results indicate that TDGs could contribute up to 50% of the total amount of diffuse intra-cluster light observed around nearby rich galaxy clusters.

rewrite_text: We present our findings on the observation and characterization of two-dimensional defect modes in optically-induced photonic crystals (OIPCs). These OIPCs are created through periodic modulation of the refractive index using femtosecond laser pulses directed into fused silica glass. We demonstrate that the defect modes can be tuned across a wide range of wavelengths, influenced by the periodicity of the photonic crystal as well as the dimensions of the defects. This research paves the way for innovative designs of optical devices utilizing these structures. Photonic crystal slabs have gained significant attention recently, as they offer an effective platform for investigating light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. Notably, three-dimensional photonic crystals with point or line defects can support localized states within their bandgap, leading to various intriguing applications such as lasers, sensors, and nonlinear optics. However, the fabrication of three-dimensional photonic crystals typically requires complex methods, which can complicate their integration with other nanoscale structures. Recently, several studies have demonstrated the successful fabrication of two-dimensional photonic crystals via direct laser writing techniques. These 2D photonic crystals provide advantages in terms of ease of fabrication, design flexibility, and compatibility with existing technologies. In this letter, we illustrate the emergence of defect modes in optically-induced photonic crystals (OPC). The OPCs are created by periodically modulating the refractive index using femtosecond laser pulses in fused silica glass. By introducing defects into the periodic structure, we observe localized defect modes within the stopband of the OPC. Moreover, we find that the defect modes can be tuned across the entire stopband by varying the spacing and/or the size of the defects. The setup used to create the OPC is depicted schematically in Fig. 1(a). A Ti:Sapphire regenerative amplifier operating at 800 nm produces pulses with a duration of 100 fs at a repetition rate of 1 kHz. original_text: We present results for multidimensional, multi-group flux-limited diffusion (MGFLD) calculations of convection and acoustic oscillations in the postbounce phase of corecollapse supernovae using an approximate treatment of neutrino transport. We find that our MGFLD models are able to reproduce many features observed in recent two-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations including the growth rate of the SASI as well as its characteristic spiral mode structure. The MGFLD models also show similar behavior when we compare their shock radii evolution during the first few hundred milliseconds after bounce. However, there is some quantitative disagreement between the two approaches concerning the amplitude of the SASI which may be due to differences in the numerical methods used or possibly deficiencies in the MGFLD approach itself. In addition, we have performed several test runs where we artificially suppressed either the advective or the acoustic part of the MGFLD scheme. These tests indicate that both parts contribute significantly to the overall dynamics of the system but that the advective part plays by far the dominant role.

We present an analytical solution for the steady-state distribution underlying the mechanistic home-range model developed by Moorcroft et al. (2006). This model is optimized for efficient computation of home ranges using integrated numerical methods. The implementation of the model is part of the R package adehabitatHR, which includes functions for calculating home ranges using the original approach (unpublished, without the partners’ solution). We illustrate how our method allows for rapid computation of home ranges over extensive landscapes composed of habitat patches. Our results indicate that the analytical solution yields home ranges comparable to those generated by the original method, though it requires less computational time when estimating home ranges over large spatial scales. Analytical solutions are particularly valuable since they enable researchers to estimate home ranges on large datasets or at finer resolutions. 

Home ranges have been a significant area of study in ecology since their introduction over 50 years ago. They represent the area within which individuals acquire essential resources such as food, shelter, mates, and cover. Beyond enhancing our understanding of animal behavior, home ranges are critical in conservation biology, wildlife management, epidemiology, and broader ecological research. Home-range models postulate that animals navigate through a mosaic of habitat patches. The movement of animals among these patches is influenced by various factors, including resource availability, vegetation structure, predation risk, and social interactions. This dynamic continues until a balance is reached between movement rates and resource availability.

Multiple approaches exist for modeling animal movement. Some models assume that animals exhibit random behavior when determining their direction, but this assumption may not always hold. For instance, if two adjacent patches offer similar resources, animals may frequently switch between them, defying the independence postulate. To address this type of behavioral complexity, Moorcroft and colleagues...

We study the nonlinear dynamics of semiconductor superlattices (SLs) under an external magnetic field, which is applied at an angle to SL layers. We show that this configuration leads to new types of bifurcation phenomena such as period doubling cascades and chaotic attractors. The results are obtained by solving numerically the coupled Schrödinger-Poisson equations for the electron wave function and electrostatic potential using the split-step Fourier method. 
 
 In particular we consider GaAs/AlGaAs SLs grown along  001  direction on top of a semi-insulating substrate. This system has been studied experimentally in Refs.  1-3  where it was shown that the application of a magnetic field perpendicularly to the growth axis causes the formation of Landau levels. However, if the magnetic field is tilted away from the normal incidence then the degeneracy between different Landau levels is lifted leading to additional effects like Bloch oscillations  4  .

These peaks were attributed to the excitation of electrons across the energy gap into higher-lying states. It should be noted however that these experiments have not yet revealed any evidence of chaotic behavior or other complex dynamical features predicted theoretically  5-7  . 
 
 Here we present numerical simulations showing how the tilting of the magnetic field affects the nonlinear dynamics of the system. Our calculations reveal several interesting features including periodic windows, period-doubling cascade and chaotic attractor.

rewrite_text: Reverberation is a crucial aspect of clarity function, yet its role remains somewhat unclear. We propose that reverberation can arise from the interaction between calcium dynamics and short-term plasticity (STP) at excitatory synapses. In our model, STP leads to a pause in spikes that is followed by periods of low firing rates caused by the depletion of neurotransmitter vesicles. This altered pattern of neurotransmitter release results in an increase in calcium concentration, which promotes the facilitation of glutamate release during the recovery phase. This positive feedback loop supports sustained reverberatory activity across multiple time scales. We suggest that reverberation plays a significant role in the recovery of neural function in certain brain areas. Reverberation is one of the most notable features of brain activity and has been observed in various species, including in the repetitive activity of the hippocampus, neocortex, thalamus, striatum, cerebellar cortex, olfactory bulbs, and retina. Despite its common occurrence, the specific functional roles of reverberation in neural processing are still not fully understood. Some theories propose that reverberation aids in memory storage or retrieval, while others suggest it could serve as a substrate for working memory or provide a mechanism for temporal processing. Additionally, some studies indicate that reverberation may reflect ongoing spontaneous neural activity.

original_text: We present new results on modelling the effects of clumps in stellar winds on their observed linear and circular polarization signatures, using Monte Carlo radiative transfer simulations. We find that for stars with high mass-loss rates (Ṁ > 10-7 M⊙ yr-1), the presence of clumps can significantly affect both the degree and angle of linear polarization produced by scattering processes within the wind. For lower mass loss rate objects (Ṁ < 10-7 M⊙yr-1) we find that the effect is less pronounced but still significant enough to be detectable at certain wavelengths. The predicted changes are found to depend strongly upon the properties of the individual clumps; specifically, they increase as the number density contrast between the clumps and surrounding medium increases. In addition, we show how these predictions may be used to constrain the physical parameters describing the clumpy structure of the wind.  These findings have important implications for future observations of hot-star winds which will be made possible through the use of next-generation instruments such as SPHERE/VLT and GPI/Gemini Observatory.

We present the first detailed analysis of the atmospheric characteristics of exoplanets with rectangular heat distribution—specifically, those that exhibit extreme greenhouse effects—using 3D general circulation models that incorporate radiative transfer and realistic opacities. Our findings indicate that nighttime temperatures are heavily influenced by opacity, which governs how heat can be transported to the night side of the planet. As we reduce opacity, the contrast between day and night temperatures increases, as the atmosphere on the nightside becomes less effective at retaining heat. This effect becomes more significant at lower opacity levels, where convection is less efficient. In cases of sufficiently low opacities, the planet can cool completely during its nighttime period, resulting in a cold night atmosphere. Our simulations demonstrate that exoplanets are likely to have diverse climatic conditions based on their atmospheric composition. 

Keywords: General Circulation Modeling, Extrasolar Planetary Systems, Radiation Transfer, Climate, Atmosphere, Energy Transport, Convection, Cooling Rates, Day-Night Contrast.

In this paper, we propose an underwater acoustic communication system using orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) combined with direct sequence code division multiple access (DS-CDMA). The proposed scheme is based on the combination of two techniques that are widely used in terrestrial wireless communications to achieve higher data rates. In order to reduce the effect of multipath fading caused by channel dispersion, cyclic prefixes are inserted into each symbol block before transmission. We also present simulation results showing performance comparisons between our proposed method and conventional single-carrier systems. Finally, we show that the proposed technique can be applied to high-speed underwater acoustic channels. Keywords: Underwater acoustic communication; Orthogonal frequency division multiplexing; Direct sequence code division multiple access; Channel dispersion; Multipath fading: Cyclic prefixes; High-speed underwater acoustic channels. 1 Introduction Acoustic waves have been extensively studied as a means of transmitting information over water due to their low cost and ease of deployment  1  . However, the limited bandwidth available at frequencies below 10 kHz has restricted the achievable data rates  2  .
Recently, there has been growing interest in developing broadband underwater acoustic communication systems capable of supporting high data rates  3  -  6  . One promising approach involves combining orthogonal frequency division multiplexing(OFDM), which was originally developed for use in wired and wireless radio-frequency applications  7  , with direct-sequence code-division multiple-access (DS-CDMA), which is commonly employed in cellular mobile networks  8  . This hybrid scheme combines the advantages of both technologies while mitigating some of their disadvantages  9  . For example, it allows us to exploit the large number of subcarriers offered by OFDM to combat inter-symbol interference (ISI) resulting from dispersive channels  10  . It also enables DS-CDMA to provide robustness against narrowband interferers  11  .

rewrite_text: We present an analysis of Lyman Alpha Emitters (LAEs) selected using narrowband imaging with Subaru/Suprime-Cam, followed by spectroscopic observations with VLT/VIMOS at a redshift of z ~ 3.1, which marks a highly active period for galaxy formation. Our study reveals that LAEs are distributed across a wide range of environments; they are found in both dense regions and more isolated areas. The clustering properties of LAEs vary with their luminosities. Specifically, we found that bright LAEs exhibit stronger clustering than their fainter counterparts. This suggests that bright LAEs may be more evolved than dimmer ones. Furthermore, we explored the relationship between clustering and the equivalent widths of Lyman-alpha emission lines. Our analysis indicates that strong clustering is associated with larger equivalent widths. These findings suggest a connection between LAEs and Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs). Keywords: Lyman Alpha Emitters.

original_text: Fullerenes are spherical molecules composed entirely of sp2-hybridized carbons, which can be arranged in different ways to form various allotropes with unique properties. The most common is the C60 molecule (buckminsterfullerene), but other forms such as nanotubes or graphene have also been reported. Fullerenes were first discovered by Kroto et al., who received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1996 for their work on them.  In this study we report on the growth mechanism and structural characterization of novel carbon-based nanomaterials that consist of an amorphous network of interconnected nanoparticles resembling fullerenes. These structures grow spontaneously when evaporating carbon atoms onto silicon substrates at temperatures between 600-700 °C under ultrahigh vacuum conditions. We show how these new carbon nanostructures exhibit remarkable mechanical properties including high elasticity and hardness combined with low friction coefficients making them ideal candidates for use as protective coatings against wear and corrosion.

rewrite_text: We present our findings on the ferromagnetic behavior in manganese (Mn)-doped zinc oxide (ZnO) thin films, synthesized using pulsed laser deposition (PLD). We discovered that all samples, regardless of their doping levels, exhibit Curie temperatures around 300 K, which is significantly higher than previously reported values. Our observations indicate that magnetization increases linearly as the external magnetic field decreases and demonstrates hysteresis loops at low fields. These results suggest that the ferromagnetic behavior originates from an exchange coupling between localized spins rather than intrinsic ferromagnetism. There is a growing interest in developing materials for spintronic applications, such as nonvolatile memory devices, which leverage the manipulation of electron spins rather than charge carriers. Among these materials, diluted magnetic semiconductors (DMS) have garnered considerable attention due to their dual site and magnetic functionalities. ZnO-based DMSs, in particular, have been extensively researched because of their wide bandgap (3.37 eV), substantial exciton binding energy (60 meV), high transparency, and material stability. However, achieving high-temperature ferromagnetism in ZnO-based DMSs has proven challenging. Although several studies have recently demonstrated observations of room-temperature ferromagnetic ordering in various ZnO-based DMS systems, most have reported relatively low saturation magnetizations. In this report, we document the observation of high-temperature ferromagnetism in Mn-doped ZnO-based DMSs produced through PLD. Our findings indicate that the dopant plays a crucial role in determining the Curie temperature. Specifically, our sample with a doping concentration of 0.5% exhibits a Curie temperature of approximately 300 K, while those with lower doping levels show Curie temperatures ranging from 150 to 250 K. Additionally, we found that the magnetization increases linearly as the external magnetic field is reduced below 1 T, with hysteretic behavior observed at very low fields. These results point to a robust ferromagnetic response in the studied materials.

original_text: We present chemical abundances for a sample of 16 Planetary Nebulae (PNe) in the Small Magellanic cloud, obtained with high resolution spectroscopy at the VLT and Keck telescopes. The PNe are located along an age sequence ranging between 1 Myr to 13 Gyrs. We find that the abundance patterns of CNO elements show no significant differences among these objects. This is consistent with previous studies which found little or no evidence for enrichment by AGB stars during this period.  However we do detect some variations in the Ne/O ratio as a function of time. These results suggest that the SMC experienced two episodes of star formation separated by about 10 billion years. In addition, our data indicate that there was only one episode of massive star formation within the last 2 billion years. Finally, we compare our results with those derived from H II regions and young open clusters in order to investigate possible systematic effects due to different evolutionary stages and/or stellar populations.

We present the analysis of the twist distribution amplitudes (DAs) for axial vector mesons in relation to their helicity states, obtained by solving the Bethe-Salpeter equation using an instantaneous approximation and by employing recently developed techniques for DAs. We find that the twist-2 DA is characterized by its first Gegenbauer moment, while the higher moments are significant primarily at large momentum fractions (x > 0.7). The twist-3 DA consists of two independent functions, one of which is proportional to the second Gegenbauer moment. Our findings indicate that the twist-4 DA is negligible compared to those of lower twists. These results will be beneficial for studying exclusive decays of axial vector mesons, such as B-meson decays into charmonium plus a photon or a pion pair.

I. INTRODUCTION
The dynamics of hadronic interactions play a crucial role in comprehending the strong forces between quarks and gluons within hadrons. Specifically, the parton distribution functions provide insights into the distribution of quarks and gluons inside hadrons. Recently, there has been significant progress in investigating the internal structures of hadrons beyond the leading twist approximation, including the analysis of transverse momentum-dependent parton distributions. In this study, we focus on a different type of nonperturbative object—the light-cone distribution amplitudes (DAs). These amplitudes describe the probability of finding a quark-antiquark pair with a given longitudinal momentum fraction and transverse position at a fixed light-like separation. It has been demonstrated that they play an important role in exclusive processes. For example, the decay constants \( f_{B\pi} \) and \( f_{Bs} \) can be expressed in terms of the lowest-order DAs, and the rates for semileptonic decays \( B \to \pi l \nu_l \) and \( B \to K l \nu_l \) depend on both the lowest and higher-order DAs. Additionally, it has been shown that the heavy-to-light transition form factor \( F_V \) for \( B \to V \) transitions depends on these distribution amplitudes.

original_text: The Generator Coordinate Method (GCM) is an efficient approach to calculate the electronic structure and properties of materials with strong electron-phonon coupling, such as polar semiconductors or insulators. In this work we present a new implementation of GCM within Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory (TDDFT), which allows us to study phonon-assisted optical excitations on large systems. The key idea behind our scheme is that it exploits the fact that TDDFT can be formulated as a linear response problem for the Kohn-Sham system, so that the calculation of the ground state wavefunction does not need to be repeated at each step during the self-consistent field iteration. We demonstrate the efficiency of our algorithm by calculating the absorption spectrum of bulk silicon under hydrostatic pressure up to 100 GPa. Our results show good agreement with previous calculations based on supercell approaches.

(2007). We employed two different methods to estimate BH masses for this sample: the virial method and the continuum-Santos method. The MF is constructed using these estimates separately, as well as in combination. Our findings are compared against previous studies that utilized similar methods but differing approaches to determine BH masses. We find that our derived schechter parameters are consistent within uncertainties with those obtained previously. This excess may be attributed to incompleteness or biases in the selection criteria used in this analysis. Additionally, we compare our results with those reported by Hopkins et al. (2006a) and Shankar et al. (2009b).

We report the observation of magnetic fluctuations at low temperatures and high fields in single crystals of YBa2Cu3O6+x (YBCO) with x=0.4, 0.45, and 0.5 using muon spin relaxation measurements. The data show that these materials are characterized by an unusual temperature dependence of the fluctuation rate which is not consistent with predictions based on Fermi liquid theory or any other conventional model for fermionic quasiparticles. We argue that this behavior can be understood within a phenomenological description of the electronic excitations as bosonic collective modes. These results provide strong evidence against the existence of well-defined fermionic quasiparticles in the normal state of these compounds. They also suggest that the pseudogap phase may have some features in common with the superfluid state. 
 
 High-temperature cuprate superconductors exhibit many remarkable properties including a rich variety of competing ground states. In particular, it has been suggested that they undergo a quantum phase transition into a novel ordered state known as the  pseudogap  phase  1  . This phase appears to exist between the underdoped regime where there is no static order but only short-range correlations  2  , and the overdoped regime where antiferromagnetism disappears  3  . It is believed that the pseudogap state plays an important role in understanding the mechanism responsible for high-Tc superconductivity  4  .
In recent years much attention has focused on the possibility that the pseudogap is associated with preformed pairs of charge carriers  5  . However, despite considerable experimental effort  6  , direct evidence for such pairing remains elusive  7, 8  . One possible explanation for this lack of success is that the pseudogap does not arise directly from pair formation  9  . Instead, it could result from the condensation of another type of collective mode  10  . For example, if the pseudogap were related to the onset of density wave ordering  11  then one would expect to see signatures of its presence in the form of low-energy magnetic fluctuations  12  . Indeed, several experiments have reported the detection of such fluctuations  13  -  16  .

The author addresses the issue of gravitational interaction between bodies by examining their informational content. The central idea is that the gravitational field can be perceived as a medium through which gravitons transmit information about the source body. Gravitational fields are treated as carriers of information regarding the state of the gravitating body. This perspective helps explain certain phenomena observed in astrophysics, such as the Pioneer anomaly, as well as in cosmology. Additionally, the author suggests utilizing the concept of informational potential to describe the evolution of the universe. This article was published in the journal *Classical and Quantum Gravity*, Volume 27, Issue 14, Pages 5993 - 6010, in November 2010. DOI: 10.1088/0264-9381/27/14/05993. Abstract: We explore the problem of gravitational interaction among bodies in terms of their information content. The main idea is that gravitational fields can be viewed as the medium for gravitons, which convey information about the source body; hence, these fields are seen as carriers of information regarding the state of the gravitating body. This perspective allows us to provide insights into certain phenomena observed in astrophysics (e.g., the Pioneer anomaly) as well as in cosmology (e.g., various cosmic phenomena). Moreover, we propose using the concept of informational potential to describe the evolution of the universe.

rewrite_text: We suggest that the metallic enhancement observed in certain pre-main-sequence T Tauri stars (PTTS) is attributable to the accumulation of planetesimals during their formation phase, a process driven by rapid planet formation and the ejection of planets into distant orbits. This hypothesis can account for both the high metallicity observed in PTTS and the low abundance ratios of refractory elements like Mg/Si or Al/Si compared to the ratios observed in objects formed through the standard core-accretion model. Furthermore, this explanation clarifies the absence of close-in giant planets around PTTS, even though these stars have undergone significant evolution in their protoplanetary disks. Our model predicts that most PTTS should possess at least one Jupiter-mass planet located at a distance greater than 1 AU. Additionally, we anticipate that many PTTS will exhibit infrared excesses resulting from the presence of debris disks formed by collisions between planetary bodies.

original_text: We present new results on diffuse gamma-ray emission produced by cosmic rays interacting with interstellar gas, based on data collected during the first year of operation of the Large Area Telescope (LAT) aboard Fermi satellite. We find that this component is well described by a power law spectrum with index ~2.3 extending up to 100 GeV. The total flux above 1 GeV amounts to about 10% of the observed Galactic diffuse emission at these energies. This result confirms previous estimates obtained using EGRET data. In addition we report an upper limit for the flux of unresolved point sources below 10 GeV which is consistent with predictions made within the framework of standard models of cosmic ray origin and propagation. Finally, we discuss implications of our findings for the interpretation of observations performed towards the supernova remnant RX J1713.7--3946. PACS numbers: 98.70.Sa, 95.55.Ym

rewrite_text: We present our findings on the extrasolar planet WASP-121b (1SWASP J140747.93-394542.7), observed using the Spitzer Space Telescope's IRAC at wavelengths of 3.6 and 4.5 microns. The data were collected over two epochs to allow us to investigate any potential changes in the planet's properties over time. Our analysis shows that the variation in the planet's brightness is consistent with prior optical observations; however, we do not detect any significant changes between the two epochs. This suggests that there are no substantial fluctuations in the temperature or composition of the planet as it orbits its host star. Our results indicate that WASP-121b has a very high albedo in both observed wavelengths, which may be attributed to clouds and/or haze. These discoveries have significant implications for our understanding of how planets form and evolve. Keywords: exoplanet, infrared.

We investigate substantial adiabatic charge transport across a quantum dot connected to two leads, where one lead is influenced by a time-varying gate voltage while the other remains in equilibrium. We demonstrate that this configuration can function as an electron pump, particularly when the driving force acts resonantly between the singlet and triplet states of the quantum dot. Specifically, we find that the pump current will flow whenever the Fermi energy aligns with a bound state within the gap created by the Coulomb interaction in the quantum dot. The magnitude of this current increases with temperature \( T \), allowing us to utilize the system as a thermometer. Finally, we discuss the implications of our findings when the driving frequency exceeds or approaches the charging energy \( U \). 

I. INTRODUCTORY REMARKS

In recent years, there has been a growing interest in using pulsed drives as sources of coherent quantum transport. This concept was initially proposed over two decades ago but has only recently seen experimental realization. A particularly intriguing class of periodically driven systems consists of those whose properties are highly sensitive to their internal degrees of freedom. These models, often referred to as impurity models, have garnered considerable attention because they offer insights into a variety of phenomena, ranging from quantum dot transistors to heavy fermion systems. Recently, several studies have theoretically explored the potential of using quantum dots and carbon nanotubes as electron pumps. However, most existing work has focused on non-interacting models, while experiments typically involve strong interactions. Thus, there is a need to extend the current understanding beyond the weak-coupling regime. The goal of this work is to investigate the effects of electron correlations on the performance of a quantum dot-based electron pump. To achieve this, we consider a quantum dot connected to two leads via tunneling barriers. One lead is driven out of equilibrium by applying a time-varying gate voltage \( V_g(t) \), while the other lead acts as a reference electrode. The schematic representation of our setup is shown in Fig. 1.

original_text: We report on the X-ray properties of the young, nearby (d = 11 pc), low-mass binary system 2MASS J1101-2677AB discovered by Burgasser et al. (2007) . The primary component is an M8 dwarf with T eff ~ 2600 K and log g ~ 5.0 while its companion has been classified as an L5 brown dwarf with T eff ~ 1400K and log g ~ 4.2. We observed this target for about 50 ks using Chandra ACIS-S in order to search for evidence of coronal activity associated with either or both components. No significant emission was detected at the position of the source down to a 3-sigma upper limit of 1 x 10^28 erg s-1 cm-2 . This non-detection suggests that if there are active regions present they must be small and/or cool compared to those found on more massive stars. In addition we find no evidence of flaring behavior during our observation which constrains any possible magnetic field strength to less than 100 G.

We introduce a framework for generating solutions related to Barbara Jarvis within the context of the coupled Einstein-scalar equations. This method incorporates vacuum solutions alongside scalar fields in a manner that results in a minimally coupled outcome. It can be utilized to produce solutions that are not explicitly expressible as functions of certain parameters (e.g., by solving algebraic equations). We demonstrate our approach with several examples, including Schwarzschild-de Sitter black holes, Reissner-Nordström anti-de Sitter black holes, Kerr-Newman-AdS black holes, and charged dilatonic black holes. Introduction: Exact solutions play a crucial role in theoretical physics, as they enable us to test theoretical predictions against viable solutions. However, identifying physically interesting solutions often proves challenging. Historically, it took over a century after the formulation of general relativity for black hole solutions to be discovered. Despite this progress, significant questions regarding black holes persist. One major difficulty in finding these solutions arises from the fact that most interesting solutions do not possess any known analytic forms. Additionally, when attempting to find solutions associated with multiple fields, such as black holes surrounded by matter or other fields, the resulting equations typically become complex differential equations that require numerical methods for their exploration, complicating the resolution of various issues—even if their existence can be guaranteed theoretically. This challenge is further exacerbated when looking to study phenomena at strong coupling, where reliable solutions may be hindered by substantial corrections resulting from higher-order perturbative expansions.

original_text: We present the results of an investigation into the physical nature of polar broad absorption line quasars (BALQSOs). We present an exploration of the asteroseismic analysis of the franchise component in the binary star system Alpha Centauri, utilizing data collected with the HARPS spectrograph at La Silla Observatory in Chile. Our findings indicate the presence of two independent frequencies that are likely associated with rotationally induced modes. **ABSTRACT:** We report on the asteroseismic analysis of the F-type main-sequence star Alpha Centauri A, which is part of a close binary system with its cooler companion, Alpha Centauri B. Our study utilized high-precision radial velocity data collected over more than four years by the HARPS spectrograph at ESO's 3.6-meter telescope at La Silla Observatory in the Chilean Andes, along with photometric observations made simultaneously with the CoRoT satellite. By applying standard methods used in asteroseismology, we identified several periodicities in both datasets, including one signal whose periodicity matches the orbital period of the binary system. This finding supports the idea that the pulsational behavior of this star is influenced by tidal effects from its companion. Additionally, our analysis reveals another set of signals with periods ranging from about 1 day to just under 2 days. These signals can be attributed to rotationally induced p-mode oscillations excited in the convective zone of the star. Their presence provides strong evidence that the surface of Alpha Centauri A has been shaped by magnetic activity generated by dynamo processes within the convective zone.

original_text: We have performed neutron powder diffraction experiments on the intermetallic compound Sm2IrIn8 in order to determine its magnetic structure and compare it with that proposed for YbMgGaO4, another member of this family of compounds. This is similar to what was found previously for YbMgGaO4 but different than the theoretical prediction based on band-structure calculations which suggested that the ordered moment should be perpendicular to the c-axis.  We also find evidence for a structural phase transition near T* ~ 80 K where there are changes in both the lattice parameters as well as the unit cell volume. These results suggest that the low temperature crystal structure may not correspond exactly to the high-temperature tetragonal symmetry predicted by theory. Finally we present specific heat data showing clear anomalies associated with both the magnetic ordering and the structural phase transition.

We present the results for the equation of state (EoS) in hot Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). We use two different approaches to solve numerically the lattice QCD EoS at finite temperature, namely the Taylor expansion method and the integral method. The latter is based on an exact representation of the pressure as a function of energy density using Padé approximants. In addition we also study the dependence of the EoS on the number of flavors Nf . Finally, we compare our numerical results with those obtained by other authors within various theoretical frameworks. Our main conclusions are that both methods give consistent results which agree well with previous calculations performed in the literature. Moreover, it turns out that the inclusion of strange quarks has only minor effects on the thermodynamic quantities considered here.

Quantum repeaters are designed to address challenges in communication channels caused by signal loss. They utilize entangled photons and optical components such as beam splitters, phase shifters, and single-photon detectors. In this study, we present a prototype of a quantum repeater featuring two nodes connected via a 50 km fiber optic link. The implementation involves several components: (1) photon generation, (2) transmission, (3) detection of photon pairs at each node, (4) Bell-state measurement between the two nodes, and (5) feed-forward operation based on the results of the Bell-state measurement. We successfully demonstrated all of these components, except for the feed-forward operation, which is currently under investigation. Our results indicate that our setup can achieve high-fidelity entanglement over distances of up to 50 km. This experiment significantly advances the practical development of quantum networks. 

In previous studies, quantum repeaters have been proposed to mitigate issues caused by channel losses. They generate entangled photons locally or remotely and employ various optical components. In this report, we detail the operation of a long-distance quantum repeater, which includes the following components: (1) photon generation, (2) transmission, (3) detection, and (4) Bell-state measurement of photon pairs at each node, along with (5) feed-forward recovery based on the results of the Bell-state measurement, as illustrated in Figures 1(a), 1(b), and 2. A pair of polarization-entangled photons was produced through spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC), with one photon acting as the signal and the other as the idler. After traversing different paths, the photons were combined at a beam splitter and transmitted through the 50-km fiber optic link. At both ends of the fiber optic line, avalanche photodiodes (APDs) were employed to resolve the photons.

We study the random spatial growth in two dimensions, where new sites are added to an initially empty square lattice at randomly chosen locations and grow into circular clusters if they do not hit any existing cluster or obstacle site.  We show that this process leads to fractal structures which can be characterized by their fractal dimension Df = 1 + (1 - p)/2p, where p is the probability for adding a new site without hitting an obstacle. The results agree well with numerical simulations.

In recent years there has been considerable interest in studying various aspects of the so-called Eden model  1  . In its original formulation it describes the growth of a single cluster on a two-dimensional substrate starting from one seed particle. This simple concept was later generalized to include several seeds  2  , as well as different shapes  3  .
The present work deals with another generalization of the Eden model: Instead of growing only one cluster we consider the simultaneous growth of many clusters competing for space  4  . As a result, some clusters may become trapped between other clusters leading to a complex pattern formation.

We find that these films can exhibit anomalously large values for their Young's moduli and Poisson ratios. These findings have implications for designing novel materials with tailored elastic properties. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in understanding how confinement alters the mechanical behavior of materials at the nanoscale. This issue is particularly relevant when exploring the properties of thin films or nanowires with microstructures; however, it becomes more pronounced when the material is restricted to only a portion of its available configuration. Such conditions frequently occur during growth processes, where defects can be introduced into the material by impurities, or during the study of colloidal suspensions. In this work, we consider a thin film with a specific microstructure whose thickness \( h \) lies between two characteristic scales \( L \) and \( d \) (see Fig. 1). Here, \( L \) represents the typical size of the unit cell, while \( d \) denotes the spacing between layers. Both lengths are assumed to be smaller than the in-plane dimensions of the sample. Such structures are commonly found in layered materials, such as graphite, transition metal dichalcogenides, and hexagonal boron nitride. They are extensively utilized in various technological applications, including photovoltaics and optoelectronics. Figure 1 illustrates our model geometry, showing a thin film with microstructures constrained to rest upon a rigid substrate.

rewrite_text: The Large Area Telescope (LAT) is one of two instruments aboard NASA's Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope, which was launched in June 2008. The LAT comprises a sophisticated system of silicon strip trackers and cesium iodide (CsI) calorimeters that detect gamma rays with energies ranging from 20 MeV to over 300 GeV. This document outlines a novel method employed by the LAT collaboration to assess the performance of its tracking systems using gamma-ray data collected during various test periods prior to launch. We demonstrate how this approach can be used to characterize the performance of each individual tracker module as well as the overall resolution of the LAT. The results are compared against ground calibration measurements conducted before the launch. Furthermore, we show how these analyses have been effectively utilized to identify issues with certain modules after launch, which were addressed through a calibration process. The LAT has been actively observing sources of high-energy photons since its launch, and to carry out these observations, it must accurately measure the direction and energy of incoming gamma rays. To achieve this, the LAT employs a combination of silicon strip detectors and CsI(Tl) scintillators arranged in four layers around a tungsten converter. Each assembly includes 16 towers, or tracking sections, made up of four silicon detectors positioned at various angles to optimize photon detection. Additionally, there are eight scintillator blocks per tower located behind the tracking systems but outside the active volume of the calorimeter, resulting in a total of 56 independent tracking channels.

rewrite_text: We propose that the release of plasma in coronal mass ejections (CMEs) is caused by two distinct mechanisms: magnetic reconnection and the catastrophic loss of equilibrium due to ideal magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) instabilities. The first mechanism involves the release of stored magnetic energy in the corona, which occurs during solar eruptive events such as flares or CMEs. This process has been extensively studied using numerical simulations based on resistive MHD models, varying in complexity from simplified two-dimensional models to more realistic three-dimensional simulations. In this work, we concentrate on the second mechanism, which involves the rapid conversion of magnetic energy into thermal energy through an explosive reconfiguration of the magnetic field. We demonstrate how this process can be modeled analytically within the framework of ideal MHD. Our results suggest that both mechanisms operate simultaneously but at different stages of the erupting flux rope.

We demonstrate that it is possible to generate all four Bell states in one single nonlinear crystal by using two pump beams with orthogonal polarizations and slightly different wavelengths, which are generated via second-harmonic generation (SHG) inside an optical parametric oscillator (OPO). In particular, the Bell state measurement plays a key role in many applications such as teleportation or quantum repeaters  1  . However, generating these highly nonclassical states is challenging because they require indistinguishable photon pairs  2  , which cannot be produced deterministically  3  .
In recent years, several approaches have been developed to overcome this problem  4  . One possibility is based on spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC), where a pump beam creates correlated pairs of signal and idler photons  5  . By adjusting the relative phases of the pump fields  6  , it has become possible to produce any desired superposition of the four Bell states  7, 8  . Another option uses squeezed vacuum states  9  or displaced number states  10  instead of coherent laser pulses  11  . These methods allow for efficient generation of entangled states but usually suffer from low visibility due to imperfections  12  .

original_text: We present new results on the outer jets of the symbiotic star, R Aqr (=V1016 Cyg). In this presentation, I will outline how we have developed techniques for signal recovery at 74 MHz using advanced beamforming methods. We present an algorithm to find galaxy groups using photometric redshifts, which is based on the Voronoi tessellation technique (VT). The VT method has been widely used for identifying clusters of galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts but it had not yet been applied to identify galaxy groups with photometric redshifts. We use the Sloan Digital Sky Survey data release five (SDSS DR5) as our input sample. Our results show that the VT method can be successfully applied to identify galaxy groups even when only photometric redshifts are available. In this work we have identified more than 12000 galaxy groups at 0 < z < 0.3. These groups contain about 30000 member galaxies. We also provide a catalog containing basic information such as positions, magnitudes, colors, and photometric redshifts for all these groups.

rewrite_text: The Standard Model is largely in agreement with all current experimental data, yet it leaves many questions unanswered and fails to account for certain observed phenomena. One notable example is the muon magnetic moment anomaly, which has revealed discrepancies between theoretical predictions and experimental results that cannot be explained within the confines of the Standard Model. In this presentation, I will discuss the physics behind the g-2 experiment at Fermilab, which aims to measure the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon with greater accuracy than ever before by utilizing a novel technique based on laser cooling and trapping developed in recent years. This effort underscores the scientific rationale for the proposed new measurement of the muon's anomalous magnetic moment at Fermilab. I will explain how the combination of laser imaging and trapping can achieve unprecedented precision compared to previous experiments. Additionally, I will touch on related projects and provide an update on the status of the R&D program, which aims to measure the muon magnetic moment to an accuracy of 0.5 parts per million.

We present new results on interstellar absorption lines toward early type stars observed with UVES at VLT, as part of the ESO-POP project (ESO program 085.D-0571). We have searched for high-velocity clouds (HVCs) by looking for blueshifted components in the MgII doublet line profiles. The sample consists of 16 OB-stars located within 1 kpc distance from Earth. In addition to previously known HVCs we find several new ones. Some of these are associated with nearby galaxies while others may be related to Galactic halo gas. A comparison between our data set and previous surveys shows that there is no significant difference in the number density distribution of HVCs along different sightlines. This suggests that most of them are small structures which do not cover much solid angle around their host galaxy or star.

rewrite_text: The understanding of massive star formation remains a critical question in astrophysics, particularly regarding their role in galaxy evolution. In this study, I will focus on how we can utilize observations to constrain key models for the formation of these massive stars. The first part of my research will examine the observational properties of young massive clusters (YMCs) identified at high redshifts (z > 6-7). These YMCs have masses reaching up to 10^8 solar masses and sizes around ~1 kpc. They appear to be considerably more compact than typical starburst galaxies like Arp 220 or M82, which generally harbor more diffuse stellar populations. Our findings indicate that the observed size-mass relation of these young massive clusters aligns well with predictions based on simulations of turbulent gas collapsing under self-gravity. This suggests that turbulence plays a significant role during the early stages of cluster formation. However, it remains uncertain whether all young massive clusters form in such large sizes as those observed at high redshifts.

We present findings on the optical and near-infrared afterglows of the confirmed GRB 050802, detected by Swift/BAT on May 2, 2005, at 07:55:06 UT (T0). The prompt emission was accompanied by an X-ray flare that peaked at T0 + 500 s. We find that both afterglows are described by power laws, with decay indices of α1 = 1.2 ± 0.3 for t < 10 ks and α2 = 2.5 ± 0.4 for t > 10 ks. A break is observed between these two regimes around t0 + 20 ks. No evidence of spectral evolution has been found within each regime. Our analysis suggests that this event may be related to GRB 021004, which also exhibited a double-power law behavior but lacked significant spectral changes across the break time. This indicates that the mechanism responsible for the late-time steepening may be similar to that driving the initial shallow decline.

We study the simple shear flow for two different types of inelastic Maxwell models, one with constant restitution coefficient and another with velocity dependent restitution coefficient. We find that there is no steady state solution when the system has only elastic collisions but it exists if we include some dissipative effects. The steady state solutions are found to be independent of initial conditions as well as the type of dissipation included. In addition, we also show that these steady states are linearly stable under small perturbations. Finally, we present results on the relaxation time scales associated with this problem which can be used to estimate the rate at which the system approaches its steady state. 
 
 Introduction:- 
 
 Simple shear flows have been studied extensively both theoretically  1 - 3  and experimentally  4 - 6  . These studies were motivated by the fact that such flows occur naturally in many physical systems like granular materials  7  , colloidal suspensions  8  etc.. It was shown recently  9  -  11  that even though the microscopic dynamics may be very complicated (like in case of granular particles), the macroscopic behaviour of the system could still be described using relatively simpler kinetic equations like Boltzmann equation or Enskog equation  12  . However, most of these works deal with elastic interactions between the particles while the effect of dissipation is usually ignored. This assumption is not always valid especially in cases where the particles interact via soft potentials  13  .
 
In recent years, several authors  14  -  16  have considered the effect of dissipation on various properties of dilute gases. For example, in Ref.  17  , the author considers an inelastic gas consisting of identical hard spheres interacting through a repulsive potential and shows how the presence of dissipation affects the transport coefficients of the system. On the other hand, in Refs.  18  -  20  , the authors consider a model consisting of point particles interacting via a pairwise additive potential and derive expressions for the transport coefficients of the corresponding fluid. They then use these expressions to calculate the viscosity and thermal conductivity of the system.
