We examine the impact of rounding on the structure of Lie networks featuring first-order phase transitions (FPTs). Our findings indicate that FPTs can be modified by either adding or removing nodes, which subsequently leads to an increase in the proportion of cooperators at equilibrium. These observations hold true for both static and dynamic models of cooperation. Notably, we assert that while the presence of FPTs is significant, it is not essential for high levels of cooperation. Additionally, we propose a straightforward strategy to identify the optimal rounding configurations necessary to achieve maximum levels of cooperation. The rounding of first-order transitions plays a crucial role in scale-free networks. 

In our research, we analyze how first-order phase transitions influence the dynamics of cooperation in social dilemmas. We begin by defining two key concepts: minimal and maximal cooperative states, which characterize parameter ranges where cooperation outweighs defection. Employing these concepts, we demonstrate that any system with phase transition properties has a unique set of parameter values that correspond to the fraction of cooperators. We then address the challenge of optimizing cooperation within these frameworks. To achieve this, we introduce a technique for rounding the parameters of first-order transitions, allowing for adjustments without altering the overall fraction of cooperators within the range of 0 to 1. Through numerical simulations, we show that this rounding process enhances the equilibrium fraction of cooperators across all scenarios examined. Lastly, we develop a method for determining the optimal rounding configurations needed to maximize cooperation.

In this LOFF state, we show that the gap parameter for pairing between quarks with opposite momenta depends on their relative angle. The magnitude of the gap decreases rapidly when they move away from each other along the Fermi surface. As a result, the energy gap vanishes completely near the boundary of the Brillouin zone.

Our findings reveal that DWs exhibit fractal behavior across all temperature ranges studied, specifically from T = 0.5J/kB to 1.2J/kB, where J is the interaction strength between spins on neighboring sites. In ferromagnetic systems, there are two types of magnetization: up and down, characterized by corresponding domain walls. In antiferromagnets, there are four possible orientations of magnetic moments, three corresponding to triangular sublattices and the fourth to a square lattice. Consequently, this results in six distinct types of domain walls.

We acquired HST photometric data on the halo of the nearby elliptical galaxy NGC 3377 using the Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 (WFPC2). These observations were part of program GO-8491 and included two exposures taken through the F606W filter at different roll angles to facilitate accurate sky subtraction. We utilized this data to measure magnitudes for over 1,000 candidate red giant branch (RGB) stars located within a 1 arcminute radius centered on the giants. Our results were compared to those obtained by Kundu & Whitmore (1998), who examined the same field using ground-based telescopes. While we found good agreement between our photometry and their findings, we also detected some discrepancies that may be attributed to crowding effects or calibration uncertainties.

original_text: We have analyzed the redshifts of two samples of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with different luminosities and found evidence for intrinsic redshift components in both cases.  The first sample consists of 12 Seyfert galaxies, which are luminous AGNs with broad emission lines. We find that their observed redshifts can be decomposed into an extrinsic component due to gravitational lensing by foreground objects and an intrinsic component whose amplitude is correlated with the widths of the broad emission lines. This correlation suggests that the intrinsic redshift may arise from Doppler shifts associated with outflows or inflows of gas on scales comparable to those probed by the broad-line region. The second sample contains low-luminosity quasars selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 4 quasar catalog. These quasars show no obvious signs of being gravitationally lensed but do exhibit significant intrinsic redshift components. In this case we find that the amplitudes of these components correlate strongly with the optical continuum slopes measured at rest-frame wavelengths near 3000 Å .

We present an approach to validating the performance of machine-learning algorithms for identifying modules in networks, based on synthetic datasets generated by simulating random walks through known modular structures. We show that this method can be used to identify and rank different types of modules with high accuracy across a range of sizes and densities. The results are robust against noise and missing links. This validation strategy is useful both as a benchmarking tool for comparing competing methods and also as a means of assessing how well existing approaches perform when applied to real-world systems. In recent years there has been growing interest in developing computational tools capable of detecting functional units within complex biological networks such as protein-protein interaction (PPI) or gene regulatory networks  1–3  . These so-called “modules” represent groups of nodes which interact more strongly among themselves than they do with other parts of the system  4  , and may correspond to molecular complexes  5  , signaling pathways  6  , metabolic cycles  7  , or even entire cellular processes  8  .
The identification of these modules is important because it provides insight into the organization of the underlying network  9  , and allows us to predict new interactions  10  , detect disease genes  11  , and understand evolutionary relationships  12  . However, despite considerable effort  13–19  , no single algorithm consistently outperforms all others  20  , so researchers have developed a variety of complementary techniques  21–23  .

We are conducting an analysis of chemical equilibrium and disequilibrium occurring in the atmospheres of substellar mass brown dwarfs (SMBDs). We have developed a novel method for calculating departures from local equilibrium, based on the premise that all species are in local thermodynamic equilibrium with one another at any given point within the atmosphere. This approach enables us to determine the abundances of individual molecular species as a function of altitude above the photosphere. Our findings indicate that there can be significant deviations from chemical equilibrium even under conditions where the local temperature is below the effective temperature. Specifically, we found that carbon monoxide abundances can be depleted by several orders of magnitude compared to predictions by equilibrium models. These results suggest that observations of SMBDs should account for non-equilibrium effects when interpreting their spectra. 

Keywords: Chemical equilibrium; Dust grains; Local thermodynamic equilibrium.

We propose a clear criterion to assess whether two multipartite quantum states are separable, meaning they can be expressed as a combination of product states. This criterion is stated using the Bloch representation of the density matrices and focuses solely on measurements performed by each party. We argue that our approach provides a more straightforward criterion for separability that is less stringent than existing methods. To demonstrate its applicability, we provide several examples.

**Introduction:** The challenge of determining whether a given state is part of the set of separable states has been extensively explored in recent years. Various authors have suggested different approaches to tackle this issue, yet none have confidently provided a definitive solution. Recently, Vidal introduced a novel method for assessing separability using the Bloch representation of the density matrices associated with any pure state. This technique allows for local measurements relevant to each party involved, but it falls short when applied to mixed states as it requires knowledge of all pure-state decompositions of such states. Here, we introduce an improved version of the Bloch representation to develop a general criterion for separability applicable to mixed states. Our results show that there is at least one decomposition into pure states that aligns with the Bloch representation of every separable state. Thus, we posit that the criterion we present is a more accessible approach for determining separability, distinct from existing criteria.

**Preliminaries:** We consider an N-partite system described by Hilbert spaces \( H_1, H_2, \ldots, H_N \). A generic element \( |\psi \rangle \in H = \bigotimes_{i=1}^{N} H_i \) is referred to as a pure state vector, while \( \rho \in D(H) \) denotes a density operator acting on \( H \). Any density operator can be expressed through its spectral decomposition, where \( \{ |\lambda \rangle \} \) for \( \lambda = 1, \ldots, d \) forms an orthonormal basis of eigenvectors of \( \rho \) and \( p_\lambda \geq 0 \).

We use the pPXF code to fit the observed spectra with single-single component models consisting of an old passively-evolving population plus a younger burst superimposed at different ages and metallicities. Our main results are summarized below:  - All objects show evidence for multiple components in their line-of-sight velocity distributions.  - In all cases we find that the best-fit model consists of two distinct components: one is dominated by older stars (age>8 Gyr), while the other has intermediate age (1-8 Gyr). - For four out of six targets, the second component shows higher metallicity than the first one.

We introduce the initial investment in a solution to the equations of motion for type II B supergravity in the AdS 5 × S 5 framework. This solution is underpinned by two independent Lagrangian functions, one residing on each side of a hypersurface Σ, which divides into three distinct regions. We demonstrate that this solution maintains eight real supercharges and has a vanishing total charge. It can be interpreted as a bound state of N = 4 super Yang-Mills theory, coupled with gauge groups SU(N) × SU(N), where the number of degrees of freedom scales as O(N²) in the large N limit. Furthermore, we discuss a class of solutions connecting different vacua of the same theory. These solutions are obtained by taking appropriate limits of our general formulation, exhibiting four supercharges and having non-vanishing quantum numbers. One specific solution we explore describes a supersymmetric Janus-like configuration that interpolates between two conformal fixed points of the same theory.

Introduction: The significant advancements in holographic dualities related to strongly coupled quantum field theories have been greatly influenced by string/M-theory. A particularly intriguing application of these concepts involves studying non-conformal theories using their dual descriptions in terms of holographic models. To construct such models, it is crucial to solve the equations of motion associated with minimal supergravity or gauged supergravity. This task becomes more manageable when the configurations preserve some fraction of the original supersymmetry, as only specific combinations of fields contribute to the solutions. In scenarios where we consider states that retain nearly all of the original supersymmetries (BPS states), the resulting dynamics depend on just five scalar fields. However, it remains challenging to find explicit solutions. One approach to tackling BPS-type equations is to consider cases where the geometry exhibits certain symmetries. An important subset of these scenarios arises when the internal manifold M6 factors into a direct product of two manifolds, M3 × M3.

original_text: The BFKL equation is an effective theory for describing high-energy scattering processes at small Bjorken-x, where x denotes the fraction of longitudinal momentum carried by one of the colliding hadrons or nuclei. The BFKL formalism has been developed into a practical tool to calculate cross sections and structure functions using numerical methods. In this talk I will present recent results on the calculation of the gluon Green s function within the framework of the so-called  dipole approach  which allows us to perform calculations analytically. This method was first introduced by Mueller and Tang in order to study diffractive deep-inelastic scattering (DDIS) off protons. It can be applied also to other processes like heavy quark production in proton-proton collisions as well as photon-photon interactions. We will discuss how we have implemented these ideas numerically and show some preliminary results obtained with our code. Finally, we will comment on possible extensions of this work towards more realistic phenomenological applications.

rewrite_text: We establish that correlation clustering is NP-hard for any constant threshold, even for graphs with a maximum degree of three and edge weights of at most four. We present an efficient algorithm that solves this problem exactly in time O(n^3). Our approach is based on reductions from the exact cover by 3-sets (X3C) problem. The X3C problem asks whether there exists a collection of subsets from a set S such that each element of S belongs to exactly 3 of these subsets; it is known to be NP-hard. For more details about our work, please refer to http://arxiv.org/abs/1206.0571. Correlation clustering is one of several topics studied within the field of clustering, alongside k-means clustering, spectral clustering, and graph partitioning. It has been explored independently by researchers including Bansal et al., Blum et al., and Dasgupta et al. Specifically, given a weighted undirected graph G = (V, E), where V represents the vertices and E denotes the edges, we say that two vertices v, u ∈ V are adjacent if they share an edge (u, v) ∈ E. A cluster C ⊆ V is defined as a subset of vertices such that their pairwise distances meet a certain threshold t > 0. More formally, given a distance function d: V × V → R+, which defines dist(u, v) as the shortest path distance between u and v, the cluster C is considered valid if and only if for all pairs u, v ∈ C, the condition dist(u, v) ≤ t holds.

We report on five new planets discovered by the NASA K2 mission, which were found in the sample of targets observed during Campaigns 1 and 2 (C1/K2). The planet candidates are all located within 100 pc of Earth with periods ranging between 3 days to 16 years. We present their discovery light curves as well as follow-up photometry obtained at several observatories around the world. All five objects have been confirmed as planetary-mass companions through radial velocity measurements using high-resolution spectroscopy or precision astrometry. 
 
 Keywords: Planetary systems - Discovery methods - Radial velocities - Astrometry - Transits - Exoplanet - K2 Mission - Nearby stars - TESS - PLATO - HARPS-N - SPECULOOS 
 
 
 
 Five intermediate-period planets from the N2K sample 
The NASA Kepler space telescope has revolutionized our understanding of extrasolar planets over its primary mission that lasted for four years . However, due to technical difficulties, only about one third of the original target list was actually observed continuously throughout this period. In order to fill out the remaining two-thirds of the original target list, K2 is observing additional fields along the ecliptic plane since 2014 .
In this work we report on five new planets detected by K2 , which were found among the sample of targets observed in campaigns 1 and 2 ( C1/K2 ) . These planet candidates are all located close to us , with distances less than 100 parsecs away , and they span orbital periods between three days up to sixteen years . Their masses range from 0 . 5 to 4 times Jupiter  s mass .  
 
 We present here the discovery light curves together with followup photometric observations performed at various observatories worldwide . All these objects have been confirmed as low-mass companions via precise radial-velocity measurements made either with high resolution spectroscopy or with precision astrometry .

rewrite_text: We present the results of our analysis of high-resolution optical spectra obtained with HST/STIS for four nearby (z < 0.1) X-ray selected Type Ibc supernovae (SNe) in order to investigate their progenitors. We find that all four show clear signs of dense circumstellar matter (CSM) surrounding them, with densities ranging from 0.01 to 0.2 parsecs. The presence of such CSM is consistent with models for post-luminous blue variable (LBV) Wolf-Rayet stars. Additionally, we detect narrow emission features that likely originate from interactions between the supernova ejecta and the surrounding wind. These findings impose strong constraints on the nature of the progenitor systems: they suggest the existence of Wolf-Rayet stars that are part of binary systems capable of transferring mass prior to their explosive events. This research was supported by NASA grant NAG5-10842. Our analysis of high-resolution STIS/HST data for these four nearby (z < 0.1; X-ray-selected) Type Ibc supernovae has provided insights into the properties of their progenitors. All four exhibit evidence of circumstellar matter (CSM; nH > 10^20 cm^-3) within 0.01 to 0.20 parsecs from the supernova locations. These high densities are indicative of the ejection of material during late stages of evolution. Furthermore, we observe narrow emission features that likely relate to the heating of the CSM by the supernova remnant. Our results indicate that these supernova events are likely the result of the deaths of Wolf-Rayet stars that are surrounded by close binary companions.

We give an explicit description of the higher algebraic K-groups in terms of certain universal cohomology classes, which are defined by using only the ring structure and the unit element of the underlying commutative ring. This is done for any commutative ring with unity R (not necessarily Noetherian). The main result can be formulated as follows: Let M be a module over R. Then there exists a natural isomorphism between the higher algebraic K-groups: 
K_n(R) = Ext^n_R(M, R)
and the group of all n-fold Massey products on M modulo those that vanish under some suitable finiteness condition. We also show how this theorem leads to a new proof of Quillen s localization theorem. Finally we discuss applications to the study of equivariant K-theory. In particular, we prove that if G is a compact Lie group acting freely on a smooth manifold X then the equivariant K-theory groups of X are isomorphic to the ordinary K-theory groups of the fixed point set X^G.

We explore the behavior of the Dicke model in the context of atomic systems, focusing on the interactions of two-level atoms coupled to a single mode of electromagnetic radiation. By employing the Holstein-Primakoff transformation, we can effectively map the system to a spin-1/2 model. We then utilize the method of paused diagonalization to analyze the energy spectrum of the model for various couplings characterized by the coupling constant \( g \) and the number of atoms \( N \). Our results are compared with findings from other methods, such as perturbation theory and numerical integration. We observe that our approach yields clear results in the weak coupling regime, although discrepancies arise as the coupling strength increases. Finally, we delve into potential applications arising from this study.

**PACS:** 03.65.Ud, 05.45.Mt, 11.10.Gh, 12.20.Dc, 13.25.Gv 

**I. INTRODUCTION**   
The Dicke model describes the collective interactions of a system of identical two-level atoms with a single mode of electromagnetic radiation. Recently, there has been a resurgence of interest in studying this model due to its potential applications in fields such as quantum optics and condensed matter physics. Specifically, the collective spontaneous emission rate of the atomic ensemble depends on the total angular momentum \( J = N/2 \) (where \( N \) is the number of atoms). The Dicke model was originally proposed over fifty years ago, and since then, various theoretical approaches have been developed to analyze it. Among these, one of the most notable is the Holstein-Primakoff transformation, which allows the original problem to be mapped to a spin-1/2 system. This method is particularly effective in the weak coupling regime, where interactions between atoms are relatively weak. However, it becomes unreliable in the strong coupling limit, as the transformation can lead to unphysical states. Recently, multiple authors have attempted to address this limitation by introducing alternative transformations or approximations, though these methods still face certain challenges.

original_text: In this work, we propose an efficient direct-voting scheme to provide data fusion assurance (DFA) in wireless sensor networks (WSNs). The proposed DFA scheme is based on the concept that each node can directly vote its local decision with other nodes  decisions and then obtain final global decision by majority voting rule. In order to reduce communication overheads caused by direct voting process, our scheme adopts two novel techniques: 1) only one-hop neighbors are allowed to cast their votes at any time instant; 2) all nodes use different time slots to transmit their votes simultaneously. We also present theoretical analysis to show how much energy consumption will be saved compared with existing schemes. Finally, extensive simulation results demonstrate that our scheme outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of both accuracy and power efficiency. Keywords: Data fusion assurance, Wireless sensor network, Power-efficient direct-voting scheme. This research was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant No. 61371040

Our objective is to estimate \( f \) in such a way that the error \( E[f - f^*]^2 \) is minimized while adhering to constraints on the smoothness of \( f \). In this work, we propose a method for recovery based on needlets, which are capable of addressing these constrained optimization problems efficiently. In particular, our approach allows us to achieve accurate estimates even when the number of available measurements \( N \) is significantly smaller than the dimensionality \( M \) of the range spanned by the operator \( A \). The proposed method is built on two main principles: first, we create a representation of functions in terms of needlets; second, we develop efficient iterative algorithms for solving large-scale optimization problems that incorporate sparsity-promoting regularizers. These methods draw inspiration from concepts in compressed sensing and build upon the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM).

rewrite_text: We present a detailed analysis of BL Lac objects (blazars) in relation to the extragalactic gamma-ray background, utilizing data collected by the Fermi Large Area Telescope from August 2008 to December 2010. This provides an exposure time of approximately 1.6 years for each source in our sample. We employed two different methods to estimate the contribution of these blazars: i) we analyzed the counts above 100 MeV as a function of redshift using a specific statistical approach; ii) we examined the observed spectral data to derive integrated fluxes at energies of 0.1 GeV and 10 TeV. The resulting estimates are consistent within statistical uncertainties. Our findings indicate that the flux F (> 100 MeV) is approximately 2.2 x 10^-8 ph cm^-2 s^-1 sr^-1, which accounts for nearly 20% of the total intensity of the extragalactic gamma-ray background. This analysis supports the conclusion that blazars are significant contributors to the emission of the extragalactic gamma-ray background.

original_text: The Standard Model (SM) is an extremely successful theory, but it has some problems that need to be addressed before we can claim to have found  theory of everything .  The SM does not explain why there are three generations of quarks and leptons with different masses or how neutrinos acquire mass. It also fails to provide any explanation for dark matter in our universe.   In this talk I will discuss my recent work on addressing these issues by introducing new particles into the SM which interact only gravitationally. These new particles are called gravitons and they carry spin-2 quantum number like graviton in general relativity. We show that if gravitons exist then their interactions with other fields lead to generation dependent masses for fermions as well as small Majorana masses for neutrinos. Gravitons also contribute to the energy density of the universe leading to possible solution to the problem of missing dark matter. Finally, we argue that gravitons may play important role in understanding hierarchy between Planck scale and electroweak scale.

rewrite_text: We analyze the properties of nonstationary random fields and electromagnetic waves in terms of their correlation functions, power spectra, and probability density functions (PDFs). We find that these fields can be described by specific partial differential equations with time-dependent coefficients. The PDFs are derived for both stationary and nonstationary cases using the method of characteristics. In particular, we present an exact expression for the PDF of the random fluctuations of a monochromatic wave propagating through a turbulent medium. This framework allows us to derive expressions for the second-order fluctuations of the electromagnetic fields at any point along the propagation path. Finally, we explore some applications of our findings to radio wave scintillation and radar signal analysis. PACS: 42.65.Tg, 43.20.Fx, 47.55.+d, 47.60.+j.

We study the phase diagram and electronic structure of bilayer ruthenate Sr3Ru2O7 using density functional theory (DFT) calculations, which show that this material is close to an insulator-metal transition driven by charge transfer between layers. We find that the Fermi surface topology changes dramatically across the metal-insulator boundary, with the appearance of new hole pockets at the Brillouin zone center. The calculated band gap agrees well with experiments on single crystals. In addition, we predict that there are two competing nematic phases near the metal-insulator boundary. One has in-plane anisotropy along the Ru-O-Ru bond direction while another one has out-of-plane anisotropy perpendicular to it. These results provide insights into the origin of the observed structural distortion in bilayer ruthenates. Bilayer ruthenates have attracted considerable attention recently due to their rich physical properties including unconventional superconductivity  1  , quantum criticality  2  , and multiferroicity  3  . Among these materials, Sr3Ru2O7 shows particularly interesting behavior because its ground state can be tuned continuously from metallic to insulating states through chemical doping or applying pressure  4  .
In recent years, several experimental studies have been performed to investigate the nature of the metal-insulator transition (MIT). For example, angle resolved photoemission spectroscopy measurements  5  found that the Fermi surface topology changed significantly when crossing the MIT line. X-ray scattering  6  showed that the crystal symmetry was lowered from tetragonal to orthorhombic below TMI = 160 K. Neutron scattering  7  revealed that the lattice parameters were different for the ab plane and c axis below TMIT ~ 150 K. However, despite extensive investigations, the microscopic mechanism behind the MIT remains unclear  8  .

rewrite_text: We present the spectroscopic follow-up for eight backyard clusters at redshifts z = 0.6 - 0.9, selected from the Red-Sequence Cluster Survey (RCS). The sample consists of four X-ray luminous clusters and four optically rich clusters, with masses ranging from M500 = 1.5 × 10^14 to 2.7 × 10^14 solar masses. We obtained spectra for over 100 cluster members using the VLT/FORS2 and Keck/DEIMOS spectrographs. From this data, we derive velocity dispersions, dynamical mass estimates, and luminosity-weighted ages for each cluster. Additionally, we investigate the scaling relations as a function of redshift up to z = 1.1. Our findings indicate that the observed properties align well with expectations from theoretical models. However, we note an offset towards lower values of σv compared to predictions derived from numerical simulations.

We present results on the statistical properties of earthquake sequences generated by the 2D Burridge-Knopff (BK) model with random initial conditions and periodic boundary conditions, using numerical simulations. rewrite_text: We are using data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory and optical spectroscopy to study the cluster Abell 576, which appears to have two main components separated by approximately 1 arcminute (around 700 kpc). This cluster has been previously examined as an example of a merging system; it shows no evidence of significant substructure or additional heating along its axis but does indicate signs of merger activity on smaller scales. In contrast, the southern component shows little indication of merging. However, this lack of evidence may be influenced by projection effects, as there are several massive structures projected along the line of sight from the cluster that have redshifts suggesting they are located behind the cluster core. We do detect diffuse emission extending beyond the virial radius of both components, which may indicate ongoing accretion. These findings suggest that Abell 576 may evolve into a galaxy cluster similar to those found in more mature states within a few gigayears.

We present the results of an analysis of the 2 Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS) data for quasars with broad absorption lines (BALQSOs). We find that about half of all BALQSOs are intrinsically redder than normal QSOs, and that this fraction increases to nearly 80% at z > 3.5. The observed number density evolution is consistent with no luminosity dependence on intrinsic color in the range 10^44 < L(1450A) < 10^46 erg/sec/sr. This result suggests that most BALQSOs have been missed by previous surveys because they were too faint or too blue. If so, then the true space density may be higher than previously estimated. 
 
 Keywords: Quasars -- Absorption Lines -- Redshift -- Galaxy Evolution 
 
 
 
 1 Introduction 
 
 Broad absorption line quasars (BALQSOs), which show blueshifted absorption features superimposed upon their emission spectra, represent only 10%-20% of optically selected quasar samples but can account for up to 50% of the total UV continuum flux absorbed by intervening gas clouds along the sightline toward distant quasars (Weymann et al., 1991) . In addition to being important probes of the physical conditions within the absorbing gas itself, BALQSOs also provide information regarding the properties of the surrounding intergalactic medium through studies of the associated metal-line systems (e.g., Weymann et al., 1979; Foltz et al., 1986; Turnshek & Savage 1988; Hamann 1998a ,b, 1999 . However, despite their importance as cosmological tools, there has been little progress made in understanding these objects since the discovery of their first examples more than 30 years ago due primarily to selection effects inherent in optical surveys (see e.g., Hewett & Foltz 2003 ) .

rewrite_text: We introduce a model for simulating disease transmission using synthetic populations created from data gathered in massively multiplayer online games (MMOGs). Specifically, we utilize the population and mobility data from the City of Heroes MMOG, which has been actively played since 2003 and boasts over one million registered players. The game’s virtual environment is divided into regions that are interconnected through player movements. Each region contains a significant number of individual households, ranging from dozens to several hundred. Our approach combines household interactions with character-to-character contacts inferred from the in-game movements to simulate disease transmission at both regional and global levels. We evaluate our model against epidemiological models derived from actual census data, noting a high level of agreement, especially when we scale down the size of the simulated population. This finding suggests that large-scale virtual environments, such as MMOGs, can effectively be used to study epidemics without the need for access to health records or detailed demographic information.

original_text: We present Gemini GMOS-S spectroscopy for two young star clusters (ages ~10 Myr) in the interacting galaxy pair NGC 3256, which are located at projected distances of 1 kpc and 2 kpc from their respective nuclei. The spectra reveal that both clusters have similar ages but different metallicities; one is metal-rich with  Fe/H  = +0.2 dex while the other has solar metallicity. We find no evidence for multiple populations within either cluster. Using these data we derive masses of 5 x 10^4 M_sol and 7 x 10^3 M_sol respectively for each cluster. These values agree well with those derived using HST photometry. Both clusters show signs of youthful star-formation activity including blue supergiants and Wolf-Rayet stars. In addition to this ongoing star-formation activity, there appears to be an older population of red giant branch stars in the more massive cluster.

rewrite_text: We explore northeast shelling-type orderings on finger cell complexes, characterized by an arrangement of their cells where each face is matched with exactly one face on its boundary. We demonstrate how these orderings can be utilized to construct acyclic matchings for the Salvetti complex associated with any finite Coxeter group \( W \). This approach provides a combinatorial proof of the Eisenhower theorem, which states that the Poincaré polynomial of this complex satisfies \( P(t) = (1 - t)(1 + \sum_{w \in W} t^{l(w)}) \), where \( l \) denotes the length function on \( W \). The work presented here stems from my PhD research at ETH Zurich under the supervision of Prof. Dr. Jürg Stadler. I would like to express my gratitude to him, as well as to Prof. Dr. Peter Schmitt, for their invaluable discussions. This research has received funding from the European Research Council under the European Union’s Seventh Framework Programme (FP/2007-2013, Grant Agreement No. 325928).

original_text: We present new near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopic observations with Keck II/DEIMOS, which cover the entire optical extent of the nearby spiral galaxy M33 out to its last measured isophote at 25 mag arcsec-2 in B-band. We also use archival data obtained by the Infrared Array Camera onboard the Spitzer Space Telescope for our study. The main goal of this work was to investigate how star formation proceeds beyond the edge of galactic disks into the surrounding intergalactic medium. Our results show that there are two distinct components along the line-of-sight towards M33: an extended component associated with diffuse ionized gas and young stars; and a compact component dominated by old stellar populations. Using these NIR spectra we have derived radial profiles of several physical parameters such as electron density, temperature, extinction coefficient etc., across the face-on view of M33 s disk. These profiles reveal interesting trends in the properties of interstellar matter within different regions of the galaxy.

rewrite_text: We investigate the properties of advection-dominated accretion flows (ADAFs) in the context of their effects on the surrounding environment and emissions. In these models, viscosity arises from magnetic reconnections between field lines anchored to differentially rotating black holes. We find that, for a reasonable range of parameters, such ADAFs can generate luminosities comparable to those observed in quasars while adhering to observational constraints regarding mass inflow rates and densities at larger radii. A key aspect of our work is that it produces outflowing winds, which can significantly enhance the surrounding environment. This effect leads to conditions where the dynamics become nearly Keplerian near the black hole's event horizon. Furthermore, we demonstrate that these winds provide sufficient support against gravitational collapse, preventing the density of the surrounding medium from dropping too low. Our findings suggest that the winds generated by magnetized ADAF models could play a crucial role in driving powerful outflows in active galactic nuclei.

original_text: We present the first public release of an archive containing all available X-ray Telescope (XRT) data for Gamma-Ray Bursts observed by the Swift satellite since its launch in November 2004. The XRT is sensitive to soft X-ray photons with energies between 0.3 and 10 keV, and has a field-of-view of 23 x 23 arcminutes. It operates in two modes: Windowed Timing mode which provides high time resolution but low sensitivity; Photon Counting mode which gives higher sensitivity at the expense of temporal information. We have processed all publicly released XRT data into one homogeneous database using standard procedures. This includes both pre-launch calibration observations as well as in-orbit calibrations performed after each observation. For each burst we provide a table listing the basic properties of the event along with the raw count rates measured during the entire exposure. In addition, we also provide a set of FITS files that contain the background subtracted light curve binned on different timescales ranging from 1 second up to several hundred seconds.

rewrite_text: The text is designed for individuals who have completed the essential concepts of control theory in relation to diabetes management and wish to explore topics related to control systems, including real-time control, discrete systems, and computer-based control methods. It discusses critical subjects such as state-space representation, stability analysis, control design, robustness concerns, model predictive control (MPC), and fuzzy logic-based control, all within the context of practical applications. The book provides several examples that illustrate the key concepts discussed throughout the chapters. It offers a thorough overview of the fundamental principles underlying modern control engineering. Alongside these foundational topics, it includes numerous illustrative examples that highlight significant ideas introduced throughout. At the end of each chapter, readers will find a summary to help reinforce their understanding of the material presented. Additionally, the book contains two appendices that provide essential resources for further study or research. This resource is suitable for graduate students pursuing advanced studies in control theory, as well as researchers in the field.

original_text:
We report on observations made with Suzaku and Swift during the 2006 eruption of the recurrent nova RS Ophiucchi (RS Oph). The X-ray light curve shows that the source was brightest at around day 50 after the optical peak, when it reached an apparent luminosity of ~10^38 erg s-1. We find evidence for nonthermal emission up to 100 keV by fitting the observed spectrum with a power-law model modified by photoelectric absorption. This is consistent with previous results obtained using data taken with other satellites such as Chandra and XMM-Newton. In addition we found that the photon index changed significantly between days 40-50 and 60-70; this may be due to changes in the physical conditions near the central engine or in the geometry of the emitting region. 
 
 We also detected significant hard X-ray emission above 10 keV which can not be explained solely by thermal bremsstrahlung radiation. A possible explanation would be inverse Compton scattering of soft photons off relativistic electrons accelerated in shocks driven into the surrounding medium. If so, then these particles should have been accelerated to energies greater than 1 PeV.

rewrite_text: We investigate the effects of Rashba spin-orbit coupling on the spin Hall conductivity (SHC) in a two-dimensional electron system with parabolic dispersion and a Zeeman effect in the presence of an external magnetic field, focusing on the implications for transport properties. Our findings indicate that the SHC is independent of temperature, gate potential, and disorder, provided that the Fermi level remains within the Zeeman gap. The calculations are performed using the Kubo formula alongside the self-consistent Born approximation. Recent studies have demonstrated that a spin current can be generated without any net charge current when electrons travel through a non-magnetic material under the influence of spin-orbit coupling. This phenomenon, known as spin Hall effect, has been theoretically predicted and experimentally observed. The underlying mechanism involves the generation of a transverse force that deflects the trajectories of moving charges, resulting in finite spin polarization at the edges of the material. There have been various theoretical approaches aimed at understanding different aspects of spin Hall transport. However, most of this research has been conducted in the absence of strong magnetic fields, where Landau quantization effects do not play a significant role. Conversely, it is well-known that Landau quantization is crucial for numerous transport properties, such as magnetoresistance and optical absorption, particularly near the quantum limit. Therefore, it is of great interest to explore how Landau quantization influences the behavior of the spin Hall conductivity.

We present an algorithm for obtaining the spacetime metric from observational data, such as those obtained by the Planck satellite and other experiments. The method is based on the fact that in general relativity (GR) the Einstein field equations are equivalent to the geodesic equation for test particles. We use this equivalence to obtain the metric tensor components directly from the observed trajectories of photons emitted at different redshifts. This approach allows us to reconstruct the full four-dimensional geometry of space-time without assuming any particular model or parametrization. In order to demonstrate our technique we apply it to simulated data generated using the publicly available code CAMB. Our results show that the recovered metric agrees well with the original one used to generate the mock data. Finally, we discuss possible applications of our method to real astrophysical datasets. Cosmology has entered into precision era thanks to recent advances in experimental techniques which have allowed astronomers to measure many important quantities related to the evolution of the universe. Among these measurements there are the temperature anisotropy power spectrum measured by WMAP  1  , PLANCK  2  and SPT  3  satellites; the baryon acoustic oscillations detected through galaxy surveys  4  ; and the luminosity distance-redshift relation inferred from type Ia supernovae  5  . These new data provide unprecedented opportunities to study fundamental physics beyond the Standard Model  6  .
In addition to providing accurate measurements of various physical parameters describing the state of the universe today, modern cosmological experiments also allow us to probe its large-scale structure over time  7, 8  . For example, the measurement of the cosmic microwave background radiation provides information about the early stages of the universe s history when the energy density was dominated by dark matter and radiation  9  . On the other hand, the detection of distant galaxies gives access to the late stage of the universe s expansion when dark energy starts dominating  10  .

rewrite_text:
We investigate the properties of frustrated spin-1/2 Heisenberg models on square lattices, examining various types of interlayer couplings, including both homogeneous and inhomogeneous interactions. We find that frustration can be mitigated by introducing a ferromagnetic coupling between layers, which leads to the emergence of inhomogeneous magnetic states characterized by spatially modulated magnetization profiles. These findings are discussed in the context of the recent development in the theory of "inverse condensation." 

Introduction: There has been growing interest in studying strongly correlated systems where competing interactions lead to complex phase diagrams exhibiting various intriguing phenomena such as valence bond solids (VBS), charge density waves (CDW), or supersolids. One particularly fascinating example is provided by layered antiferromagnets. These materials consist of weakly coupled planes of spins arranged in a regular structure. Due to strong geometric frustration caused by competing nearest-neighbor interactions \(J_1\) along the layers and \(J_2\) across the planes, these systems exhibit a rich array of phenomena, ranging from long-range Néel order at low temperatures to disordered paramagnetic states at high temperatures.

In this work, we focus on two prototypical members of this class of materials: CuGeO\(_3\), where each tetrahedral unit forms a honeycomb-like lattice, and BaCo\(_2\)As\(_2\), which consists of layers made up of corner-sharing triangles. Both materials have garnered significant interest due to their unusual magnetic behavior. For instance, in CuGeO\(_3\), it has been experimentally shown that the system transitions from a collinear antiferromagnetically ordered state below \(T_N = 29\) K to a non-collinear VBS state above \(T^* \approx 70\) K. In contrast, the situation in BaCo\(_2\)As\(_2\) is more complex, with several studies suggesting the coexistence of three distinct magnetic phases: a commensurate antiferromagnetic order below \(T_C = 38\) K and a helimagnetic phase.

original_text:
We study the existence and stability properties of non-topological solitons in scalar field theories with kinetic self coupling, which are relevant to models for dark matter particles interacting via self-interactions mediated by light bosons.  We show that stable soliton solutions exist only if the mass of the boson is larger than twice the mass of the dark matter particle. For smaller masses we find unstable solitonic solutions whose lifetime decreases exponentially as the mass ratio approaches one. The results presented here can be used to constrain the parameter space of such models using astrophysical observations. Introduction:-The possibility of new physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) has been widely discussed recently  1  . In particular, there have been many attempts at constructing extensions of the SM that include additional fields or interactions  2  , motivated by the fact that none of its fundamental parameters have yet been measured experimentally  3  .
In this work we consider an extension of the SM where the Higgs sector consists of two complex scalars  4  . This model contains several interesting features including spontaneous CP violation  5  , radiative electroweak symmetry breaking  6  , and the presence of a pseudo-Goldstone boson  7, 8  . It also provides a simple framework within which to discuss possible connections between dark matter  9  and neutrino masses  10  . Furthermore it allows us to explore the phenomenology associated with the production of heavy neutral gauge bosons  11  and their subsequent decay into pairs of charged leptons  12  . Finally, it may provide a natural explanation for the origin of baryogenesis  13  through the out-of-equilibrium decays of the heavier scalar  14  .
One feature of these models is the presence of a second scalar particle, denoted by H 0 , which mixes with the SM-like Higgs h 0  15  . As a result, both states acquire physical masses m h0 and m H0 respectively  16  . If the mixing angle θH is small then mH ≫ mh  17  . We present new abundance determinations for the light neutron-capture elements Sr, Y, Zr, Ba, La, Ce, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Dy, Yb, and Lu in eight planetary nebulae (PNe). The PNe are selected to have high signal-to-noise ratio optical spectra obtained with HST/STIS or FUSE that allow accurate measurements of their elemental abundances. We find that all but one PN show evidence for enrichment by the slow-neutron capture process (s-process) relative to solar values. In most cases we can identify specific s-process contributions from individual isotopes such as 92Zr, 138Ba, 144Sm, 146Eu, 151Gd, 157Dy, 162Yb, 174Lu, 176Hf, 182W, and 205Pb. These results provide important constraints on theoretical models of nucleosynthesis in low-mass asymptotic giant branch stars.

rewrite_text: We present polarization observations conducted with the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) and the Parkes backyard telescopes targeting the supernova remnant G156.2+5. The ATCA data were collected during two observing sessions: one from May 24 to 25, 1998, using the H214 array, and another from September 14 to 15, 1999, using the EW352 array. These observing configurations provided baselines that ranged from 15 meters to 5 kilometers. Each session lasted for 3 hours, consisting of 12-minute scans interspersed with 10-second slews. The total bandwidth was 128 MHz, centered around 1384 MHz. Data were processed using MIRIAD, and after flagging the bad channels, we generated Stokes Q and U maps, which are presented in Figure 1. While we did obtain polarized intensity images, they did not reveal any polarized emission above our sensitivity threshold. This finding aligns with single-dish measurements that showed no evidence of polarized emission from this source.

rewrite_text: We present the tenth installment of cosmological hydrodynamic simulations that examine the formation of dark matter halos within various cosmic environments, including clusters, filaments, superclusters, and voids. Our findings indicate that: (i) The mass accretion histories of halos are predominantly influenced by major mergers with other halos at high redshifts (z > 1). (ii) Unlike clusters, the growth of filamentary structures is primarily driven by smooth continuous accretion along their lengths, leading to an extended formation history for these objects, which can be traced back to early times (z < 5). (iii) Sheet-like structures form through the merger of smaller filaments into larger ones. They experience significant mass gain through continuous accretion, while also undergoing mergers with smaller structures during their development. (iv) Voids evolve almost entirely due to gas accretion. Their assembly timescales are generally longer than those of clusters and filaments, as they exist in less dense surrounding environments.

In this paper, we present an explicit formula for the maximum allowable delay in a linear time-invariant system with multiple delays by using the concept of passivity index. The proposed method is applied to a biochemical reaction network model consisting of two species interacting through three reactions. We show that our results are consistent with those obtained via numerical simulations. Finally, it should be noted that the proposed approach can also be used as a tool for analyzing other types of networks such as social or economic ones. In recent years there has been growing interest in studying complex dynamical behaviors of biological systems  1  . One important aspect of these studies concerns how different components interact within a cell  2  , which leads naturally to mathematical models based on chemical kinetics  3  .
The most common type of kinetic modeling involves ordinary differential equations (ODEs)  4  describing interactions between various molecular species  5  . However, due to the complexity of cellular processes  6  , many ODE models contain several state variables  7, 8  and/or parameters  9  whose values cannot always be determined experimentally  10  . This uncertainty may lead to significant errors when estimating the behavior of the underlying system  11  . To overcome this problem, stochastic approaches have recently been developed  12  . Another possibility consists in considering uncertainties in the form of unknown external disturbances  13  .

rewrite_text: We present near-infrared (NIR) observations of the Carina Nebula, using the ISAAC instrument at the VLT in Chile, and compare these data to optical observations by Smith et al. (2000). The NIR data reveal details about the structure of the nebular shell surrounding the Trumpler 16 cluster. We find that the brightest section of the shell is situated between two regions likely shaped by dust accumulation. Additionally, we identify several embedded knots within the shell, which may be the remnants of parent stars or protostars from an earlier period of star formation activity in this region. Lastly, we uncover a number of Herbig-Haro objects associated with the clusters Trumpler 14 and 15. Our findings suggest that the Carina Nebula continues to be a site of active star formation. The conference will be held on September 24-25 at the University of Milan-Bicocca (Italy). The main topics to be discussed are Einstein s role as an intellectual figure; his contribution to science, art and culture; his influence on contemporary society and its future development. 
The event is organized by the Italian National Committee for UNESCO with the support of the International Union of Pure and Applied Physics (IUPAP), the European Physical Society (EPS) and the Institute of Advanced Studies of the University of Bologna. 
 
 The conference aims to celebrate the centenary of Albert Einstein s birth and to promote the dissemination of knowledge about him among scientists, artists, students and the general public. It also intends to foster international cooperation between researchers working in different fields related to Einstein s work.  
 
 The program includes plenary lectures given by internationally renowned speakers, parallel sessions dedicated to specific themes, poster presentations and cultural events such as exhibitions, concerts and performances.

rewrite_text: We examine the phenomenological implications of the speed of sound in brane inflationary models, where the inflaton corresponds to the distance between two parallel branes moving in a higher-dimensional space. Our findings indicate that for values of the speed of sound (cs < 0.1), there are no significant deviations from the predictions made by standard slow-roll inflation. However, when cs > 0.1, we find that the tensor-to-scalar ratio and the spectral index, dns/dlnk, can differ notably from their values predicted within the framework of slow-roll inflation. Specifically, if cs = 1, we obtain the relations r = 16(nT)²/5 and dns/dlnk = -8(nT)¹/5, which could provide a compelling explanation for the observed high values of nT suggested by WMAP7 data and supported by other CMB experiments.

original_text: We present an alternative method to the usual Feynman path integral description for calculating the probability amplitudes in quantum walk models, based on the concept of scattering states and their associated S-matrix elements. We show that this new formalism allows us to obtain exact results for several interesting cases where standard methods fail or are not applicable. In particular we consider two different types of boundary conditions at one end of the chain (the origin) which lead to completely different behaviour of the system as time evolves. The first type is known as Dirichlet boundary condition, corresponding to reflecting particles back into the origin after they have left it once; while the second case corresponds to absorbing particles when they reach the origin. For both these cases we calculate exactly the evolution operator over all times t > 0 using our new method. Finally, by applying the inverse Fourier transform to the evolution operator we can recover the full probability distribution function of finding the walker at any position x along the chain at time t.

rewrite_text: The solar magnetic field is a significant factor in many dynamic processes within our solar system, such as coronal heating and solar wind dynamics. The magnetic lines woven throughout the heliosphere play a crucial role in influencing space weather phenomena. In this study, we utilize the magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model developed by Usmanov et al. (2010) to analyze the structure and behavior of the Sun's open magnetic field. We evaluate how the global characteristics of our simulated magnetic field compare with observations made at 1 AU using spacecraft data. Our simulations successfully replicate the observed latitudinal distribution of the solar magnetic field density and its variation with radial distance from the Sun. They also offer insights into the temporal evolution of the heliospheric magnetic field, which can be leveraged to forecast the state of interplanetary conditions several days in advance. This research was supported by NASA grants NNX10AC85G (PI: S. Riley), NNG09FA40C (PI: A. Schwadron), and NNM07AA01A (PI: J. McComas).

We present new observations in the optical, infrared (IR), and ultraviolet (UV) spectral ranges for the symbiotic binary system H1-36. The analysis is based on high-resolution spectroscopy obtained with the UVES spectrograph at the VLT telescope as well as low resolution data taken by other authors. We find that the observed spectrum can be explained by two components: an accretion disk around a white dwarf and a red giant. In addition we detect emission lines originating in the wind of the red giant. Our results are consistent with previous studies which suggested that this object belongs to the group of symbiotics where the mass transfer proceeds via Roche lobe overflow. 
 
 Keywords: Symbiosis, Binary systems, Red giants, Accreting binaries, Winds, Mass loss, Spectroscopy, Ultraviolet radiation, White dwarfs, Emission lines, Stellar winds

rewrite_text: We present distance measurements and Santos velocities for the closest late-type M, L, and T dwarfs, based on high-precision radial velocities obtained with the HARPS spectrograph at La Silla Observatory in Chile over an eight-year period (2003-2009). We find that nearly all of these objects are members of young nearby open clusters or associations, with the exception of LP 944-20, which is identified as being part of the northeast region of the Hyades supercluster based on its proper motion. This study suggests that most brown dwarfs are younger than 100 million years. It implies the existence of two populations among very low-mass stars and brown dwarfs: those that are associated with nearby clusters or associations and those that are not gravitationally bound to any cluster. This indicates that some brown dwarfs may reside outside of known clusters or disperse quickly after formation. Finally, we examine the implications of these findings for understanding the kinematics of the lowest mass stars and brown dwarfs.

We present an improved factorization formula for the fragmentation functions (FFs) of hadrons containing one heavy quark, which is valid in both leading order and next-to-leading order QCD perturbation theory. The new formula takes into account all possible contributions to the FFs at each perturbative order. We show that our results are consistent with those obtained by using other approaches such as the operator product expansion method or the renormalization group equation approach. Finally we give numerical predictions on some important quantities related to the charm-quark FFs. PACS numbers: 12.38.Qk, 13.25.Gv, 11.15.Tk

rewrite_text:
We investigate a system of interacting bosons subject to a repulsive contact interaction, transitioning through a quench from the superfluid to the Mott insulator phase. Our findings reveal that, at late times, the system exhibits universal behavior characterized by power-law decaying correlations and a logarithmic growth of entanglement entropy. We derive the associated exponents analytically by mapping the problem onto a classical statistical mechanics framework for a driven diffusive system. This research was funded by NSF grant PHY-0960291 (M.S.) and DOE grants DE-FG03-92-ER40701 and DE-SC0012704 (A.K.).

INTRODUCTORY REMARKS: The experimental realization of quantum degenerate gases has opened new avenues for understanding strongly correlated many-body systems. Ultracold atomic gases, in particular, have been employed to investigate phenomena such as fermionization, supersolidity, and Mott insulating states. In this article, we examine a captivating class of experiments where the properties of these systems can be explored by varying their parameters. For instance, if the strength of inter-boson repulsion or the density of the gas is altered, it takes some time for the system to reach thermal equilibrium. During this nonequilibrium phase, the system exhibits novel features like dynamical scaling and non-thermal fixed points. These phenomena are crucial for our fundamental understanding of quantum matter and provide valuable insights into potential pathways for realizing novel phases of matter.

Recently, there has been significant interest in the nonequilibrium dynamics of bosonic systems. A particularly well-studied scenario is when the system is initially prepared in a highly excited state far from equilibrium. Interestingly, despite being in a state far from equilibrium, the system tends to relax into a steady state that can be characterized by a Gibbs distribution. Conversely, if the initial state lies deeply within the ordered phase, the system behaves differently and does not simply relax to the expected steady state.

original_text: We present an exact expression for the energy density functional in terms of the local electronic charge and spin densities, which is valid for any number N of electrons on a two-dimensional jellium surface with arbitrary spin-orbit interaction strength. The resulting sum rules are shown to be equivalent to those derived by Stillinger and Lovett (SL) for the case of zero spin-orbit coupling but they also include additional contributions due to this term. We show that these new terms can be expressed as functions of the SL parameters only. This result allows us to obtain explicit expressions for all the relevant physical quantities such as the exchange-correlation potential or the magnetization profile at finite temperature. Finally we discuss how our results could be used to improve existing approximations within Density Functional Theory. rewrite_text: We propose an experiment to entangle two independent photons in a controlled time environment, utilizing only passive optical elements and photon detectors. This approach is based on comparing the arrival times of the photons at different locations. We believe this measurement can facilitate entanglement between the photons without the need for post-selection or backward causation. This method holds promise for applications in quantum communication networks, where it could enable the generation of entangled states over significant distances. Entanglement plays a crucial role in various fields of physics, including condensed matter systems, atomic gases, trapped ions, and quantum information theory. Specifically, entanglement is essential for applications such as quantum teleportation, superdense coding, secure key distribution, and quantum computing. In recent years, several proposals have been made to generate entanglement between remote photons. However, most of these schemes rely on nonlinear optical processes, which can be challenging to implement experimentally, or involve post-selection, which complicates the analysis. Recently, we introduced a straightforward method to generate entanglement between remote photons using only passive optical components and photon detectors. Our approach focuses on measuring the precise arrival times of the photons at different locations. In this paper, we present detailed calculations to demonstrate the effectiveness of our method and assess its experimental feasibility. Figure 1 illustrates a schematic diagram of our setup, where two identical sources emit pairs of photons (shown in red) toward Alice’s station (A) and Bob’s station (B). Each source utilizes a laser to generate photon pairs through spontaneous parametric down-conversion. These photons travel through separate paths until they reach stations A and B. At these locations, Alice and Bob perform measurements on their respective photons, noting the arrival times \( t_A \) and \( t_B \).

We present Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) radio images and multi-epoch optical photometry for 7 blazars selected from the Roma-BZCAT catalog as candidates to be members of the Red Giants Branch (RGB). The sources are located at redshifts between 0.1 and 1, with luminosities ranging from 1045 erg/s to 1012 erg/s in the rest frame range 2-10 keV. We find that all but one source show compact cores on milliarcsecond scales; only RGB J0152+017 shows an extended structure. All these results suggest that most of our targets belong to the class of Flat Spectrum Radio Quasars rather than Blazar-like AGNs. In addition we report new spectroscopic data obtained by us or taken from literature which confirm this hypothesis.

We have analyzed the impact of masking a portion of the sky on CMB temperature fluctuations using simulated datasets. Our findings indicate that it is crucial to consider the effects of masked pixels when estimating the angular power spectrum (APS) at large scales, particularly for low multipoles (l < 20). We observed that the APS estimates derived using standard methods based on harmonic decomposition can be biased if there are correlations between masked and unmasked regions. In this study, we propose a novel approach that takes these effects into account. Our method has been applied to estimate the APS of the WMAP three-year dataset after excluding point sources above 5 mJy. Our results are in good agreement with those obtained from analyses conducted without any masking.

We report on the first demonstration of quantum key distribution (QKD) with high bit rates and low error rates in an optical fiber link spanning more than 100 km, including 20 km of standard telecom fibers and 80 km of dispersion-shifted fibers. The QKD system uses polarization encoding and decoy-state BB84 protocol to generate secret keys at a rate up to 1 Mbit/s per user. We use two types of single-photon detectors based on InGaAs/InP avalanche photodiodes operated either in Geiger mode or as gated-mode single-photon counters. To overcome the detector dark count noise we employ active feed-forward techniques that allow us to achieve a secure key generation rate of 0.5 Mbit/s for each user. However, most existing QKD experiments are limited to short-distance transmissions because of the extremely weak intensity of single photons  3  .
Recently, several groups have demonstrated QKD over distances longer than 50km  4  -  8  . Nevertheless, these results still suffer from relatively low key generation rates mainly caused by the large dark counts of the employed single-photon detectors  15  .

We study the nonlinear evolution of baryonic acoustic oscillations (BAO) in an expanding universe using numerical simulations with N-body particles and hydrodynamic gas dynamics. We find that BAOs are suppressed by nonlinear gravitational clustering, but they can be recovered by applying a Wiener filter to the density field at each redshift. The reconstructed power spectrum agrees well with linear theory predictions on large scales where the effect is negligible. On small scales, however, we observe significant deviations between the two spectra due to nonlinear effects such as shell crossing and virialization. These results suggest that it may be possible to use BAOs as standard rulers for cosmological distance measurements even when the underlying matter distribution becomes highly nonlinear. In this work, we present our main findings below. 
1 Introduction

Baryons play important roles in galaxy formation through their interactions with dark matter. For example, observations show that galaxies form around peaks of the primordial density fluctuations which grow into massive halos via gravitational instability. Therefore, understanding how baryons evolve in time and space is crucial for studying galaxy formation processes.

In recent years, there has been growing interest in measuring the large-scale structure of the Universe using baryonic tracers like neutral hydrogen or stars. One promising method involves tracing the spatial distribution of these objects back in time using spectroscopic surveys. This technique allows us to measure the statistical properties of the cosmic web, including its geometry and topology, over a wide range of redshifts.

Since the amplitude of the BAO signal depends only weakly on the physical state of the medium, it provides a robust way to probe the expansion history of the universe independent of other cosmological parameters  2  .

original_text: We report on four new quasars at redshifts z > 6, found in the Canada France Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS). The objects were selected as part of an ongoing survey for high-z quasars using photometric data obtained with CFHT and Spitzer Space Telescope. We present their optical to near-infrared SEDs, which are well fitted by composite quasar templates. Their luminosities range between 1.5 x 10^14 erg s-1 cm-2 and 2.1 x 10^15 erg s-1 cm-2 . Our findings indicate that both pulsars exhibit strong evidence of subpulse drift, which is modulated by an underlying pattern of emission. The Large Area Telescope (LAT) is one of two instruments aboard NASA s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, launched in June 2008. The LAT consists of an array of silicon strip trackers and cesium iodide calorimeters that detect gamma rays with energies between 20 MeV to more than 300 GeV. This document describes a novel method used by the LAT collaboration to monitor the performance of its detector system during flight using cosmic ray data taken over several months prior to launch. We show how this method can be applied to characterize the response function of each individual tracker module as well as the overall energy resolution of the entire LAT. These results are compared against ground calibration measurements performed before launch. Finally we demonstrate how these techniques have been successfully employed to identify problems with some modules after launch which were subsequently fixed through software updates. The Large Area Telescope (L AT ) is one of two instruments flown on NASA s Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope  1  . Launched into space in June 2008, it has detected thousands of sources of high-energy photons since then  2  .
In order to perform such observations, the L AT must accurately measure the direction and energy of incoming photons. To accomplish this task, the L AT uses a combination of silicon strip detectors and CsI(Tl) scintillators arranged in four layers around a central tungsten converter foil  3  , see Figure 1 . Each layer contains 16 towers, or  trajectory segments , consisting of 4 silicon strips oriented at different angles relative to the incident photon trajectory  4  . In addition there are 8  strips  per tower located behind the silicon sensors but outside of the active volume of the calorimeter  5  . Together they form a total of 56 independent tracking channels  6  .

rewrite_text: We present a framework for MHD simulations of the magneto-rotational instability (MRI) in a stratified, Keplerian disk threaded by an initially vertical magnetic field, utilizing the ZEUS-2D code. We investigate both isothermal and adiabatic equations of state to determine how the MRI is influenced by the thermodynamic properties of the gas. In all scenarios, we find that the growth rate of the fastest-growing mode aligns well with linear theoretical expectations when appropriately normalized. However, there are notable differences in our results depending on whether the simulations have reached steady-state equilibrium. For instance, the stress profiles observed at late stages vary among different models. This indicates that precise predictions of the saturation levels of the MRI may require high-resolution simulations that run for extended periods, encompassing multiple orbital cycles. Lastly, we find that the inclusion of radiative effects does not significantly impact the characteristics of the turbulence generated by the MRI.

original_text: We introduce the concept of generalized conditional random fields (GCRFs) and show how they can be used to model arbitrary probability distributions over structured data sets, such as sequences or trees.  We present an efficient algorithm for learning GCRF parameters using gradient descent on the log-likelihood objective function.   Finally we demonstrate that our approach is able to learn accurate models for several challenging sequence labeling tasks including part-of-speech tagging in natural language processing and protein secondary structure prediction in bioinformatics. Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) (Lafferty et al., 2001 ) are undirected graphical models which have been successfully applied to many problems involving sequential data, e.g. (Sha & Pereira, 2003) . In this work, we propose Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs), a generalization of CRFs which allows us to represent any distribution over structured data sets like sequences or trees. The key idea behind GCRFs is to use a set of latent variables to capture dependencies between different parts of the input space. This enables us to efficiently compute the partition function required by standard CRFs with dynamic programming techniques. The production of light elements in the early universe is one of the most important unsolved problems in astrophysics, cosmology, nuclear physics and particle physics. The standard model (SM) of elementary particles cannot explain how these elements were created during the first few minutes after the Big Bang. In this talk I will present an overview on our current understanding about the origin of light nuclei with A=1-3 produced by photonuclear reactions at high temperatures and densities in the early universe. This includes theoretical predictions for the abundances as well as experimental results obtained using radioactive beams at GSI Darmstadt. Finally, I will discuss possible future experiments to test some of the key predictions made within the SM. Keywords: Photonuclear reaction, Light element synthesis, Big Bang nucleosynthesis, Astrophysical SNe Ia explosion mechanism, Nuclear structure theory. 1 Introduction.
Light element synthesis in the early universe is among the most challenging open questions in modern science  1  . It has been known since the 1960s that photons can induce nuclear fusion processes leading to the creation of light elements like D, 3 He, 4 He, 7 Li or 9 Be  2  , but it was not until recently when we have gained sufficient knowledge about the physical conditions prevailing in the early universe  3  .
In particular, the temperature T and density ρ reached values up to 10 12 K and 10 15 g/cm 3 respectively  4  . These extreme conditions are only accessible today in laboratory experiments using relativistic heavy-ion collisions  5  . However, due to the extremely short time scales involved  6  , such experiments do not allow us to study the formation of light elements directly  7, 8  . Instead they provide information about the properties of hot dense matter which may be relevant for the description of the initial stages of supernova explosions  9  . On the other hand, the abundance pattern observed in primordial objects like white dwarfs  10  or metal-poor stars  11  provides valuable constraints on the models describing the evolution of the chemical composition of the universe  12  .

rewrite_text: This article provides an overview of the dynamics of vortices in trapped, dilute atomic gases at low temperatures. We discuss how these vortices can be characterized by macroscopic wave functions and demonstrate that they are described by nonlinear Schrödinger equations incorporating external potentials. The study of these phenomena has been extensive over many years, and we highlight some properties related to vortex formation. In particular, we examine stationary states corresponding to the condensate without rotation (vortex-free) as well as rotating states where quantized circulation is represented by singularities known as vortices. Additionally, we briefly discuss various experiments on vortex production in cold atomic systems. Vortices also appear in superfluids like liquid helium and dilute atomic gases, carrying quantized angular momentum and playing significant roles in phenomena such as turbulence and quantum transport. This article serves as an introduction to the theoretical framework of vortices in trapped atomic gases.

original_text: We present an in-depth study of the galaxy cluster Z3146, which is one of the most luminous clusters in X-rays known to date (Lx = 1.5 x 1045 erg/s). The main goal of this work was to investigate whether or not there are any signatures of AGN activity associated with the central cD galaxy. We have obtained deep optical spectroscopy for more than 100 galaxies within the virial radius of the cluster using the Keck telescope. In addition we have carried out Chandra observations that allow us to resolve individual point sources down to luminosities as low as Lx ~ 3 x 1041 erg/s. Our results show that:  -The brightest cluster galaxy has a very complex spectrum dominated by emission lines produced by gas ionized by hot stars.  -There is no evidence for significant nuclear activity in the form of broad line regions and/or high excitation narrow-line regions.  -The total mass profile derived from our spectroscopic data agrees well with previous estimates based on gravitational lensing measurements.

rewrite_text: We conducted an in-depth analysis of data for the nearby dwarf spheroidal galaxy, Hercules (dSph), using the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT). The observations are utilized to investigate the stellar populations within this galaxy. Our findings indicate that the surface brightness profile is primarily characterized by an exponential function over most of its area, although we observe a notable deviation at approximately 30 arcseconds from the center. This anomaly may be associated with tidal interactions or stripping events involving Hercules and other galaxies. Through color-magnitude diagrams, we reveal the presence of two distinct components within Hercules: one that has been stripped away and another that appears to be intact. These results suggest that Hercules was once more extensive than it is at present. Finally, using our photometric data, we examined the line-of-sight velocity dispersion as a function of the projected distance from the center of Hercules. Our findings indicate that the central region of Hercules exhibits a velocity dispersion that is lower compared to regions that are farther out.
