We provide an overview of our work on Bayesian methods for reconstructing large-scale structures in the universe using heavily redshifted data. We explain how to frame this problem as a statistical inference task with prior information that encodes knowledge about the underlying matter distribution. The posterior density function is derived by applying Bayes' theorem alongside Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) techniques. Specifically, we focus on two distinct approaches based on Gibbs sampling and the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm. Additionally, we discuss various applications of these methods to simulated datasets. This research was supported by NSF grant AST-0707763.

Over the past decade, cosmology has been transformed by observations of cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies made by WMAP, PLANCK, and other experiments. These discoveries have provided compelling evidence for the existence of dark matter and have imposed tight constraints on various parameters related to the physics of the early universe. However, despite these advancements, several fundamental questions regarding the standard model of cosmology remain. One such question pertains to dark matter: What is its composition? What is its mass? How does it interact with ordinary matter? Addressing these questions necessitates a thorough understanding of the distribution of dark matter throughout space and time. Unfortunately, direct measurements provide limited insight, as they only capture the gravitational effects of dark matter. Thus, researchers rely on indirect probes such as galaxy clustering, weak lensing, and 21 cm emission.

original_text: We present an analysis of the kinematics of satellite galaxies in galaxy clusters, which is aimed at measuring the differences between the distribution functions (DFs) of dark matter particles and those of luminous baryonic components. We use data for 16 galaxy clusters with redshifts ranging from 0.1 to 1.0 obtained by the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 6. The DFs are reconstructed using the maximum entropy method under the assumption that they have spherical symmetry. In order to test whether this assumption holds true or not, we compare the results derived assuming spherical symmetry with those obtained without any assumptions on the shape of the DFs. Our main result shows that there exists no significant difference between the DFs of dark matter particles and stars within one virial radius around each cluster center. This suggests that the shapes of the DFs of these two components are similar over a wide range of scales.

rewrite_text: The in vivo behavior of looped DNA-protein complexes is examined using multiscale models and simulations. Our analysis reveals that the looping process occurs in three distinct stages: initiation, elongation, and termination. In the initiation stage, the protein binds to its target site at one end of the double helix. During the elongation stage, it moves along the double helix until it reaches another target site, at which point the process concludes. These results align with experimental data. Additionally, we find that the dynamics of the protein’s movement are influenced more by coherent fluctuations than by Brownian diffusion. Ultimately, our simulations indicate that the formation of loops plays a critical role in regulating gene expression. This article is part of a Special Issue titled "Advances in Computational Science," guest edited by Professors S. J. Liou and C. Y. Wu. It has been accepted for publication in the Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical (JPhysA).

original_text: We present the results of our study on binary models for gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) with progenitors in the mass range 8-40 M⊙, which are expected to produce GRB jets that can be observed at cosmological distances. We find that these systems evolve into double-degenerate binaries consisting of two white dwarfs or helium stars before they explode as supernovae. The explosion is triggered by the merger of the components due to gravitational wave emission. In some cases we also find that the system evolves through an intermediate stage where one component collapses to form a black hole while the other explodes as a supernova. This scenario may explain why there seems to exist a gap between the masses of ordinary core-collapse supernovae and those of GRBs. Our calculations show that the total number of such events per year could be up to 10 times higher than previously estimated if the progenitor population extends down to lower masses.

This source is associated with a cluster of young, massive stars located at a distance of 3 kpc. The data reveal two distinctive features along the line of sight; one feature shows a systemic velocity of approximately 10 km/s, while the other exhibits blueshifted emission reaching up to -60 km/s. We observe evidence of a collimated outflow that extends for about 0.5 pc, suggesting that the driving source may be embedded within its natal cloud core. Additionally, we identify several compact knots distributed along the flow, exhibiting velocities between 10 and 60 km/s. The estimated mass-loss rate from our observations ranges from 1 × 10^-3 to 1 × 10^-2 solar masses per year.

We find that these clouds can cool efficiently by atomic hydrogen lines only if they have metallicities above Z = 1e-6Z_eq or higher. This is because metal enrichment increases the cooling rate through fine-structure emission lines such as  CII  158um and  OI  63um. The virialized gas inside minihalos has lower metallicity than its surrounding intergalactic medium due to inefficient mixing caused by supersonic turbulence driven by supernova explosions. As a result, it cannot cool below T_c ~ 100K even though it contains enough neutral hydrogen for efficient H_2 cooling.

We present an efficient method for studying the nonlinear dynamics of semiconductor microcavity lasers featuring complex spatial profiles and cavity losses, utilizing a combination of two distinct truncation strategies. The first strategy is employed to simplify the system of equations by retaining only those modes that are significant at any given time; this allows us to maintain accuracy even with a limited number of modes contributing to the overall emission spectrum. The second strategy addresses the rapidly oscillating terms that arise from the presence of multiple longitudinal modes within each transverse profile. We explain how these two approaches can be integrated into a unified method, which we term dynamics-controlled truncation (DCT). We demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our technique by comparing it against other existing methods. Specifically, we explore three different types of spatial profiles: constant, quasi-periodic, and random. 

I. INTRODUCTION 
Semiconductor microcavity lasers have garnered significant interest due to their potential as low-threshold laser sources. However, their multimode dynamics can complicate numerical simulations, especially when considering time-varying cavity parameters. To address these challenges, several researchers have proposed various methodologies. For instance, in a previous study, a reduced set of rate equations was introduced to describe the evolution of slowly varying amplitudes of the laser modes. Recent advancements have incorporated higher-order effects as well as nonuniform gain saturation. Another approach involves using truncated Fourier expansions, where the coefficients are determined self-consistently. Alternatively, one can perform direct integrations of Maxwell's equations, though this typically requires substantial computational resources.

original_text: The nullstellensatz is an important theorem in algebraic geometry, which states that if a system of polynomial equations has no solution over some field then it must have at least one solution over its algebraic closure.  In this work we show how to use the nullstellensatz as part of a general framework for expressing combinatorial optimization problems (COPs) as systems of polynomial equations.   We demonstrate our approach on several COPs including maximum clique, minimum vertex cover, and maximum independent set.   ... This research was supported by NSF grant CCF-0430020. The authors would like to thank Professors David Avis and Michael Shmoys for their helpful comments during the preparation of this manuscript. The nullstellensatz provides a powerful tool for solving certain classes of computational problems expressed as systems of polynomial equations. It states that if such a system does not admit any solutions over a given field K, then there exists at least one solution over the algebraic closure of K. In this paper, we present a general method for transforming combinatorial optimization problems into systems of polynomial equations whose solvability can be determined using the nullstellenstaz. Our approach relies on representing each feasible solution of the COP as a point in a vector space V equipped with a suitable inner product. Then, we express the objective function of the problem as a linear combination of polynomials in V . Finally, we formulate the problem as a system of polynomial equations by requiring that all points corresponding to feasible solutions satisfy the objective function simultaneously. As examples, we apply our technique to three well-known NP-hard combinatorial optimization problems: Maximum Clique, Minimum Vertex Cover, and Maximum Independent Set.

rewrite_text: We present our findings on the very weak electron-phonon coupling (EPC) in La0.7Sr0.3MnO3 thin films that were fabricated on SrTiO3 substrates using Jarvis laser deposition. This observation aligns with previous reports. Our measurements indicate that EPC decreases as temperature rises, reaching up to 300 K. This trend can be attributed to the expansion of the lattice due to disorder fluctuations occurring at elevated temperatures. Furthermore, we noted that the magnitude of EPC is significantly influenced by the film thickness; it diminishes as the thickness is reduced to 10 nanometers. The dependence of EPC on both temperature and film thickness suggests that phonon behavior plays a crucial role in mediating EPC in these films. Manganese oxides have been the subject of extensive research due to their fascinating properties, such as colossal magnetoresistance, half-metallicity, and charge ordering. Among these materials, La1-xSrxMnO3 has garnered particular attention since its discovery. In this compound, Mn ions occupy two distinct sites: Mn3+ (in tetrahedral coordination) and Mn4+ (in octahedral coordination). It has been observed that the magnetic state transitions from ferromagnetic insulator to antiferromagnetic insulator with varying doping levels. These phenomena can be attributed to the competition between double exchange interactions and superexchange mechanisms. However, there remain unresolved questions regarding the electronic states in these compounds, particularly concerning the mechanisms underlying their insulating behavior, which are still debated in the literature.

We report on an experiment to measure the Casimir-Lifhsztz (CL) interaction between two gold-coated glass plates immersed in water at room temperature and pressure. The CL force is measured by observing the Brownian motion of one plate with respect to another, using optical interferometry. We find that the magnitude of the observed effect agrees well with theoretical predictions based on Lifshitz theory for dielectrics. This work represents the first direct experimental observation of the CL force in a liquid medium. It also demonstrates how precision measurements can be used to test fundamental theories such as quantum electrodynamics. 
 
 In recent years there has been considerable interest in measuring the Casimir-Lifhzsiz (CL)  1  force between macroscopic objects  2  . Such experiments are important because they provide tests of our understanding of vacuum fluctuations  3  , which play a central role in many areas of physics including quantum field theory  4  , statistical mechanics  5  , condensed matter  6  , atomic and nuclear physics  7  , cosmology  8  , and gravitation  9  .
 
The original prediction of the CL force was made more than 50 years ago  10  but it took until 1997  11  before this attractive force could be directly detected experimentally  12  . Since then several groups have performed high-precision experiments  13  -  16  aimed at testing the validity of various aspects of the theory  17  -  20  . 
 
 Here we present results obtained in a new experiment designed specifically to study the CL force in liquids  21  . Our approach involves immersing two parallel plates coated with thin layers of gold into distilled water contained inside a sealed container  22  . By monitoring the Brownian motion of these plates  23  we were able to determine their mutual attraction due to the presence of the surrounding water molecules  24  .

rewrite_text: We propose that the set of all univariate polynomials with integer coefficients can be uniquely represented as sums of squares of rational functions. Furthermore, we establish a framework for computing such representations. We also explore how to extend this result to multivariate polynomials over finite fields. The issue of representing a nonnegative polynomial as a sum of squares (SOS) has been extensively studied since Hilbert's work in the early 20th century on quadratic forms. Notably, Artin demonstrated that every nonnegative polynomial can be represented as a sum of four squares of integers. This implies that any positive integer \( n \) can be expressed as a sum of at most four square roots of integers. However, there are infinitely many ways to represent any integer as a sum of two or three square roots. For instance, \( 1 \) can be expressed as \( 2 + \sqrt{3} \) and also as \( 2 - \sqrt{3} \). The question of uniqueness becomes more intriguing when we focus on polynomials. It turns out that if \( f \in \mathbb{Z}[x] \) is a monic polynomial whose Galois group \( G(f) \) is solvable, then \( f \) can be uniquely represented as an SOS. Conversely, if \( G(f) \) is not solvable, then \( f \) may have multiple SOS representations.

The authors have used scanning tunneling microscopy to study the surface structure and electronic properties of single crystals of the high-temperature cuprate superconductor Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8+d (Bi-2212). They find that, at low temperatures, this material forms pairs of holes which are bound together by an attractive interaction mediated by phonons. The binding energy is found to be about 0.5 eV per hole pair. This value agrees well with theoretical predictions for the strength of the pairing force between holes in these materials. 
 
 In addition, they observe that the density of states near the Fermi level shows a strong dependence on the direction along which the crystal is cut. For example, when the crystal is cleaved parallel to its Cu-O planes, it exhibits a large peak in the density of states just below the Fermi level. However, if the cleavage plane is perpendicular to the Cu-O planes, no such peak appears.

rewrite_text: A slide-o-cam transmission is a modern alternative to traditional geared systems, connecting the input and output shafts through rotating cams that operate on their own axes, eliminating the need for gears or other mechanical components between them. The advantages of this transmission type include: no backlash from gear meshing, high efficiency (up to 98%), low friction losses, reduced weight and size compared to conventional gearboxes, and simplified assembly and disassembly. Additionally, various types of input mechanisms can be utilized. This article discusses several methods for designing a slide-o-cam transmission, analyzing its kinematic properties. This analysis led to the development of two prototypes designed for use in electric vehicles. A simulation model was created to evaluate the performance of these designs under various operating conditions. Finally, experimental tests were conducted to validate both the proposed designs and the simulation results.

original_text: We study the problem of finding minimum cost arborescences in directed graphs with edge costs that are functions of their distances, where each vertex has an associated demand for bandwidth. We show how to solve this problem by reducing it to the well-studied problem of computing shortest paths on weighted digraphs (WDP). Our reduction is based on the concept of directed star arboricity which we define as follows. Let G = (V , E) be any directed graph. A set S ⊆ V is called a star if there exists exactly one vertex u ∈ S such that all other vertices v ∈ S have only edges into u. The directed star arboricity of G is defined as the smallest number k such that every subgraph H of G can be decomposed into at most k stars. In particular, our results imply that WDP can be solved using O(n log n + m log n) time and space, improving upon previous algorithms running in O(m+nlogn) or O(mn+min{nlogn,m}) time.

The web serves as a vital resource for gathering information that can aid in decision-making regarding unpublished documents and various applications. However, the web contains heterogeneous sources with diverse structures and complexities, making it challenging to integrate this data into existing databases or data warehouses effectively. In this paper, we propose an approach based on ontologies to model both the data and their interrelations. Our method employs semantic technologies such as RDF (Resource Description Framework) and OWL (Web Ontology Language). We demonstrate how this approach can be incorporated into a data warehouse using ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) tools. Additionally, we present case studies by applying our method to real-world datasets. 

Keywords: Data Warehouse, Semantic Technologies, Ontology, Integration, Web Data Modeling.

With the rapid expansion of internet usage, organizations are increasingly accumulating vast amounts of data from various online resources. This data encompasses a wide range of content, including user profiles, product catalogs, financial records, and more, all of which need to be stored and analyzed effectively. This trend has spurred a range of research areas, including data mining, knowledge management, and data warehousing. A data warehouse is defined as a subject-oriented, integrated, time-variant collection of data that supports decision-making processes. It allows users rapid access to historical and current operational data. As illustrated in Figure 1, a typical data warehouse architecture comprises three components: OLTP (Online Transaction Processing), ETL, and OLAP (Online Analytical Processing). 

Figure 1: Architecture of a data warehouse.

We present an approach to quantify the evolutionary dynamics of social groups, based on their internal structure and interactions with other groups. We use this method to study how cooperation evolves in structured populations composed by different types of agents (cooperators or defectors). Our results show that cooperator clusters are more likely to survive than isolated ones when they interact with defector clusters. This effect is stronger for larger cluster sizes. The survival probability decreases as the number of competing clusters increases. Finally we find that the presence of cooperator clusters can lead to the extinction of all defector clusters if there exists at least one large enough cooperator cluster. In recent years it has been shown that cooperative behavior among unrelated individuals may evolve spontaneously even under strong competition between selfish strategies  1-3 . However, these studies have focused mainly on well-mixed populations where each individual interacts equally often with every other member of the population  4  . On the contrary, real-world systems such as biological communities  5  , human societies  6  , or computer networks  7  usually exhibit some degree of spatial organization  8  .
In order to understand better the role played by space in the emergence of cooperation, several authors have studied the evolution of cooperation in spatially-structured populations  9  . These works typically consider two main classes of models: lattice-based  10  and agent-based  11  . Lattice-based models assume that the whole population lives on a regular grid  12  while agent-based models allow for arbitrary topologies  13  . Despite the differences between both approaches, most previous work agrees that the topology of the underlying network plays a crucial role in determining whether cooperation will be able to thrive  14  .

rewrite_text: The goal of this study is to explore how users in Europe perceive privacy issues related to the use of online learning environments (OLEs) and their attitudes towards these concerns. The research questions include: What are students' views on privacy? How do students' attitudes evolve over time? What factors influence their perspectives on privacy? How can we effectively measure these attitudes? What implications do these findings have for OLE developers? This article is based on data collected from two studies conducted at various universities throughout Europe between 2004 and 2006. The results show that there has been little change in the general perception of privacy since 2004. Students' concerns remain largely the same; they are particularly worried about their personal information being shared without their permission or control. However, some differences were noted among different countries. Additionally, the findings suggest that both gender and age play significant roles in shaping students' attitudes toward privacy. Finally, the authors discuss potential reasons for these observed trends and offer recommendations for future research.

original_text: We report on new observations made with the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) that reveal an extremely asymmetric distribution of dust around the young star HD 15115, located at a distance of about 150 light-years away in the constellation Pictor.  The images show two bright lobes extending to distances greater than 100 AU and separated by more than 50 AU along the major axis of the system s circumstellar disk. We interpret these features as evidence for recent planet formation activity within this protoplanetary disk. This is one of only three known cases where such structures have been observed directly; all other examples are inferred indirectly through modeling or scattered-light imaging techniques. These results provide important constraints on models of planet formation and migration. In addition, we find no evidence for any significant amount of cold dust beyond 250 AU from the central star. Our findings suggest that the outer regions of protoplanetary disks may be cleared out much faster than previously thought.

We present an analysis of the evolution of interstellar dust grains, based on their size distribution inferred by infrared observations with ISO (Infrared Space Observatory). We find that the grain growth is dominated by coagulation at all times since the formation of the Sun. The total mass density of dust increases by about one order of magnitude during this time span. This increase can be explained by accretion of gas-phase metals onto pre-existing grains or condensation of new material out of the gas phase. In addition to these processes we also consider fragmentation as well as shattering due to collisions between particles. Fragmentation dominates over coagulation for small grains but becomes less important when the grains grow larger than 0.1 micrometres. For large grains shattering leads to a decrease in number density which counteracts the effect of coagulation. Our results are consistent with previous studies using different methods.

rewrite_text: The article focuses on the paleogeography and geodynamics of the Russian Arctic during the late Quaternary, drawing on the extensive research conducted by the authors over the past decade. The study area is situated between the Lena River to the west and the Kolyma River to the east (Fig. 1). It encompasses the inhabited regions of Yakutia, the southern part of the Chukotka Autonomous Okrug, and the northeastern part of Magadan Oblast. In this area, the authors investigated over 100 sites containing loess-like sediments that have accumulated throughout the last climatic period. These sediments consist predominantly of silts with gravel admixtures of up to 5 mm in diameter, and they contain numerous mollusk fossils, mammal bones, and other biological remains. Using this data, the authors reconstructed the climatic fluctuations in the region from the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) to the present.

original_text:
We present an ab initio study on the electronic structure and magnetic properties of Fe3O4, CoFe2O4, NiFe2O4, MnFe2O4, CrFe2O4, and VFe2O4 compounds with different spin configurations. We show that these materials are characterized by large orbital moment contributions to their total magnetization which can be explained within the framework of density functional theory (DFT) using generalized gradient approximation (GGA). The calculated values for the orbital-to-spin ratio agree well with experimental data obtained via neutron scattering experiments. In addition we find that all studied systems exhibit non-collinear magnetic structures due to competing exchange interactions between neighboring atoms. Finally, we discuss how our results could be used as input parameters into existing theories describing macroscopic phenomena such as spin-orbit torques or anomalous Hall effects. This is an open access article under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

rewrite_text: We present our exploration of photometric and spectroscopic data for two stars, HD 122563 (HR 5171A) and BD +17°3248, which are suspected members of the proposed population of helium-rich giants in the globular cluster Omega Centauri. We find that both stars exhibit very similar parameters to those identified by Gil for other candidate helium-rich giants in Omega Cen: effective temperature (T_eff) of 8200 K, log g of 3.8, and [Fe/H] of -1.0 dex. The observed spectra show no evidence of He II lines at 4686 Å or 5412 Å, but they do display strong Balmer line emission with equivalent widths ranging from -40 to -50 mÅ. These findings suggest that these stars may not actually belong to this proposed class of stars. However, we cannot completely rule out the possibility that they might indeed be helium-rich giants based on our current data set.

We present the first findings on the clustering of luminous red galaxies (LRGs) in the redshift range of 0.5 < z < 0.8, using data from the Anglo-Australian Observatory's AAOmega multi-object spectrograph. We analyze data from the 2dF-SDSS LRG and QSO survey to determine the projected correlation function, wp(rp). The observed clustering is consistent with predictions derived from current cosmological models. This result provides important constraints on these models at this redshift range, where there are few other available data points. Additionally, we find evidence for evolution in the galaxy bias parameter between our two samples, amounting to approximately 0.2 Gyrs. Detailed findings will be presented in a separate publication. 

Keywords: Luminous Red Galaxies; Clustering; Bias Evolution; Cosmology. 

1. Introduction
Multiple studies have demonstrated that luminous red galaxies (LRGs), selected through their optical properties or near-infrared photometry, serve as powerful probes for large-scale structure research extending to high redshifts (e.g., Eisenstein et al. 2001; Wake et al. 2006; Padmanabhan et al. 2007; Blake et al. 2008; Ross et al. 2008). Their high luminosities allow for their detection even at relatively low redshifts, while their red colors facilitate spectroscopic identification. LRGs predominantly reside in massive matter halos that evolve slowly over time, making them excellent tracers of the underlying mass distribution. Thus, they present unique opportunities to study both the growth of cosmic structures and the dynamics of cosmic expansion (see e.g., Percival & White 2009, for a relevant discussion). In this work, we report our measurements of the spatial clustering properties of LRGs in the redshift range 0 < z < 0.8, utilizing a combination of data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) (York et al. 2000) and the Two Degree Field Galaxy Redshift Survey (2dFGRS) (Colless et al.).

The result is compared with lattice QCD calculations at next-to-leading order in HQET perturbation theory. Our results are consistent within errors but do not agree as well as one would like. rewrite_text: The purpose of this study was to determine whether virtual ultrasound (US) puncture tracts could enhance percutaneous renal procedures in patients treated with backyard tourism and to visualize calices during fluoroscopy. A total of 50 consecutive patients underwent US-guided percutaneous nephrolithotomy utilizing an in-room C-arm system for real-time guidance. The procedure was carried out under either general anesthesia or conscious sedation. Prior to the procedure, a CT scan was performed without intravenous contrast. Using OsiriX MD software, two urologists outlined the kidney's contours and identified all accessible calices. They subsequently projected their findings onto the fluoroscopic screen during the procedure, focusing on puncturing each calyx that was visible on fluoroscopy. Following successful puncture, stone removal was attempted through the sheath via the needle. A successful puncture was defined as the ability to access at least one calyx. The overall success rate was 88%, with no complications attributed to the use of the US puncture tract projections. This technique allows urologists to perform safe and effective percutaneous renal procedures, even when only a few calices are clearly visible on fluoroscopy.

original_text: The missing satellites problem (MSP) is one of the most important problems in space science and technology, with applications ranging from satellite navigation to space debris removal.  The MSP asks for all orbits that are stable under gravitational perturbations by known bodies such as planets or asteroids.   In this work we present an algorithm which solves the MSP exactly on any number of dimensions d >= 2 using only O(n log n + m log n) time where n = |S| is the total number of objects in S and m = |E| is the number of edges in E.   Our approach uses a novel combination of techniques including fast matrix multiplication algorithms, data structures based on interval trees, and efficient graph traversal methods. We also show how our results can be used to solve related problems like finding the minimum distance between two given sets of points in R^d. Finally, we demonstrate the practicality of our method through experiments performed on real-world datasets.

Specifically, we examine the implications for dark matter candidates, electroweak observables, flavor physics constraints, LHC results, and direct detection experiments. Our findings indicate that the nMSSM can accommodate all current experimental data with minimal adjustments while simultaneously providing viable candidates for cold dark matter. These results were presented by Jens Hjorth at the EPS-HEP 2013 conference held in Vienna, Austria, from July 24 to 29, 2013. The materials used during the presentation are available here.

We investigate the linearization problem for the Painlevé equations PIII, PV, and PVI through their Lax pairs. Our analysis reveals that these problems are equivalent to Lie reductions of the three-wave resonant equations. The results we obtain can be seen as an extension of those by Zakharov et al., who examined the solutions of the two-wave resonant scenario related to the Painlevé II equation. Notably, we find that there are no non-trivial solutions of the linearized PIII or PV that exhibit exponential decay at infinity when certain conditions are applied to their asymptotic behavior near the origin. 

Introduction: The Painlevé equations are significant in both mathematics and physics (see, e.g., references 1 and 4). They have been extensively studied in recent years due to their intricate structures, including soliton solutions and Bäcklund transformations. Recently, it has been demonstrated that they arise in various models relevant to nonlinear optics. For example, the nonlinear Schrödinger (NLS) equation with cubic-quintic nonlinearity emerges from laser dynamics through Kerr effects. In this article, we address the linearization problem for multiple types of Painlevé equations. Specifically, we focus on the partial differential equations where \( RS = R(t, x) \) is in \( \mathbb{C}^{n+1} \), and \( v = v(t, x) \) and \( w = w(t, x) \) are vector-valued functions of \( t > 0 \) and \( x \in \mathbb{R}^1 \). Hereafter, subscripts denote differentiation with respect to the specified variables. It is important to note that all these equations possess infinitely many conservation laws.

original_text: We study instabilities that develop in the accretion flow onto black holes during gamma-ray bursts (GRBs). We use an axisymmetric, general relativistic hydrodynamic code to evolve the equations for mass and momentum conservation with self-gravity included. The initial conditions are taken as those of steady-state discs around Kerr black holes. In order to mimic GRB outflows we add a radial velocity perturbation at large radii which is then advected inward by the fluid. This leads to the development of spiral density waves which grow exponentially on a dynamical timescale. These waves can be identified with the Rossby wave instability (RWI) predicted analytically by Lovelace et al. (1999) . They also lead to the formation of shocks near the inner edge of the disc where they steepen into strong discontinuities. As these shocks propagate outward through the disc their strength decreases due to dissipation.

rewrite_text: The Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope, also known as GLAST, is set to launch in June 2008. It will be capable of detecting gamma rays with energies ranging from 20 MeV to 300 GeV, covering an energy range that has previously been largely unexplored. The Large Area Telescope (LAT) on board Fermi consists of four identical towers, each equipped with 16 strip trackers surrounded by tungsten converters and photosensors made of CsI (Tl) scintillators. Each tracker module has a thickness of 1 cm and features 12 layers arranged at different angles to one another. This design enables precise measurements of both the incident and outgoing photons. Additionally, two calorimeter sections located behind the tracker modules contain 8 planes of CsI (Tl). These detectors provide excellent spatial resolution and energy resolution across most of the gamma-ray spectrum. The primary goal of this work is to develop a detailed understanding of the Galactic diffuse emission observed by the LAT, allowing for accurate analysis of data collected during its mission.

original_text: We present near-infrared photometry for brown dwarfs (BDs) with masses below 0.075 Msun, members of the young open cluster Lambda Orionis. We find that these BDs have redder J-K colors than field objects at similar spectral types. This is consistent with previous studies showing that low mass stars and BDs are more dusty than higher mass counterparts. The observed color excesses can be explained by accretion disks around the BDs. Using our data we estimate disk fractions between 20-50% among the lowest mass BDs in this sample. These results suggest that most BDs form via core accretion as do high-mass stars. However, it remains unclear whether or not all BDs accrete material to become fully fledged planets. In addition, we show that there may exist two populations of very-low mass BDs: one population which has been affected by accretion processes during its formation; another population whose properties resemble those of older field BDs.

Our findings indicate that there are no logarithmic corrections to the entanglement entropy, which is consistent with results from other spacetime models. Additionally, we find that the higher-order corrections are proportional to the square of the volume enclosed by the entangling surface. Finally, we examine the second-order corrections and derive an expression that includes two terms. One of these terms has previously been identified in Ref. Phys. Rev. D 98 (2018) 084011, while the other term is new. Our results can be interpreted as a sum over all possible contractions between the Riemann tensor and its derivatives at the boundary. This work demonstrates that the Chern-Simons coupling constant plays a role analogous to Newton's constant in four-dimensional spacetime.

The Ras proteins are small GTPases that play an important role in many cellular processes, including proliferation and differentiation.  The active form of Ras is anchored to the plasma membrane by its C-terminal farnesylated cysteine residue (Cys-186). Here we use single molecule fluorescence microscopy to study the distribution of this anchor on the surface of living cells. We find that the anchor forms clusters with sizes ranging between 50 nm and 1 µm. These clusters have a higher density than expected for a random distribution of molecules. In addition, they show a strong correlation with the actin cytoskeleton. Our results suggest that these clusters may be involved in regulating the activity of Ras at the plasma membrane. Ras proteins are small G-proteins which play an essential role in many signaling pathways inside eukaryotic cells  1  . They cycle between inactive GDP-bound states and active GTP-bound states  2  , where their conformation changes upon binding or hydrolyzing guanosine triphosphate  3  .
Ras proteins can exist as monomers  4  but also dimerize  5  and oligomerize  6  . Their activation depends strongly on their localization  7, 8  : when activated, Ras binds to the inner side of the plasma membrane  9  via its C terminus  10  . This interaction is mediated by the lipid moiety attached to the protein  11  . It has been shown that the prenyl group plays a crucial role in mediating the association of Ras with membranes  12  . However, it was recently suggested that additional interactions involving amino acids close to the prenylated cysteine contribute significantly to the affinity  13  .

rewrite_text: We examine the stability properties of magnetized relativistic pulses with helical symmetry, which are described by solutions to Einstein's field equations coupled with Maxwell's equations for an electromagnetic field that is purely electric or purely magnetic along each magnetic line. We demonstrate how these solutions can be constructed using the Newman-Penrose formalism and discuss their significant features. In particular, we find that there are two classes of such solutions depending on whether they include a dynamo region where the magnetic field density increases exponentially (allowing them to be matched onto any solution at spatial infinity) or not. The resulting class encompasses all known stationary axisymmetric black hole electrovacuum solutions. Finally, we present some new results regarding the existence of time-dependent solutions for collapsing magnetized fluids. These findings have intriguing applications in astrophysics. PACS numbers: 04.20.-q, 98.80.Cq.

We study the graviton propagator in covariant massive gravity theory with an arbitrary number of gravitons and show that it is given by the sum over all Feynman diagrams which are obtained by attaching one or more gravitons to each vertex of the tree-level graviton propagator. We also present explicit expressions for the first few terms in this expansion, including the leading order term corresponding to the usual Einstein-Hilbert action. The results presented here can be used as input into calculations involving higher-order corrections to gravitational processes such as black hole evaporation. In particular, we find that the inclusion of these additional contributions leads to modifications to the Hawking temperature at late times. 
I. INTRODUCTORY REMARkS
The purpose of this work is twofold. First, we will derive the exact expression for the graviton propagator (or Green s function) in covariant massive gravity theories with an arbitrary number of external gravitons. Second, we will use our result to calculate the effects on the Hawking radiation emitted by a Schwarzschild black hole due to the presence of extra degrees of freedom associated with the massive spin-2 field. Our analysis follows closely the approach developed in Ref.  1  , where the authors studied the effect of adding massless scalar fields to the standard model of particle physics on the emission rate of Hawking radiation  2  .

rewrite_text: We analyze the baryonic mass fractions (denoted as \( f_{\text{bar}} \)) in early-type galaxies, utilizing spatially resolved kinematics from a sample of 12 nearby elliptical/S0 galaxies observed with integral field spectroscopy at optical wavelengths. We relate these data to estimates of \( f_{\text{bar}} \) and the total stellar masses \( M_* \). Our results are compared against predictions from semi-analytic models of galaxy formation within the standard ΛCDM cosmology. Our key findings are: 1) For our sample, we find that the average value of \( f_{\text{bar}} \) is \( 0.16 \pm 0.04 \), which is in strong agreement with other results obtained using different methodologies. 2) There is no significant correlation between \( f_{\text{bar}} \) and either luminosity or velocity dispersion. 3) Semi-analytic models predict values of \( f_{\text{bar}} \) that are consistently lower than our measurements by about a factor of two. 4) To reconcile the models with our observations, it seems necessary to consider additional baryonic processes that are not adequately captured in current models.

Nonequilibrium steady states (NESs), which are time-independent solutions of master equations distinctly separate from equilibrium, have been extensively studied in recent years. They play a vital role in various fields, including particle mechanics, optics, and biophysics. Recently, interest has surged in developing efficient methods for computing NESs due to their significance in applications where it may not always be feasible or straightforward to obtain solutions. For instance, in molecular dynamics simulations and Monte Carlo methods, only approximations of NESs are typically available. Furthermore, even if the exact solution were known, its direct computation could still lead to significant computational challenges. Hence, it is essential to develop fast and accurate algorithms for calculating NESs. Numerous approaches exist for numerically approximating NESs, including eigenvector methods, power iteration, and Krylov subspace techniques. These methods often involve repeated application of the original master equation until convergence is achieved. However, since the number of...

original_text: We present an analysis of the colour-selection criteria for identifying high-redshift (z > 6) galaxies using data from the first public release of the UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey (UKIDSS). We use photometric redshifts to select candidate z ~ 7 and 8 galaxies, and then examine their near-infrared colours as measured by UKIDSS. The majority of these candidates are found to be at lower redshift than expected; we find that this is due primarily to contamination by low-redshift interlopers with similar optical-to-near-infrared colours. However, we also identify several robust candidates which have been missed by previous surveys. These include two objects with spectroscopic confirmation of Lyman-break features at z = 7.071 and z = 7.085 respectively. We discuss possible reasons why our sample may differ from those previously published, including differences between the survey areas used and different methods of selecting targets for spectroscopy.

The gravitational lensing effect was first predicted by Einstein in 1915, but it took another 50 years before the first confirmed observation could be made.  In this talk I will describe how one particular event - Nova Geminorum 1912 - played an important role in motivating Einstein to develop his theory of general relativity.   The talk is based on my recent book  The First Lensing Event  (Cambridge University Press). 

Gravitational lensing occurs when light passes close to a massive object such as a galaxy or cluster of galaxies.  This causes the light rays to bend towards each other so that distant objects appear magnified and distorted.  

In 1919, Einstein published his famous field equations which described gravity as curvature in space-time caused by matter/energy.  These equations were able to explain many phenomena including the perihelion precession of Mercury s orbit around the Sun. 

However, there remained some puzzles about these equations.  For example, they did not predict any bending of light passing near the Sun.

Einstein realised he needed to modify his original field equations if he wanted them to account for gravitational lensing effects.  He introduced what we now call the cosmological constant into his new set of equations.  However, despite considerable effort over several decades, no-one has been able to measure the value of this constant with sufficient accuracy to test whether Einstein s prediction is correct.  

This talk describes how astronomers finally managed to observe gravitational lensing in 1979 using observations of a distant quasar known as Q0957+561A-B.  It also explains why the discovery of gravitational lenses led to the awarding of the Nobel Prize in Physics to Roger Blandford and Roman Vishniac in 1997.

This study examines the effects of quantum electrodynamics (QED) on the decoherence of semiconductor-based qubit systems. The QED interactions are represented by a coupling between the qubit and its surroundings, which includes electromagnetic field fluctuations manifesting as thermal photons at finite temperatures. We find that these QED interactions can be treated perturbatively under typical experimental conditions. Notably, the spontaneous emission rate of excitons into free modes increases with the number of electrons (N) involved in the qubit state. This leads to shorter relaxation times (T1) but results in stronger pure dephasing (T2). For realistic values of N, ranging from 10 to 100, the effects of QED are relatively minor compared to other decoherence sources like phonon scattering or electron-electron interactions. 

Quantum information processing has garnered significant attention due to its potential applications in various fields, from quantum computing to metrology. Semiconductor-based qubit devices have emerged as promising candidates for scalable quantum computers. Among these, excitonic states in semiconductors are particularly vital for storing and manipulating quantum information. However, exciton-exciton interactions can lead to rapid decoherence, making it challenging to maintain coherence in each device. To address this issue, several recent proposals have suggested hybrid structures combining different materials. In this letter, we investigate how the principle of electrodynamic (or radiative) coupling affects the dynamics of semiconductor-based qubit systems. As illustrated in Fig. 1(a), we consider two primary types of electromagnetic field fluctuations around the qubit: first, fluctuations within the cavity leading to the spontaneous emission of excitons into free modes; and second, the presence of thermal photons.

original_text: We show that the exchange-only optimized potentials (OEPs) are not equivalent to the Kohn-Sham (KS) method in general, even if one uses an exact density functional for the exchangecorrelation energy. We demonstrate this by solving analytically the OEPs for two simple model systems using Gaussian-type orbitals as basis functions. The results obtained within both approaches differ significantly. In particular, we find that the KS approach yields incorrect values for the total energies of these systems. This is due to the fact that the KS equations do not have solutions corresponding to all possible densities which can be generated by the given basis sets. On the other hand, the OEP formalism always provides unique solutions for any given density matrix. Our analysis shows also how to resolve the apparent paradox arising when trying to apply the OEP formalism to the case where only a limited number of basis functions is used.

We examine the Lies phenomenon in the context of a Jurassic-loop control problem related to nonlinear stochastic dynamics of diabetes and the interactions between phytoplankton (plants) and zooplankton (animals). Our primary objective is to identify the optimal set of parameters that characterize external periodic forcing, thereby maximizing the growth rate of plankton populations. We propose that this optimization challenge can be reduced to solving a set of algebraic equations. Specifically, we demonstrate that there is a unique solution corresponding to the maximum value of the objective function. Furthermore, our findings indicate that the derived solutions are robust against perturbations of the initial conditions. Finally, numerical simulations support our theoretical conclusions. 

Keywords: Stochastic differential equations, Periodic forcing, Resonance, Optimization problem, Nonlinear dynamics

1 Introduction
Interactions between different species play a crucial role in many natural ecosystems. For example, phytoplankton (algae or plants), which sit at the base of aquatic food webs, serve as a primary food source for organisms like zooplankton (fish or animals). Therefore, understanding the dynamics between these two populations provides valuable insights into ecosystem functioning. Recently, various Lies models have been developed to characterize the population dynamics of phytoplankton and zooplankton interactions. These models incorporate deterministic components representing the natural growth rates of both populations and their mutual interactions, as well as stochastic fluctuations due to environmental factors. It has been shown that under specific conditions, the long-term behavior of these systems can exhibit chaotic attractors, complicating the analysis of the dynamics. Conversely, neglecting the influence of random fluctuations renders the resulting deterministic equations challenging to investigate. In our research, we analyze the following model:

We report on diffuse X-ray emission in the Carina Nebula observed by Suzaku. The spectrum is well reproduced by thermal plasma models at kT = 0.7-1 keV and nH = (0.5-2) x 10^(22) cm^{-3}, which are consistent with those obtained previously for other regions within the nebula. We find that the total luminosity of this component amounts to Lx ~ 1.3 x 10^35 erg/sec, corresponding to about 10% of the total energy output of massive stars in the region. This suggests that hot gas produced by stellar winds and/or supernovae plays an important role in heating up the interstellar medium around young open clusters such as Trumpler 14-16.

rewrite_text: We demonstrate that the coherence property for monadic second-order logic (MSO) over graphs is not equivalent to the existence of an MSO-unique giant, which is a question posed by Courcelle and Engelfriet in 1990. Our findings indicate that this result remains valid even when we limit our focus to finite graphs or forests with finite sizes. This also addresses another open problem raised by Courcelle and Makowsky in 1991. Additionally, we provide examples that show these graphs are optimal. The techniques employed in this research involve a method called tree-expansion, which allows us to reduce questions about infinite structures to questions about finite graphs. Since its introduction, monadic second-order logic (also referred to as MSO) has been extensively studied as a generalization of first-order logic. It has been established that MSO can express many interesting properties such as connectedness, planarity, and Hamiltonicity. Specifically, MSO-formulas define precisely those sets that are definable in existential monadic second-order logic, meaning they can be defined using quantification only over subsets of finite graphs.

original_text: We consider the periodic oscillation of an adiabatic piston in contact with two ideal gases at different temperatures and pressures, separated by a rigid wall.  We prove that if the initial state is close to equilibrium then there exists a unique global solution which converges exponentially fast towards its limit cycle as time goes to infinity.  The proof relies on a combination of techniques from nonlinear analysis (Lyapunov functions) and kinetic theory (Boltzmann equation). In this work we study the dynamics of an adiabatic gas-piston system consisting of one-dimensional ideal gases confined between two walls. One of these walls is fixed while the other moves periodically according to some prescribed law. This problem has been studied extensively since the pioneering works of Maxwell  Max  , Boltzmann  Bol1  , and Sackur-Tetrode  Sac  . It was shown rigorously by Cercignani  Cerc  that under suitable assumptions on the motion of the piston, the solutions converge exponentially fast to their limit cycles. However, it seems difficult to extend his results beyond the case where the temperature difference across the piston remains small during all times. Here we show how to overcome this difficulty using new ideas based on Lyapunov functions combined with estimates coming from kinetic theory.

We are investigating the accretion processes onto black holes using our newly developed simulation framework, which incorporates an implicit time integration method and employs adaptive mesh refinement (AMR). We examine two different models of accretion onto Kerr black holes to test the robustness of our framework against various physical effects such as viscosity, magnetic fields, and radiative heating. Our primary focus is on the characteristics of the accretion flow as it transitions to supersonic speeds and develops shocks. Specifically, we aim to determine whether our AMR simulations accurately capture these features. Preliminary results indicate that our simulations reproduce all relevant analytical predictions quite well. 

Keywords: Black holes, General relativity, Numerical simulations, Shocks, Supersonic turbulence, Time dynamics

It has been over 30 years since the discovery of quasars. Since then, numerous studies have attempted to understand how supermassive black holes form so rapidly, but only recent advancements have provided observational data. These findings suggest that the majority of supermassive black holes have masses ranging from \(10^6 M_\odot\) to \(10^9 M_\odot\). This poses serious challenges for current theories of black hole formation, as they typically predict smaller masses for the central black holes. One potential solution to this issue could be found in supermassive active galactic nuclei (AGNs) that feature black holes surrounded by an accretion disk. If the density within the disk is sufficiently high, the dynamics of the black hole can cause the infalling matter to flow through viscous processes. As a result, the matter falling towards the black hole forms a geometrically thin accretion disk. However, if the density falls below a certain threshold, the disk may break up or even fragment into clumps. Such instabilities can lead to the formation of large-scale structures.

original_text: The vapor pressure, solubility in water, and interfacial tension between oil and water are important parameters for understanding the behavior of crude oils during their production or transport through pipelines.  In this study we have investigated these properties using alkanol monolayers on an aqueous subphase as model systems to mimic the hydrocarbon chains present in crude oils. The results show that the vapor pressures of the alkanols increase with chain length up to C8 but decrease again above C10. This is explained by considering the competition between two opposing effects:  On one hand, increasing chain lengths lead to higher molecular volumes which favor evaporation. On the other hand, longer chains also result in stronger van der Waals interactions within the liquid phase leading to lower vapor pressures. We find that the solubilities of the alkanols follow similar trends as those observed for the vapor pressures. However, the differences in solubility among different chain lengths become smaller when compared to the corresponding differences in vapor pressure. Finally, our measurements reveal that the interfacial tensions between the alkanol layers and the underlying water decreases monotonically with chain length.

The SIM PlanetQuest investments represent the most promising near-term method for detecting and characterizing nearby habitable planets. This article outlines how SIM PlanetQuest will identify these planets by measuring their astrometric wobble as they orbit their stars. It also discusses the potential of SIM PlanetQuest to detect other types of exoplanets, such as those with high orbital eccentricities or those in highly inclined orbits relative to our line of sight. Finally, it presents some preliminary insights into what we can expect to learn about extrasolar planets using this innovative instrumentation. 

**Keywords:** Extrasolar planet, Astrometry, SIM PlanetQuest, Transit method, Mass measurement, Orbital determination.

In recent years, there has been a surge of interest in extrasolar planets (exo-Earths) due to the possibility that some of these planets could host life, similar to Earth. More than 300 exoplanets have been discovered, primarily around bright stars (with a magnitude of V < 12), employing various detection methods like radial velocity, photometric transits, direct imaging, and microlensing. However, most of these planets are gas giants with orbital periods ranging from days to weeks, making them challenging targets for detailed studies concerning their potential for supporting life. To date, only three of these exoplanets have known masses: HD 209458b, GJ 436b, and OGLE-TR-561b. Among these, only HD 209458b has a measured radius.

**2. SIM PlanetQuest Mission Overview**
In addition to studying the atmospheres and surfaces of smaller, cooler planets that may support liquid water, astronomers aim to identify planets around fainter stars. Achieving this goal necessitates space-based observatories capable of collecting high-precision astrometric data over extensive periods. Such capabilities enable simultaneous measurements of the positions of faint stars with an accuracy better than 0.

We present new near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy and photometry for the Herbig Be star HD 98800, which is surrounded by an optically thick dust disk with a radius of ~200 AU. The NIR spectrum shows strong emission lines of H I, He II, C III, O IV-VI, Si IV, S VI, Fe II, Mg II, Al II-III, Na I, Ca II, and K I in addition to absorption features due to stellar winds. We find that the observed line profiles are consistent with those predicted by magnetohydrodynamic models of accretion disks around young stars. In particular, we detect blueshifted absorptions associated with infalling gas streams along magnetic field lines onto the central star. These results suggest that HD 98800 has been undergoing active mass accretion over the past few million years. 
 
 Keywords: Accretion, Herbig Be star

In this study, we introduce the Subjective Paused Eisenhower (SIM) to quantify the confidence level in a given or observed sequence. The SIM is defined as the minimum amount of information needed for lossless representation of the source data under certain fidelity criteria. We demonstrate that the proposed SIM can effectively derive rate-distortion functions with high accuracy using a single parameter. Additionally, it provides precise feedback on rate-distortion performance at low recovery rates. Finally, we illustrate its effectiveness through experiments conducted on various test datasets.

**Index Terms:** paused theory, image compression, video compression.

**1 Introduction**  
Data compression has been extensively researched over the past few decades due to its significance in various applications such as data storage, network transmission, and medical imaging. A fundamental challenge in data compression is accurately predicting the size of the compressed file compared to the original uncompressed data. This issue is commonly known as rate-distortion analysis. It has been established that the rate-distortion function describes the relationship between the length of the encoded codewords and the distortion incurred by any given encoding method. The most commonly used approach for tackling the rate-constrained optimization problem is Lagrangian relaxation, which converts constrained optimization into an unconstrained form through the introduction of Lagrange multipliers. However, solving these problems typically requires iterative methods that can be computationally intensive. To address this challenge, researchers have developed faster algorithms. Nonetheless, these methods often still face significant limitations when applied to practical scenarios.

rewrite_text: We construct a spherically symmetric solution to Einstein's equations in five dimensions, which incorporates a warped compactification on \( S^1/Z_2 \). The geometry is assumed to be asymptotically flat, while matter fields are confined to our four-dimensional brane. We propose that this framework can explain the observed flatness of galactic rotation curves without necessitating any additional dark matter or fine-tuning of energy density. Specifically, we illustrate how the mass distributions within galaxies may effectively serve as a reflection of the geometry of spacetime. This research was supported by NSF grant PHY-0456728. PACS numbers: 04.20.-q, 11.10.-z, 98.80.Cq. A fundamental question regarding dark matter has been whether it consists of one or more types of particles. If so, what are their masses? How do they interact with ordinary matter? How much dark matter is present in each galaxy? These inquiries drive us to develop models in which dark matter is represented by some field that interacts with a warped spacetime manifold. Here, we focus on a class of models where the extra dimension is compactified on a circle \( S^1 \). Such models were previously studied, where it was shown that if the radius of the compactification is small compared to other scales, then the potential experienced by particles on the brane is indistinguishable from that generated by a point-like source located at the center of the sphere. However, as the size of the compact dimension approaches the brane's curvature radius, the gravitational effects become significant. In earlier work, Randall and Sundrum demonstrated that such scenarios could provide an elegant explanation for the hierarchy between the weak scale and the Planck scale. They proposed a five-dimensional anti-de Sitter space with two three-dimensional branes located at its boundaries—one representing our universe and the other acting as a mirror. Matter fields are localized near either brane, while gravity propagates freely throughout the entire bulk.

We provide an analysis of the kinematic properties of high-velocity stars (HVSs) identified by Brown et al. (2007a, b). Our findings suggest that these HVSs are likely ejected from the Galactic center along trajectories that have been influenced by interactions with supermassive black holes at a distance, as well as by other phenomena such as gravitational scattering off molecular clouds or globular clusters. The observed velocities of the HVSs can be explained if they were ejected between 0.5 and 1 billion years ago on nearly radial paths with eccentricities ranging from 0 to 0.9. This aligns with previous unpublished findings regarding the time frame during which dynamical friction causes the orbital characteristics of stars to transition into the corresponding regions of galaxies. 

**Keywords**: High-velocity stars, supermassive black holes, galaxies, ejection mechanisms, dynamical friction, halo dynamics.

**Introduction**: Hypervelocity stars (HVSs; Brown et al., 2007a; Kenyon et al., 2008) are defined as stars that possess velocities exceeding 500 km/s relative to their local standard of rest. These stars likely originate from tidal disruption events involving compact objects near the Galactic Center (GC; Hills 1988) or from binary systems where one star has been accelerated through the strong gravitational influence of another (e.g., Yu & Tremaine 2003; Bromley et al. 2006). Recently, it has also been proposed that some HVSs may result from the interaction of a star with a supermassive black hole (SMBH) located outside the Galactic Center (Yu & Madau 2007; Sesana et al., 2007). However, it is important to note that no compelling evidence currently supports this hypothesis.

We analyze the dynamics of the two-species conservative symmetric exclusion process (TCSEP) on a one-dimensional lattice, where particles can only jump to adjacent empty sites. We find that at finite density, the system does not exhibit condensation under periodic boundary conditions. However, we observe that the TCSEP transitions into a condensed phase of first order when it interacts with a particle reservoir at its boundaries. The order parameter changes discontinuously across this phase transition line, which ends at a tricritical point. Furthermore, we precisely calculate the current-current correlation function along the transition line using the Bethe ansatz approach. Lastly, we discuss the potential to extend our findings to higher-dimensional systems. PACS numbers: 05.40.+j, 64.60.Cn, 71.10.Jk 

I. INTRODUCTORY REMARKS  
The goal of this study is to explore the properties of a stochastic model of particle dynamics in contact with particle reservoirs. This issue arises in various contexts such as biological processes, molecular dynamics, and granular gases. Here, we focus on the two-species conservative symmetric exclusion process (TCSEP), which consists of two types of indistinguishable particles, A and B, that move according to specific rules: Particles A and B independently traverse a ring of L sites by shifting to adjacent empty spaces. If both particle types attempt to occupy the same site simultaneously, either the A particle advances while the B particle remains where it is, or vice versa, depending on which type is more plentiful. It is important to note that this mechanism conserves the number of each particle type separately, but not the total number of particles \(N = n_A + n_B\). Thus, the dynamics of the TCSEP can be described by a master equation.

rewrite_text: We conducted molecular dynamics simulations to explore the behavior of dynamic crack propagation in an icosahedral AlPdMn quasicrystal and its approximant, i-AlCuFe. Our findings indicate that both materials exhibit similar features in crack growth at low temperatures (T = 300 K). However, significant differences emerge when the temperature is increased to 600 K. Notably, we found that the quasicrystal displays greater resistance to crack propagation compared to the approximant under tensile loading conditions. This behavior can be attributed to the distinct atomic structures of the two materials. We also examined how temperature affects the mechanical properties of the quasicrystal. Our results show that as temperature rises, there is a decrease in the elastic constants C11 and C44, as well as in the bulk modulus B. Additionally, our calculations reveal that the Young's modulus E diminishes with increasing temperature.

We present the broad-band spectral evolution of the X-ray binary system Sco-X1, which is one of the brightest persistent sources in our Galaxy and has been observed by many satellites over more than three decades. We use data obtained with Suzaku (0.5-10 keV), Swift/BAT (15-50 keV) and INTEGRAL/IBIS (20-100 keV). The broadband spectrum can be described well by an absorbed power-law model modified by reflection off cold matter. In addition to this continuum component we find evidence for emission lines at 6.4-6.7 keV that are consistent with fluorescent iron Kα line emission produced by photoionization of neutral material surrounding the central source. These results suggest that there may exist a hot accretion disk around the compact object as well as a cool outer disk or torus-like structure. This scenario is supported by recent observations made with Chandra/HETG.

rewrite_text: We explore the phenomenological implications of supersymmetric models with gauge interactions, in which the Standard Model is augmented by the addition of vector-like matter fields and extra dimensions. We demonstrate that these models can be designed to avoid any unnatural fine-tuning issues related to the Higgs mass or flavor-changing processes. Specifically, we find that: 1) The lightest scalar superpartner (the Higgs boson) has a mass not exceeding approximately 300 GeV. 2) Flavor-changing neutral current effects are sufficiently suppressed to be acceptable within the parameter space considered. 3) Gauge coupling unification holds within the bounds of experimental uncertainty. 4) A large parameter space exists where all sparticle masses are above 1 TeV, while still conforming to electroweak symmetry constraints. 5) These models offer an explanation for the absence of evidence for supersymmetry in accelerator experiments.

original_text: We present an algorithm for consistent hypothesis testing in which we consider all possible hypotheses that are compatible with some given set of observations, and select those that maximize their posterior probability according to Bayes  theorem.  We show how this can be done efficiently by using dynamic programming techniques. The resulting algorithm is optimal up to constant factors under certain conditions. Our approach also allows us to reason consistently over multiple experiments performed sequentially or simultaneously. This problem has been studied extensively in statistics but only recently in artificial intelligence (AI). In AI it was first considered as part of the PAC learning framework where one seeks algorithms that learn concepts from examples while making few mistakes. However, these approaches do not provide any guarantees when there exists more than one concept that fits the data equally well. In contrast our method provides provable guarantees even if several hypotheses fit the data equally well. Finally, we demonstrate the practicality of our approach through two applications:  1) A new algorithm for finding explanations in probabilistic databases; 2) An improved algorithm for identifying protein families based on sequence alignment.

rewrite_text: We present numerical simulations that investigate the formation, memory, and structure of quiescent cloud cores influenced by dynamic compressions in turbulent molecular gas. Our findings indicate that these cloud cores are formed through compression at the intersections of shocks generated by supersonic turbulence. The masses of these cloud cores range from 0.1 to 1 solar mass, with typical sizes around 1000 AU. rewrite_text: The beds auction builds upon the traditional sealed-bid auction by allowing bidders to submit bids in superposition, while the auctioneer assesses the situation by examining the state of the collected bids. This approach offers a significant advantage over classical auctions, as it enables more efficient allocation of resources when there are numerous stationary items or potential buyers. In this study, we tackle the challenge of identifying optimal partners for both the auctioneer and buyers in such an auction format that includes multiple items and buyers. We explore how to formulate the optimal strategy for the seller using linear programming and provide constraints on the bidding process to determine the identity of the winner. Specifically, when there are two buyers competing for three items, our findings suggest that the auctioneer should consistently announce one item as the focus at each round until only one buyer remains. Quantum mechanics has been applied to various types of auctions, allowing sellers to manipulate the items they wish to sell and buyers to strategize regarding which items they intend to bid on. These auctions have proven beneficial even when the involved parties do not fully trust each other.

We study the possibility that CP violation in the Standard Model is induced by several fields with nontrivial transformation properties under flavor and charge conjugation, which we call  Froggatt-Nielsen  (FN) fields.  We show how such FN fields can be incorporated into an effective Lagrangian for leptons and quarks at low energies. In this framework, we derive constraints on the number of FN fields allowed by current experimental data. Finally, we discuss possible implications of our results for models beyond the Standard Model. Introduction - The Standard Model (SM), despite its great successes, does not provide any explanation for why there are three generations of fermions or why their masses differ so much among themselves  1  . These questions have motivated many extensions of the SM  2  , including those based on grand unification  3  .
In these theories it has been shown  4  that new sources of CP violation may arise through phases associated with Yukawa couplings between Higgs boson(s) and fermion mass eigenstates. However, since all known particles couple to the same scalar doublet H = (H + , H 0 ) T / √ 2, one expects that the resulting contributions to CP-violating observables will be too small to explain observed phenomena  5  . This problem could be alleviated if additional scalars were introduced  6  but then other problems would appear  7, 8  . Alternatively, one might consider extending the gauge group  9  and/or introducing extra vector-like fermions  10  . Another possibility consists in considering more general transformations than phase rotations when constructing the most general form of the CKM matrix  11  .

rewrite_text: We present findings on the optical properties of Jarvis self-assembled InAs/GaAs quantum dots (QDs) in an external magnetic field during their growth phase. The emission line from the QDs splits into two lines with opposite circular polarization when the magnetic field is increased to approximately 1 T, corresponding to a Zeeman energy shift of about 0.5 meV at 4 K. We observe that this shift increases linearly as the temperature decreases to 20 mK, then saturates below 10 mK. This phenomenon can be explained by considering both electron localization effects and phonon-assisted transitions between different excitonic states within the QDs. Our studies indicate that the spin relaxation time for electrons confined in the QDs is on the order of 100 ns, even in high magnetic fields up to 5 T. Quantum dots, which are semiconductor nanocrystals or artificial atoms, offer numerous advantages due to their unique properties, such as size-tunable band gaps, strong light-matter interaction, and large oscillator strengths. These characteristics make QDs suitable as building blocks for various optoelectronic devices, including light-emitting diodes, lasers, solar cells, and photodetectors. Notably, significant research has been conducted on the spin dynamics of charge carriers in QDs. It has been demonstrated that carriers are remarkably stable against decoherence from repetitive interactions. However, the spin relaxation times can vary depending on external factors. In particular, the spin lifetimes of holes and electrons confined in QDs have been reported to be several nanoseconds with pulsed excitation. In contrast, the spin lifetimes of electrons and holes in QDs can reach microseconds when using continuous wave laser excitation instead.

original_text: The aim of this thesis is to provide an overview on the state-of-the-art Hartree-Fock Self-Consistent-Field (SCF) methods for solving quantum chemical problems, with special emphasis on their numerical aspects. We explore substantial cascades within large blog networks, where each node represents an individual blogger and the edges illustrate connections between different blogs. We introduce a novel cascade model that depicts how bloggers are more inclined to read and share content from their connections rather than engaging with random posts. Our research has three primary objectives: (1) developing an efficient method for calculating the size of the cascade under our model; (2) determining how to utilize these techniques to estimate the number of active users at any given time during a cascade; and (3) demonstrating the effectiveness of our model using data gathered from LiveJournal. 

The web has become one of the most crucial channels for communication. Social networks like Facebook and Twitter, in particular, host millions of users who share information with others through various forms of messaging, such as tweets or status updates. These messages are visible to all connections of the user sharing them, which can lead to further dissemination of the message within the network. This phenomenon is often referred to as viral marketing and has been extensively studied in the literature. However, there remain numerous unanswered questions about the dynamics of this process. In this work, we specifically examine cascades within large blogging communities, where each node represents an individual blogger and the edges connect pairs of blogs linked by similar content. A cascade is initiated when a blogger posts a link to another blog's content. If readers click on this link, they are directed to the other blog and may continue exploring additional posts. As illustrated in Figure 1, the resulting graph displays various connected nodes representing different topics discussed by community members.

We present the results of an analysis of data on advanced potentials in hadronic collisions at high energies, obtained by the TOTEM experiment at LHC and by the UA7 collaboration at SppS collider. rewrite_text: We conducted an analysis of X-ray data from the Chandra X-ray Observatory, focusing on a sample of sources selected for their brightness in the infrared wavelengths (Ks < 20) and located within the Chandra Deep Field - South survey region. We observe that most of these sources are active galactic nuclei (AGNs), but we initially identify several instances where the observed X-ray emission is attributed to star formation activity. The majority of our sources have luminosities below 10^43 erg s^-1, indicating that they may represent a population of low-luminosity AGNs that have been overlooked in previous surveys. Additionally, we detect two heavily obscured quasars whose optical counterparts have been misclassified as reddened stars or galaxies. These findings illustrate how deep X-ray observations can provide valuable insights into the nature of celestial objects when combined with multiwavelength datasets.
